sec_questions: At the top of the trajectory of a projectile, the directions of its velocity and acceleration are:
Inclined to each other at an angle of 45∘

Direction of velocity is always tangent to the path so at the top of trajectory, it is in horizontal direction and acceleration due to gravity is always in vertically downward direction. It means angle between \(\vec{v}\) and \(\vec{g}\) are perpendicular to each other.
A tyre is moving on its axis with an angular speed of \(50 \mathrm{~rad} / \mathrm{sec}\). Find the angular acceleration working on it if it stops moving in \(10 \mathrm{sec}\).

The relation between angular acceleration \(\alpha\) and changing angular velocity \(\omega\) is given by:

\(\omega_1=\omega_0+\alpha t\)

where \(\omega_1=\) final angular velocity, \(\omega_0=\) initial angular velocity \(\alpha=\) angular acceleration

Here \(\omega_0=50 \mathrm{~rad} / \mathrm{sec}\)

\(\omega_1=0 \)

\(\omega_1=\omega_0+\alpha \mathrm{t} \)

\(0=50+\alpha \times 10 \)

\(\alpha=-5 \mathrm{~rad} / \mathrm{sec}^2\)  

(Here -ve sign tells, the direction of angular acceleration will be opposite to the direction of the angular velocity.)

So, Angular acceleration \(\alpha=5 \mathrm{~rad} / \mathrm{sec}^2\)

It is possible to project a particle with a given velocity in two possible ways so as to make them pass through a point \(\mathrm{P}\) at a horizontal distance \(\mathrm{r}\) from the point of projection. If \(\mathrm t_1\) and \(\mathrm t_2\) are times taken to reach this point in two possible ways, then the product \(\mathrm{t}_1 \mathrm{t}_2\) is proportional to:

Let angle of projection in the first case is \(\theta_1\) and  in the second case is \(\theta_2\).

The time taken to reach point \(\mathrm{P}\) in the first case is \(t_1\)and in the second case is \(t_2\).

Let velocity of projection (same for both the cases)\(=u\).

In the first case,

Time taken \(t_1=\frac{2 u \sin \theta_1}{g}\)

And in the second case,

Time taken \(t_2=\frac{2 u \sin \theta_2}{g}\)

It is also given that the horizontal distance between point \(\mathrm{P}\) and point of projection is \(\mathrm{r}\), and we know that this distance is called range. 

Then \(r=\frac{u^2 \sin 2 \theta_1}{g}\)

For the same value of range in both cases, we can write:

\( \theta_1+\theta_2=90^{\circ}\cdots(1) \)

\(\theta_2=90^{\circ}-\theta_1\cdots(2)\)

On substituting \(90^{\circ}-\theta_1\) for \(\theta_2\) in equation (2), we get:

\(t_2=\frac{2 u \sin \left(90^{\circ}-\theta_1\right)}{g} =\frac{2 u \cos \theta_1}{g}\)

The product of time taken to reach point \(\mathrm{P}\) in both the cases is given by \(t_1 t_2\). We will substitute \(\frac{2 u \sin \theta_1}{g}\) for \(t_1\) and \(\frac{2 u \cos \theta_1}{g}\) for \(t_2\) in the relation for the product of time taken.

\( t_1 t_2=\left(\frac{2 u \sin \theta_1}{g}\right)\left(\frac{2 u \cos \theta_1}{g}\right) =\frac{2}{g}\left(\frac{u^2 \sin 2 \theta_1}{g}\right)\)

Substitute r for \(\frac{u^2 \sin 2 \theta_1}{g}\) in the above expression.

\(t_1 t_2=\frac{2}{g} r \)

\(t_1 t_2 \propto r\)

From the top of a tower of height 40m, a ball is projected upwards with a speed of \(20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) at an angle of elevation of \(30^{\circ}\). The ratio of the total time taken by the ball to hit the ground to its time of flight (time taken to come back to the same elevation) is:

Time of flight,

\(\mathrm{T}=\frac{2 \mathrm{~V} \sin \theta}{\mathrm{g}}=\frac{2 \times 20 \times \sin 30^{\circ}}{10}=2 \mathrm{sec}\)

Total time taken by the ball to hit the ground is;

\(\mathrm{t}=\frac{\text { distance }}{\text { velocity }}=\frac{40}{20 \sin 30^{\circ}}=\frac{40}{20 \times \frac{1}{2}}=4 \mathrm{sec}\)

So, the ratio is \(4: 2=2: 1\)
A projectile has a maximum range of 200 m. What is the maximum height attained by it?

Given, Range \(=200 \mathrm{~m}\)

For maximum range \(\theta=45^{\circ}\)

\(\mathrm{R}_{\max }=\frac{\mathrm{u}^2 \sin 2 \theta}{\mathrm{g}}=\frac{\mathrm{u}^2}{\mathrm{~g}}\)

Thus the maximum height,\(\mathrm{H}_{\max }=\frac{\mathrm{u}^2 \sin ^2 \theta}{2 \mathrm{~g}}=\frac{\mathrm{u}^2}{\mathrm{~g}} \times \frac{\sin ^2 45^{\circ}}{2}=200 \times\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^2=50 \mathrm{m}\)
Which of the following remain constant for a projectile fired from the earth?

Projectile motion is the motion of an object projected into the air, under only the acceleration of gravity. The object is called a projectile, and its path is called its trajectory. 

There is only a horizontal velocity component and it is always constant because there is no acceleration in the horizontal direction.

\(\mathrm{u}_{\mathrm{x}}=\mathrm{u} \cos \theta \rightarrow\) horizontal component at maximum height.

So, Horizontal component of velocity remains constant for a projectile fired from the earth.
A body is projected with a kinetic energy K at an angle of 60° with the horizontal. Its kinetic energy at the highest point of its trajectory will be:

Let initial velocity \(=v_0\)

Then initial kinetic energy \(k=\frac{1}{2} m v_0^2\)

At highest point \(v=v_0 \cos 60^{\circ}=\frac{v_0}{2}\)

So, kinetic energy at highest point \(=\frac{1}{2} m v^2=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{~m} \frac{v_0^2}{4}=\frac{K}{4}\)
A clock has a minute hand of length \(14 \mathrm{~cm}\). At what speed does the tip of the minute hand move in a duration of half an hour?

Length of minute hand \(=14 \mathrm{~cm}\)

So, The distance covered by the minute hand in half an hour \( d=\pi R\)

Where \(\mathrm{R}=\) length of the minute hand

\(\Rightarrow d=\frac{22}{7} \times 14=44 \mathrm{~cm}\)

The time taken in half an hour \( \mathrm{t}=30 \times 60=1800 \mathrm{sec}\)

We know that, 

Speed \((v)=\frac{\text { Distance }(d)}{\text { time }(t)}\)

Then the speed of the tip of the minute hand move in a duration of half an hour is

\( v=\frac{44}{1800}=\frac{11}{450} \mathrm{~cm} / \mathrm{s}\)
Which of the following statements is not true for a particle moving in a circle with a constant angular speed?
The velocity vector is tangent to the circle
The acceleration vector is tangent to the circle
The acceleration vector points to the centre of the circle
The velocity and acceleration vectors are perpendicular to each other

The acceleration vector is tangent to the circle. This is not true for a particle moving in a circle with a constant angular speed.

When a particle is moving with a constant angular speed on a circular path then it is called uniform circular motion.

In a uniform circular motion, the velocity and acceleration are perpendicular to each other. There is no tangential acceleration in uniform circular motion. There is only centripetal acceleration is there which is towards the centre.

A projectile has a range \(\mathrm{R}\) and time of flight \(\mathrm{T}\). If the range is doubled by increasing the speed of projection, without changing the angle of projection, the time of flight will become:

We know that, \(\mathrm{R}=\frac{\mathrm{v}_0^2 \sin 2 \theta_0}{\mathrm{~g}}\)

When the range is doubled without changing the angle of projection, the initial velocity becomes \(\sqrt{2}\) times.

Now, \(\mathrm T=\frac{2 \mathrm{v_0 \sin \theta_e}}{\mathrm g}=2 \times \sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{Rg}}{\sin 2 \theta_0}} \times \frac{\sin \theta_0}{\mathrm{~g}}\)

As \(T \propto \sqrt{R}\), the time of flight will become \(\sqrt{2}\) T.

A stone is thrown upward with speed \(\mathrm{u}\) and it attains maximum height \(\mathrm{h}\). Another stone thrown upward from the same point with speed \(3 \mathrm{u}\) attains maximum height \(\mathrm{H}\). Relation between \(\mathrm{h}\) and \(\mathrm{H}\) is:

Given, 

\(\mathrm{u}=\) speed of first stone, \(\mathrm{h}=\) height attained by first stone, \(3 \mathrm{u}=\) speed of another stone

At the topmost point, the motion of a particle thrown vertically upwards, \(v=0\)

By third equation of motion for the upward motion:

\( v^2=u^2-2 g h \)

\(  0=u^2-2 g h \)

\( u^2=2 g h \)

\( h=u^2 / 2 g \ldots(1) \)

For the second stone and from equation (1) we have,

\(H=\frac{(3 u)^2}{2 g}=\frac{9 u^2}{2 g} \)

\(\mathrm{H}=9 \mathrm{~h}\)

So, the relation between \(h\) and \(H\) is \(H=9 h\)

A ball is projected with a velocity of \(15 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) making an angle of \(30^{\circ}\) with the horizontal. What will be the time of flight of the ball? ( \(\mathrm{g}=10\) \(\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^2\) )

When an object is thrown at an angle \(\theta\) with some initial velocity, it goes in projectile motion before hitting the ground.

The time of flight of the object \(\mathrm{T}=\frac{2 \mathrm{usin} \theta}{g}\)

where \(\mathrm{u}=\), \(\theta=\) angle of projection with horizontal, and \(\mathrm{g}=\) gravitational acceleration.

Here \(\mathrm{u}=15 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

\(\theta=30^{\circ} \)

\( g=10 \mathrm{~m}/\mathrm{s}\)

Time of flight \((\mathrm{T})=\frac{2 u \sin \theta}{g}=\frac{2 \times 15 \times \sin 30}{10}=\frac{15}{10}=1.5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)
A man walks \(8 \mathrm{~m}\) towards the east and then \(6 \mathrm{~m}\) towards the north. The magnitude of his displacement is:

Given that, walk \(8 \mathrm{~m}\) east then walk \(6 \mathrm{~m}\) north.

We know that angle between north and east \(=90^{\circ}\).


So, apply Pythagoras theorem:

\(d^2=a^2+b^2\)

So,

\(d^2=8^2+6^2=64+36=100 \)

\(d=10\) meter
Two vectors each of magnitude 'a' produce a resultant vector of magnitude 'a'. Find the angle between the two original vectors.

The Resultant of two vectors is given by:

\(R^2=\left(A^2+B^2+2 A B \cos \theta\right)\)

where \({R}\) is the resultant vector, \({A}\) and \({B}\) are the two vectors, and \(\theta\) is the angle between two vectors.

Given that \(A=B=a\) and \(R=a\)

We know that

\({R}=\sqrt{ \left({A}^2+{B}^2+2 {AB} \cos \theta\right)} \)

\(\Rightarrow a=\sqrt{ a^2+a^2+2 a \times a \cos \theta  }\)

\(\Rightarrow a^2=2 a^2+2 a^2 \cos \theta\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{-1}{2}=\cos \theta\)

\(\Rightarrow \theta=\frac{2 \pi}{3}\)
For projectile motion, the correct relation between maximum height \(\mathrm{H}\) and the range \(\mathrm{R}\) is ( \(\theta\) is angle of projection):

When a particle moves in projectile motion, its velocity has two components-. vertical component ( \(u \sin \theta\) ) and horizontal component ( \(u \cos \theta\) ).

Let us consider the initial velocity of the projectile is \(\mathrm{u} {~m} /{s}, \mathrm{H}\) is the maximum height of the projectile and \(\mathrm{R}\) is its horizontal range.

The time of flight of projectile (\(T)=\frac{2 u \sin \theta}{g}\)

Where \(\mathrm{u}=\) velocity, angle \(=\theta\) with the \(\mathrm{x}\)-axis, and \(\mathrm{g}=\) gravitational acceleration

The maximum height a projectile can attain \(\mathrm H=\frac{u^2 \sin ^2 \theta}{2 \mathrm g}\)

The range of flight \(\mathrm R=\frac{u^2 \sin 2 \theta}{\mathrm g}\)

To find \(\theta\), let us divide the maximum height of the projectile by horizontal range

\(\frac{H}{R}=\left(\frac{\frac{u^2 \sin ^2 \theta}{2 g}}{\frac{u^2 \sin 2 \theta}{g}}\right) \)

\( \frac{H}{R}=\left(\frac{u^2 \sin ^2 \theta \times g}{u^2 \sin 2 \theta \times 2 g}\right)\)

\( \frac{H}{R}=\frac{\sin ^2 \theta}{2 \sin 2 \theta}\) (we know that \(\sin 2 \theta=2 \sin \theta \cos \theta )\)

\( \frac{H}{R}=\frac{\sin \theta \sin \theta}{2 \times 2 \sin \theta \cos \theta} \)

\( \frac{H}{R}=\frac{\sin \theta}{4 \cos \theta}\) (As \(\cos \theta / \sin \theta=\cot \theta)\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{R}=4 \mathrm{H} \cot \theta\)
Two forces of \(5 \mathrm{~N}\) and \(7 \mathrm{~N}\) act on the particle with an angle \(60^{\circ}\) between them. Find the resultant Force.

According to vector law of addition:

\(\overrightarrow{{R}}=\overrightarrow{{A}}+\overrightarrow{{B}} \)

\(R=\sqrt{A^2+B^2+2 A B \cos \theta}\)

\(A=5 \mathrm{~N}, {B}=7 \mathrm{~N}\), and \(\theta=60^{\circ}\)

The magnitude of the resultant force is given by:

\( R=\sqrt{5^2+7^2+2 \times 5 \times 7 \cos 60} \)

\( {R}=10.44 \mathrm{~N}\)
A boy moves \(4 \mathrm{~m}\) to the east then he turned left and moves \(12 \mathrm{~m}\), after that he climbs a pole to a height of \(3 \mathrm{~m}\). Find the displacement of the boy.

Let the initial position of the boy is considered as the origin.

So the initial position vector of the boy is,

\(\Rightarrow \overrightarrow{d_1}=0 \hat{i}+0 \hat{j}+0 \hat{k}\)

So according to the diagram, the final position vector of the boy is given as,

\(\Rightarrow \overrightarrow{d_2}=4 \hat{i}+3 \hat{j}+12 \hat{k}\)

By equation 1 and 2 the resultant displacement of the boy is given as,

\(\Rightarrow d=\sqrt{\left[\left(x_2-x_1\right)^2+\left(y_2-y_1\right)^2+\left(z_2-z_1\right)^2\right]} \)

\(\Rightarrow d=\sqrt{\left[(4-0)^2+(3-0)^2+(12-0)^2\right]} \)

\(\Rightarrow d=13 \mathrm{~m}\)
One of the rectangular components of a velocity of \(80 \mathrm{Kmh}^{-1}\) is \(40 \mathrm{Kmh}^{-1}\). Find the other component.

Let assume \(v\) (rectangular components) is given \(80 \mathrm{Kmh}^{-1}\), the velocity of the horizontal component \(\left(v_x\right)=40 \mathrm{Kmh}^{-1}\), then the velocity of the vertical component \(\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{y}}=\) ?

As \(v=\sqrt{v_x^2+v_y^2}=v_y=\sqrt{v^2-v_x^2}\) 

On putting the value of \(\mathrm{v}\) and \(\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{x}}\) from the above, we get

\(v_y=\sqrt{80^2+40^2}=\sqrt{6400-1600}=\sqrt{4800}=69.28 k m h^{-1}\)

So,\(v_y=69.28 \mathrm{kmh}^{-1}\)
A child pulls a rope attached to a stone with a force of \(60 \mathrm{~N}\). The rope makes an angle of 60 degrees to the ground. What is the effective force along the horizontal direction?

The vector has two components: 1. Vertical component and 2. Horizontal component


Vertical component \(\left(F_y\right)=F \operatorname{Sin} \theta\)

Horizontal component \(\left(F_x\right)=F \operatorname{Cos} \theta\)

The horizontal component is responsible to move the stone along the ground.

\(\vec{F}=F_x=F \cos \theta \)

\({F}_{{X}}=60 \cos 60^{\circ}=30 \mathrm{~N}\)

So, the effective value of the pull tending to move the stone on the ground is \(30 \mathrm{~N}\).
Three kids \(A, B\) and \(C\) are pulling a rope as shown in the figure. What are the magnitudes of force with which \(B\) and \(C\) must pull in order to keep this system in equilibrium?

Equilibrium of the system is achieved when the net force acting on the system is zero i.e. the sum of the horizontal component of forces must be zero and the sum vertical components of the force must be zero.

\(\Rightarrow \Sigma F_x=0\) and \(\Sigma F_y=0\)


Therefore, for equilibrium \(\mathrm{A} \sin 30^{\circ}=\mathrm{B}\) and \(\mathrm{A} \cos 30^{\circ}=\mathrm{C}\)

\(\Rightarrow B=20 \cos 30^{\circ}=10 \sqrt{3} \mathrm{~N} \)

\(\Rightarrow C=20 \sin 30^{\circ}=10 \mathrm{~N}\)
Which of the following statement is correct regarding a uniform circular motion?

In a uniform circular motion, the magnitude of the velocity of the body remains constant. However, the direction of the body keeps changing. Hence, there is a non-zero velocity which keeps changing due to change in direction. It is because of the constant change in the direction of the velocity of the body, there is an acceleration acting on the body, which is non-zero.
A wheel is rotating in a circular motion with the angular speed of 3600 revolution per minute (rpm). What will be its speed in \(\mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec}\)?

\(\mathrm{f}=3600 \mathrm{rpm}\)

Angular velocity \(\omega=\frac{2 \pi f}{60}\)

where \(f\) is in revolution per minute and \(\omega\) is in terms of radian per second.

\(\omega=\frac{2 \pi f}{60}=\frac{(2 \pi \times 3600)}{60}\)

\(\omega=120 \pi \mathrm{~rad} / \mathrm{sec}\)

A stone is tied at the end of a string of \(2 \mathrm{m}\) length and then rotated with a constant angular velocity of \(10 \mathrm{~rad} / \mathrm{sec}\). The centripetal acceleration of the stone will be:

In a circular motion, the component of the acceleration directed along the radius of the circle is called centripetal acceleration. It is responsible for the change in direction of velocity. 


\(\Rightarrow a_c=\frac{v^2}{r}=\omega^2 r\)

Where \(v=\) velocity, \(r=\) radius, \(a_c=\) Centripetal acceleration, \(\omega=\) angular velocity

Here \({r}=2 \mathrm{m}\) and \(\omega=10 \mathrm{~rad}/\mathrm{sec}\)

\(\Rightarrow a_c=10^2 \times 2=200 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\)
What is time of flight of a projectile motion?
The time after which the ball reaches highest point.
The time of projection or the time a projectile takes to get projected.
The time for which a projectile will be in air after projection and before hitting the ground.

Projectile motion is a kind of motion that is experienced by an object when it is projected near the Earth's surface and it moves along a curved path under the action of gravitational force.

Option C: The time for which a ball will be in the air after projection and before hitting the ground:

In this time the ball has completed its time in the air and hit the ground. So this time from projection point to hit the ground is the time of projection.
Choose correct relation between the maximum height \(({H})\) and time of flight \(({T})\) of a projectile motion:

Maximum height is the height from the point of projection, a projectile can reach. The mathematical expression of the horizontal range is:

\(\Rightarrow H=\frac{v^2 \sin ^2 \theta}{2 g}\cdots(1)\)

The time of flight of projectile motion is the time from when the object is projected to the time it reaches the surface.

\(\Rightarrow T=\frac{2 v \sin \theta}{g}\)

On squaring both, we get

\(\Rightarrow T^2=\frac{4 v^2 \sin ^2 \theta}{g^2}\cdots(2)\)

On dividing equations (1) and (2), we get

\(\Rightarrow \frac{H}{T^2}=\frac{\frac{v^2 \sin ^2 \theta}{2 g}}{\frac{4 v^2 \sin ^2 \theta}{g^2}}=\frac{g}{8} \)

\(\Rightarrow H=\frac{1}{8} g T^2\)
The co-ordinates of moving particle at any time \(t\) are given as \(x=\alpha t^3\) and \(y=\beta t^3\). The Speed of the particle at \(t\) is given by:

The velocity of an object is the rate of change of its position with respect to a frame of reference, and is a function of time. Velocity has two components: horizontal component \({v}_{{x}}\), vertical component \({v}_{{y}}\).

\(\Rightarrow {v}^2={v}_{{x}}^2+{v}_{{y}}^2\)


As \({x}=\mathrm{at}^3\)

\(\therefore v_x=\frac{d x}{d t}=3 \alpha t^2\)

Also, \(y=\beta t^3\)

\(\therefore v_y=\frac{d y}{d t}=3 \beta t^2 \)

\(\Rightarrow v=\sqrt{v_x^2+\nu_y^2}=3 t^2 \sqrt{\alpha^2+\beta^2}\)

Angular displacement \((\theta)\) is defined as total angle displaced by the particle from its starting position and it is given as radian or degrees. The unit of angular displacement is rad or Degree. Angular displacement, counter-clockwise is positive and clockwise is negative conventionally.
A runner runs \(200 \mathrm{~m}\), east, then changes direction and runs \(300 \mathrm{~m}\), west. If the entire trip takes 60 \(\mathrm{sec}\), what will be the average velocity?

The ratio of the total displacement travelled by a body to the total time taken by it is its average velocity.

Average velocity \(=\frac{\text {Total displacement }}{\text {Total time }}\)

\(=\frac{300-200}{60}=\frac{100}{60}=1.67 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

When the object follows a circular path at a constant speed, the object is said to be in uniform circular motion. It is given by the formula

\(v=\omega r\)

Where \(v=\) Linear speed \((\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s})\)

\(r=\) Radius of the circular path (m)

\(\omega=\) Angular speed (radians/s)
Which is the vector that gives the position of a point with reference to a point other than the origin of the coordinate system?

Displacement vector is the vector that gives the position of a point with reference to a point other than the origin of the coordinate system. The displacement vector with reference to a point other than the origin provides a concise description of the change in position of a point relative to that reference point.
The internal energy change for a system is \(+20 \mathrm{Cal}\) and the work done is \(-200 \mathrm{Cal}\). Find the heat exchanged between the system and the surrounding.

Given that:

\(\Delta \mathrm{W}=-200 \mathrm{Cal}\) and \(\Delta \mathrm{U}=+20 \mathrm{Cal}\)

According to the first law of Thermodynamics:

Heat exchanged \((\Delta Q)=\Delta W+\Delta U=-200+20=-180 \mathrm{Cal}\)
When the amount of work done is \(333 \mathrm{cal}\) and change in internal energy is \(167 \mathrm{cal}\), then the heat supplied is:

Given \(-\Delta W=333 \mathrm{cal}\) and \(\Delta U=167 \mathrm{cal}\)

From the first law of thermodynamics, we have

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow \Delta Q=\Delta U+\Delta W \\ & \Rightarrow \Delta Q=167+333=500 \mathrm{cal}\end{aligned}\)
If heat is supplied to an ideal gas in an isothermal process:
The internal energy of the gas will increase

For an ideal gas, Internal energy \(U=f(T)\) only

As the process is isothermal, so \(T\) will remain constant or \(\Delta T=0\)

\(\therefore \Delta U=0\)

From First Law of Thermodynamics

\(\Delta \mathrm{Q}=\Delta \mathrm{U}+\Delta \mathrm{W}\)

\(\Delta \mathrm{Q}=0+\Delta \mathrm{W}\)

As Heat is Supplied to the system is +ve so, work will also be +ve. \((\Delta W=+v e)\)

So, we can say that the work is done by the gas.
The correct thermodynamic conditions for the spontaneous reaction at all temperatures is:
ΔH>0 and ΔS<0
ΔH<0 and ΔS>0
ΔH<0 and ΔS<0

ΔH<0 and ΔS>0

∵ ΔG=ΔH−TΔS

For reaction to be spontaneous, ΔG should be negative, this works if ΔH is negative and ΔS is positive.
\(400 \mathrm{~J}\) of work is done on a gas to reduce its volume by compression adiabatically. What is the change in internal energy of the gas?

Given \(-\Delta W=400 \mathrm{~J}\)

For the adiabatic process,

\(\Delta \mathrm{Q}=0\)

As work is done on the gas, so

\(\Delta \mathrm{W}=-400 \mathrm{~J}\)

Change in internal energy,

\(\Delta U=\Delta Q-\Delta W=0-(-400)\)

\(\Delta U=-400 \mathrm{~J}\)
The change in internal energy of a 2 moles of a gas is \(-10 \mathrm{~J}\). Find the work done on the gas if the process is adiabatic.

Given - \(\Delta U=-10 \mathrm{~J}\)

When a thermodynamic system undergoes a physical change in such a way that its change in heat remains constant, then the change is known as an adiabatic.

In adiabatic process, \(\Delta {Q}=0\)

From the first law of thermodynamics:

\(\Rightarrow \Delta \mathrm{Q}=\Delta \mathrm{U}+\Delta \mathrm{W}\)

\(\Rightarrow 0=\Delta \mathrm{U}+\Delta \mathrm{W}\)

\(\Rightarrow \Delta \mathrm{W}=-(-10)=10 \mathrm{~J}\)
A device that converts heat energy into work in a cyclic process is:

A heat engine is a closed-cycle device that takes heat from a hot reservoir, does useful work and rejects the remaining heat to a cold reservoir. A device that converts heat energy into work in a cyclic process is a heat engine.
For the thermodynamic heat pump, heat flows from:

A heat pump is a device that maintains a system or a body at a temperature higher than the surrounding temperature.

In the heat pump, the heat is removed from the low-temperature body and is added to the high-temperature body.
A gas expands adiabatically at constant pressure such that its temperature \(T \propto \frac{1}{\sqrt{V}}\), the value of \(C_p / C_r\) of gas is:

Given, 

\(T \propto V^{\frac{-1}{2}}=T=k V^{\frac{-1}{2}}=k=T V^{\frac{1}{2}} \ldots\) (1)

For adiabatic process, \(\mathrm{PV}^{\mathrm{Y}}=\) constant or \(k=T^{Y-1} \ldots\) (2)

equating both the equations we get,

\(\mathrm{TV}^{\frac{1}{2}}=\mathrm{TV}^{\mathrm{Y}-1}\)

\(\mathrm{Y}-1=\frac{1}{2}\)

\(\mathrm{Y}=\frac{3}{2}\)
A black body is heated from \(27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) to \(127^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\). The ratio of their energies of radiations emitted will be:

We know that

\(\mathrm{E}=\sigma \mathrm{T}^4\)

Where \(\mathrm{E}\) is rate of emission of radiation of a body at temperature \(\mathrm{T}\).

\(\mathrm{E}_1=\sigma(27+273)^2\)

\(\mathrm{E}_2=\sigma(127+273)^2\)

\(\frac{\mathrm{E}_1}{\mathrm{E}_2}=\frac{(300)^4}{(400)^4}=\frac{81}{256}\)
The ratio of the relative rise in pressure for adiabatic compression to that for isothermal compression is :

For adiabatic case slope of \(\mathrm{PV}\) graph is given by \(\gamma \times(\frac{\mathrm{P}}{ \mathrm{V}})\) and for isothermal case it is given by \((\frac{\mathrm{P}}{\mathrm{V}})\).

Ratio of them will be \(\gamma\).

One gram of water on evaporation at atmospheric pressure forms \(1671 \mathrm{~cm}^3\) of steam. The heat of vaporisation at this pressure is \(540 \mathrm{cal} / \mathrm{gm}\). The increase in internal energy is:

\(\begin{gathered}\Delta Q=\Delta U+P \Delta V \\ m L=\Delta U+P \Delta V \\ \Delta U=m L-P \Delta V \\ m L=1 \times 540=540 \mathrm{cal}\end{gathered}\)

\(P \Delta V=1 \times 10^5(1671-1) \times 10^{-6}=167 \mathrm{~J}\)

\(=\frac{167}{4.2}=40 \mathrm{~cal}\).

\(\therefore \Delta U=540-40=500 \mathrm{cal}\)

3 moles of gas requires \(60 \mathrm{cal}\) of heat for \(5^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) rise in temperature at constant volume. Then heat required for 5 moles of the same gas under constant pressure for \(100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) raise in temperature is:

At constant volume, \(\mathrm{W}={0}\)

So, \(\mathrm{Q}=\mathrm{U}=\mathrm{nC}_{\mathrm{v}} \Delta \mathrm{T}\)

\(60=3 C_v \times 5\)

\(C_V=4\)

\(C_p=C_v+R\)

\(C_p=4+2=6\)

At constant pressure,

Q = nCpΔT

Q = 5×6×100

Q = 3000 cal

A quantity of heat ' \(Q\) ' is supplied to a mono-atomic ideal gas which expands at constant pressure. The fraction of heat that goes into work done by the gas is:

The heat \(\mathrm{Q}\) is converted into the internal energy and work. According to the first law of thermodynamics,

\(\mathrm{Q}=\mathrm{U}+\mathrm{W}\)

\(\mathrm{nC}_{\mathrm{p}} \Delta \mathrm{T}=\mathrm{nC}_{\mathrm{v}} \Delta \mathrm{T}+\mathrm{W}\)

The dfraction of heat converted to work is given as

\(\frac{\mathrm{W}}{\mathrm{Q}}=\frac{\mathrm{nC}_{\mathrm{p}} \Delta \mathrm{T}-\mathrm{nC}_{\mathrm{v}} \Delta \mathrm{T}}{\mathrm{nC}_{\mathrm{p}} \Delta \mathrm{T}}=\frac{\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{p}}-\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{v}}}{\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{p}}}=\frac{\frac{5}{2} \mathrm{R}-\frac{3}{2} \mathrm{R}}{\frac{5}{2} \mathrm{R}}=\frac{2}{5}\)

A given mass of a gas is compressed isothermally until its pressure is doubled. It is then allowed to expand adiabatically until its original volume is restored and its pressure is then found to be 0.75 of its initial pressure. The ratio of the specific heats of the gas is approximately:

let Initial value of volume,pressure and temperature of gas be \(V_0, P_0, T_0\)

In step one, gas is compressed isothermally, so temperature will be constant

After first step :

Pressure \(=2 \mathrm{P}_0 ;\) Temperature \(=\mathrm{T}_0\)

from \(P V=n R T\) Volume \(=\frac{V_0}{2}\);

In 2nd step, gas is allowd to expand adiabatically to restore its original volume

After 2nd step:

Pressure \(=0.75 \mathrm{P}_0\), Volume \(=\mathrm{V}_0\),

from the adiabatic process relation between \(\mathrm{P}\) and \(\mathrm{V}-\mathrm{PV}^\gamma=\) constant

\(P_1 V_1^\gamma=P_2 V_2^\gamma\)

\(\left(\frac{V_1}{V_2}\right)^\gamma=\frac{P_2}{P_1}\)

\(\begin{aligned} & \mathrm{V}_1=\frac{\mathrm{V}_0}{2}, \mathrm{P}_1=2 \mathrm{P}_0 \\ & \mathrm{~V}_2=\mathrm{V}_0 \text { and } \mathrm{P}_2=0.75 \mathrm{P}_0\end{aligned}\)

so \(\left(\frac{\frac{\mathrm{V}_0}{2}}{\mathrm{~V}_0}\right)^{\gamma}=\frac{0.75 \mathrm{P}_0}{2 \mathrm{P}_0}\)

\(\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^\gamma=\frac{3}{8}\)

on solving this:

\(\gamma=1.41\)

Which of the following law of thermodynamics is responsible for heat transfer?

The transfer of heat is primarily governed by the laws of thermodynamics, and specifically, the second law of thermodynamics is most directly related to heat transfer. The second law of thermodynamics states that the total entropy of an isolated system will never decrease over time; it tends to increase or, at best, remain constant. In the context of heat transfer, it implies that heat will naturally flow from regions of higher temperature to regions of lower temperature, and not the other way around.
Heat does not spontaneously flow from a colder body to a hotter one. Which of the following thermodynamics law states this?

The concept of entropy as a physical attribute of a thermodynamic system is established by the second law of thermodynamics. Despite following the necessity of energy conservation as specified in the first law of thermodynamics, entropy predicts the direction of spontaneous processes and determines whether they are irreversible or impossible.
What is the value of the absolute thermodynamic temperature scale?
The temperature of an object on a scale with 0 as absolute zero is known as absolute temperature, also known as thermodynamic temperature. Kelvin and Rankine are absolute temperature scales.
Which of the following is chosen as the standard thermometric substance?
Smallest variation is observed among different gas thermometers.
The entropy of an isolated system can never ____.
The entropy of an isolated system always increases and remains constant only when the process is reversible.

\(\begin{aligned} & 0=\Delta U+W \\ & \Delta U=-W \\ & \Delta U=\text { Negative }\end{aligned}\)

The process will be Isochoric.

\(Q \rightarrow+v e\) (when the heat is transferred to the system)

\(Q \rightarrow\)-ve (when the heat is taken out of the system)

\(\mathrm{W} \rightarrow+\mathrm{ve}\) (when the work is done by the system)

\(\mathrm{W} \rightarrow\)-ve (when the work is done on the system)

In the isothermal process if the heat given to the system is \(100 \mathrm{~J}\), the change in internal energy and the work done of the system will be:

Given,

\(Q=100 \mathrm{~J}\)

In the isothermal process, the temperature remains constant during the process,

\(\Rightarrow \Delta T=0\)....(1)

The change in internal energy is given as,

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow \Delta U=n C_v \Delta T \\ & \Rightarrow \Delta U=n C_v \times 0 \\ & \Rightarrow \Delta \mathrm{U}=0 \mathrm{~J}\end{aligned}\)

By the first law of thermodynamics,

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow \mathrm{Q}=\mathrm{W}+\Delta \mathrm{U} \\ & \Rightarrow 100=\mathrm{W}+0 \\ & \Rightarrow 100=\mathrm{W} \\ & \Rightarrow \mathrm{W}=100 \mathrm{~J}\end{aligned}\)
Which of the following is an intensive variable?

Intensive Property: These are the properties of the system which are independent of mass under consideration. For example: Pressure, Temperature, density, composition

Extensive Properties: The properties which depend on the mass of the system under consideration. For example: Internal Energy, Enthalpy, Mass, Volume, Entropy, weight.

From above it is clear that, the temperature is an intensive variable.

The efficiency of a heat engine can never be:

A heat engine is a device which converts continuously heat energy to mechanical energy in a cyclic Process. The main parts of a heat engine are:

  • Source: It is a heat reservoir at a higher temperature  T1.
  • Sink: It is a reservoir at a lower temperature T2. 
  • Working Substance: Working substance is any gaseous or liquid substance that performs a mechanical work when heat supplied to it.
  • The diagram below shows the essential components of a heat engine.


Where,

HE = Heat Engine

TH = Temperature of Source / Hot reservoir

TL = Temperature of Sink / Cold Reservoir

Q1 = Heat absorbed from Source

Q2 = Heat rejected to Sink

The efficiency(η) of a heat engine is defined as:

\(\therefore \eta=\frac{W}{Q_{1}}=\frac{Q_{1}-Q_{2}}{Q_{1}}=1-\frac{Q_{2}}{Q_{1}}\)

Now, W = Q1  - Q2

The efficiency of the heat engine is always less than 1.  This is because in reality none of the engines can convert absorbed heat completely into work, as some of the heat will always be dissipated during the process. Also stated, according to the second Law no heat engine can have 100% efficiency
If the temperature of the source is increased, the efficiency of the Carnot engine:

The efficiency \((\eta)\) of the Carnot engine is given by:

\(n=1-\frac{T_C}{T_H}\)

Here if \(T_H\) increases, the value of \(T_C / T_H\) decreases, and hence the value of \(\left(1-T_d / T_H\right)\) increases. If the temperature of the source \(\left(T_H\right)\) is increased then the efficiency of the Carnot engine increases.

An ideal gas heat engine operates in Carnot's cycle between \(227^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) and \(127^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \mathrm{It} \mathrm{absorbs}\) \(6 \times 10^4 \mathrm{~J}\) at high temperature. The amount of heat converted into work is:

Given - \(T_1=227+273=500 \mathrm{~K}, T_2=127+273=400 \mathrm{~K}\), Heat absorbed by the engine is \(Q_1=6 \times 10^4 \mathrm{~J}\)

The efficiency of heat engine is given by-

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow \eta=\frac{W}{Q_1}=1-\frac{T_2}{T_1} \\ & \Rightarrow \frac{W}{6 \times 10^4}=1-\frac{400}{500} \\ & \Rightarrow \frac{W}{6 \times 10^4}=1-\frac{4}{5} \\ & \Rightarrow \frac{W}{6 \times 10^4}=\frac{1}{5} \\ & \Rightarrow W=\frac{6 \times 10^4}{5}=1.2 \times 10^4 \mathrm{~J}\end{aligned}\)

The heat given to an ideal gas in isothermal conditions is used to:
increase temperature and in doing external work

When a thermodynamic system undergoes a physical change in such a way that its temperature remains constant, then the change is known as an isothermal process.

As we know that the internal energy of the system is a function of temperature alone, so in the isothermal process, the change in internal energy is zero.

\(\Rightarrow \Delta \mathrm{Q}=0+\Delta \mathrm{W}=\Delta \mathrm{W}\)

Therefore, the heat given to an ideal gas in isothermal conditions is used to do external work.
110 joule of heat is added to a gaseous system whose internal energy is \(40 \mathrm{~J}\). Then the amount of external work done is:

Given that, \(\Delta Q=110 \mathrm{~J}, \Delta U=40 \mathrm{~J}\)

According to the first law of thermodynamics:

\(\Delta \mathrm{Q}=\Delta \mathrm{W}+\Delta \mathrm{U}\)

\(\Delta \mathrm{U}=\Delta \mathrm{Q}-\Delta \mathrm{W}\)

\(40 \mathrm{~J}=110 \mathrm{~J}-\Delta \mathrm{W}\)

\(\Delta \mathrm{W}=110-40=70 \mathrm{~J}\)
A Carnot engine whose sink is at 300 K has an efficiency of 40%. By how much should the temperature of the source be increased so as to increase its efficiency by 50% of original efficiency?

Temperature of \(\operatorname{sink} T_L=300 \mathrm{~K}\)

Original efficiency \(\eta=40 \%=0.4\)

Let the Initial temperature of the source be \(T_H\)

Using \(\eta=1-\frac{T_L}{T_H}\)

\(\therefore 0.4=1-\frac{300}{\mathrm{~T}_{\mathrm{H}}} \Longrightarrow \mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}}=500 \mathrm{~K}\)

Now the efficiency of the engine is increased by \(50 \%\) of original efficiency,

\(\therefore\) New efficiency \(\eta^{\prime}=40 \%+20 \%=60 \%\)

\(\therefore \eta^{\prime}=1-\frac{\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{L}}}{\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}}^{\prime}}\)

OR \(0.6=1-\frac{300}{T_H^{\prime}}\)

\(\mathrm{OR} \frac{3 \mathrm{OO}}{\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}}^{\prime}}=0.4 \Rightarrow \mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}}^{\prime}=750 \mathrm{~K}\)

Increase in source temperature \(\Delta \mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}}=\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}}^{\prime}-\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}}=750-500=250 \mathrm{~K}\)
If Q, E and W denote respectively the heat added, change in internal energy and the work done in a closed cycle process, then:

Internal energy depends only on the initial and final states of temperature and not on the path.

In a cyclic process, as initial and final states are the same, change in internal energy is zero \((\Delta E=0)\).

Hence \({E}\) is \(\Delta {U}\), the change in internal energy.

The second law of thermodynamics is concerned with the:

What makes molecules tend to drive back to their original positions when an deforming force is removed from an elastic material?
Deforming force gives a negative force to make molecules back to original position.
Charge on the molecules makes molecules to come back to its original positions.
Intermolecular forces that works between the molecules.

Option (B): There may be or may not be a charge on the molecules of the solid. So this can't be the reason to drive molecules back to their original positions.

If the length of a rod has becomes half by cutting it, how much load it can bear before breaking as compare to before?

Breaking Stress: It is also called ultimate tensile stress. It is the maximum stress a material can stand before it breaks.

Tensile stress:  The force applied along a rod divided by the cross-sectional area of the rod perpendicular to the applied force is called tensile stress.

Tensile stress \(= \frac{\text{Force}}{\text{Cross section area}}\)

From the definition, it is clear that the breaking stress of a rod does not depend on its length.

So, If we half the length of the rod, the force required to break it will remain the same. So, it can bear the same load as before.
The length of a wire is 'L' and volume is V(fixed). If constant force F is applied on the wire, the extension produced in the wire will be proportional to _____

Given that length = L and volume = V and Force = F

Since, in the stress formula we have to use area A that is not given in the question.

So, Volume V = Area A × length L

A = \(\frac{V}{L}\)

From Hooke's law,

Stress = k × Strain

From Hooke's law,

\(\frac{F}{A}=k \times \frac{\Delta L}{L}\)

\(\frac{F}{\frac{V}{L}}=k \times \frac{\Delta L}{L}\)

\(\frac{F L}{V}=k \times \frac{\Delta L}{L}\)

\(\frac{F L^{2}}{k V}=\Delta L\)

So, extension \(\Delta L \propto L^{2}\)

The extension produced in this wire by a constant force \(F\) is proportional to \(L^{2}\).
If stress developed in a material is \(6 \times 10^{7}\) N/m and strain developed is \(2 \times 10^{2}\). What will be the proportionality constant according to Hook's law?

Given: Stress \(=6 \times 10^{7}\) N/m and strain \(=2 \times 10^{2}\)

We know that:

Stress \(= k \times\) Strain

Where, \(k\) is the proportionality constant.

So, from the formula of stress, we get, 

\(6 \times 10^{7}= k \times 2 \times 10^{2}\)

\(k =3 \times 10^{5}\) N/m
Which of the following is correct regarding the region B to D in a typical stress-strain curve as given below?
Point B to D, material follows Hook's Law.
Strain does not occur for given stress.
Strain increases very slowly even for a small change in the stress.
Strain increases rapidly even for a small change in the stress.

Option (D): From B to D, in the stress-strain curve, the curve is almost flat or increasing slowly.

This flatness tells that a very less increase in stress will give a high change in strain because the slope is very low.

Option (A): A material follows Hook's law in the region from O to point A only.

So, this is not the correct answer.

Option (B): Since in region B to D curve increasing in the x-axis i.e. strain axis, it means the material has a strain in this region.

So, this is not the correct answer.

Option (C): If the slope of the curve were high, the less change in strain would have been due to more change in the stress.

But the curve here B to D is less sloped or almost flat for some material.

So, this is not the correct answer.
Which of the following is correct for point A to B in the stress-strain curve?
If we remove the load the body will return to its original dimension
If we remove the load the body will not return to its original dimension

Option (A): Point B is the elastic point. Up to point B, when the load is removed, the body returns to its original dimension.

Option (B): Stress is proportional to strain up to point A from point O.

Hook's law is followed up to in the region of OA only. After it, there is no proportionality.

So, in the region A to B, the material does not follow proportionality law or Hook's law.

Therefore, both options (A) and (B) are the correct answer.
An increase of \(0.1 \%\) in the length of a wire of cross-section \(10^{-6}\) m\(^{2}\) causes tension of \(1 \times 100\) N in the wire. The Young's modulus of the material of the wire is:

Given: \(\% dl\) is percentage change in lenght \(=0.1 \%\), A is area \(=10^{-6}\) m\(^{2}\) and P is Tension in wire \(=100\) N

We know that,

\(\% d l=\frac{d l}{l} \times 100\)

\(\Rightarrow \% d l=\frac{d l}{l} \times 100=0.1\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d l}{l}=10^{-3} \quad \cdots\) (1)

By Hooke's law,

\(\sigma=E \epsilon\)

Where, \(\sigma\) is stress, E is young's modulus, \(\epsilon\) is strain.

From the formula, we get,

\( E=\frac{\sigma}{\epsilon}\)

\(\Rightarrow E=\frac{\frac{P}{A}}{\frac{d l}{l}}\)

\(\Rightarrow E=\frac{100}{10^{-6} \times 10^{-3}}\)

\(\Rightarrow E=10^{11}\) N/m\(^{2}\)

A steel wire of 1 m long and 1 mm\(^{2}\) cross-section area is hanged from the rigid end when the weight of 1 kg is hung from it then change in length will be (for wire Youngs coefficient Y \(=2 \times 10^{11}\) N/m\(^{2})\):

Given: Young modulus \(Y =2 \times 10^{11}\) N/m\(^{2}\), mass \(m =1\) Kg, \(L =1\) m, Area \(A =1\) mm\(^{2}=1 \times 10^{-6}\) m\(^{2}\), Change in length \(\Delta L =?\), and Force F \(=\) mg \(=1 \times 10=10\) N

The young modulus of the material is given by,

\(Y=\frac{F L}{A \Delta l}\)

The above equation can be rewritten for \(\Delta L\) as,

\(\Delta L=\frac{F L}{A Y}\)

Substituting the given value in the above equation,

\(\Delta L=\frac{10 \times 1}{1 \times 10^{-6} \times 2 \times 10^{11}}=5 \times 10^{-5}\) m

\(\Rightarrow \Delta L =0.05\) mm
Why water is more elastic than air?

It is known that liquids are incompressible and gases can be easily compressed.

Therefore, water has greater resistance to compression than water i.e., it has a greater value of bulk modulus of elasticity. Also, water is more elastic than air because bulk modulus of elasticity is reciprocal of compressibility and air is more compressible than water. Thus, water will be more elastic than air as air has greater compressibility.
In the elastic behaviour of solids, the intermolecular forces are in which equilibrium?
Intermolecular forces are not in the equilibrium

Each molecule of an elastic solid is acted upon by the forces because of neighboring known as intermolecular force.

Due to an external force on an elastic body, the body gets displaced. Thus, molecules are displaced from their original position. But when the external force is removed, they come back to its original position. Thus, the force between the molecules (intermolecular forces) is in stable equilibrium.
A liquid placed inside a glass tube rises due to capillary action. If the angle of contact made by the liquid on the glass is \(\theta\), which of the following is true?

Consider a capillary tube of radius r dipped in a liquid of density \(\rho\). Let us assume that the liquid rises to a height of \(h\) in the tube due to the surface tension \(\sigma\) and g is acceleration due to gravity.


    \(\theta\) is the contact angle made by the liquid meniscus with the capillary tube's surface.

    On balancing the forces in the liquid column of height \(h\),

    Weight of the water in column = Upwards force due to surface tension

    Mass of water \(\times g =\sigma \cos \theta \times\) perimeter

    Density \(\times\) volume \(\times g=\sigma \cos \theta \times 2 \pi r\)

    \(\rho \times \pi r^{2} h \times g=\sigma \cos \theta \times 2 \pi r\)

    Capillary rise, \(h=\frac{2 \sigma \cos \theta}{\rho g r}\)

    Capillary rise is dependent on \(\theta\). Therefore capillary rise depends on the values of \(\cos \theta\).

    For a rise in the liquid column, the value of capillary rise 'h' must be positive. This is possible when \(\cos \theta\) is positive i.e., \(0^{\circ}<\theta<90^{\circ}\)
The Young's modulus of the material of a wire is \(2 \times 10^{10}\) N/m\(^{2}\). If the elongation strain is \(1 \%\), then the energy stored in the wire per unit volume in J/m\(^{3}\) is:

Given: Young modulus \(Y =2 \times 10^{10} N / m ^{2}\), elongation strain is \(1 \%, U =\) energy stored per unit volume.

We know that:

Young's modulus, Y \(=\frac{\text { stress }}{\text { strain }}\)

Using this the energy stored per unit volume can be given as,

U \(=\frac{\text { strain energy }}{\text { volume }}=\frac{1}{2} \times Y \times \text {strain}^{2} \quad \dots\) (1)

Now, as we have all the values just put it in the equation number (1),

\(U =\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) \times 2 \times 10^{10} \times \left(\frac{1}{100}\right)^{2}=10^{6}\) J/m\(^{3}\)

So, energy stored in the wire per unit volume in J/m\(^{3}\) is \(10^{6}\).

A student conducted an experiment on a wire and observed that there was no change in the volume of the wire due to a change in its length by stretching. The Poisson's ratio of the material of the wire is:

Let the length of the wire be I, r its radius, and A its cross-sectional area.

Poisson's ratio, \(\nu=-\frac{\epsilon_{t}}{\epsilon_{l}}=-\frac{\frac{d r}{r}}{\frac{d l}{l}} \quad \ldots\) (1)

Volume of wire, \(V=\) Length \(\times\) Cross-sectional area \(=l \times \pi r^{2}\)

\(d V =\pi r ^{2} \cdot d +2 mrl \cdot dr\)

Since, there is no change in volume, \(dV =0\)

\(0=\pi r^{2} \cdot d l+2 \pi r l dr\)

\(\Rightarrow \pi r^{2} \cdot d l=-2 \pi r l \cdot d r\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d r}{r}=-\frac{1}{2} \frac{d l}{l}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\frac{d r}{r}}{\frac{d l}{l}}=-\frac{1}{2}\quad \ldots\) (2)

Substituting (2) in (1),

Poisson's ratio, \(\nu=-\frac{\frac{d r}{r}}{\frac{d l}{l}}=-\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right)=0.5\)
When a spring is stretched by 2 cm the energy stored is 100 J. If it is stretched further by 2 cm, its energy increases by ________.

Given: lenght of spring \({x}=2\) cm

\(\text {Energy stored }=\frac{1}{2} {kx}^{2}\)

\(100=0.5 \times {k} \times 2^{2}\)

\({k}\) =\(\frac{100}{2}=50\)

\(\text {now, } {x}=4\) cm

\(\text {Energy stored }=\frac{1}{2}{kx}^{2}\)

\(=0.5 \times 50 \times 4^{2} \)

\(=400\) J

so, stored energy increases by \(= 400-100=300\)
Work done in blowing the soap bubble in the air of radius 2R is W. Find the work done in blowing the soap bubble of radius R.

We know that:

Work done to blow a bubble \(=\) Surface tension \(\times\) surface area

Since, the soap bubble is in the air so there will be two surfaces in contact with the air (inside and outside)

Work done to blow a bubble \(=\) Surface tension \(\times 2 \times\) surface area of the bubble

Work done to blow a bubble of radius 2R

\(W = T \times 2 \times A\)

Where, T is the surface tension and A  is area

\(W = T \times 2 \times\left(4 \pi(2 R )^{2}\right)\)

\(W =32 T \pi R ^{2} \quad \ldots\) (i)

Work done to blow a bubble of radius R

\(W ^{\prime}= T \times 2 \times A = T \times 2 \times\left(4 \pi R ^{2}\right)\)

\(W ^{\prime}=8 T \pi R ^{2}\quad \ldots\) (ii)

Eq (ii) / eq (i)

\(\frac{W^{\prime}}{W} =\frac{8 T \pi R^{2}}{32 T \pi R^{2}}\)

\(\frac{W^{\prime}}{W} =\frac{1}{4}\)

\(W^{\prime}=\frac{W}{4}\)
Calculate the work done in blowing the soap bubble when the difference in surface area is 1 cm\(^{-2}\) and surface tension of bubble is 3 dyne cm\(^{-1}\).

Given: The change in the Area of the soap bubble \((\Delta A)\)

\(\Delta A =1\) cm\(^{2}\)

\(W = S \times \Delta A\)

Where, W is the work done, S is the surface tension of bubble

\(W =3 \times 1 erg\)

\(W =3~erg\)

Since, \(1 \text { erg }=1 \times 10^{-7}\) J

\(W =3 \times 10^{-7}\) J

So, work done is \(3 \times 10^{-7}\) J
The specific gravity of an oil is 0.9 and the viscosity of the oil is 0.28 stokes at 38ºC. What will be the viscosity in Ns/m2?

Given:

ρ = 0.9 x 1000 kg/m3

ν = 0.28 stokes = 0.28 x 10-4 m2/s

We know that,

μ = ρ x ν

Where, ρ = density of oil = specific gravity of oil x density of water, μ is viscosity in Ns/m2  and ν is viscosity of oil

μ = (0.9 x 1000) x (0.28 x 10-4) Ns/m2

μ = 0.0252 Ns/m2

A square metal plate of 10 cm side moves parallel to another plate with a velocity of 10 cms-1, both plates immersed in water. If the viscous force is 200 dyne and the viscosity of water is 0.01 poise, what is their distance apart?

Given: \(A=100\) cm\(^{2}\), \(\eta=0.01\) poise, \(dv=10\) cms\(^{-1}\), \(dy=?\)

We know that:

Newton's formula for the viscous force between two parallel layers is given by:

\(F =\eta A \frac{ dv }{ dy }\)

Where, \(\eta \) is viscosity of water, A is area, dv is velocity and dy is distance

On putting the value of the above we get,

\(dy =\frac{\eta Adv }{ F }\)

\(=\frac{0.01 \times 100 \times 10}{200}\)

\(=0.05\) cm

Thus, the distance will be \(0.05\) cm.
Bernoulli's principle is given by the equation: \(P+\frac{1}{2} \rho v^{2}+\rho g h=K\) (const.) The dimension of \(\left[\frac{P}{K}\right]\) is the same as:

Given: equation is \(P+\frac{1}{2} \rho v^{2}+\rho g h=K\) (const.)

So, the dimension of [P] will be equal to the dimension of \(\left[\frac{1}{2} \rho v^{2}\right]\) and \([\rho g h]\) and K (const.)

We know that:

\([P]=\left[\frac{1}{2} \rho v^{2}\right]=[\rho g h]=[K]\)

Where, \(P\) is the pressure exerted by the fluid, \(v\) is the velocity of the fluid, \(\rho\) is the density of the fluid, \(h\) is the height of the container.

The dimension of \([ P ]=\) The dimension of \([ K ]\)

So, the dimension of \(\left[\frac{P}{K}\right]=\) dimensionless or no dimension.

There the quantity \(\left[\frac{P}{K}\right]\) is a dimensionless quantity.

Calculate the minimum pressure required to force the blood from the heart to the top of the head (vertical distance = 50 cm). Assume the density of the blood to be \(1.40\) g.cm\(^{-3}\). Friction should be neglected.

Given: \(h _{2}- h _{1}=50\) cm, \(\rho=1.04\) g cm\(^{-3}\), g is \(9.8\) ms\(^{-2}\) on changing into cm we get 980 ms\(^{-2}\)

According to Bernoulli's Law:

\(P_{1}+\frac{1}{2} \rho v_{1}^{2}+\rho g h_{1}=P_{2}+\frac{1}{2} \rho v_{2}^{2}+\rho g h_{2}, \ldots \ldots \ldots\) (i)

Minimum Pressure will be \(h _{1}\) is the full-body height, \(h _{2}\) is the distance of the body from the heart to the foot.

\(P _{1}- P _{2}=\rho g \left( h _{2}- h _{1}\right)+\frac{1}{2} \rho\left( v _{2}^{2}- v _{1}^{2}\right) \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots\) (ii)

\(\left(v_{2}=v_{1}\right)\) so \(\frac{1}{2} \rho\left(v_{2}^{2}-v_{1}^{2}\right)=0 \)

Assume that: \(P _{1}- P _{2}=\rho g \left( h _{2}- h _{1}\right)\)

Where, \(P _{1}- P _{2}\) change in pressure, \(h _{2}- h _{1}=\) vertical distance ,assume that \(\left( v _{2}= v _{1}\right.\) ) rate of velocity is same for the flow of blood from heart to the head on putting the value from above equation, we get,

\(P _{1}- P _{2}=1.04 \times 980 \times 50\) dyne cm\(^{-2}=5.1 \times 10^{4}\) dyne cm\(^{-2}\)

The terminal velocity of a copper ball of radius 2 mm falling through a tank of honey is 30 mm/s. What will be the drag force exerted by the oil on the copper ball if the viscosity of the oil is 1 N-s/m2.

Given: \(r =2 mm =2 \times 10^{-3} m , v =30 mm / s =30 \times 10^{-3} m / s , \eta=1 N - s / m ^2\)

We know that:

viscous drag force \(F =6 \pi \eta rv\)

Where, \(r\) is the radius of the sphere, \(v\) is the velocity, and \(\eta\) is the viscosity of the fluid.

\(F =6 \pi \times 1 \times 2 \times 10^{-3} \times 30 \times 10^{-3} \)

\(=36 \pi \times 10^{-6} N \)

\(=1.13 \times 10^{-4} N\)

Consider an object falling freely under an influence of gravity in air. How fast an object reaches terminal velocity and the value of its terminal velocity depends upon _______ if we consider air drag as negligible.
The mass of the falling object & acceleration due to gravity.
The height from which it is dropped and acceleration due to gravity only.
The density of the falling object & acceleration due to gravity.

Under free fall where gravity is the sole influence on the body, the total energy remains the same.

Potential energy gets converted into the kinetic energy. Potential Energy keeps on decreasing and kinetic energy keeps on increasing.

Given, Drag is negligible

For attaining terminal velocity drag force is required.

Thus, the body will never achieve terminal velocity.
Pressure inside two soap bubbles is 1.01 and 1.03 atmosphere. Ratio between their volumes is:

Given:

Atmospheric pressure \(=1\)

Pressure in bubble \(1=1.01\)

Pressure in bubble \(2=1.03\)

So, external pressure in bubble 1 is \(1.01-1=0.01\) atm

External pressure in bubble 2 is \(1.03-1=0.03\) atm

Let the radius of bubble 1 is \(R _{1}\)

Let the radius of bubble 2 is \(R _{2}\)

We know that the formula of pressure inside the soap bubble is given as:

\(\frac{P_{1}}{P_{2}}=\frac{\frac{4 T}{R_{1}}}{\frac{4 T}{R_{2}}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{P_{1}}{P_{2}}=\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{R_{1}}{R_{2}}=\frac{0.03}{0.01}=\frac{3}{1}\)

Now, the ratio of volume is:

\(\frac{\frac{4}{3} \pi\left(R_{1}\right)^{3}}{\frac{4}{3} \pi\left(R_{2}\right)^{3}}=\frac{\left(R_{1}\right)^{3}}{\left.R_{2}\right)^{3}}=\left(\frac{3}{1}\right)^{3}=\frac{27}{1}\)

So, the required ratio is 27 : 1.
Find the strain energy of the wire on applying a load of F, if the length of the wire is l, cross section area is A, and young modulus is Y.

The volume of material \(=\) Area \(\times V = Al\) \(E=\frac{1}{2} \times\) stress \(\times\) strain \(\times\) volume \(\quad \ldots\) (i)

We don't know strain here, so we will change strain into stress and \(Y\).

\(Y=\frac{\text { stress }}{\text { strain }}\)

From the equation (1), we get, strain energy of the wire:

\(E=\frac{1}{2} \times\) stress \(\times \frac{\text { stress }}{Y} \times\) volume

\(E=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{\text { stress }^{2}}{Y} \times\) volume

\(E=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{\left(\frac{F}{A}\right)^{2}}{Y} \times A l\)

\(E=\frac{1}{2} \frac{F^{2}}{A Y} l\)
A water drop and a soap bubble have the same radii. If the surface tension of water is two times that of soap solution, the ratio of excess pressure inside the water drop and soap bubble is:

Let \(R_{1}, R_{2}\), and \(T_{1}, T_{2}\) be the radius and surface tension of water drop and soap bubble respectively.

Given that:

\(R _{1}= R _{2}\) and \(T _{1}=2 T _{2}\)

We know that:

Work done by excess pressure \(=\) force \(×\) displacement \(=\) pressure \(×\) surface area \(× dR = P × 4πR2 × dR \quad \ldots \) (1)

Energy (work done) \(= T \times\) area \(=2 T \times\) change in area \(=2 T \times\left(4 \pi\{ R + dR \}^{2}-4 \pi R ^{2}\right)=2 T (4 \pi(2 RdR ))\quad \ldots \) (2)

Equating (1) and (2),

\(P \times 4 \pi R ^{2} \times dR =2 T \times(4 \pi(2 RdR ))\)

Excess pressure, \(P=\frac{4 T}{R}\)

The ratio of excess pressure:

\(\frac{P_{1}}{P_{2}}=\frac{\frac{2 T_{1}}{R_{1}}}{\frac{4 T_{2}}{R_{2}}}=\frac{\frac{2\left(2 T_{2}\right)}{R}}{\frac{4 T_{2}}{R}}=\frac{1}{1}\)

When the temperature of black body increases, it is observed that the wavelength corresponding to maximum energy changes from \(0.26 \mu m\) to \(0.13 \mu m\). The ratio of the emissive powers of the body at the respective temperatures is:

From Wien's displacement law,

\(\lambda_{\max } \propto \frac{1}{ T }\)

Where, \(\lambda_{\max }=\) Maximum wavelength, \(T =\) Time

Let initial and final temperature \(T _{1}\) and \(T _{2}\), and corresponding powers \(P _{1}\) and \(P _{2}\) respectively.

From Stefan's law,

\(\frac{ P _{1}}{ P _{2}}=\left(\frac{ T _{1}}{ T _{2}}\right)^{4}\)

\(=\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{4}=\frac{1}{16}\)
Which of the following phenomenon is responsible for the transference of heat from one end of a metallic rod to the other end?
Conduction is the mode of transfer of heat in the form of particle vibration from hotter end to colder end of a body.

Consider two hot bodies \(A\) and \(B\) which have temperature \(120^{\circ} C\) and \(80^{\circ} C\) respectively at time \(t =0\) sec. The temperature of the surrounding is \(40^{\circ} C\). The ratio of the rate of cooling for the body \(A\) and the body \(B\) at \(t=0\) sec will be:

Given: \(t =0\) sec, \(T _{ tA }=120^{\circ}\) C, \(T _{ tB }=80^{\circ}\) C and \(T _{ s }=40^{\circ}\) C

Where, \(T _{ tA }\) is Temperature of body A , \(T _{ tB }\) is the temperature of body B and \(T _{ s }\) is the temperature of the surroundings.

According to Newton's law of cooling, the rate of cooling of a body is given as,

\(R \propto\left(T_{ t }- T _{ s }\right) \quad \ldots\) (1)

For body A: \(\left(T_{t A}=120^{\circ} C \right)\)

\(R _{ A } \propto\left(T_{ tA }- T _{ s }\right)\quad \ldots\) (2)

For body B: \(\left(T_{t B}= 80^{\circ} C \right)\)

\(R _{ B } \propto\left(T_{ tB }- T _{ s }\right)\quad \ldots\) (3)

By equation (2) and equation (3),

\(\frac{R_{A}}{R_{B}}=\frac{\left(T_{t A}-T_{s}\right)}{\left(T_{t B}-T_{s}\right)}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{R_{A}}{R_{B}}=\frac{\left(T_{t A}-T_{s}\right)}{\left(T_{t B}-T_{s}\right)}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{R_{A}}{R_{B}}=\frac{(120-40)}{(80-40)}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{R_{A}}{R_{B}}=\frac{2}{1}=2:1\)
Two absolute scales A and B have triple points of water defined to be 200 A and 350 B. What is the relation between TA and TB ?

As we know, triple point of water on absolute scale = 273.16 K, Size of one degree of kelvin scale on absolute scale A \(=\frac{273.16}{200}\)

Value of temperature \(T_A\) on absolute scale \(A\)

\(=\frac{273.16}{200} T_A\)

Value of temperature \(T_B\) on absolute scale \(B\)

\(=\frac{273.16}{350} T_B\)

Since \(T_A\) and \(T_B\) represent the same temperature,

\(\therefore  \frac{273.16}{200} T_A  =\frac{273.16}{350} T_B\)

 or \(T_A  =\frac{200}{350} T_B=\frac{4}{7} T_B\)
When a rope is pulled on either side, what is the stress acting on it?
A tensile stress occurs when something is being pulled. A rope experiences tensile stress because it is flexible. In other words, a rope cannot be pushed.
What will happen to the elastic property of Gold when Potassium is added to gold?
The elastic property of gold remains unaltered
The addition of impurities causes variation in the elastic property of materials. Potassium when added to gold increases its elasticity thereby making it easy to be electroplated.
Which type of elasticity is involved in tangential push on the upper face of a block?

Rigidity modulus is defined as the ratio between tangential stress and shearing strain. When a tangential stress is applied to the upper face of a block, the cube gets deformed and there is relative displacement.
If the material has breaking point lies very close to elastic limit, the material is:
If the material has breaking point lies very close to elastic limit, the material is ductile.

Stress versus strain graph for a material is shown in figure. In graph a represents proportional limit, b represents elastic limit and d represents breaking point. If large deformation takes place between elastic limit and breaking point, then the material is called:
If large deformation takes place between elastic limit and breaking point then the material is brittle.
only proportional region of the stress-strain curve
entire elastic region of the stress-strain curve
elastic as well as plastic region of the stress-strain curve

The Hooke's law itself states that it is valid only proportional region of the stress-strain curve i.e. only to that limit where the material is behaving elasticallv.

Accordina to Hooke's law, within the elastic limit stress is proportional to strain, provided the strain is small.

Thus, Stress \(\propto\) Strain, \(\Rightarrow \frac{Stress }{Strain} =\) a constant (Young's modulus)
A load of \(2 \mathrm{~kg}\) produces an extension of \(1 \mathrm{~mm}\) in a wire of \(3 \mathrm{~m}\) in length and \(1 \mathrm{~mm}\) in diameter. The Young's modulus of wire will be:

Two wires are made of the same material and have the same volume. The first wire has cross-sectional area A and the second wire has cross-sectional area 3A. If length of the first wire is increased by Δl on applying a force F, then how much force is needed to stretch the second wire by the same amount?
9F

\(Y=\frac{F I}{A \Delta l}\)

\(F=\frac{Y A \Delta l}{l}=\frac{Y A^2 \Delta l}{V}\)

\((\because V=A l)\)

\(\therefore \frac{F_1}{F_2}=\left(\frac{A_1}{A_2}\right)^2=\left(\frac{A}{3 A}\right)^2\) 

\(\quad=\frac{1}{9}\) 

\(\Rightarrow F_2=9 F_1=9 F\)
A man grows into a giant such that his linear dimensions increase by a factor of 9. Assuming that his density remains same, the stress in the leg will change by a factor of:

Stress \(=\frac{\text { force }}{\text { Area }}\)

Let linear dimensions be \(\mathrm{l}, \mathrm{b}, \mathrm{h}\).

Stress \(=\frac{\text { Force }}{\mathrm{l} \times \mathrm{b}}\)

Now, dimensions increase by facror of g.

So, Now S' \(=\frac{\text { Force }}{9 \mathrm{l} \times 9 \mathrm{~b}}=\frac{\mathrm{ma}}{81 \mathrm{lb}}\)

\(S^{\prime}=\frac{\rho V a}{81 \times l b}\)

\(\therefore \frac{S^{\prime}}{S}=\frac{9^3 V}{81 \times l b} \times \frac{l b}{V}\)

\(S^{\prime}=9 S\)

Hence stress in leg will change by factor of 9.

One \(\mathrm{Kg}\) of a diatomic gas is at a pressure of \(8 \times 10^4 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^2\). The density of the gas is 4 \(\mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^3\). The energy of the gas due to its thermal motion will be:

For a diatomic molecular gas, internal energy per molecule is

\(\mathrm{U}=\frac{5}{2} \mathrm{NK}_{\mathrm{B}} \mathrm{T}\)...(1)

\(\mathrm{PV}=\mathrm{NK}_{\mathrm{B}} \mathrm{T}\)...(2)

From equation (1) and (2)

\(\mathrm{U}=\frac{5}{2} \mathrm{PV}\)

Here, \(\mathrm{P}=8 \times 10^4 \mathrm{~N} \mathrm{~m}^{-2}, \rho=4 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}, \mathrm{~m}=1 \mathrm{~kg}\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{U}=\frac{5}{2} \times 8 \times 10^4 \times \frac{1}{4}=5 \times 10^4 \mathrm{~J}\)
Why do beams in construction, such as those used in bridges and supports, often have a cross-sectional shape resembling an 'I'?

The 'I' shape in structural engineering efficiently distributes loads and minimizes bending due to its design. The horizontal top and bottom flanges resist bending forces effectively, providing a large load-bearing surface. This design is economical, versatile, and optimally utilizes materials, making it a common and effective choice for beams in construction.
What does lateral strain represent in the context of material deformation under stress?
Strain occurring parallel to the applied force.
Lateral strain is the deformation occurring perpendicular to the applied force, providing insights into material behavior under stress.
The Poisson's ratio for a certain material is zero. What is inferred from this statement?

Poisson's ratio zero means that there either transverse or longitudinal strain does not take place in the material. The material does not deform either in the lateral direction by the application of force or in the axial direction by the application of force.

This happens when the material does not deform i.e. the material is rigid.
The ratio of hydraulic stress to the corresponding strain is known as:

Bulk modulus is defined as the ratio of hydraulic stress to the corresponding strain.

When a bodv is submeraed in a fluid, it underaoes hvdraulic stress (equal in maanitude to the hvdraulic pressure). This leads to a decrease in the volume of the bodv thus producina a strain called volume strain.

The ratio of hvdraulic stress to the corresponding hydraulic strain is called bulk modulus.

\(K=-\frac{P}{\frac{\Delta V}{V}}\)
For an isotropic, homogeneous and elastic material obeying Hook's law, number of independent elastic constants is:

For an isotropic, homogeneous, and elastic material obeying Hook's law, the number of independent elastic constants is 2 .

It means to fully define the elastic behaviour of isotropic material only 2 elastic constants are good enough.
The proportionality limit is proportional to the area of cross-section. The material type and loading type will have no influence on the proportionality limit.
Where in the stress-strain curve, the hooke’s law is valid?
The hooke’s law itself states that it is valid only up to the elastic range of the material I.e. only to that limit where the material is behaving elastic.
For perfectly elastic body, the value of co-efficient of restitution is:
Collisions in which there is no loss of overall kinetic energy is known as a perfectly elastic collision. This type of collision has the maximum coefficient of restitution of e = 1.

A piece of copper having a rectangular cross-section of \(15.2 \mathrm{~mm} \times 19.1 \mathrm{~mm}\) is pulled in tension with \(44,500 \mathrm{~N}\) force, producing only elastic deformation. Calculate the resulting strain?
Three fluids 1, 2 and 3 have Bulk Moduli of \(k 1, k 2\) and \(k_3\) respectively. If \(k 1>k 2>\) \(\mathrm{k}_3\), which liquid will have the highest compressibility:

Bulk modulus is a measure of how difficult it is to compress a substance. A higher bulk modulus indicates that the substance is less compressible, while a lower bulk modulus indicates that the substance is more compressible.

Therefore, if \(k 1>k 2>k 3\), fluid 1 would be the least compressible (most difficult to compress), followed by fluid 2, and fluid 3 would be the most compressible (easiest to compress).
Which of the following statements explains why crystalline solids exhibit well-defined geometrical external shapes?

Crystalline solids have well-defined geometrical external shapes because of their ordered and repeating atomic structure, forming a three-dimensional lattice. This organized arrangement leads to distinct crystal faces and planes, resulting in the characteristic shapes observed in crystalline materials.
Which of the following statements best defines a perfectly plastic body?
A material that returns to its original shape after deformation.
A material that undergoes permanent deformation without any increase in stress.
A material that exhibits both elastic and plastic behavior.
A material that has high ductility and low hardness.

Plasticity (also known as plastic deformation) is the ability of a solid material to undergo permanent deformation, a non-reversible change of shape in response to applied forces.

If, on removal of deforming force, a body does not regain its original configuration even a little, then it is said to be perfectly plastic. Putty or mud is an example of a perfectly plastic body.
In the three states of matter, the elastic coefficient can be:

The elastic characteristic that is found in all the three states of matter (solid, liquid and gas) is Bulk Modulus.

Bulk Modulus refers to the tendency or volumetric elasticity of an object to get deformed in all directions when it is uniformly loaded in all the directions. In other words, it represents how much a substance is resistant to compression.
For a constant hydraulic stress on an object, the fractional change in the object's volume \(\left(\frac{\Delta V}{V}\right)\) and its bulk modulus are related as:

\(B=\frac{\text { stress }}{\text { volume strain }}=\frac{\text { stress }}{\frac{\Delta V}{V}}\)

\(\frac{\Delta V}{V}=\frac{\text { stress }}{B}\)

As stress is constant

\(\frac{\Delta \mathrm{V}}{\mathrm{V}} \propto \frac{1}{\mathrm{~B}}\)
A wire is loaded by 6 kg at its one end, the increase in length is 12 mm. If the radius of the wire is doubled and all other magnitudes are unchanged, then increase in length will be:
\(l \propto \frac{1}{r^2}\), If radius of the wire is doubled then increment in length will become \(\frac{1}{4}\) times of 12 =\( \frac{12}{4}\) = 3 mm
A rope of 1cm in diameter breaks if tension in it exceeds 500N. The maximum tension that may be given to a similar rope of diameter 2cm is:

Young's modulus of the rope, \(\mathrm{Y}=\frac{\text { Stress }}{\text { Strain }}=\frac{\frac{\mathrm{T} }{ \mathrm{A}}}{\frac{\Delta {l}} { {l}}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{T}=\mathrm{Y} \times \frac{\Delta {l}}{{l}} \times \frac{\pi \mathrm{d}^2}{4}\)

where, \(\mathrm{d}\) is the diameter of the rope and \(\mathrm{T}\) is the tension

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{T} \propto \mathrm{d}^2\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\mathrm{T}_2}{\mathrm{~T}_1}=\frac{\mathrm{d}_2^2}{\mathrm{~d}_1^2}\)

Given : \(\mathrm{T}_1=500 \mathrm{~N}\)

\( \mathrm{d}_1=1 \mathrm{~cm}\)

\(\mathrm{~d}_2=2 \mathrm{~cm} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\mathrm{T}_2}{500}=\frac{2^2}{1^2}\)

\( \Rightarrow \mathrm{T}_2=2000 \mathrm{~N}\)

Two blocks of masses \(1 \mathrm{~kg}\) and \(2 \mathrm{~kg}\) are connected by a metal wire going over a smooth pulley. The breaking stress of metal is \(\frac{40}{3 \pi} \times 10^6 \mathrm{Nm}^{-2}\). What should be the minimum radius of wire used if it should not break? \(\left(\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\right)\)
0.5 mm
1.5 mm
2 mm
1 mm

\(\mathrm{T}=\frac{2 \mathrm{~m}_1 \mathrm{~m}_2}{\mathrm{~m}_1+\mathrm{m}_2} \mathrm{~g}\)

\(=\frac{2 \times 1 \times 2}{1+2} \times 10 \mathrm{~N}\)

\(=\frac{40}{3} \mathrm{~N}\)

If \(\mathrm{r}\) is the minimum radius, then breaking stress \(=\frac{\frac{40}{3}}{\pi \mathrm{r}^2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{40}{3 \pi r^2}=\frac{40}{3 \pi} \times 10^6\)

\(\Rightarrow r^2=\frac{1}{10^6} \text { or } \quad r=\frac{1}{10^3} \mathrm{~m}\)

\(\Rightarrow r=\frac{1}{10^3} \times 10^3 \mathrm{~mm}=1 \mathrm{~mm}\)

Three wires A, B, C made of different materials elongated by \(1.5,2.5,3.5 \mathrm{~mm}\), under a load of \(5 \mathrm{~kg}\). If the diameters of the wires are the same, the most elastic material is that of:

Elasticity =\( \frac{(\text{force} \times \text{ length of wire})}{(\text{area} \times \text{elongation of wire})}\)

Here, force is same for all the three wires as load is same for all.

So, the measurement of elasticity is inversly proportional to elongation of wire and wire A has least elongation soits elasticity is maximum.
The length of a wire under stress changes by \(0.01 \%\). The strain produced is:
If a member, whose tensile strength is more than 1.5 times the shear strength and is subjected to an axial load upto failure, the failure of the member will occur by:

We know that maximum shear stress induced in a member which is subjected to an axial load is equal to half of maximum normal stress. Thus for a material with tensile strength more than 1.5 times the shear strength the failure occurs due to shearing.
Doppler shift in frequency does not depend on the:
Distance between the source and the observer

Doppler effect:  If the source or the observer or both move with respect to the medium, then the frequency observed may be different from the frequency of the source.

  • This apparent change in frequency of the wave due to the motion of the source or the observer is called the Doppler Effect.
  • The apparent frequency of the sound experienced by the observer, when the observer is stationary and the source is moving is \(\nu^{\prime}=\frac{v}{v \pm u} \nu^o\).
A sounding horn is rotating rapidly in a horizontal circle, the apparent frequency of the horn observed at the centre of the circle:
Since the horn is rotating in the circle, hence the distance between it and the centre will be the same. Therefore, the apparent frequency will remain same.

Echocardiogram is more closely related to:

A. Doppler effect

B. Zeeman effect

C. Photoelectric effect

D. Magnetic effect

To examine the heart, Doppler echocardiography is used to produce the Doppler ultrasonography.

  • Doppler Echocardiography is a method by which one can identify the direction and velocity of blood flow.
  • Doppler can be used for various purposes in echocardiography.
  • The principles of Doppler as we use it in echocardiography were discovered by Christian Doppler.
An observer is moving towards the stationary source of a sound, then:
Apparent frequency will be less than the real frequency
Apparent frequency will be greater than the real frequency
Apparent frequency will be equal to real frequency
Only the quality of sound will change

When an observer is moving towards the stationary source of sound, then the apparent frequency will be greater than the real frequency. Then the apparent frequency heard in this situation

\( u^{\prime}=\left[ rac{\left(v-v_m ight)-v_o}{\left(v+v_m ight)-v_s} ight] u^o\)

As the source is stationary and medium is constant, then \(v _{ m }=0\) and \(v _{ s }=0\)

\( u^{\prime}=\left[ rac{v-\left(-v_o ight)}{v} ight] u^o=\left[ rac{v+v_o}{v} ight] u^o\)
Choose the correct phenomenon in which the frequency heard by the observer will be maximum.
A source is moving towards a stationary observer.
An observer is moving towards a stationary source.
An observer is moving away from a stationary source.
Both the source and observer move towards each other.

Apparent frequency \(\left(f^{\prime}\right)=f\left(\frac{V \pm V_o}{V \pm V_s}\right)\)

  • The apparent frequency will be maximum when the denominator is minimum and numerator of the above formula is maximum.
  • The numerator of the formula will be maximum when sign between V and VS is positive, means both sound and the observer moves in opposite direction.
  • The denominator will be minimum when the sign between V and VO is negative, means both the sound and source move in same direction.

Apparent frequency \(\left(f^{\prime}\right)=f\left(\frac{V+V_O}{V-V_s}\right)\)

Above these two conditions are only valid when both the source and observer moves towards each other. In this case the, the sound and observer will move in opposite direction and the sound and source move in same direction.
A whistling engine is approaching a stationary observer, then the apparent frequency will be:

Given \(v_0=0 m / sec\)

A whistling engine is approaching a stationary observer, so the engine is a source.

By the Doppler effect formula, the apparent frequency is given as,

\(\Rightarrow f^{\prime}=\frac{\left(v+v_o\right)}{\left(v-v_s\right)} \times f\)

\(v _0\) is taken as positive when it moves towards the source and negative when it moves away from the source.

\(v _{ s }\) is taken as negative when it moves towards the observer and positive when it moves away from the observer.

Therefore when a whistling engine is approaching a stationary observer, the apparent frequency is given as,

\(\Rightarrow f^{\prime}=\frac{(v+0)}{\left(v-v_s\right)} \times f \)

\(\Rightarrow f^{\prime}=\frac{v}{\left(v-v_s\right)} \times f \)

\(\because v >\left( v - v _{ s }\right) \)

\(\therefore f ^{\prime}> f\)

A sound source producing waves of frequency 300 Hz and wavelength 1 m. The observer is stationary, while source is going away with the velocity 30 m / s, then apparent frequency heard by the observer is:

Given \(v_0=0 m / s , v_{ s }=-30 m / s f =300 Hz\) and \(\lambda=1 m\)

\(v _{ S }\) is negative, because source is moving away from the observer.

We know that velocity of sound

\(\Rightarrow v = f \lambda \)

\(\Rightarrow v =300 \times 1=300 m / s\)

\(\Rightarrow f^{\prime}=\frac{\left(v+v_o\right)}{\left(v-v_s\right)} \times f \)

\(\Rightarrow f^{\prime}=\frac{(300+0)}{(300-(-30))} \times 300 \)

\(\Rightarrow f^{\prime}=\frac{300}{330} \times 300 \)

\(\Rightarrow f^{\prime}=273 H z\)
An observer is moving towards a stationary source of frequency 250 Hz with a velocity of 40 m/s. If the velocity of sound is 330 m/s, the apparent frequency heard by the observer will be:

Given \(f =250 Hz , v _0=40 m / s , v _{ s }=0 m / s\) and \(v =330 m / s\)

When the source and the observer moving towards each other the apparent frequency is given as,

\(\Rightarrow f^{\prime}=\frac{\left(v+v_o\right)}{\left(v-v_s\right)} \times f \)

\(\Rightarrow f^{\prime}=\frac{(330+40)}{(330-0)} \times 250 \)

\(\Rightarrow f^{\prime}=280 Hz\)
The loundness and pitch of a sound note depends on _____.

When the amplitude of the sound is large, then the sound wave is considered to be louder. As the intensity is proportional to the square of the amplitude so the loudness of the sound also depends on the intensity of the sound. The pitch of sound waves depends on the frequency of the waves.
Musical instruments having same loudness and pitch can be distinguished by:

Sound "quality" or "timbre" describes those characteristics of sound which allow the ear to distinguish sounds that have the same pitch and loudness. Timbre is then a general term for the distinguishable characteristics of a tone. Timbre is determined by the harmonic content and the dynamic characteristics of the sound such as vibrato and the attack-decay envelope of the sound wave.
Shrillness of sound is determined by ________ of sound.

Pitch or Shrillness: The frequency of a sound wave is the parameter that the ear understands as pitch.

  • A higher frequency sound has a higher pitch, and a lower frequency sound has a lower pitch.
  • So, the correct option is Frequency.
Doppler shift in frequency does not depend upon:
Distance from the source to the listener
Doppler shift in frequency does not depend upon Distance from the source to the listener.
Which of the following statements is consistent with the Doppler effect?
As the source of sound moves towards the listener the pitch of the sound appears to be higher.
As the source of sound moves towards the listener the pitch of the sound appears to be lower.
As the source of sound moves away from the listener the pitch of the sound appears to be higher.
As the listener moves towards the source of sound the pitch of the sound appears to be lower.

Doppler effect:

If the source or the observer or both move with respect to the medium, then the frequency observed may be different from the frequency of the source.

This apparent change in frequency of the wave due to the motion of the source or the observer is called the Doppler Effect.

The apparent frequency of the sound experienced by the observer, when the observer is stationary and the source is moving is

\(f^{\prime}=\left(\frac{v}{v \pm v_S}\right) f\)

The apparent frequency of the sound experienced by the observer, when the source is stationary and the observer is moving is

\(f^{\prime}=\left(\frac{v \pm v_O}{v}\right) f\)

Where,

v= speed of sound in the medium,

f'= apparent frequency,

f= natural frequency

\(v_S\) & \(v_O\)= speed of the source & observer respectively

From the above explanation, we can see that, when a source is moving and the observer is stationary the sound appears to be of higher frequency and this is because of the Doppler effect.
As per Doppler Effect, which equation tells the relation between velocity of listener, source, true and apparent frequencies of sound if the source and observer both are in motion towards each other?

Let \(V_0\) represents the velocity of listener and \(V_s\) represents the velocity of source and \(V\) be the velocity of sound and \(n\) and \(n_1\) be the true and apparent frequencies of sound, then

\(n_1=n\left(\frac{V+V_0}{V-V_s}\right)\) tells the relation, when the source and the observer both are in motion towards each other

\(n_1=n\left(\frac{V-V_0}{V+V_s}\right)\) tells the relation, when the source and the observer both are in motion away from each other

\(n_1=n\left(\frac{V-V_0}{V-V_s}\right)\) tells the relation, when the source and observer both are in motion source following the observer

\(n_1=n\left(\frac{V+V_0}{V+V_s}\right)\) tells the relation, when the source and observer are in motion observer following the source.

A train is approaching towards a platform with a speed of \(10 ms ^{-1}\) while blo whistle of frequency \(340 Hz\). What is the frequency of whistles heard by a observer on the platform? Given the speed of sound \(=340 ms ^{-1}\).

Given that \(v_s=10 m / s ; f_0=340 Hz ; v=340 m / s\);

\(f=f_0\left(\frac{v}{v-v_s}\right)=340\left(\frac{340}{340-10}\right) \approx 350 \)

f =350 Hz
A source of sound of frequency 450 cycles/sec is stationary but an observer is moving toward a source with 34 m/sec speed. If the speed of sound is 340 m/sec, then the apparent frequency will be:

Given \(n_0=450\) cycles \(/ sec , v=340 m / sec\) and \(v_0=34 m / sec\)

Formula to calculate the apparent frequency when the observer is moving towards the source is

\(n^{\prime}=\left[\frac{v+v_o}{v}\right] n^o \)

\(\Rightarrow n^{\prime}=\left[\frac{340+34}{340}\right] 450=495 cycles / sec\)
Superposition of two waves of nearly equal frequency
