When two sound waves of nearly same frequencies, travelling in a medium along the same direction, superimpose on each other, the intensity of the resultant sound at a particular position rises and falls regularly with time. This phenomenon of regular variation in the intensity of sound with time at a particular position is called beats.

Beat frequency: The number of beats produced per second is called a beat frequency.

From above it is clear that, the phenomenon of wavering of sound intensity when two waves of nearly the same frequencies and amplitudes travelling in the same direction, are superimposed on each other is called beats.
The sum of two frequencies of two sound source sounding together
The difference of two frequencies of two sound source sounding together
The multiplication of two frequencies of two sound source sounding together
The fraction of two frequencies of two sound source sounding together

We consider two sine waves of equal amplitudes and directions. The different frequencies and wavelengths of the waves are considered here while the wave speeds are the same.

  • Beat frequency: The difference in frequency of two sound sources sounding together is called beat frequency. So option 2 is correct.
  • The beat frequency is produced when two waves of different frequencies superimpose when they travel in the same path with the same wave speed.

Let a source have frequency f1 and the other source has frequency f2 then the beat frequency is given by:

Beat frequency (f) = |f1 – f2|
To hear the beats from two different sounds, which of the following conditions should be followed?
The two sounds must have their frequencies in audible range i.e. 20 Hz to 20KHz
The difference between two sound waves should not be more than 10Hz
Amplitudes of the two sound waves should be equal.
All of the above conditions are necessary

Conditions for hearing beats:

  • The two superimposed sound waves producing beats must have a frequency in the audible range i.e. 20 Hz to 20KHz
  • The two waves should have a very small difference in their frequencies. This difference should not be more than 10 Hz.
  • The amplitude of the Waves should preferably be equal so that the maximum and minimum intensity of sound produced in the beats can be heard distinctly and clearly.

All the conditions are necessary.
Two sound waves of slightly different frequencies propagating in the same direction produce beats due to:

Beats: When two sound waves of slightly different frequencies interfere, a repeating sound is heard known as beats.


  • The above diagram shows the interference of two sound waves of slightly different frequencies and resulting beat from zero to high amplitude. In the diagram, C.I. means points of constructive interference and D.I. destructive interference.
  • A loud voice is heard or a peak in the beat pattern in the diagram, when constructive interference occurs.
  • When destructive interference occurs, no sound is heard as in the diagram no displacement on the beat pattern.
The frequency of the beats heard when two sounds of close frequencies 'f1' and 'f2' superimpose is ____________.

Let a source have frequency \(f_1\) and the other source has frequency \(f_2\) then the beat frequency is given by:

Beat frequency \((f)=\left|f_1-f_2\right|\)

The frequency of the beats heard when two sounds of close frequencies ' \(f_1\) ' and ' \(f_2\) ' superimpose is \(f_2-f_1\).
What would be the frequency (in Hz) of the beats when two sounds of frequencies 256 Hz and 260 Hz superimpose?

Given that,

Frequency of sound wave \(1, f_1=256 Hz\)

Frequency of sound wave 2, \(f _2=260 Hz\)

Thus the frequency of beats is

\(f=\left|f_1-f_2\right|=|260-256|=4 H z\)
Two waves of length 50 cm and 51 cm produced 12 beats per second. The velocity of the sound is:

Given:

\(N =12\) beats per second, \(\lambda_1=51 cm , \lambda_2=50 cm\)

Number of beats per second \((N)\) is:

\(N=\frac{V}{\lambda_1}-\frac{V}{\lambda_2} \)

\(12=V\left(\frac{1}{50}-\frac{1}{51}\right) \)

\(12=V\left(\frac{1}{50 \times 51}\right) \)

\(V=12 \times 50 \times 51=30600 cm / s =306 m / s\)

Two tuning forks, A and B, produce notes of frequencies 258 Hz and 262 Hz. An unknown note sounded with A produces certain beats. When the same note is sounded with B, the beat frequency gets doubled. The unknown frequency is ______.

Given that \(f_A=258 Hz\) and \(f_B=262 Hz\) and the frequency of the unknown fork is \(f\) Let it produces \(b\) beats with \(A\) and \(2 b\) with \(B\). So

\(f_A-f=b \)...(i)

\(f_B-f=2 b\)...(ii)

so from above equations

\(f_B-f_A=b \)

\(b=262-258=4 H z\)

from equation (i)

\(f=f_A-b \)

\(f=258-4\)

unknown frequency \(f=254 Hz\)
Two tuning forks have frequencies 450 Hz and 454 Hz respectively. On sounding these forks together, the time interval between successive maximum intensities will be:

Given \(- f _1=450 Hz\) and \(f _2=454 Hz\)

The time interval between successive maximum intensities will be

\(\Rightarrow T=\frac{1}{\text { Beat frequency }} \)

\(\Rightarrow T=\frac{1}{f_2-f_1}=\frac{1}{454-450}=\frac{1}{4} sec\)
An organ pipe open at both ends contains:
An organ pipe open at both ends contains longitudinal stationary waves.
Which of the following is correct regarding a standing wave in a closed organ pipe?
At the open end it has node and at the closed end it has antinode.
At the open end it has antinode and at the closed end it has node.
At the both the ends it has antinode.
At the both the ends it has node.

Closed-end: Nodes are the points that have no displacement.

  • The air molecules are not free to vibrate here at the closed end, so no displacement. Therefore nodes are formed here.

Open-end: Antinodes are the points that have a maximum displacement

  • The air molecules are free to vibrate here with maximum displacement due to no restriction. 
  • So maximum displacement. Therefore antinodes are formed here.
For a stationary wave, if frequency is equal to ____________ then it is called fundamental mode. ('v' is the speed of travelling waves on the string of length 'L')

The frequency (f) in fundamental mode is given by:

\(f=\frac{v}{2 L}\)

where \(v\) is the speed of sound, \(L\) is the length string.
Four wires of identical lengths, diameters and materials are stretched on a sonometer box. The ratio of their tension is 1 : 4 : 9 : 16. The ratio of their fundamental frequencies is:

Given, Tension in ratio \(=1: 4: 9: 16\)

We know that,

\(v_0= rac{1}{2 L} \sqrt{ rac{T}{\mu}} \)

\(\Rightarrow v_0 \propto \sqrt{T} \)

\(\Rightarrow u_1: u_2: u_3: u_4 \Rightarrow \sqrt{T_1}: \sqrt{T_2}: \sqrt{T_3}: \sqrt{T_4} \Rightarrow 1: 2: 3: 4\)

When a string is divided into three segments of length \(l _1, l_2\) and \(l _3\), the fundamental frequencies of these three segments are \(v_1, v_2\) and \(v_3\) respectively. The original fundamental frequency \((v)\) of the string is:

The fundamental frequency of a string \(( v )\) is given by

\(\Rightarrow v=\frac{n}{2 l} \sqrt{\frac{T}{m}}\)

As \(T\) and \(m\) is constant

\(\therefore v \propto \frac{1}{l} \)

\(\Rightarrow v _1 l _1= v _2 l _2= v _3 l _3= k \) [Where k = constant]

\(\Rightarrow l_1=\frac{k}{v_1}, l_2=\frac{k}{v_2}, l_3=\frac{k}{v_3}\)

The original length of the string is

\(\Rightarrow l=\frac{k}{v}\)

The total length of the string is

\(\Rightarrow l=l_1+l_2+l_3\)

Substitute the value of \(l, l_1, l_2\), and \(l_3\) in the above equation, we get

\(\Rightarrow \frac{k}{l}=\frac{k}{v_1}+\frac{k}{v_2}+\frac{k}{v_3} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{v}=\frac{1}{v_1}+\frac{1}{v_2}+\frac{1}{v_3}\)
Which of the following statement is/are true for an ideal gas?
There is no attractive force between the molecules

An ideal gas is a hypothetical concept where it is assumed that there are no intermolecular forces of attraction between the molecules of the gas and that the volume occupied by these molecules is negligible.

All ideal gases obey the ideal gas equation given by:

\({PV}=\mathrm{nRT}\)

Where \({P}=\) pressure of the gas, \({V}=\) volume of the gas, \({n}=\) number of moles, \({T}=\) temperature and \({R}=\) universal gas constant.

Since the ideal gas molecules occupy negligible space, it can be concluded that they do not occupy space. Ideal gases do not have intermolecular forces, so they do not have attractive forces between the molecules. In gases, the particles move randomly in all directions, frequently colliding with each other and the side of the container they are kept in.
What is the value of specific heat capacity for an isothermal process?

We know that,

Specific heat \(S=\frac{\Delta Q}{\Delta T}\)

An isothermal process is a process in which the temperature does not change or \(\Delta \mathrm{T}=0\)

\(S=\frac{\Delta Q}{\Delta T}=\frac{\Delta Q}{0}=\infty\)

The Specific heat for the isothermal process is \(\infty\).
Which of the following equation represents Charle's Law of gas?

According to Charle's Law, at constant pressure, for a given mass of gas its absolute temperature is directly proportional to the Volume of the given mass of gas.

\( T \propto V \)

\(\frac{V}{T}=\) Constant
Which of the following formula is correct for Universal Gas Constant?

We know that, 

Ideal gas equation is given by

\(P V=n R T\)

Where \({P}=\) pressure, \({V}=\) volume, \({T}=\) temperature, \({n}=\) is the number of mole and \({R}=\) =universal gas constant

For an ideal gas equation, The universal gas constant can be written as

\(R=\frac{P V}{n T}\)
According the kinetic theory of gases, which of the following relation between pressure (P) and volume (V) is correct? ( \({M}\) is mass and \({v}\) is velocity of the gas particles)

According to Pascal's law, a gas transmits pressure equally in all directions and the pressure exerted by the gas is given by-

\(P=\frac{1}{3} \rho v^2\)

We know that density \(=\) Mass/Volume

\(\rho=\frac{M}{V} \)

\(P=\frac{1}{3} M V^2 v^2\)

\(P V=\frac{1}{3} M v^2\) is the correct relation according to the kinetic theory of gases.
Kinetic theory of gases was developed by:

Kinetic theory of gases states that all gaseous molecules remain under random and continuous motion and the velocity of the particles depends on the temperature. Using this theory various properties like pressure, temperature, the energy of the molecules can be explained. This theory is called the Kinetic Theory of gases which were developed by Clausius and Maxwell, and Ludwig Eduard Boltzmann. They explained the distribution of molecular velocities and various properties like pressure, temperature, the energy of the molecules.
What is the volume occupied by \(132 {~g}\) of \({CO}_2\) at \(27^{\circ} {C}\) when a pressure of \(5 {~atm}\) is applied? (Molar mass of \({CO}_2=44 {~g} / {mol}\) )

Given that:

Pressure, \({P}=5 {~atm}\)

Temperature, \({T}=27^{\circ} {C}=(273+27)=300 {~K}\)

\({R}=0.082 {~L} {~atm} {~K}^{-1} {~mol}^{-1}\)

The molar mass of \({CO}_2=44 {~g} / {mol}\)

Number of moles in \(132 {~g}\) of \({CO}_2, {n}=\frac{132}{44}=3 {~mol}\)

Using the ideal gas law,

\({PV}={nR} T\)

\(5 \times {V}=3 \times 0.082 \times 300\)

\(\Rightarrow V=14.76 \) litre
Which of the following parameter does not belong to the ideal gas law?

The ideal gas equation is given by:

\({PV}={nRT} \)

This equation establishes a relationship between pressure, volume, amount of gas, and temperature. So, time is not involved in ideal gas law.
On increasing the temperature of solids, the kinetic energy of the particles:

The energy possessed by a body due to its motion is called Kinetic energy.

The energy of a molecule in the solid is due to its randomness. If there is a change in the temperature of the solid, the randomness of the molecules will change. Once we increase the temperature, the randomness will increase, and hence the kinetic energy of the molecules increases.
In the relation from Kinetic theory of gases, "\(PV = (\frac{1}{3}) {nMv}^{2 "}\), if ' \(n\) ' is number of moles of the gas then '\(M\)' stands for:

According to kinetic theory, the molecules of a gas are in a state of continuous random motion. They collide with one another and also with the walls of the vessel. Whenever a molecule collides with the wall, it returns with a changed momentum, and an equal momentum is transferred to the wall (conservation of momentum).

According to the kinetic theory of gases:

\(P V=(\frac{1}{3}) n M v^2\)

Where \(P\) is pressure \(n\) is number of moles, \(M\) is the molecular mass of the particles and \(v\) is the speed of the particles.
Which of the following best represents the relationship between internal energy '\(U\)' of an ideal gas and its absolute temperature '\(T\)'?

There are no attractive forces between the gas molecules of an ideal gas. Hence, the internal energy of the gas will only be kinetic energy i.e. \(U=K E\).

The kinetic energy of an ideal gas is dependent on its temperature as:

\( K E=\frac{3}{2} k_B T \)

\({KE} \propto {T} \)

\({U} \propto {T}\)

Therefore, the plot of internal energy vs time will be a straight line through the origin.
Ratio of \(rms\) velocities of \({O}_2\) and \({H}_2\) at equal temperature will be:

The effective velocity of gas particles in a gaseous sample is called Root-meansquare speed (RMS speed). RMS velocity is given by:

\(V_{r m s}=\sqrt{\frac{3 R T}{M}}\)

Where \({R}=\) Universal gas constant, \({T}=\) temperature, and \({M}=\) Molar mass of the gas .

\({M}_{{O}_2}=32\) and \({M}_{{H}_2}=2\)

RMS velocity of \({O}_2\) gas is given by:

\( V_{O_2}=\sqrt{\frac{3 R T}{M_{O_2}}}=\sqrt{\frac{3 R T}{32}}\cdots(1)\)

RMS velocity of \({H}_2\) gas is given by:

\( V_{H_2}=\sqrt{\frac{3 R T}{M_{H_2}}}=\sqrt{\frac{3 R T}{2}}\cdots(2)\)

On dividing equation (1) and (2) , we get

\( \frac{V_{O_2}}{V_{H_2}}=\frac{\sqrt{\frac{3 R T}{32}}}{\sqrt{\frac{3 R T}{2}}}=\sqrt{\frac{2}{32}}=\frac{1}{4}=1:4\)
The relationship between translational kinetic energy of the molecules in a gas '\(E\)' an its temperature '\(T\)' is:

The energy necessary to accelerate a rigid body from rest to a certain velocity is known as the object's translational kinetic energy. Motion from one point to another that follows a straight line is referred to as translational motion. The translational kinetic energy of the molecules is given by:

\(E=\frac{3 N K_B T}{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow 2 {E}=3 {~K}_{{B}} {N} {T}\)

Where \({K}\) is Boltzmann constant, \({T}\) is temperature and \({N}\) is the number of molecules.
The rms speed of gas at \(27^{\circ} {C}\) is \({V}\). If the temperature of the gas is raised to \(327^{\circ} {C}\), then the rms speed of a gas is:

The rms speed of any homogeneous gas sample is given by:

\(V_{r m s}=\sqrt{\frac{3 R T}{M}}\)

Where \({R}=\) universal gas constant, \({T}=\) temperature and \({M}=\) Molecular mass

Initial rms velocity \(\left(V_{{rms_1 }}\right)=V\), initial temperature \(\left(T_1\right)=27^{\circ} {C}=300{~K}\) and final temperature \(\left(T_2\right)=327^{\circ} {C}=600 {~K}\)

As the sample is the same, therefore the molecular mass will be the same. So,

\(\Rightarrow V_{{rms}} \propto \sqrt{T} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{V_{r m s_1}}{V_{r m s_2}}=\sqrt{\frac{T_1}{T_2}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{V}{V_{r m s_2}}=\sqrt{\frac{300}{600}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\)

\(\Rightarrow {V}_{{rms_2}}={V} \sqrt{2}\)

If the ideal gas inside a cylindrical tank is kept at \(54^{\circ} {C}\). If the pressure remains constant but its volume decreases from \(10 {~m}^3\) to \(6 {~m}^3\). What is the ratio of the initial and final temperature?

Given, 

\(V_1=10 {~m}^3, V_2=6 {~m}^3 \)

Pressure is constant so we can apply Charles's law

\(\Rightarrow \frac{V_1}{V_2}=\frac{T_1}{T_2} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{10}{T_1}=\frac{6}{T_2} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{T_1}{T_2}={5}: {3}\)
At constant volume, for a fixed amount of a gas the pressure of the gas increases with rise of temperature due to:

The average kinetic energy of translation per molecules of the gas is related to temperature by the relationship:

\( K E=\frac{3}{2} k_B T\cdots(1)\)

So, the average kinetic energy of the gas molecule is directly proportional to the absolute temperature of the gas. So, if the temperature is increasing, the average velocity of the gas also increases.

According to the kinetic theory of gases, the relation between the pressure and the average velocity of the gas is given as,

\( P=\frac{N m v^2}{3 V}\cdots(2)\)

Where \({N}=\) number of molecules, \({m}=\) mass of the gas molecule, \({v}^2=\) average velocity of the gas, and \(V=\) volume

\({P} \propto {v}^2\cdots(3)\)

So when the temperature of the gas is increased its average velocity increases and by equation 3 it is clear that if the average velocity of the gas increases at constant volume, its pressure also increases.
When a truck carrying LPG cylinders moves with a uniform velocity on the road, the temperature of the gas molecules inside the cylinder:

When the truck moves with uniform velocity, the centre of mass of the gas molecules also moves with uniform velocity. As a result, there will be no change in the relative motion of gas particles and trucks. So, the velocity of gas particles does not change i.e. kinetic energy does not change. The temperature of gas molecules is a measure of their kinetic energy. As kinetic energy does not change, the temperature will also not change.
At a given temperature RMS velocity of a gas molecules is '\({v}\) \({m} / {s}\). Find \(rms\) velocity of the gas, if the temperature of the gas becomes \(4\) times of the initial value.

Root-Mean Square(rms) velocity is calculated by:

\(v=\sqrt{\frac{3 R T}{M}}\)

where \({T}\) is the temperature of the gas, \({M}\) is the mass of the gas, and \({R}\) is the universal gas constant.

Given that \({v}=500 {~m}/{s}\); Later the temperature is \(4\) times.

\({T}^{\prime}=4 {~T}\)

initially \(v=\sqrt{\frac{3 R T}{M}}\cdots(1)\)

Later \(v^{\prime}=\sqrt{\frac{3 R T^{\prime}}{M^{\prime}}}\)

\(v^{\prime}=\sqrt{\frac{3 R(4 T)}{M}}\)

\(v^{\prime}=2 \times \sqrt{\frac{3 R T}{M}}\)

From eq.(1)

\(v^{\prime}=2 \times v=2 v\)
At what temperature, the \(rms\) velocity of gas molecules would be double of its value at NTP, if pressure is remaining constant?

Let \(v_1\) be the \(rms\) velocity at S.T.P and \(v_2\) be the r.m.s. velocity at unknown temperature \(T_2\).

\(\because {V} \propto \sqrt{{T}} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{{v}_1^2}{{v}_2^2}=\frac{{T}_1}{{~T}_2} \)

\(\Rightarrow {T}_2=\left({T}_1\right)\times \left(\frac{{V}_2}{{~V}_1}\right)^2 \)

\(\Rightarrow {T}_2=(273)\times (2)^2 \)

\(\Rightarrow {T}_2=1092 {~K} \)

\(\therefore {T}_2=(1092-273)=819^{\circ} {C}\)
At room temperature \(\left(27^{\circ} {C}\right)\) the rms speed of molecules of a certain diatomic gas is found to be \(1930 {~m} / {sec}\). The gas is:

From the expansion of pressure,

\( P=\frac{1}{3} \rho {v}_{r m s}^2 \)

\(\Rightarrow v_{r m s}=\sqrt{\frac{3 P}{\rho}} \)

\(v_{r m s}=\sqrt{\frac{3 P V}{\text { Mass of gas }}}=\sqrt{\frac{3 R T}{M}}\)\(\quad{\left[\because \rho=\frac{M}{V}\right]}\)

Where, \{R}=\) universal gas constant, \({M}=\) molar mass, \({P}=\) pressure due to density,\(\rho=\) density.

Given:

\({T}=27^{\circ} {C}=27+273=300 {~K}, {~V}_{{rms}}=1930 {~m} /{sec}\)

\(v_{r m s}=\sqrt{\frac{3 P V}{\text { Mass of gas }}}=\sqrt{\frac{3 R T}{M}}\)

\(1930=\sqrt{\frac{3 \times 8.31 \times 10^3 \times 300}{M}}\)

\(\text { Mass }=2 {~g}\), So the gas is \({H}_2\)

Two circular elastic balloons are filled with air, one of the balloons is kept in a water tub filled with water at \(0^{\circ} {C}\) and the other in water at room temperature. What is the relationship between the diameters of those balloons?

Baloon- 1 kept in water at \(0^{\circ} {C}\).

Baloon-2 kept in water at room temperature \(\left(25^{\circ} {C}\right)\).

Since the temperature around Baloon-2 is more than of balloon- 1

\(\therefore\) Baloon-2 expands

\(\Rightarrow\) Diameter of Baloon-2 \(>\) Baloon-1
The molar specific heat at constant pressure for diatomic gas is:

Specific heat at constant volume \(\left(C_{{V}}\right)\) and Constant pressure \(\left(C_{{P}}\right)\) for monoatomic (Ex- He), diatomic (Ex-(H2), polyatomic (Ex-H2O)

For diatomic gas is, \(C_{{V}}=\frac{5}{2}R\) and  \(C_P=\frac{5}{2}R+R=\frac{7R}{2}\)
Which type of ideal gas will have the largest value for \(C_p-C_v\)?
The value will be the same for all.

As we know that the specific heat at constant volume \(\left(C_v\right)\) and constant pressure \(\left(C_p\right)\)for

For monoatomic gas is, \(C_v=\frac{3}{2} R\) and \(C_p=\frac{3}{2} R+R=\frac{5}{2} R\)

For diatomic gas is, \(C_v=\frac{5}{2} R\) and \(C_p=\frac{5}{2} R+R=\frac{7}{2} R\)

For polyatomic gas is, \(C_v=3 R\) and \(C_p=3 R+R=4R\)

But we know that, for an ideal gas,

\( C_{{p}}-C_{{v}}=R\)

\(\therefore C_{{p}}-C_{{v}}\) for monoatomic gas will be \(C_{{p}}-C_{{v}}=\frac{5}{2} R-\frac{3}{2} R=R\)

\(\therefore C_{{p}}-C_{{v}}\) for diatomic gas will be \(C_{{p}}-C_{{v}}=\frac{7}{2} R-\frac{5}{2} R=R\)

\(\therefore C_{{p}}-C_{{v}}\) for monoatomic gas will be \(C_{{p}}-C_{{v}}=4 R-{3} R=R\)

So, \(C_p-C_v\) will be same for all ideal gas.
For a polyatomic gas which has '\({f}\)' vibrational modes, what is '\({C}_{{v}}\)' equal to? '\({C}_{{v}}\)' is molar specific heat at constant volume)

A polyatomic gas molecule has, in general, three translation degree of freedom, three rotational degrees of freedom and certain number \(f\) of vibrational mode, therefore the total energy of one mole of such gas is:

\({U}=(3+{f}) {RT}\)

As we know,

\(C_v=\frac{d U}{d t} \)

\(\Rightarrow d U=\frac{d}{d T}(3+f) R T=(3+f) R\)

The molar specific heat capacity of a gas at constant volume is \({C}_{{v}}=(3+\) f) \(R\).
The number of Degree of freedom for a diatomic molecule is: (Assume molecules are rigid)

The number of independent ways by which a gas molecule can move, without any constraint imposed on it, is called the number of degrees of freedom. 

A diatomic molecule has a degree of freedom \(5\), because it can move in translational motion in \(x, y\) and \({z}\)-direction.

The degree of freedom due to translational motion \(=3\)

and due to rotational motion, degree of freedom \(=2\)

So total degree of freedom \(=3+2=5\)
For a gas of non rigid mono-atomic molecules, the value of heat capacity ratio \(\gamma\) is:

Molecular specific heat at constant volume \(C_v=\frac{f R}{2}\)

molecular specific heat at constant pressure \(C_p=C_v+R=\frac{(2+f) R}{2}\)

where \(f\) is the degree of freedom.

For monoatomic molecule degree of freedom \(f=3\).

For diatomic molecule degree of freedom \(f={5}\)

\({C}_{{v}}=\frac{f R}{2}=\frac{3R}{2}\)

\({C}_{{p}}=\frac{(2+f) R}{2}=\frac{5 R}{2} \)

\( \gamma=\frac{C_p}{C_v}=\frac{5}{3}\)

The molar specific heats of an ideal gas at constant pressure and volume are denoted by \(\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{P}}\) and \(\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{\gamma}}\), respectively. If \(\gamma=\frac{C_P}{C_\gamma}\) and \(\mathrm{R}\) is the universal gas constant, then \(\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{V}}\) is equal to:

We have,

\(\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{P}}-\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{V}}=\mathrm{R}\cdots(1) \)

\(\gamma=\frac{C_P}{C_V} \)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{P}}=\gamma \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{V}}\cdots(2)\)

Putting (2) in (1) we have

\(\gamma C_V-C_V=R \)

\(\Rightarrow C_V(\gamma-1)=R \)

\(\Rightarrow C_V= \frac{R}{(\gamma-1)}\)
The amount of heat energy required to raise the temperature of \(1 \mathrm{~g}\) of Helium at NTP, from \(T_1 \mathrm{~K}\) to \(\mathrm{T}_2 \mathrm{~K}\) is:

Heat required to change the temperature from \(T_1\) to \(T_2\).

\(\mathrm{Q}=\mathrm{n} \cdot \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{v}} \cdot\left(\mathrm{T}_2-\mathrm{T}_1\right)\cdots(1)\)

\({n}\) is the number of moles present in given mass.

\({n}=\frac{\text { given mass of helium }}{\text { molar mass of helium }}=1 \mathrm{gm} / 4 \mathrm{gm}=\frac{1}{4} \cdots (2) \)

For monoatomic Gas

\(\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{v}}=\frac{3}{2} \mathrm{R}\)

or \( \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{v}}=\frac{3}{2} \times \mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{b}} \times \mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{a}}\cdots (3)\)

Putting (2) and (3) in (1) we get

\(Q=\frac{1}{4} \times \frac{3}{2} \times K_b . N_a=\frac{3}{8} N_a k_B\left(T_2-T_1\right)\)
The mean free path of a gas molecule depends on:

The mean free path or average distance between collisions for a gas molecule may be estimated from kinetic theory. Mean free path displays inverse proportionality to the density of molecules and molecular diameter.

\(\begin{aligned} & \lambda_{\text {mean }} \propto \frac{1}{\text { density of molecule }} \\ & \text { and } \lambda_{\text {mean }} \propto \frac{1}{d^2}\end{aligned}\)
It does not depend on the temperature
Initially, it increases and then decreases with the increase in temperature

The time interval between two successive collisions of electrons with the atoms in the conductor is known as relaxation time.

\(\tau=\frac{\text { mean free path }}{\text { r.m.s velocity of electrons }}\)

As the temperature increases, the thermal energy of electrons increases. Thus they collide more frequently with the atoms and hence the average relaxation time which is the average time between successive collisions decreases. Thus temperature is inversely proportional to relaxation time. With the rise in temperature increases consequently, average relaxation time \((\mathrm{\tau})\) decreases.
The work-energy theorem equates the change in the kinetic energy of an object to:
The net force applied on the object.
The net work done by the force on the object.
The loss in potential energy of the object.

The work-energy theorem states that the net work done by the forces on an object equals the change in its kinetic energy.
Work done, \((W)=\Delta K E=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}-\frac{1}{2} m u^{2}\)
Where \(m\) is the mass of the object, \(v\) is the final velocity of the object and \(u\) is the initial velocity of the object.
From the work-energy theorem, the net work done by the forces on an object equals the change in its kinetic energy.
The kinetic energy of a body increases from 50 J to 150 J in 10 s. Then the power of the body is:

Given,

\(KE _{1}=50 J\)

\(KE _{2}=150 J\)

\(t =10 s\)

As we know,

The work-energy theorem states that the net work done by the forces on an object is equal to the change in its kinetic energy.

\( W =\Delta KE\)

Where \(W=\) work done and \(\Delta K E=\) change in kinetic energy

By the work-energy theorem,

\( W=\Delta KE \)

\(\therefore W=K E_{2}-K E_{1} \)

\(\Rightarrow W=150-50 \)

\(\Rightarrow W=100 J\)

So, the power of the body \( (P)=\frac{W}{t}\)

Where \(W=\) work and \(t=\) time

\(\therefore P=\frac{100}{10} \)

\(\Rightarrow P=10 W\)
A truck accelerates from speed v to 2v. Work done during this is process of acceleration is:
Three times as the work done in accelerating it from rest to v.
Same as the work done in accelerating it from rest to v.
Four times as the work done in accelerating it from rest to v.
Less than the work done in accelerating it from rest to v.

When a body is in linear motion, its energy due to motion will be kinetic energy.

\(K =\frac{1 }{ 2} \times m \times v ^{2}\)

where \(K\) is the kinetic energy of the body, and \(m\) is the mass of the body, and \(v\) is its velocity.

Work-Energy Theorem: The net work done on an object is equal to a change in its Kinetic energy.

\( W =\Delta K \)

\( W = K _{ f }- K _{ i }\)

Where \(W\) is work done, \(K_{f}\) is final kinetic energy and \(K_{i}\) is initial kinetic energy.

Given,

Initial velocity \(= v\)

Final velocity \(=2 v\)

Let the mass of the truck is \(m\).

Initial kinetic energy \(K _{ i }=\frac{1 }{ 2} \times m \times v ^{2}\)

Final kinetic energy \(K _{ f }=\frac{1 }{ 2} \times m \times(2 v)^{2}=2 \times m \times v^{2}\)

Net work done \(W=\Delta K=K_{f}-K_{i}\)

\(\therefore W=2 \times m \times v^{2}-\frac{1 }{ 2} \times m \times v^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow W=\frac{3 }{ 2} \times m \times v^{2} \)

\(\Rightarrow W=3 K_{i}\)

So, Net work done is three times as the initial kinetic energy of the mass or work done in accelerating it from rest to \(v\).
A particle of mass m is moving along the x-axis such that its velocity is given by \(v=k \sqrt{x}\). The work done by the force during the first t seconds is:

As we know,

Work done by a variable force is given by,

\(W=\int_{x_{1}}^{x_{2}} F(x) d x\)

Work done, \((W)=\int_{0}^{t} F . d x=\int_{0}^{t} m a . d x\)

We know that, acceleration, \(a=\frac{d v}{d t}\)

\(\therefore W=\int_{0}^{t} m \frac{d v}{d t} \cdot d x \)

\(\Rightarrow W=\int_{0}^{t} m \frac{d(k \sqrt{x})}{d t} \cdot d x \)

\(\Rightarrow W=\int_{0}^{t} m \frac{k}{2 \sqrt{x}} \frac{d x}{d t} \cdot d x \)

\(\Rightarrow W=\int_{0}^{t} m \frac{k}{2 \sqrt{x}} v \cdot d x\)

\(\Rightarrow W=\int_{0}^{t} m \frac{k}{2 \sqrt{x}} k \sqrt{x} . d x \)

\(\Rightarrow W=\int_{0}^{t} m \frac{k^{2}}{2} \cdot d x \)

\(\Rightarrow W=m \frac{k^{2}}{2}[x]_{t=0}^{t=t}\) ...(1)

Given,

Velocity \(v=k\sqrt{x}\)

As we know, 

Velocity, \(v=\frac{d x}{d t}\)

\(\therefore k \sqrt{x}=\frac{d x}{d t} \)

\(\Rightarrow k d t=\frac{d x}{\sqrt{x}}\)

On integrating, we get

\(kt =2 \sqrt{ x }\)

At \(t=0, x=0\)

\(\therefore x=\frac{k^{2} t^{2}}{4}\)...(2)

Substituting (2) in (1), we get

\(W=m \frac{k^{2}}{2}\left[\frac{k^{2} t^{2}}{4}\right]\)

\(\Rightarrow W=\frac{m k^{4} t^{2}}{8}\)
A force (F) acting on a particle is such that F is inversely proportional to the distance covered. The work done by the force in moving the particle from point 'a' to point 'b' is proportional to:

As we know,

Work done by a variable force is given by,

\(W=\int_{a}^{b} F(x) d x\)

Let \(x\) be the distance covered.

Given that \(F \propto \frac{1}{x}\)

Work done, \((W)=\int_{a}^{b} F(x) d x\)

\(\therefore W \propto \int_{a}^{b} \frac{1}{x} d x \)

\(\Rightarrow W \propto[\ln (x)]_{a}^{b} \)

\(\Rightarrow W \propto \ln (b)-\ln (a) \)

\(\Rightarrow W \propto \ln \left(\frac{b}{a}\right)\)
A body of mass 10kg at rest is acted upon simultaneously by two forces 4N and 3N at right angles to each other. The kinetic energy of the body at the end of 10 s is:

Given,

\(m =10 kg , F _{1}=4 N , F _{2}=3 N , \theta=90^{\circ}\) and \(t =10 s\)

Since the two forces are acting perpendicular to each other, so the resultant force is given as,

\( F=\sqrt{F_{1}^{2}+F_{2}^{2}} \)

\(\Rightarrow F=\sqrt{4^{2}+3^{2}} \)

\(\Rightarrow F=5 N\)...(1)

By Newton's second law of motion, the force acting on the body is given as,

\( F = ma\)

Where \(m=\) mass and \(a=\) acceleration

\( a=\frac{F}{m} \)

\(\Rightarrow a=\frac{5}{10} \)

\(\Rightarrow a=\frac{1}{2} m / s^{2}\)...(2)

Kinetic energy \(KE=\frac{1}{2} mv^{2}=\frac{1}{2}m (at)^{2}\)

\(\therefore KE =\frac{1}{2} \times 10 \times (\frac{1}{2}\times 10)^{2}\)

\(=\frac{1}{2} \times 10 \times(5)^{2}\)

\(= 125J\)

So, the kinetic energy of the body at the end of \(10 s\) is \(125J\).
For the negative work done the angle between the force and the displacement must be:

As we know,
The work done by a force on a body is given as,
\(W=F x \times \cos \theta\)...(1)
By equation (1) we can say that the work done will be negative when the value of \(\cos \theta\) is negative.
We know that the value of \(\cos \theta\) is negative when the \(\theta\) is greater than \(90^{\circ}\).
So, for the negative work done the angle between the force and the displacement must be an obtuse angle.
A mass of 5 kg is moving along a circular path of radius 1 m. If the mass moves with 300 revolutions per minute, its kinetic energy would be:

Given,

Mass \(( m )=5 kg\)

Radius \(( R )=1 m\)

Velocity \(( v )=300 rpm =\frac{300 }{ 60}=5 rpm\)

As we know,

The angular speed is given by,

\(\omega=2 \pi v\)

\(\therefore \omega =2 \pi \times 5=10 \pi rads ^{-1} \)

\(v=\omega R\)

\(\therefore v =10 \pi \times 1=10 \pi ms ^{-1}\)

Kinetic energy, \((KE)=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}=\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} R^{2}\)

\(=\frac{1}{2} \times 5 \times(10 \pi)^{2}\)

\(=250 \pi^{2}\)
If the kinetic energy of a body is increased nine times then the momentum of the body will be increased by:

Given,

\(KE _{2}=9 KE _{1}\)

We know that the kinetic energy of a body is given as,

\( K E=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}\)...(1)

The linear momentum of a body is given as,

\( P = mv\)...(2)

By equation (1) and equation (2) the relation between the kinetic energy and the momentum is given as,

\( K E=\frac{P^{2}}{2 m}\)...(3)

By equation (3) for the initial position,

\( K E_{1}=\frac{P_{1}^{2}}{2 m}\)...(4)

By equation (3) for the final position,

\( K E_{2}=\frac{P_{2}^{2}}{2 m} \)

\(\Rightarrow 9 \times K E_{1}=\frac{P_{2}^{2}}{2 m}\)...(5)

By equation (4) and equation (5),

\(\frac{P_{2}^{2}}{2 m} \times \frac{2 m}{P_{1}^{2}}=\frac{9 \times K E_{1}}{K E_{1}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{P_{2}^{2}}{P_{1}^{2}}=9 \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{P_{2}}{P_{1}}=3 \)

\(\Rightarrow P_{2}=3 P_{1}\)

So, if the kinetic energy of a body is increased nine times then the momentum of the body will be increased by three times.
A man increases his speed by 2m/s, then his kinetic energy gets doubled. The original speed of the man is:

The energy possessed by a body due to the virtue of its motion is called kinetic energy.
\( K E=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}\)
Where \(KE =\) kinetic energy, \(m =\) mass and \(v =\) velocity
Given,
\(\Delta v = v _{2}- v _{1}=2 m / s\)
\(KE _{2}=2 KE _{1}\)
Where \(\Delta v =\) increase in speed
Initial kinetic energy, \(K E_{1}=\frac{1}{2} m v_{1}^{2}\)...(1)
Final kinetic energy, \(K E_{2}=\frac{1}{2} m v_{2}^{2}\)...(2)
By equation (1) and equation (2),
\( K E_{2}=2 K E_{1} \)
\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} m v_{2}^{2}=2 \times \frac{1}{2} m v_{1}^{2} \)
\(\Rightarrow v_{2}^{2}=2 v_{1}^{2} \)
\(\Rightarrow v_{2}=\pm \sqrt{2} v_{1}\)...(3)
Since,
\( \Delta v=v_{2}-v_{1}=2 m / s\)
By equation (3), we get
\( \sqrt{2} v_{1}-v_{1}=2 \)
\(\Rightarrow v_1(\sqrt{2}-1)=2\)
\(\Rightarrow v_{1}=\frac{2}{\sqrt{2}-1} \)...(4)
On dividing and multiplying by \(\sqrt{2}+1\) in equation (4), we get
\( v_{1}=\frac{2}{\sqrt{2}-1} \times \frac{\sqrt{2}+1}{\sqrt{2}+1} \)
\(\Rightarrow v_{1}=\frac{2(\sqrt{2}+1)}{(\sqrt{2})^{2}-1^{2}}\)
\(\Rightarrow v_{1}=2(\sqrt{2}+1) m/s\)
So, the original speed of man is \(2(\sqrt{2}+1) m/s\).
Find the ratio of the magnitude of linear momentum, if two bodies A and B of mass 9 kg and 25 kg respectively are moving with equal kinetic energy.

Given,

\(m _{ A }=9 \) kg

\(m _{ B }=25\) kg

\(KE _{ A }= KE _{ B }\)

As we know,

The relation between the kinetic energy and the momentum is given as,

\( P ^{2}=2 mKE\)

Momentum for body A, \((P_{A})^{2}=2 m_{A} \times K E_{A}^{2}\)

\(\therefore (P_{A})^{2}=2 \times 9 \times K E\) 

\(\Rightarrow (P_{A})^{2}=18 \times K E\)...(1)

Momentum for body B \((P_{B})^{2}=2 m_{B} \times K E_{B}^{2}\)

\(\therefore (P_{B})^{2}=2 \times 25 \times K E\) 

\(\Rightarrow (P_{B})^{2}=50 \times K E\)...(2)

On dividing equation (1) and (2), we get

\(\frac{(P_{A})^{2}}{(P_{B})^{2}}=\frac{18 \times K E}{50 \times K E}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{(P_{A})^{2}}{(P_{B})^{2}}=\frac{9}{25}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{P_{A}}{P_{B}}=\sqrt{\frac{9}{25}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{P_{A}}{P_{B}}=\frac{3}{5}\)

\(\Rightarrow P_{A}: P_{B}=3: 5\)

So, the ratio of linear momentum is \(3:5\).
A force \(F=P y^{2}+Q y+R\) acts on a body in the y direction. The change in kinetic energy of the body during a displacement from \(y=-a\) to \(y=a\) is:

The work-energy theorem states that the net work done by the forces on an object equals the change in its kinetic energy.

Work done, \((W)=\Delta K=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}-\frac{1}{2} m u^{2}\)

Where \(m\) is the mass of the object, \(v\) is the final velocity of the object and \(u\) is the initial velocity of the object.

Work-energy theorem for a variable force:

Kinetic energy, \(K=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}\)

\( \frac{d K}{d t}=\frac{d\left(\frac{1 }{ 2} m v^{2}\right)}{d t} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d K}{d t}=m \frac{d v}{d t} v\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d K}{d t}=m a v\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d K}{d t}=F v \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d K}{d t}=F \frac{d x}{d t} \)

\(\Rightarrow d K=F d x\)

On integrating, we get

\( \int_{K_{i}}^{K_{f}} d K=\int_{x_{i}}^{x_{f}} F d x \)

\(\Rightarrow \Delta K=\int_{x_{i}}^{x_{f}} F d x\)

From the work-energy theorem, a change in kinetic energy equals the work done.

\( \Delta K=\int_{x_{i}}^{x_{f}} F d x \)

\(\Rightarrow \Delta K=\int_{-a}^{a}\left(P y^{2}+Q y+R\right) d y \)

\(\Rightarrow \Delta K=\left[\frac{P y^{3}}{3}+\frac{Q y^{2}}{2}+R y\right]_{-a}^{a} \)

\(\Rightarrow \Delta K=\left[\left(\frac{P a^{3}}{3}+\frac{Q a^{2}}{2}+R a\right)-\left(\frac{-P a^{3}}{3}+\frac{Q a^{2}}{2}-R a\right)\right] \)

\(\Rightarrow \Delta K=\frac{2 P a^{3}}{3}+2 R a\)

A car of mass 1 tonne is moving with a speed of 30 m/s. It suddenly applies the brakes and stops after moving a certain distance d. The frictional force between the tyres and road is \(F = k \sqrt{ x }\) where x is the distance covered. If k = 1000, the distance d covered by the car before stopping is:

Given,

Mass, \((m) =1\) tonne \(=1000 kg\)

Initial velocity, \(u=30 m / s\)

Final velocity, \(v=0 m / s\)

Here, friction does the work, and therefore work done is negative.

So, we can consider \(F =- k \sqrt{ x }\)

From the work-energy theorem,

\( \Delta K=\int_{x_{i}}^{x_{f}} F d x \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} m\left(v^{2}-u^{2}\right)=\int_{0}^{d}-k \sqrt{x} d x \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} \times 1000 \times\left(0^{2}-30^{2}\right)=\int_{0}^{d}-1000 \sqrt{x} d x \)

\(\Rightarrow-450=\left[-\frac{2 x^{\frac{3 }{ 2}}}{3}\right]_{0}^{d} \)

\(\Rightarrow 450=\frac{2 d^{\frac{3 }{ 2}}}{3} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{450 \times 3}{2}=(d)^{\frac{3}{2}} \)

\(\Rightarrow 675 =(d)^{\frac{3}{2}} \)

We can write this as:

\( (77)^{\frac{3}{2}}=(d)^{\frac{3}{2}} \)

\(\therefore d=77 m\)
Which of the following is a true representation of the Work-Energy theorem for a variable force?

The work-energy theorem states that the net work done by the forces on an object equals the change in its kinetic energy.

Work done, \((W)=\Delta K=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}-\frac{1}{2} m u^{2}\)

Where \(m\) is the mass of the object, \(v\) is the final velocity of the object and \(u\) is the initial velocity of the object.

Work-energy theorem for a variable force:

Kinetic energy, \(K=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}\)

\( \frac{d K}{d t}=\frac{d\left(\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}\right)}{d t} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d K}{d t}=m \frac{d v}{d t} v\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d K}{d t}=m a v\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d K}{d t}=F v \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d K}{d t}=F \frac{d x}{d t} \)

\(\Rightarrow d K=F d x\)

On integrating, we get

\( \int_{K_{i}}^{K_{f}} d K=\int_{x_{i}}^{x_{f}} F d x \)

\(\Rightarrow \Delta K=\int_{x_{i}}^{x_{f}} F d x\)

All the given options are correct as they are all different forms of representing the work-energy theorem for a variable force.
For one dimensional motion, the force F(x) and the potential energy U(x) are related as:

The potential energy is equal to negative work done in shifting an object from some reference point to a given position for conservative force.
In mathematical form, it is given as,
\( d U(x)=-F(x) d x \)
\(\therefore F(x)=\frac{-d U(x)}{d x}\)
where \(F\) is the force in newton and \(\frac{d U }{ dx}\) is change in potential energy per unit length.
A ball falls from a height of a 20 m, and then bounces back up to 10 m height. The loss of energy is:

Let,

Initial height before drop \(\left( h _{1}\right)=20 m\)

Final after bounce \(\left( h _{2}\right)=10 m\)

The potential energy of the ball before drop \(\left(P_{1}\right)\) \(=m g h_{1}=20mg\)

The potential energy of the ball after bounce \(\left( P _{2}\right)\) \(= mgh _{2}=10mg\)

As the ball is falling, its potential energy will decrease continuously until it reaches the ground and then it will start increasing after the bounce.

So the potential energy after dropping will be the fraction of initial potential energy.

The loss of energy is given by:

\( \Delta P \times 100=\frac{P_{1}-P_{2}}{P_{1}} \times 100 \)

\(\Rightarrow \Delta P=\frac{20mg-10mg}{20mg} \times 100\)

\(\Rightarrow \Delta P=50 \%\)
An ice rock of mass 50 kg falls from the height 100 m. What will be its speed when it reaches the height of 10m? (g = 10 m/s2)

Given,

Initial height \((h_{i})=100 m \)

Final height \((h_{f})=10 m \)

Mass \((m)=50 kg\)

Since the height is decreasing so there will be a loss in potential energy.

Loss in potential energy is given as,

\(P E_{f}-P E_{i}=m g h_{f}-m g h_{i} \)

\(\Rightarrow \Delta P E=(50 \times 10 \times 100)-(50 \times 10 \times 10)\)

\(\Rightarrow \Delta P E=(50000-5000)J\)

\(\Rightarrow \Delta P E =45000 J =45 KJ\)

Since there is the only gravitational force acting on the given system which is a conservative force. So total mechanical energy will be conserved.

So initial mechanical energy will be equal to final mechanical energy which means the lost potential energy will be converted into kinetic energy.

Gain in kinetic energy \(=\) Loss in potential energy

\(\therefore\) Gain in kinetic energy \(=45 KJ\)

Since initial kinetic energy is zero. 

\(\therefore\) Initial speed \(=0\)

Gain in kinetic energy \(= \Delta KE\)

\(\Rightarrow 45000= \frac{1 }{ 2}m (v^{2}- u^{2})\)

\(\Rightarrow 45000= \frac{1 }{ 2}mv^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow 45000= \frac{1 }{ 2}\times 50 \times v^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{45000\times 2}{50}=v^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow 1800=v^{2}\)

\(\therefore v= 42.42 m / s\)

So, its speed when it reaches the height of \(10m\) is \(42.42m/s\).
A ball of mass 1 kg having a speed of 10 m/s hits a spring (unstretched) in such a way that it compresses. Find maximum compression in the spring. (Given spring constant k = 2500 N/m)

Since there is the only spring force acting which is a conservative force. So total mechanical energy will be conserved.

Initially, when spring is unstretched, it will have no potential energy but kinetic energy is given to it.

\(P E_{i}=0 \)

\(KE_{i}=\frac{1 }{ 2}\left(m \times v^{2}\right)\)

The spring will be compressed maximum when all the kinetic energy is converted into potential energy.

So finally kinetic energy will become zero.

\(K E _{ f }=0\)

As we know,

The potential energy of a spring is given by:

\(P E_{f}=\frac{1}{2} k x^{2}\)

Where \(k\) is the spring constant and \(x\) is the elongation or compression in the spring.

According to the conservation of mechanical energy,

Total initial mechanical energy \(=\) Total final mechanical energy

\(\therefore KE_{i}+PE_{i}= KE _{ f }+ PE _{ f }\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} m v ^{2}+0=0+\frac{1 }{ 2} k x ^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow m v ^{2}= k x ^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow 1\times (10)^{2}=2500 \times x ^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow 100=2500 x ^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{100}{2500}=x^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \sqrt{\frac{1}{25}}=x\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{5}=x\)

\(\Rightarrow x = 0.2 m\)

\(\therefore x = 2 0 cm\)
The total force constant of the springs shown in the figure will be:

The constant used to measure the spring stiffness is called as spring constant. When a spring is stretched or compressed, so that its length changes by an amount x from its equilibrium length, then it exerts a force.

As we know,

\(F=-k x\)

Where \(k=\) spring constant, and \(x=\) stretched length

Equivalent spring constant in parallel is given by:

\(k_{p}=k_{1}+k_{2}\)

Equivalent spring constant in series is given by:

\(k _{s}=\frac{1}{k_{1}}+\frac{1}{ k_{2}}\)

From the figure, it is clear that the first two springs are parallel.

\(k_{p}=k_{1}+k_{1}=2 k_{1}\)

\(k _{ p }\) is in series with \(k _{2}\), then

\(\therefore k _{s}=\frac{1}{k_{p}}+\frac{1}{k_{2}}\)

Total spring constant is given by,

\(\frac{1}{k_{\text {resultant}}}=\frac{1}{2k _{1}}+\frac{1}{k_{2}}\)

So, \(k_{\text {resultant }}=\left(\frac{1 }{2k _{1}}+\frac{1 }{k_{2}}\right)^{-1}\)
If non-conservative forces are involved, part of the mechanical energy may get transformed into __________.

According to the mechanical energy conservation rule, if the forces on a system are only conservative forces, the total mechanical energy will remain constant. But if some of the forces involved are non-conservative on the system. A part of the mechanical energy may be lost. Since the overall energy of an isolated system remains constant. This loss in mechanical energy gets transformed into other forms such as heat, light, and sound.
Which of the following is not correct disadvantage regarding nuclear energy plants?
Nuclear energy increases the temperature of the water body
Nuclear power plants require more water than coal power plant

Nuclear energy is the energy in the nucleus of an atom. Nuclear energy is generated by nuclear fusion and nuclear fission reactions. Nuclear energy plants do not release carbon emission but there are other disadvantages:

Disadvantages of nuclear energy plants:

  • ​It causes thermal pollution.
  • Its wastes are radioactive materials
  • It requires a large amount of water.

Thermal pollution: Most of the nuclear power plants are located on banks of the river, ocean, or large lakes. These plants use cooling water from these water bodies to condense steam back into the water. This process causes the cooling water to increase in temperature and is then released back into the body of water which can harm marine life.

Radioactive wastes: Nuclear power creates radioactive wastes such as uranium, used reactor fuel, and many other radioactive wastes. These radioactive materials can be dangerous to human health for thousands of years.

Need a large amount of water: Nuclear power plants require a lot of water to produce energy more than coal power plants. A study shows that in the year 2015, the USA consumed 320 billion gallons of water to produce nuclear power that is way more than what was used in coal power plants. 

Nuclear energy does not release carbon emissions which is responsible for global warming. So this is not the disadvantage of nuclear energy.
A block is moving with some speed on the horizontal rough ground, after some time it stopped. What can be the possible reasons for it?
Kinetic energy of the block becomes negative
Kinetic energy of the block is converted into potential energy
Kinetic energy of the block is converted into heat energy

Friction is not a conservative force. Work done by friction force is lost in the form of sound energy, heat energy, etc. In the question, it is given that the block stops after some time. Here kinetic energy is lost. We can say that the kinetic energy of the block is ‘lost’ due to the frictional force. This kinetic energy loss makes a slight increase in its temperatures. The work done by friction is not lost but is transferred as heat energy. Due to this way kinetic energy of the block is converted into heat energy. This is the reason a block is moving with some speed on the horizontal rough ground, after some time it stopped.
Which of the following will said to be conserved, when an arrow hit a target and gets embedded in it? (consider target and arrow as a system)

Linear momentum (p) is the product of the mass and velocity of an object i.e.,

​p = m × v

Where m is mass and v is velocity.

The Law of conservation of momentum states that for two or more bodies in an isolated system, the total momentum remains constant before and after the collision unless an external force is applied.

A perfectly elastic collision is defined as a collision in which no loss of kinetic energy takes place. Bouncing off of one another is considered an elastic collision. A collision in which some part of kinetic energy is converted to some other form of energy is called an inelastic collision. In an inelastic collision, neither the kinetic energy nor the potential energy gets conserved.

In the case of an arrow hitting the target and getting embedded in it, the inelastic collision between the arrow and the target takes place. In an inelastic collision, only the linear momentum gets conserved.
The coefficient of restitution for perfectly inelastic bodies is:

A perfectly elastic collision is defined as one in which there is no loss of kinetic energy and the momentum of the system is conserved in the collision.

An inelastic collision is defined as one in which there is a loss of kinetic energy and the momentum of the system is conserved in the collision.

The coefficient of restitution is the ratio of relative velocity after impact to the relative velocity before impact. 

Coefficient of restitution \(e=\frac{\text { Relative velocity after collision }}{\text { Relative velocity before collision }}=\frac{ v _{2}- v _{1}}{ u _{1}- u _{2}}\)

  • For perfectly elastic collision, e \(=1\)
  • For inelastic collision, \(e<1\)
  • For a perfectly inelastic collision \(e =0\)

From the above discussion, we can say that the coefficient of restitution for perfectly inelastic bodies is equal to 0.

A ball of mass \(2 kg\) is moving with velocity \(15 m / s\) and hits a wall and returns with some velocity. If the coefficient of restitution between wall and ball is \(\frac{2}{3}\), find loss in kinetic energy during the collision.

Given, 

Mass of a ball = 2 kg

First object is a wall and second object is a ball. 

Coefficient of restitution \((e)=\frac{2}{3}\)

The initial velocity of the ball, \(u_1=0\)

The initial velocity of the wall, \(v_1=0\)

The final velocity of the ball, \(u_2=15 m/s\)

The final velocity of the wall, \(v_2=?\)

According to the Newton's law of restitution,

\(v_{2}-v_{1}=-e\left(u_{2}-u_{1}\right)\)

\(\Rightarrow v _{2}-0=-\frac{2}{3}(15-0)\)

\(\Rightarrow v _{2}=-10 m / s\)  (Here negative sign means opposite to initial direction)

Loss in Kinetic energy \(=\) Initial kinetic energy \(-\) final kinetic energy

Loss in Kinetic energy \(=\frac{1}{2} m (u_2-u_1)^{2}-\frac{1}{2} m (v_2-v_1)^{2}\)

\(=\frac{1}{2} m (15-0)^{2}-\frac{1}{2} m (-10-0)^{2}\)

\(=\frac{1}{2} \times 2 \times (15)^{2}-\frac{1}{2} \times 2 \times (10)^{2}\)

\(= 225-100\)

\(=125 J\)
A force \(\vec{F}=(5 \hat{i}+3 \hat{j})\) newton displaces a body by \((2 \hat{i}-\hat{j})\) metre. The work done by the force is:

Given,
\(\vec{F}=(5 \hat{i}+3 \hat{j})\) and \(\vec{x}=(2 \hat{i}-\hat{j})\)
As we know,
Work done by the force is given by,
\(W=\vec{F} \cdot \vec{x} \)
\(\Rightarrow W=(5 \hat{i}+3 \hat{j}) \cdot(2 \hat{i}-\hat{j}) \)
\(\Rightarrow W=10-3 \)
\(\Rightarrow W=7 J\)
So, the work done by the force is 7 Joules.

A car of mass \(m\) starts from rest and accelerates so that the instantaneous power delivered to the car has a constant magnitude \(P_{0}\). The instantaneous velocity of this car is proportional to:

As we know,

Power \((P_{0})=F v\) 

By putting \(F=ma\), we get

\(\therefore P_{0}=m a v\) 

By putting \(a=\frac{dv}{dt}\), we get

\(\Rightarrow P_{0}=m v \frac{d v}{d t}\)

Integrating both sides, we get

\(\int P _{0} dt =\int mvdv \)

\(\Rightarrow P _{0} t =\frac{ mv ^{2}}{2} \)

\(\Rightarrow v^{2}=\frac{2 P _{0} t }{ m } \)

\(\Rightarrow v \propto \sqrt{t}\)

\(\therefore v \propto t ^{\frac{1 }{ 2}}\)
When a ball is thrown upward and it comes back to initial position, which of the following is correct regarding its energy?
Kinetic energy first decrease and becomes zero then increase
Potential energy first increase and becomes maximum then decrease

Initially, when the ball is thrown. It is given some speed. So it will have kinetic energy. As the ball goes up, its speed will decrease and at the highest point speed will be zero. So the kinetic energy will start to decrease and will be zero at the highest point. After that when the ball comes down, its speed increases. So, the kinetic energy will increase. So, kinetic energy first decreases then increases.

Initially, when the ball is on the ground at its lowest point, it will have the lowest or zero potential energy. As the ball goes up, its potential energy will increase due to an increase in height and will be minimum at the highest point. After that when the ball comes down, its height decreases. So, the potential energy will decrease. So, potential energy first increases then decreases.
The work done by a conservative force in a closed path is:

Given that work is done in a closed path.

So, displacement in a closed path will be zero.

Work done by conservative force is given by,

\(W=\vec{F} \cdot \vec{d}\)

\(=\vec{F} \cdot 0\)

\(=0\)

Work done by a conservative force in a closed path is zero.

Clearly here it does not matter, from which path the body is going. The work done by a conservative force depends only on the endpoints.
Work done by spring force depends on:

As we know that spring force is given by,

\(F_{s}=-k x\)

Where \(F_{s}\) is the spring force, \(x\) is the displacement from the equilibrium position and \(k\) is the spring constant.

So, work done by spring force for moving an object from \(x_{1}\) to \(x_{2}\),

\(W=\int_{x_{1}}^{x_{2}} F \cdot d x\)

\(\Rightarrow W=\int_{x_{1}}^{x_{2}}(-k x) . d x\)

\(\Rightarrow W=\left[\frac{-k x^{2}}{2}\right]_{x_{1}}^{x_{2}} \)

\(\Rightarrow W=\frac{k x_{1}^{2}}{2}-\frac{k x_{2}^{2}}{2}\)

So, work done by spring force depends only on the endpoints, not on the path of motion.

A bullet fired into a fixed target loses half of its velocity after penetrating \(3 {~cm}\). How much further will it penetrate before coming to rest assuming that it faces constant resistance to motion?

Let initial velocity of the bullet = u

After penetrating \(3 \mathrm{~cm}\) its velocity becomes \(\frac{\mathrm{u}}{2}\) 

From \(v^2=u^2-2 a s\)

\(\left(\frac{u}{2}\right)^2=u^2-2 a(3)\)

\(\Rightarrow 6 a=\frac{3 u^2}{4} \Rightarrow a=\frac{u^2}{8}\)

Let further it will penetrate through distance \(x\) and stops at point \(C\).

For distance \(B C, v=0, u=\frac{u}{2}, s=x, a=\frac{u^2}{8}\)

From \(v^2=u^2-2 a s \Rightarrow 0=\left(\frac{u}{2}\right)^2-2\left(\frac{u^2}{8}\right) \cdot x \Rightarrow x=1 \mathrm{~cm}\).

A uniform chain of length \(2 \mathrm{~m}\) is kept on a table such that a length of \(60 \mathrm{~cm}\) hangs freely from the edge of the table. The total mass of the chain is \(4 \mathrm{~kg}\). What is the work done in pulling the entire chain on the table ?

As we know if we pull the chain, each part of the chain will not cover same height, therefore will not contribute the same potential energy, so let's take mass of the chain \(L^{\prime}=\frac{L}{2 n}\)

Now we can write

\(W=\frac{m g L}{2 n^2}\)

Given, 

length = \(2 \mathrm{~m}\)

mass = \(4 \mathrm{~kg}\)

After putting all the values and solving

\(=\frac{4 \times 10 \times 2}{2 \times\left(\frac{10}{3}\right)^2}=3.6 \mathrm{~J}\)
A particle moves in a straight line with a retardation proportional to its displacement. Its loss of kinetic energy for any displacement x is proportional to:

Given that,

a∝−x

⇒a=−kx

Now using \(a=\frac{v d v}{d x}\)

\(\Rightarrow v d v=-k x d x\)

\(\Rightarrow \quad \int_{v_1}^{v_2} v d v=-k \int_0^x x d x\)

\(\Rightarrow \quad \frac{v_2^2-v_1^2}{2}=\frac{-k \cdot x^2}{2}\)

or, \(\left(v_1^2-v_2^2\right)=k x^2\)

Now, loss in kinetic energy is given by

\(\Delta K \cdot E=\frac{1}{2} m v_1^2-\frac{1}{2} m v_2^2\)

\(=\frac{1}{2} m\left(v_1^2-v_2^2\right)=\frac{k m x^2}{2}\)

Thus, the loss in kinetic energy is proportional to \(x^2\).

A spherical ball of mass \(20 \mathrm{~kg}\) is stationary at the top of a hill of height \(100 \mathrm{~m}\). It rolls down a smooth surface to the ground, then climbs up another hill of height of \(20 \mathrm{~m}\) above the ground. The velocity attained by the ball is:

Mass of the ball \(m=20 \mathrm{~kg}\)

Height of the first hill \(h_1=100 \mathrm{~m}\)

Height of the second hill \(h_2=20 \mathrm{~m}\)

If \(v\) is the speed of the ball and \(g\) is the acceleration due to gravity then, According to the law of conservation of energy we have

\(\begin{aligned} & m g h_1=m g h_2+\left(\frac{1}{2} m v^2\right) \\ & \Rightarrow m g\left(h_1-h_2\right)=\frac{1}{2} m v^2 \\ & \Rightarrow v=\sqrt{2 g\left(h_1-h_2\right)} \\ & =\sqrt{2 \times 10 \times(100-20)} \\ & =40 m s^{-1}\end{aligned}\)

A force \(\vec{F}=(5 \hat{i}+3 \hat{j}+2 \hat{k}) \mathrm{N}\) is applied over a particle which displaces it from its origin to the point \(\vec{r}=(2 \hat{i}-\hat{j}) \mathrm{m}\). The work done on the particle in joules is:
A particle is acted upon by a force of constant magnitude which is always perpendicular to the velocity of the particle. If the motion of the particle takes place in a plane, it follows that :

Since the particle is acted upon by a force of constant magnitude which is always perpendicular to the velocity of the particle, so work done by the force in the direction of the velocity is zero. So the magnitude of velocity will not change due to the force.

Kinetic energy is \(\mathrm{KE}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{mv}^2=\) constant.

Now mass and magnitude of velocity will always be constant in this given situation so the kinetic energy will also be constant.
A body falling from a height of 10 m rebounds from the floor. If it loses 20 % of the energy in the impact, how high will it rebound?

The ball rebounds after striking the ground and loses 20 % energy. 

Let ball has been dropped initially at height h from ground level. 

The energy of  the ball is P = m g h

h = 10 m (given)

So, after losing, the energy left is (100 - 20)% of m g h 

0.8 × m g h 

It will rebound with this energy

Let the height obtained after rebound h' 

So, max potential energy obtained 

m g h' = 0.8 × m g h 

⇒ h' = 0.8 × h = 0.8 × 10 m = 8 m
A lorry and a car moving with the same K. E. are brought to rest by applying the same retarding force, then:
Lorry will come to rest in a shorter distance
Car will come to rest in a shorter distance
Both come to rest in a same distance

Both come to rest in a same distance

Stopping distance \(=\frac{\text { kinetic energy }}{\text { retarding force }} \Rightarrow\mathrm{s}=\frac{1 \mathrm{mu}^2}{2 \mathrm{~F}}\)

If lorry and car both possess same kinetic energy and retarding force is also equal then both come to rest in the same distance.

A force of \(100 \mathrm{~N}\) is applied on a mass of \(3 \mathrm{~kg}\) as shown in the figure. The coefficient of friction between the surface and the block is \(\mu=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\). The frictional force acting on the block is:
15 N downwards
25 N upwards
20 N downwards
30 N upwards

Along the horizontal direction,

\(F \cos 30^\circ=N=\frac{100 \sqrt{3}}{2}\)

Along vertical direction, 

\(F \sin 30^\circ-m g=50-30=20 \mathrm{~N}\)

So, friction must act in the downward direction to balance \(20 \mathrm{~N}\) and prevent relative motion between the block and wall.

Limiting friction \(f_{\max }=\mu \mathrm{N}\)

\(\begin{aligned} & =\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \times 100 \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \\ & =50 \mathrm{~N}>20 \mathrm{~N}\end{aligned}\)

Therefore, friction force will only be \(20 \mathrm{~N}\) downwards.

A boy starts pushing a rickshaw of mass \(120 \mathrm{~kg}\) initially at rest. The rickshaw is moving now with a speed of \(18 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}\). How much work has been done by the boy? Avoid the effect of friction.

Given - mass \((\mathrm{m})=120 \mathrm{~kg}\), initial velocity \((\mathrm{u})=0 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}=0 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) and final velocity \((\mathrm{v})=18 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}=5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

The work done by the boy is

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow W=\frac{1}{2} m\left(v^2-u^2\right) \\ & \Rightarrow W=\frac{1}{2} \times 120 \times(25-0)=1500 J\end{aligned}\)
The work-energy theorem equates the change in the kinetic energy of an object to:
The net force applied on the object
The net work done by the force on
The loss in potential energy of the object

Work-energy theorem: The work-energy theorem states that the net work done by the forces on an object equals the change in its kinetic energy.

From the work-energy theorem, the net work done by the forces on an object equals the change in its kinetic energy.

A constant force of \(200 \mathrm{~N}\) is applied on a body of mass \(64 \mathrm{~kg}\) which is initially at rest, till it attains a velocity of \(5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\). How much distance it has travelled?

Given - \(F=200 \mathrm{~N}, \mathrm{~m}=64 \mathrm{~kg}, \mathrm{u}=0 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) (the body is at rest initially), and \(v=5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

According to the Work-energy theorem:

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow F \times s=\frac{1}{2} m\left(v^2-u^2\right) \\ & \Rightarrow 200 \times s=\frac{1}{2} \times 64 \times(25-0) \\ & \Rightarrow s=4 \mathrm{~m}\end{aligned}\)
The kinetic energy of a body increases from \(50 \mathrm{~J}\) to \(150 \mathrm{~J}\) in 10 sec. Then the power of the body is:

Given \(\mathrm{KE}_1=50 \mathrm{~J}, \mathrm{KE}_2=150 \mathrm{~J}\) and \(\mathrm{t}=10 \mathrm{sec}\)

By the work-energy theorem,

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow \mathrm{W}=\Delta \mathrm{KE} \\ & \Rightarrow \mathrm{W}=\mathrm{KE}_2-\mathrm{KE}_1 \\ & \Rightarrow \mathrm{W}=150-50 \\ & \Rightarrow \mathrm{W}=100 \mathrm{~J}\end{aligned}\)

So the power of the body is,

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow P=\frac{W}{t} \\ & \Rightarrow P=\frac{100}{10} \\ & \Rightarrow \mathrm{P}=10 \mathrm{~W}\end{aligned}\)
A porter carries luggage on his head from one end of the platform to the other end which is roughly \(200 \mathrm{~m}\) apart. The work done by the porter on the luggage is zero because:
The weight of the luggage is perpendicular to the distance moved
The porter moved slowly, so work done cannot be accounted
The work done does not depend on the distance moved

In the given case, the force acting on the luggage is its weight i.e. acting downwards due to gravity.

As the porter moves from one end of the platform to the other end, the distance moved is perpendicular to the direction of the force.

Thus, the work done on the luggage will be zero as the weight of the luggage is perpendicular to the distance moved.
If \(100 \mathrm{~N}\) force is applied to a block of mass \(15 \mathrm{~kg}\) at \(60^{\circ}\) angle and displaces it by \(5 \mathrm{~m}\). Then the net work done on the block will be:

Given that,

Force applied on the block, \(\mathrm{F}=100 \mathrm{~N}\)

Mass of block, \(m=15 \mathrm{~kg}\)

The angle at which force is applied, \(\theta=60^{\circ}\)

Displacement, \(d=5 \mathrm{~m}\)

i.e., \({W}=\mathrm{Fd} \cos \theta=100 \times 5 \times \cos 60^{\circ}\)

\(\therefore W=100 \times 5 \times \frac{1}{2}=250 J\)

A body of mass \(20 \mathrm{~kg}\) is at rest. If two forces \(4 \mathrm{~N}\) and \(3 \mathrm{~N}\) at right angle to each other are acting simultaneously on the body, then the work done by the forces in \(12 \mathrm{sec}\) is equal to:

Given \(m=20 \mathrm{~kg}, F_1=4 \mathrm{~N}, \mathrm{~F}_2=3 \mathrm{~N}, \theta=90^{\circ}\) and \(t=12 \mathrm{sec}\)

Since the two forces are acting perpendicular to each other, so the resultant force is given as,

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow F=\sqrt{F_1^2+F_2^2} \\ & \Rightarrow F=\sqrt{4^2+3^2} \\ & \Rightarrow \mathrm{F}=5 \mathrm{~N}\end{aligned}\)

By Newton's second law of motion, the force acting on the body is given as,

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{F}=\mathrm{ma}\)

Where \(\mathrm{m}=\) mass and \(\mathrm{a}=\) acceleration

\(\Rightarrow a=\frac{F}{m}\)

\(\Rightarrow a=\frac{5}{20}\)

\(\Rightarrow a=\frac{1}{4} m / s^2\)

By the second equation of motion, the displacement of the body is given as,

\(\Rightarrow s=u t+\frac{1}{2} a t^2\)

Where \(\mathrm{u}=\) initial velocity, \(\mathrm{a}=\) acceleration and \(\mathrm{t}=\) time

\(\Rightarrow s=0+\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{1}{4} 12^2\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{s}=18 \mathrm{~m}\)

The work done is given as,

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{W}=\mathrm{Fs} \cos \theta\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{W}=5 \times 18 \times \cos 0^{\circ}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{W}=90 \mathrm{~J}\)
If a light and a heavy body have equal kinetic energy, which one has a greater momentum?

Given, kinetic energy is the same.

Let the mass of body 1 is \(m_1\), body 2 is \(m_2\), the momentum of body 1 is \(p_1\) and body 2 is \(p_2\).

\(K=\frac{p_1^2}{2 m_1}=\frac{p_2^2}{2 m_2}\)

Clearly, momentum is directly proportional to the mass if Kientic Enegy is constant.

\(\mathrm{P}=2 \mathrm{mK}\)

\(\mathrm{K}\) and 2 is constant.

\(\mathrm{P} \propto \mathrm{m}\)

So, if mass will increase, momentum will increase.

Two cars of masses \(m_1\) and \(m_2\) are moving with the same kinetic energy. The mass \(m_1\) is more than the \(m_2\). If both the cars have equal retardation when the brakes are applied then the distance covered by both the cars are \(S_1\) and \(\mathrm{S}_2\) respectively, before coming to rest. Then:

Given \(m_1>m_2, \mathrm{a}_1=\mathrm{a}_2=\mathrm{a}\) (retardation)

The kinetic energy of a body is given as,

\(\Rightarrow K E=\frac{1}{2} m \times v^2\).....(1)

Both the cars have equal kinetic energy,

\(\Rightarrow K E_1=K E_2=K E\).....(2)

For the car of mass \(m_1\),

\(\Rightarrow K E=\frac{1}{2} m_1 \times v_1^2\).....(3)

For the car of mass \(m_2\),

\(\Rightarrow K E=\frac{1}{2} m_2 \times v_2^2\).....(4)

By equation 3 and equation 4 ,

\(\Rightarrow m_1 \times v_1^2=m_2 \times v_2^2\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{v_1^2}{v_2^2}=\frac{m_2}{m_1}.....(5)\)

\(\Rightarrow v_1<v_2\)

The third equation of motion is given as,

\(\Rightarrow v^2=u^2+2 a S\)

For mass \(m_1\),

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow 0^2=v_1^2-2 a S_1 \\ & \Rightarrow S_1=\frac{v_1^2}{2 a}....(6)\end{aligned}\)

For mass \(m_2\),

\(\Rightarrow 0^2=v_2^2-2 a S_2\)

\(\Rightarrow S_2=\frac{v_2^2}{2 a}.....(7)\)

By equation 6 and equation 7 ,

\(\Rightarrow \frac{S_1}{S_2}=\frac{v_1^2}{v_2^2}.....(8)\)

By equation 5 and equation 8 ,

\(\Rightarrow S_1<S_2\)
A mass of \(5 \mathrm{~kg}\) is moving along a circular path of radius \(1 \mathrm{~m}\). If the mass moves with 300 revolutions per minute, its kinetic energy would be:

Mass \((\mathrm{m})=5 \mathrm{~kg}\)

Radius \((R)=1 \mathrm{~m}\)

velocity \((v)=300 \mathrm{rpm}=300 / 60=5 \mathrm{rps}\)

The angular speed is given by -

\(\omega=2 \pi v=2 \pi \times 5=10 \pi \mathrm{rads}^{-1}\)

\(v=\omega R\)

\(v=(10 \pi)(1)\)

\(v=10 \pi \mathrm{ms}^{-1}\)

Kinetic energy,

\(K \cdot E=\frac{1}{2} m v^2\)

\(=\frac{1}{2} m \omega^2 R^2\)

\(=\frac{1}{2} \times 5 \times(10 \pi)^2\)

\(\text { KE }=250 \pi^2 \mathrm{~J}\)
If the work done is positive, then which of the following is true?
The final kinetic energy increases by the amount of the work
The initial kinetic energy is more than final kinetic energy
Work energy theorem is not valid anymore

We know that, \(W=\Delta K E=K E_{\text {final }}-K E_{\text {initial }}\)

So, if the work done is positive, the final kinetic energy increases by the amount of the work.
A bullet when fired at a fixed target has its speed decreased to \(50 \%\) after penetrating \(15 {~cm}\) into it. What additional thickness it will penetrate before coming to rest?

Given that the velocity decreases to \(50 \%\) after penetrating \(15 \mathrm{~cm}\), i.e. \(V_2=\frac{V_1}{2}\)

Let \(\mathrm{x}\) be the distance travelled by the bullet through \(15 \mathrm{~cm}\). and \(\mathrm{F}\) be the retarding force

Using work-energy theorem

\(\begin{aligned} & -F x=\frac{1}{2} m \times\left(V_2^2-V_1^2\right) \\ & -F x=\frac{1}{2} m \times\left(\frac{V_1^2}{4}-V_1^2\right)\end{aligned}\)

by solving we get,

\(\frac{1}{2} m V_1^2=\frac{4}{3} F x....(1)\)

Let \(x^{\prime}\) be the distance travelled by the bullet inside the target when the velocity becomes zero.

i.e for \(V_2=0\)

Using work energy theorem we get

\(-F x^{\prime}=\frac{1}{2} m\left(0^2-V_1^2\right)\)

\(\frac{1}{2} m V_1^2=F x^{\prime} \ldots \ldots \ldots . .\mathrm(2)\)

From equation \((1)\) and \((2)\)

\(F x^{\prime}=\frac{4}{3} F x\)

Given \(x=15 \mathrm{~cm}\)

\(x^{\prime}=\frac{4}{3} \times 15\)

we get \(x^{\prime}=20 \mathrm{~cm}\)

Therefore the additional thickness bullet will penetrate before coming to rest \(=20-15=5 \mathrm{~cm}\)
only in the presence of an external force
only in the presence of an internal force
only in the presence of an conservative forces

Energy and work are scalar quantities. So, their values depend on the sum of individual work done by the forces. If these forces cause a displacement, it will be accounted for in work done. The work-energy theorem can be applied in the cases of conservative forces, non-conservative forces, internal forces, external forces, and so on. Thus, the work-energy theorem is valid for all types of forces.

A force is acting on a body of mass \(6 \mathrm{~kg}\) such that it causes a displacement of \(\frac{t^2}{4} \mathrm{~m}\) where \(\mathrm{t}\) is a time. The work done by the force in \(2 \mathrm{sec}\) is:

Given \(\mathrm{m}=6 \mathrm{~kg}\) and displacement \(\mathrm{s}=\frac{t^2}{4} \mathrm{~m}\)

We know that the velocity of the object is given as,

\(\Rightarrow v=\frac{d s}{d t}\)

\(\Rightarrow v=\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{t^2}{4}\right)\)

\(\Rightarrow v=\frac{t}{2}\)....(1)

The kinetic energy is given as,

\(\Rightarrow K E=\frac{1}{2} m \times v^2\)

\(\Rightarrow K E=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\frac{t}{2}\right)^2\)

\(\Rightarrow K E=\frac{1}{8} m \times t^2\)....(2)

The kinetic energy at \(t=0 \mathrm{sec}\) is given as,

\(\Rightarrow K E_1=\frac{1}{8} \times 6 \times 0^2\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{KE}_1=0 \mathrm{~J}\)

The kinetic energy at \(\mathrm{t}=2 \mathrm{sec}\) is given as,

\(\Rightarrow K E_2=\frac{1}{8} \times 6 \times 2^2\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{KE}_2=3 \mathrm{~J}\)

By work-energy theorem, the work done by the force in \(2 \mathrm{sec}\) is given as,

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{W}=\Delta \mathrm{KE}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{W}=\mathrm{K} \mathrm{E}_2-\mathrm{KE}_1\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{W}=3-0\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{W}=3 \mathrm{~J}\)

A body 'A' of mass \(5 \mathrm{~kg}\) and a body ' \(B\) ' of mass \(10 \mathrm{~kg}\) are dropped simultaneously from a height of \(15 \mathrm{~m}\). Calculate the ratio of their K.E., \(\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{A}} / \mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{B}}\) when they are \(10 \mathrm{~m}\) above the ground. (Take \(\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\) )

Given that:

Mass of \(A\left(m_A\right)=5 \mathrm{~kg}\)

Mass of \(B\left(m_B\right)=10 \mathrm{~kg}\)

Height \((H)=15 \mathrm{~m}\)

Initial \(P E_A=m_A g H=5 \times 10 \times 15=750 \mathrm{~J}\)

Initial \(P E_B=m_B g H=10 \times 10 \times 15=1500 \mathrm{~J}\)

When they come to \(10 \mathrm{~m}\) height:

Final \(\mathrm{PE}^{\prime} \mathrm{A}=\mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{A}} \mathrm{gh}=5 \times 10 \times 10=500 \mathrm{~J}\)

Final \(PE'B =m_B g h=10 \times 10 \times 10=1000 \mathrm{~J}\)

\(K E\) of \(A\left(K_A\right)=P E_A-P E_A^{\prime}=750-500=250 \mathrm{~J}\)

\(K E\) of \(B\left(K_B\right)=P E_B-P E_B^{\prime}=1500-1000=500 \mathrm{~J}\)

So \(\frac{K_A}{K_B}=\frac{250}{500}=\frac{1}{2}\)
Find the potential energy gained by a body of mass \(50 \mathrm{~kg}\), if it is raised by \(10 \mathrm{~m}\). (use \(\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\) )

Given that: the mass of body \(50 \mathrm{~kg}\),

Height covered \(10 \mathrm{~m}, \mathrm{~g}=\) \(10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\).

Potential energy \(=\) mass \(\times\) acceleration due to gravity \((\mathrm{g}) \times\) height covered

P. E. \(=m \times g \times h=50 \times 10 \times 10=5000\) Joule.

An ice rock of mass \(50 \mathrm{~kg}\) falls from the height \(100 \mathrm{~m}\). How much potential energy will be lost when it reaches the height of \(10 \mathrm{~m} ?\left(\mathrm{~g}=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\right)\)

Given that the initial height is \(h_i=100 \mathrm{~m}\); final height \(h_f=10\) \(\mathrm{m}\); mass \(\mathrm{m}=50 \mathrm{~kg}\)

Loss in potential energy is given by:

\(P E_f-P E_i=m g h_f-m g h_i\)

\(\Delta P E=50 \times 10 \times 10-50 \times 10 \times 100=-45000 \mathrm{~J}=-45 \mathrm{KJ}\)
When a spring is suspended with \(100 \mathrm{gm}\) mass, it is stretched by \(1 \mathrm{~cm}\). Find the spring constant. \(\left(\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\right)\)

Given that spring is stretched due to \(100 \mathrm{gm}=0.1 \mathrm{Kg}\) mass. So here spring force will be weight of the mass.

\(W=F_s=0.1 \times 10=1 \mathrm{~N}\)

Spring is stretched by \(=1 \mathrm{~cm}=0.01 \mathrm{~m}\)

\(F_s=W=-k x\)

\(1=k \times 0.01\)

\(k=100 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}\)
Work done by spring force depends on___________.

We know that spring force is given by:

\(F_{\mathrm{s}}=-\mathrm{kx}\)

So work done by it for moving an object from \(x_1\) to \(x_2\)

\(W=\int_{x_1}^{x_2} F \cdot d x=\int_{x_1}^{x_2}(-k x) \cdot d x=\left[\frac{-k x^2}{2}\right]_{x_1}^{x_2}\)

\(W=\frac{k x_1^2}{2}-\frac{k x_2^2}{2}\)

So work done by spring force depends only on the endpoints, not on the path of motion.
Which of the following statement is correct regarding electric energy?
Electrical energy is a type of kinetic energy caused by moving electric charges.
Electrical energy is a type of potential energy caused by having electric charges.
Electrical energy is a type of chemical energy caused by having electric charges.
Electrical energy is a type of chemical energy caused by moving electric charges.
Electric energy: The kinetic energy caused by moving electric charges is called electric energy. If the charges move faster, the more electrical energy they will carry.
When a dam is made on the way of a river, the energy of river water is transformed in the form of:

The river is flowing, it has speed. So it will have kinetic energy.

When the dam is made of the way of the river, water gets collected and gradually attains a height.

This way it attains potential energy due to its position. So When a dam is made on the way of a river, kinetic energy is transformed into potential energy.
A particle has initial velocity \((2 \vec{\imath}+3 \vec{\jmath})\) and acceleration \((0.3 \vec{\imath}+0.2 \vec{\jmath})\). The magnitude of velocity after 10 seconds will be:

Given,

\(-v=(2 \vec{\imath}+3 \vec{\jmath}), a=(0.3 \vec{\imath}+0.2 \vec{\jmath})\)

We know that,

\(\Rightarrow {v}={u}+{at} \)

\(\Rightarrow v=(2 \vec{\imath}+3 \vec{\jmath})+(0.3 \vec{\imath}+0.2 \vec{\jmath}) \times 10 \)

\(\Rightarrow v=5 \vec{\imath}+5 \vec{\jmath} \)

\(\Rightarrow|v|=\sqrt{5^2+5^2} \)

\( \Rightarrow v=5 \sqrt{2}\) units
The process of splitting a vector into two or more vectors in such a way that their combined effect is same as that of the given vector called:

Resolution of vectors is the process of splitting a vector into two or more vectors in such a way that their combined effect is the same as that of the given vectors. The vectors into which the given vector is split are called Components of vectors.

Vertical component \(\left({F}_{{y}}\right)={F} \operatorname{Sin} \theta\)

Horizontal component \(\left(F_x\right)=F \operatorname{Cos} \theta\)
A body is simultaneously given two velocities, one \(30 {~m}/{s}\) due east and other is \(40 {~m}/{s}\) due north . Find the resultant velocity.

Let the body start from \(\mathrm{O}\), as shown in figure


\(\vec{V}_A=\overrightarrow{O A}=30 {~m}/{s}\), due East

\(\vec{V}_B=\overrightarrow{A B}=40 {~m}/{s}\), due north

According to the parallelogram, \(\overrightarrow{O B}\) is the resultant velocity.

To find the resultant velocity of its magnitude is given by:

\( R=\sqrt{A^2+B^2} \)

\(v=\sqrt{v_A^2+v_B^2}=\sqrt{30^2+40^2}=50 {~m}/{s}\)
For a projectile the angle between the velocity and the \(x\)-axis as a function of time is:

If a projectile is launched with an initial velocity \({v}_0\), at an angle \(\theta\) from the horizontal plane, then its vertical position can be found from its horizontal position and is given by:

\(y=x\) \(\tan \theta-\frac{g x^2}{2 v_0^2 \cos ^2 \theta} \)


\( y=\) vertical position \(({m}) \), \(x=\) horizontal position \(({m}) \)

\({v}_0=\) initial velocity (combined components, \(({m} / {s})\)

\({g}=\) acceleration due to gravity (\(9.80 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2)\)

\(\theta=\) angle of the initial velocity from the horizontal plane (radians or degrees) 

Here \({u}_{{ox}}={u} \cos \theta, {a}_{{x}}=0, {t}={t}\) and \({v}_{{ox}}=?\)

According to Kinematic equations for uniformly accelerated motion,

\({v}_{{x}}={u}_{{x}}+{a}_{{x}} {t} \)

\({v}_{{x}}={u} \cos \theta\)

Similarly, \({u}_{{oy}}={u} \sin \theta, {a}_{{x}}=-{g},{t}={t}\) and \({v}_{{y}}=\) ?

\(\Rightarrow v_y=u_{0 y}-g t \)

\(\Rightarrow v_y=u \sin \theta-g t\)


Now, let PR make an angle \(\beta\) with the horizontal direction.

In \(\triangle {RPL}\),

\( \tan \beta=\frac{R L}{P L}=\frac{v_y}{v_z} \)

\(\Rightarrow \tan \beta=\frac{R L}{P L}=\frac{u \sin \theta-g t}{u \cos \theta} \)

\(\Rightarrow \tan \beta=\frac{u_{v y} g t}{u_{v x}} \)

\(\Rightarrow \beta=\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{u_{o y}-g t}{u_{o x}}\right)\)
A wooden block is acted upon by two mutually perpendicular forces of magnitudes \(F_1\) and \(F_2\) on one of its corners. Which of the following is the net force acting on the wooden block?

According to thr triangle law of vector addition, the magnitude and direction of the resultant are calculated as follows:

\(\vec{R}=\vec{P}+\vec{Q}\)

The magnitude of \({R}=\sqrt{P^2+Q^2+2 P Q \cos \theta}\)

The two forces act on the corner i.e. same point.

Since the two forces are perpendicular to each other, \(\theta=90^{\circ}\)

So, the net force \(=\sqrt{F_1^2+F_2^2+2 F_1. F_2 \cos 90^{\circ}}=\sqrt{F_1^2+F_2^2}\)
Mohan is sitting inside a moving train. He throws a ball vertically upwards. Seema is standing on the platform watching Mohan through the train window. She will observe the motion of the ball as:

For Seema standing on the platform, the ball has two velocities: the vertical component of velocity (as the ball is thrown vertically upwards by Mohan) and the horizontal component(due to the velocity of the train in the horizontal direction). So, Seema will observe projectile motion.
A gun fires two bullets at \(60^{\circ}\) and \(30^{\circ}\) with the horizontal the bullets strike at same horizontal distance. The maximum heights for the two bullets are in the ratio:

As we know, the maximum height attained by the particle \(\mathrm{H}=\frac{\mathrm{u}^2 \sin ^2 \theta}{2 \mathrm{~g}}\)

Given that, the bullets are fired at the same initial speed.

\(\frac{\mathrm{H}}{\mathrm{H}^{\prime}}=\frac{\mathrm{u}^2 \sin ^2 60^{\circ}}{2 \mathrm{~g}} \times \frac{2 \mathrm{~g}}{\mathrm{u}^2 \sin ^2 30^{\circ}} \)

\(\frac{\mathrm{H}}{\mathrm{H}^{\prime}}=\frac{\sin ^2 60^{\circ}}{\sin ^2 30^{\circ}}=\frac{3}{1}=3:1\)

The angles of projection of three projectiles \(\mathrm{A}, \mathrm{B}\) and \(\mathrm{C}\) are \(45^{\circ}, 30^{\circ}\) and \(90^{\circ}\) respectively with the horizontal direction. Horizontal range covered by the projectiles is:

Given angle of projection for \(\mathrm{A}, \mathrm{B}\) and \(\mathrm{C}\) with respect to horizontal are \(45^{\circ}, 30^{\circ}\) and \(90^{\circ}\) respectively.

Horizontal range is given by \(\mathrm R=\frac{v_0^2 \sin 2 \theta}{g}\)

For maximum horizontal range \(\mathrm{R}=\mathrm{R}_{\max }, \sin 2 \theta=1\)

\(\Rightarrow 2 \theta=90^{\circ}, \theta=45^{\circ}\)

For minimum horizontal range \(, \mathrm{R}=\mathrm{R}_{\min }, \sin 2 \theta=0\)

\(\Rightarrow 2 \theta=180^{\circ} \cdot \theta=90^{\circ}\)

So, the horizontal range is maximum for \(45^{\circ}\) and minimum for \(90^{\circ}\).
Two forces of magnitudes \(2 \mathrm{~F}\) and \(\sqrt{2} \mathrm{~F}\) act such that the resultant force is \(\sqrt{10 } \mathrm{~F}\). Then find the angle between the two forces.

The magnitude and direction of the resultant vector are calculated as follows:

\(\vec{R}=\vec{P}+\vec{Q}\)

The magnitude of \(\mathrm{R}=\sqrt{P^2+Q^2+2 P Q \cos \theta}\)

Given that:

The magnitude of the resultant \(R=\sqrt{10  } F\)

Let the two forces be \(P=2 F\) and \(Q=\sqrt{2} F\)

The angle between the two forces is \(\theta\).
