\(\sqrt{P^2+Q^2+2 P Q \cos \theta}=R \)

\(\sqrt{(2 F)^2+(\sqrt{2} F)^2+2(2 F)(\sqrt{2}F) \cos \theta}=\sqrt{10} F \)

\(\Rightarrow 4 \sqrt{2} F^2 \cos \theta=4 F^2 \)

\(\Rightarrow \cos \theta=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \)

\( \Rightarrow \theta=45^{\circ}\)
What is/are the assumption(s) while studying the projectile motion?
There is almost no effect due to curvature and rotation of earth.
Acceleration due to gravity is not constant in magnitude and direction at all points of projectile motion.

An object that is in flight after being thrown or projected is called a projectile. Assumptions made in the study of projectile motion:

  • There is no frictional resistance to air.
  • There is almost no effect due to the curvature and rotation of the earth.
  • Acceleration due to gravity is constant in magnitude and direction at all points of projectile motion.
The vector sum of three vectors \(\vec{A}, \vec{B}\) and \(\vec{C}\) is zero. If \(\hat{i}\) and \(\hat{j}\) are unit vectors in the directions of \(\vec{A}\) and \(\vec{B}\) respectively, then:
\(\vec{C}\) should be in the plane of \(\hat{i}\) and \(\hat{j}\)

As the vector sum of three vectors \(\vec{A}, \vec{B}\) and \(\vec{C}\) is zero, so the polygon formed by taking vectors \(\vec{A}, \vec{B}\) and \(\vec{C}\) in the same order must be closed.Since there are three vectors so the polygon will be a triangle. \(\hat{i}\) and \(\hat{j}\) are unit vectors in the directions of \(\vec{A}\) and \(\vec{B}\) respectively, so the direction of vector \(A\) will be along the \({x}\)-axis,  the direction of vector \({B}\) will be along the \({y}\)-axis and the direction of vector \({C}\)  should be in the plane of \(\hat{i}\) and \(\hat{j}\).
When a motion is described as relative, what does it mean?
It means that motion is independent of the frame of reference.
It means that motion depends on the frame of reference selected.
It means that motion of any object is described relative to the motion of Earth.

When we measure the velocity of an object, the reference frame is taken to be the ground or the earth. For example, if you are inside a moving bus and the bus is moving at a speed of \(50 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}\), then your speed according to another passenger sitting on that bus is zero. According to him, you are not moving. But if someone observes you from outside the bus, standing on the ground, according to him, you are moving with \(50 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}\) as you are on the bus and the bus is moving with \(50 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}\). So, the motion observed by the observer depends on the location (reference frame) of the observer. This type of motion is called relative motion.

If a motion is described as relative, it means its motion depends on the reference frame from which the motion is observed. It means that motion is relative to the motion of the reference frame.

A boat \(A\) is moving towards the north with a velocity of \(100 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}\) and boat \(B\) is moving towards the south with a velocity of \(50 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}\) such that both are moving towards each other, what will be the velocity of boat A with respect to an observer in boat \(B\)? (Consider boat is moving on still water)

Velocity is not always a fixed definite quantity it may change from one frame of reference to another. If an object is travelling in a straight line parallel to each other then there exist two cases of relative velocity

Case 1: The relative velocity of 2 objects moving toward each other in opposite direction is given by

\({v}_{\text {relative }}=\left|{v}_1+{v}_2\right|\)

Case 2: The relative velocity of 2 objects moving in the opposite direction away from each other as given below

\({v}_{\text {relative }}=\left|{v}_1-{v}_2\right|\)

Velocity of boat \(1, {v}_1=100 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}\)

Velocity of boat 2, \({v}_2=50 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}\)

Now relative velocity of boat \(A\) with respect to a passenger sitting inside train \(B\) can be given as

\(v_{\text {relative }}=v_1+v_2=100+50=150 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}\)
Two players in a field are running with the same velocity \(v\) in the opposite direction to each other. Find the velocity of one player with respect to others.

The relative velocity of two objects moving towards each other in opposite direction is given by:

\(v_{\text {relative }}=\left|v_1+v_2\right|\)

relative velocity \(={v} _1+{v}_ 2\)

Given that,

The velocity of each player \(={v}_1={v}_2={v}\)

Both players are moving in the opposite direction to each other:

So relative velocity \(=\left|v_1+v_2\right|=v+v=2 v\)
Which one of the following is not a scalar quantity?

Power is the rate of energy transfer with respect to time, so it is a scalar quantity. Density is the amount of mass contained in a given volume of the substance, so it is a scalar quantity. Kinetic energy is the energy possessed by an object by virtue of its motion, so it is a scalar quantity.

Torque is a turning effect due to a force applied on an object and causes rotatory motion. The direction of rotation depends on the direction of the force. Thus, torque is a vector quantity.
The basic difference between a scalar and vector is one of:

Scalar quantity gives you an idea about how much of an object is there, but vector quantity gives you an indication of how much of an object there is and that also in which direction. So, the main difference between these two quantities is associated with the direction, i.e. scalars do not have direction but vectors do.

Vectors can be added by triangle law of addition.

Vector addition is defined as the geometrical sum of two or more vectors as they do not follow regular laws of algebra. Triangle law of vector addition states that when two vectors are represented as two sides of the triangle with the order of magnitude and direction, then the third side of the triangle represents the magnitude and direction of the resultant vector.
Magnitude of displacement of a particle is:
is equal to the path length of the particle between two points.
is less than the path length of the particle between two points.
is either less or equal to the path length of the particle between two points.
is more than the path length of the particle between two points.

The magnitude of displacement of a particle is the shortest distance between its initial and final positions. It is either less or equal to the path length of the particle between two points.

The maximum possible value for displacement is the distance travelled, so it cannot be of a greater value than distance (path length). If two displacements in the same direction are added, then the magnitude of their sum will be equal to the distance travelled.
Two forces of \( 5\) and \(10\) dynes respectively are acting on a particle, the resultant force never can be:

The Resultant of two vectors is given by:

\(R^2=\left(A^2+B^2+2 A B \cos \theta\right)\)

where \({R}\) is the resultant vector, \({A}\) and \({B}\) are the two vectors, and \(\theta\) is the angle between two vectors.

Maximum value of \(R=A+B\) when \(\theta=0^{\circ}\)

Minimum value of \(R=A-B\) when \(\theta=180^{\circ}\)

Given forces are \(= 5\) and \(10\) dynes.

The maximum value of the resultant \(R=A+B=10+5=15\) dynes

The minimum value of the resultant \(R=A-B=10-5={5}\) dynes

The resultant force can be between \(5\) dynes to \(15\) dynes.

So the result could not be 4 dynes.
Upon which of the following factors the equation of trajectory of a projectile motion is not dependent?

A projectile is an object that is given an initial velocity, and is acted on by gravity. The path the object follows is called its trajectory. 

If a projectile is launched with an initial velocity \({v}_0\), at an angle \(\theta\) from the horizontal plane, then its vertical position can be found from its horizontal position and is given by:

\({y}={x} \tan \theta-\frac{{gx}^2}{2 {v}_0^2 \cos ^2 \theta}\)

\(y=\) vertical position \((m)\)

\({x}=\) horizontal position \((\mathrm{m})\)

\({v}_0=\) initial velocity (combined components, \(\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\) )

\({g}=\) acceleration due to gravity \(\left(9.80 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\right)\)

\(\theta=\) angle of the initial velocity from the horizontal plane (radians or degrees)

So we can say that the equation depends on the angle of projection, initial velocity and acceleration due to gravity. But mass and density of an object are not related to the trajectory equation.

A man throws a ball at an angle of 15 degree with a horizontal, with a velocity of 20 \(\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\). Then how far will the ball hit the ground (in meters)? (use \(\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\) )

Given 

\(-\mathrm{u}=20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) and \(\theta=15^{\circ}\)

The mathematical expression of the horizontal range is;

\( R=\frac{v^2 \sin 2 \theta}{g} \)

\(\Rightarrow R=\frac{20^2 \times \sin 2 \times 15^{\circ}}{10}\)

\(\Rightarrow R=\frac{400 \times \frac{1}{2}}{10}=20 \mathrm{~m}\)

A projectile projected at \(30^{\circ}\) with the horizontal achieves a horizontal range \(\mathrm{R}\). It can achieve the same horizontal range \(\mathrm{R}\) if projected (with the same initial velocity) at which of the following angle \(\alpha\) with the vertical?
It cannot achieve the same horizontal range for any angle \(60^{\circ}\) with the vertical.

Horizontal projected angle \(=30^{\circ}\), Range \(=R=R_1=R_2\)

Let the projection velocity \(=\mathrm{u}\)

When thrown at angle \(\theta=30^{\circ}\) with horizontal

\({R}_1=\frac{{u}^2 \sin 2\left(30^{\circ}\right)}{{g}}=\frac{{u}^2 \sin 60^{\circ}}{{g}}\cdots(1)  \)

When thrown with an angle \(\alpha\) with vertical

\({R}_2=\frac{{u}^2 \sin 2\left(90^{\circ}-\alpha\right)}{{g}}=\frac{{u}^2 \sin \left(180^{\circ}-2 \alpha\right)}{{g}} \)

\({R}_2=\frac{{u}^2 \sin 2 \alpha}{{g}}-\cdots(2) \quad\left(\operatorname{Sin}\left(180^{\circ}-\theta\right)=\sin \theta\right)\)

As \(R_1=R_2\)

\( \frac{{u}^2 \sin 60^{\circ}}{{g}}=\frac{{u}^2 \sin 2 \alpha}{{g}} \Rightarrow \alpha=30^{\circ} \)

\(\alpha=30^{\circ}\)

The ceiling of a long hall is \(25 \mathrm{~m}\) high. What is the maximum horizontal distance that a ball thrown with a speed of \(40 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) can go without hitting the ceiling of the hall?

Given, \(u=40 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} ; \mathrm{h}=25 \mathrm{~m} ; \mathrm{R}=\) ?

Let \(\theta\) be the angle of projection with the horizontal direction to have the maximum range, with maximum height \(=25 \mathrm{~m}\)

Maximum height is given by:

\(h=25=\frac{u^2 \sin ^2 \theta}{2 g}=\frac{(40)^2 \sin ^2 \theta}{2 \times 9.8} \)

\(\sin \theta=\sqrt{\frac{25 \times 2 \times 9.8}{40^2}}=0.5534 \)

\(\theta=33.6^{\circ}\)

Horizontal Range is given by:

\(R=\frac{u^2 \sin 2 \theta}{g} \)

\(=\frac{(40)^2 \times \sin 2 \times 33.6}{9.8}=\frac{(40)^2 \times \sin 2 \times 33.6}{9.8}\)

\(R==\frac{1600 \times 0.9219}{9.8}\)

\( R=150.5 \mathrm{~m}\)
In a projectile motion, maximum horizontal range is obtained at the projection angle of _________ with horizontal.

Horizontal Range \(\mathrm{R}=\frac{u^2 \sin 2 \theta}{g}\) will change according to the speed and angle of projection \(\theta\).

For range \({R}=\frac{u^2 \sin 2 \theta}{g}\) to be maximum, \(\sin 2 \theta\) should be maximum.

\(\sin 2 \theta=1 \Rightarrow \sin 2 \theta=\sin 90^{\circ}\)

\( 2 \theta=90\)

\(\theta=45^{\circ}\)

So, at an angle of \(45^{\circ}\), the maximum horizontal range is obtained.
Find the angle between the two vectors \(2 i+4 j-k\) and \(4 i-j+k\).

Given

\(\vec{a}=2 i+4 j-k\) and \(\vec{b}=4 i-j+k\).

The dot product is defined as:

\(\vec{a} \cdot \vec{b}=(2 i+4 j-k) \cdot(4 i-j+k)\)

\(=(2)(4)+(4)(-1)+(-1)(1)=8-4-1=3\)

The magnitude of vectors is given by:

\(|a|=\sqrt{\left(2^2+4^2+(-1)^2\right)}=\sqrt{21}=4.5 \)

\(|b|=\sqrt{\left.4^2+(-1)^2+(1)^2\right)}=\sqrt{18}=4.24\)

The angle between the two vectors is:

\(\theta=\cos ^{-1} \frac{3}{(4.5)(4.24)} \)

\( \theta=\cos ^{-1} \frac{3}{18.9} \)

\(\theta=\cos ^{-1} 0.16\)
Two equal forces acting on a body in different directions have their resultant equal to the magnitude of one of the force. Find the angle between them?

Let's assume two forces \(A\) and \(B\) having two equal force have their resultant equal to either.

\({A}={B}={R} \)

The magnitude of resultant of two vectors is given by:

\(R=\sqrt{A^2+B^2+2 A B \cos \theta}\)

Where \(A\) and \(B\) are the magnitudes of two vectors and \(\theta\) is the angle between them

\( R=\sqrt{A^2+B^2+2 A B \cos \theta} \)

\(A=\sqrt{A^2+A^2+2 A A \cos \theta} \)

\(A^2=2 A^2(1+\cos \theta) \)

\(1+\cos \theta=\frac{1}{2} \)

\(\cos \theta=-\frac{1}{2}, \text { Since }\left(\cos -\frac{1}{2}=120^{\circ}\right)\)

So, the angle between them \(\theta=120^{\circ}\)
Any vector in an arbitrary direction can be replaced by:
Two or three vectors perpendicular to each other and have the magnitude of resultant more than that of the original vector
Two or three vectors parallel to each other and have the magnitude of resultant equal to the original vector but direction opposite to it.
Two or three arbitrary vectors whose resultant is equal to the original vector (Both magnitude and direction)
It is impossible to replace a vector.

Any vector in an arbitrary direction can be replaced by two or three arbitrary vectors that have original vectors as their resultant, such that the laws of vector addition are followed. Two or more parallel vectors can be used to represent a single vector, such that the magnitude of the resultant is the difference of magnitudes of arbitrary vectors. The direction is the same as that vector whose magnitude is the greatest among the arbitrary ones.
A body moves along the circumference of a circular track of radius \(\mathrm{R}\). What is the displacement of the body when it covers \(\frac{3}{4}\) the of its circumference?

Let us assume that the body starts the journey from point \(Q\) and reaches point \(T\) after completing \(3 / 4\) of the circumference.


Now, the initial point is \(\mathrm{P}\) and the final point is \(\mathrm{T}\). Hence, displacement is equal to the distance QT.

From the figure,

\({OT}={R} , {OQ}={R}\)

Therefore,

\(\Rightarrow Q T=\sqrt{O Q^2+O T^2}\)

\(=\sqrt{R^2+R^2}=\sqrt{2 R^2}=R \sqrt{2}\)
If three students traveled from point A to B but took different paths, which one of the following have highest displacement?

The displacement is the shortest distance covered by a body and distance is an actual path covered by a moving object. If all three students start from point A and end there journey at point B, thus all will have same displacement.
A car moves in a circular path of radius \(30 \mathrm{~m}\) and takes \(5 \mathrm{sec}\) to reach the diametral end, then the average velocity of the car to reach the diametral end is:

We know that, 

\( v=\frac{d x}{d t}\)

Where \(\mathrm{dx}=\) displacement , and \(\mathrm{dt}=\) time

Here \(\mathrm{R}=30 \mathrm{~m}\), and \(\mathrm{dt}=5 \mathrm{sec}\)

When a car moves along the circular parts then the shortest distance between the two diametral ends is given as,

\( \Rightarrow d x=2 R \)

\(\Rightarrow d x=2 \times 30 \)

\(\Rightarrow d x=60 \mathrm{~m}\)

So the displacement is \(60 \mathrm{~m}\).

Therefore the average velocity is given as,

\(\Rightarrow v=\frac{d x}{d t} \)

\(\Rightarrow v=\frac{60}{5}=12 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{sec}\)
At which point the acceleration of a particle executing SHM is maximum and what will be its value?

The equation of displacement in SHM is given by:

x = A sinωt .........(i)

differentiate eq (i) with respect to time t

v = Aω cosωt

differentiate it with respect to time t

a = -Aω2 sinωt

a = -ω2 A sinωt

a = -ω2 x

\(\vec{a}=-\omega^2 \vec{x}\)

the maximum value of a can be obtained for the maximum value of displacement x.

For SHM displacement is maximum at its extreme point i.e. x = A. So

amax = Aω2

And this maximum value is obtained at x = A or an extreme point.
At which point the speed of a particle executing SHM is maximum and what will be its value?

The equation of velocity in SHM is given by:

\(\left.v=\omega \sqrt{( A^2-x^2}\right.)\)

the max value of \(v\) in this equation can be obtained when \(x=0\)

\( \left.v=\omega \sqrt{( A^2-0^2}\right.) \)

\( v _{\max }= A \omega\)

And \(x =0\) means mean position or equilibrium position.

So at the mean position, the speed of a particle executing SHM is maximum and its value is \(A \omega\).

A block of mass M is attached to the lower end of a vertical spring. The spring is hung from a ceiling and has a force constant value k. The mass is released from rest with the spring initially unstretched. The maximum extension produced in the length of the spring will be:

Applying conservation of energy

Potential energy gained = Potential energy lost

\((\frac{1} { 2}) kx ^2= mgx\)

\(x =\frac {2 mg} { k}\)
Two simple Harmonic Motions of angular frequency 100 and 1000 rad s–1 have the same displacement amplitude. The ratio of their maximum accelerations is:

Given Angular Frequency of two Simple Harmonic Motions \(\omega_1=100 \text { and } \omega_2=1000\)

Amplitude displacement of both SHM is the Same (A).

Acceleration of SHM -1 given as \(a _1=-\omega_1^2 A -\)  (1)

Acceleration of SHM -2 is given as \(a_2=-\omega_2^2 A-\) (2)

Ratio of Equation (1) and Equation (2) is

\(\frac{a_1}{a_2}=\frac{-\omega_1^2 A}{-\omega_2^2 A}\)

Putting the Values of \(\omega_1\) and \(\omega_2\) we get

\( \frac{a_1}{a_2}=\frac{-\omega_1^2 A}{-\omega_2^2 A} \)

\( \frac{a_1}{a_2}=\frac{100^2}{1000^2}=\frac{1}{10^2}\)
A particle is executing SHM along a straight line. Its velocities at distances \(x _1\) and \(x _2\) from the mean position are \(V _1\) and \(V _2\), respectively. Its time period is:

Given that velocities at distances \(x_1\) and \(x_2\) from the mean position are

\(V_1\) and \(V_2\),

So

\(v_1 =\omega \sqrt{A^2-x_1^2}\)

\(v_1^2 =\omega^2\left(A^2-x_1^2\right) \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \) (i)

\(v_2 =\omega \sqrt{A^2-x_2^2} \)

\(v_2^2 =\omega^2\left(A^2-x_2^2\right) \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots\) (ii)

subtract (i) - (ii)

\( v_1^2-v_2^2=\omega^2\left(x_2^2-x_1^2\right) \)

\( \omega^2=\frac{v_1^2-v_2^2}{x_2^2-x_1^2}\)

Since \(\omega=\frac{2 \pi}{T}\)

\(T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{x_2^2-x_1^2}{V_1^2-V_2^2}}\)
The displacement of a particle in simple harmonic motion in one time period is: (A is the amplitude)

The time period is the time required for a body in SHM to starting from the mean position and coming back to it.  So, after the interval of this time period, the body comes back to its initial position.

The initial position is equal to the final position hence net displacement is zero.
When a simple pendulum is rotated in a vertical plane with constant angular velocity, the centripetal force is:

Centripetal force is that force which is required to move a body in a circular path with uniform speed.

The force acts on the body along the radius and towards the centre.

Formulae for centripetal force is: \(F=\frac{m v^2}{r^2}\)

Where F = Centripetal force, m = mass of the body, v = velocity of the body and r = radius

In a vertical circular motion, centripetal force remains same at all points on circular path and always directed towards the center of circular path.
A car is moving with 30 m/s velocity in 500 m radius path. If the velocity is increasing by 2 m/sec2 then the resultant acceleration will be :

Given that,

\( v=30 m / s \)

\(r=500 m\)

Tangential acceleration \(=2 m / s ^2\)

centripetal acceleration \(= \frac{v ^2} {r} =900 / 500=1.8 m / s ^2\)

Net acceleration \(=\sqrt{a_T^2+a^2C}=\sqrt{2^2+1.8^2}=2.7 m / s ^2\)
Motion of a particle can be described in x-direction by X = a sin (ωt), and y-direction by Y = b Cos (ωt). The particle is moving on:

Given that,

\( X=a \sin (\omega t)\)

\( \frac{X} a=\sin (\omega t) \quad \ldots 1) \)

\( Y=b \cos (\omega t) \)

\(\frac{Y} b=\cos (\omega t) \quad \ldots 2)\)

Square the both equations 1 and 2 and add them, we get

\(\left(\frac{x}{a}\right)^2+\left(\frac{y}{b}\right)^2=(\operatorname{Sin} w t)^2+(\operatorname{Cos} w t)^2=\operatorname{Sin}^2 w t+\operatorname{Cos}^2 w t=1\)

Since \(\operatorname{Sin}^2 \theta+\operatorname{Cos}^2 \theta=1\)

\(\frac{x^2}{a^2}+\frac{y^2}{b^2}=1\)

This is the equation of ellipse. Thus motion of the particle can be described as an elliptical path.
A To and Fro motion where the restoring force on the moving object is directly proportional to the object's displacement and acts towards the object's equilibrium position is known as ____________.

Simple harmonic motion occurs when the restoring force is directly proportional to the displacement from equilibrium.

F α -x

Where F = force and x = the displacement from equilibrium.

The negative sign tells that direction of force is opposite to displacement from the equilibrium position i.e. towards the equilibrium position.

It is a to and fro motion about its equilibrium position.

Which of the following is/are the characteristics of simple harmonic motion.

(i) The total energy is conserved.

(ii) The acceleration is directly proportional to the displacement and is directed towards its mean position.

(iii) The simple harmonic motion cannot be represented using sinusoidal functions.

(iv) There are a maximum and minimum displacement about the equilibrium point.

Characteristics of simple harmonic motion:

  • SHM is regularly repeating. i.e., SHM is periodic in nature.
  • The acceleration is directly proportional to the displacement and is directed towards the mean position.
  • The total energy is conserved in a simple harmonic motion.
  • SHM can be represented using periodic functions like sine or cosine functions.
  • From inspecting the table it is clear statements (i), (ii) & (iv) are correct.

Two bodies M and N of equal masses are suspended from two separate massless springs of spring constant k1 and k2 respectively. If the two bodies oscillate vertically such that their maximum velocities are equal, the ratio of the amplitude of vibration of M to that of N is:

Let \(V_1=\) Velocity of the first particle, \(V_2=\) Velocity of the second particle, \(\omega_1=\) Angular velocity of the first particle, \(\omega_2=\) Angular velocity of the second particle, \(T_1=\) Time period of the first particle, \(T_2=\) Time period of the second particle, \(a_1=\) Amplitude of the first particle, and \(a_2=\) Amplitude of the second particle

The velocity of the first and second particle is given by:

\( \Rightarrow V _1= a _1 w _1\)

\(\Rightarrow V _2= a _2 w _2\)

The value of \(\omega_1, \omega_2\), and \(T_1, T_2\) is given by:

\( \Rightarrow T_1=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{m}{k_1}} \)

\( \Rightarrow T_2=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{m}{k_2}} \)

\( \Rightarrow \omega_1=\frac{2 \pi}{T_1}\)

Substituting the value of \(T_1\) in the equation \(\omega_1\), the equation of \(\omega_1\) becomes

\( \Rightarrow \omega_1=\frac{2 \pi}{2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{m}{k_1}}}\)

\( \Rightarrow \omega_1=\sqrt{\frac{k_1}{m}}\)

Similarly, the value \(\omega_2\) can be written as

\(\Rightarrow \omega_2=\sqrt{\frac{k_2}{m}}\)

At the maximum velocity \(V_1=V_2\)

\( \Rightarrow a_1 \omega_1=a_2 \omega_2 \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{a_1}{a_2}=\frac{\omega_2}{\omega_1}\)

Substituting the value of \(\omega_1\) and \(\omega_2\) in the above equation

\(\Rightarrow \frac{a_1}{a_2}=\frac{\sqrt{\frac{k_2}{m}}}{\sqrt{\frac{k_1}{m}}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{a_1}{a_2}=\sqrt{\frac{k_2}{k_1}}\)

The angular frequency and the initial phase of the particle performing simple harmonic motion are \(\pi~ rad / sec\) and \(\frac{\pi}{2}\) rad respectively. The maximum displacement will take place after a time interval of:

Given \(\omega=\pi ~rad / sec\), and \(\phi=\frac{\pi}{2} rad\)

The equation of simple harmonic motion is given as,

\(\Rightarrow y = a \cdot \sin (\omega t +\phi)\)

For maximum displacement,

\( \Rightarrow \sin (\omega t+\phi)=1 \)

\(\Rightarrow \omega t+\phi=\pi \)

\(\Rightarrow \pi t+\frac{\pi}{2}=\pi \)

\(\Rightarrow \pi t=\frac{\pi}{2} \)

\( \Rightarrow t=\frac{1}{2} s e c\)

\( \Rightarrow t=0.5 sec\)

A particle starts to move from an extreme position. If the time period of this simple harmonic motion is T and amplitude is A, find the time taken to move from mean position to displacement \( \frac{\sqrt{ 3} A } 2\).

Given that the time period is T and amplitude is A.

When the particle starts from the extreme position equation of SHM is: x = A cos ωt 

Let particle reach \(x=\frac{3 A }{ 5}\) distance in \(tsec\)

\( \frac{\sqrt{ 3} A } 2= A \cos \omega t \)

\( \frac{\sqrt{3} } 2=\cos \omega t\)

\( \cos \frac{\pi} 6=\cos \omega t \)

\(\frac{\pi} { 6}=\omega t \)

\( \frac{\pi } {6}=(\frac{2 \pi } T) t \)

\( t=\frac{T} {12}\)

A body is executing simple harmonic motion. When its displacements from the mean position are 4 cm and 5 cm, then it has velocities of 10 cm/s and 8 cm/s respectively. The time period of this simple harmonic motion is:

Kinetic Energy when body is moving with velocity 10 cm /s 

Displacement from mean position x = 4 cm

So, we can say 

\(10=\omega \sqrt{\left(A^2-4^2\right)}\)...(1)

Also, when displacement is \(5 cm\), velocity is \(8 cm / s\)

\(8=\omega \sqrt{\left(A^2-5^2\right)}\)...(2)

Dividing (1) by (2)

\(\frac{5}{4}=\frac{\omega \sqrt{A^2-4^2}}{\omega \sqrt{A^2-5^2}} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{5}{4}=\frac{\sqrt{A^2-4^2}}{\sqrt{A^2-5^2}}\)

\( \Rightarrow \frac{25}{16}=\frac{A^2-4^2}{A^2-5^2}\)

\( \Rightarrow 25 A^2-25 \times 5^2=16 A^2-16 \times 4^2 \)

\( \Rightarrow 9 A^2=625-256=36\)

\( \Rightarrow A^2=41\)...(3)

Putting (3) in (1) we get

\( 10=\omega \sqrt{\left(41-4^2\right)} \)

\( \Rightarrow 10=\omega \sqrt{(41-16)} \)

\( \Rightarrow 10=\omega \sqrt{(25)} \)

\(\Rightarrow 10=\omega 5 \)

\(\Rightarrow \omega=0.5 \)

\( \Rightarrow \frac{2 \pi} { T}=0.5 \)

\( \Rightarrow T=2 \pi \times 0.5=\pi\)
The maximum acceleration of a particle executing SHM is given by α. Find its maximum velocity if its time period is T.

Given that maximum acceleration \(=\alpha\) and time period \(=T\)

So, angular frequency \(\omega=\frac{2 \pi}{T}\)

Since maximum acceleration \(=A \omega^2\)

\( \alpha=A \omega^2 \)

\( A=\frac{\alpha } {\omega^2}\)

Now Maximum velocity \(=A \omega\)

put the value from eq. (ii)

Maximum velocity \(=\left(\frac{\alpha }{ \omega^2}\right) \omega=\frac{\alpha } \omega\)

put the value of \(\omega\) from eq (i)

Maximum velocity \(=\frac{\alpha}{\omega}=\frac{\alpha T}{2 \pi}\)
The wave equation is \(y=\sqrt{ } 5 \sin (12 x+\sqrt{3} t+\pi)\). Then which of the following represents the acceleration of the motion:

Given \(-y=\sqrt{5} \sin (12 x+\sqrt{3} t+\pi)\)

The equation of motion of simple harmonic motion is given by

\(\Rightarrow Y = A \operatorname{Sin}( kx +\omega t +\phi)\)

Comparing the given equation with the standard equation we get

\(A=\sqrt{5}, K=12 \text {, and } \omega=\sqrt{3}\)

The general equation of acceleration in simple harmonic motion is given by

\(\Rightarrow a=-\omega^2 y\)

Substitute the value of \(\omega=\sqrt{ } 3\)

The value of acceleration is given by

\( \Rightarrow a=(\sqrt{ 3})^2 y \)

\(\Rightarrow a=3 y\)
Two simple harmonic motions at a right angle to each other with equal amplitude and time periods and having a phase difference of \(\frac{π}{2}\) are superposed. The resultant curve will be:

Given \(a _1= a _2= a , T _1= T _2= T\) and \(\phi=\frac{\pi}{2}\)

We know that angular frequency is given as,

\(\Rightarrow \omega=\frac{2 \pi}{T}\)...(1)

Since \(T_1=T_2=T\),

So by equation 1,

\(\Rightarrow \omega_1=\omega_2=\omega\)...(2)

The equation of first simple harmonic motion is given as,

\(\Rightarrow y_1=\operatorname{asin} \omega t\)...(3)

The equation of second simple harmonic motion is given as,

\( \Rightarrow y_2=\operatorname{asin}(\omega t+\phi) \)

\(\Rightarrow y_2=\operatorname{asin}\left(\omega t+\frac{\pi}{2}\right) \)

\( \Rightarrow y_2=\operatorname{acos} \omega t\)...(4)

By squaring and adding equation 3 and equation 4,

\( \Rightarrow y_1^2+y_2^2=(a \sin \omega t)^2+(a \cos \omega t)^2 \)

\( \Rightarrow y_1^2+y_2^2=a^2\left(\sin ^2 \omega t+\cos ^2 \omega t\right)\)

\( \Rightarrow y_1^2+y_2^2=a^2\)...(5)

Equation 5 is an equation of a circle.
Equation of a particle executing simple harmonic motion is given by- y = a sin(ωt + ϕ). What will be its total phase at any time t?

The equation of displacement y = a sin(ωt + ϕ)

The phase of this equation is (ωt + ϕ).

ϕ is the only initial phase.
An oscillator executes SHM is given by \(y=A\) Sinwt + BCos\(\omega\)t, Find the acceleration of \(SHM\) when \(\omega t =\frac{\pi}{2}\)

Given \(y=A\) Sin \(\omega t+B \operatorname{Cos} \omega t\)

The velocity is given by:

\(\Rightarrow V=\frac{d y}{d t}=\frac{d(A \operatorname{Sin} \omega t+B \operatorname{Cos} \omega t)}{d t}\)

\(\Rightarrow V=A \omega \operatorname{Cos} \omega t-B \omega \operatorname{Sin} \omega t\)

Again differentiating the above equation with respect to \(t\)

\(\Rightarrow a=\frac{d V}{d t}=\frac{d(A \omega C o s \omega t-B \omega \operatorname{Sin} \omega t)}{d t}=-A \omega \times \omega \operatorname{Sin} \omega t-B \omega \times \omega \operatorname{Cos} \omega t \)

\( \Rightarrow a =- A \omega^2 \operatorname{Sin} \omega t - B \omega^2 \operatorname{Cos} \omega t\)

Substituting the value \(\omega t=\frac{\pi}{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow a =- A \omega^2\)

A spring can be used to determine the mass m of an object in two ways: (i) by measuring the extension in the spring due to the object; and (ii) by measuring the oscillation period for the given mass.

Which of the methods can be used in a space station orbiting Earth?

Now according to our first case, the extension in the spring due to the object of mass (m) is given by equation

F = -kx

Where k is spring constant and x is the length of the spring, whereas force is exerted on spring because the mass was suspended through it and hence greater the mass higher will be the extension of spring

∴ mg = -kx

This same principle is used in a device known as Spring balance which is used to measure weight.

But this method won’t be possible if used in a space station orbiting Earth.

Similarly, the time period of oscillation of spring can be calculated using

\(T=2 \pi \sqrt{\left(\frac{m}{k}\right)}\)

But time period of oscillation of spring only depends on mass and spring constant and spring constant is independent of gravitational acceleration hence

T ∝ m

Hence oscillation method can be used to determine the mass of an object.
The size of a simple pendulum is kept very small (point mass) because:
Due to large size pendulum experience more air resistance.
By definition of the simple pendulum the bob should be a point mass.
Due to large size the effective length of the string will increase.

According to the definition of the simple pendulum, the bob must be a point mass.

If the size of the bob will be more then more surface area will be exposed in the air and more resistance will act which will alter the time period of the pendulum. 

Due to the large size, the net distance between the point of the hanging of the pendulum and the center of the bob will increase. This length is called an effective length.

This increase in the effective length of the pendulum will affect the time period.

The time period of a pendulum is 0.5 S on earth surface. What will be the new time period when this pendulum is taken on a planet where acceleration due to gravity becomes one by twenty fourth of that of the earth and length of the pendulum rod reduced to \(\frac{1}{6}\) of the original length?

Given that:

Time period on earth \(= T\)

\(T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{1}{ g }}=0.5 sec\)

Now on the other planet:

New length = \(l ^{\prime}= \frac{l} {6}\) and acceleration due to gravity \(= g ^{\prime}=\frac{ g }{24}\)

New time period,

\( T^{\prime}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{ l ^{\prime}}{ g ^{\prime}}}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{1 \times 24}{6 \times g }}\)

\( T ^{\prime}=2 T =1 sec\)
What will happen when we replace the string of a simple oscillating pendulum by a rubber band?
It will alter the time period of pendulum
The time period of pendulum will get doubled.
The time period will reduced to half

When a point mass is suspended with the help of a inextensible string or rod of negligible mass and does the to and fro motion about its mean position is called as simple pendulum.

According to the definition of the simple pendulum the string or rod should be inextensible. When we replace it with a rubber band which is not an inextensible material then the time period of the pendulum will get changed/altered.
An oscillatory system executes simple harmonic execution when its:
Acceleration and displacement are inversely proportional to each other and act in same direction.
Acceleration and displacement are directly proportional to each other and act in same direction.
Acceleration and displacement are inversely proportional to each other and act in opposite direction
Acceleration and displacement are directly proportional to each other but are in opposite directions.

Simple Harmonic Motion (SHM): Simple harmonic motion is a special type of periodic motion or oscillation where the restoring force is directly proportional to the displacement and acts in the direction opposite to that of displacement.

Example: Motion of an undamped pendulum, undamped spring-mass system.

Force \((F)=-k x\)

Acceleration \((a)=-(\frac{k}  m) x\)

Where a is acceleration, \(x\) is the displacement of the system from its equilibrium position, \(m\) is the mass of the system and \(k\) is a constant associated with the system.

From the above expression for acceleration, the acceleration and displacement are directly proportional to each other and they are in opposite direction to each other. So option (D) is correct.
What will be wavelength of a wave given below?

The wavelength of a wave is the distance between consecutive crests or troughs.

Hence in our case, we can consider any point on the graph as measure the distance between its successive point.

Thus, in this case, the distance between any two successive crests or trough is 8 units.
A sine wave is travelling in a medium. What is the minimum distance between two particles always having the same speed is:

Wavelength (λ): It is equal to the distance travelled by the wave during the time in which anyone particle of the medium completes one vibration about its mean position.

Or distance travelled by the wave in one time period is known as wavelength.

Or is the distance between the two successive points with the same phase.


A sine wave has both maxima and minima. The speed at the maximum and the minimum points are the same whereas the direction of motions is different. A sine wave is travelling in a medium, the minimum distance between the two particles always having the same speed is \(\frac{\lambda}{2}\).
The kind of motion executed by ball displaced from its equilibrium position at the bottom of bowl is _________ kind of motion.

A ball that is displaced from its equilibrium position from the bottom of the bowl covers equal amplitude to both sides of the equilibrium point

The distance covered will be equal in equal interval of time and the motion will be regularly repeating.

Since the ball covers equal distance in equal intervals of time and the motion is regularly repeating the motion is periodic in nature. 

The trajectory of the particle is parabolic in nature. 

The characteristics of motion executed by the ball are periodic. 

 The kind of motion executed by the ball is regularly repeating.
A simple pendulum is hanging from rigid support with a flexible string of length 78 cm. The bob is heavy and has a diameter of 4 cm. Find the time period of the pendulum.

Given that length of string \(I_1=78 cm =0.78 m\)

Radius of bob is \(=\frac{d }{ 2}=\frac{4 }{ 2}=2 cm =0.02 m\)

Effective length \((L)=I_1+\) radius of bob. \(\Rightarrow L=0.80 m\).

Gravitational acceleration ' \(g\) ' \(=9.81 m / s ^2\). (We know)

\(T =2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{1}{ g }}\), using this equation for the time period of the pendulum.

\(T =2 \times 3.14 \sqrt{\frac{0.80}{9.81}}=1.794 s . \approx 1.8 s\)
A spring has a spring constant of 1000 N/m and its initial expansion is 10 cm. Calculate the work done in extending the spring from 10 cm to 20 cm.

k =1000 N / m, \(x _1=10\) cm, \(x _2=20\) cm

A spring has a spring constant of \(1000 N / m\) and its initial expansion is \(10 cm\).

Using formula,

\(\Rightarrow W=\frac{1}{2} k x^2\)

Where \(k\) is spring constant, \(x =\) Displacement of the spring.

\( \Rightarrow \) Initially at \( x_1=10 cm =0.1 m .\)

\( \Rightarrow W_1=\frac{1}{2} \times 1000 \times 0.1^2=5 J\)

at \(x _2=20 cm =0.2 m\).

\(\Rightarrow W_2=\frac{1}{2} \times 1000 \times 0.2^2=20 J\)

Work done to extend the spring up to \(20 cm\).

\(\Rightarrow W=W_2-W_1=20-5=15 J\)
Which one of the following cannot be the unit of 'Pressure'?

The pressure is the perpendicular force acting per unit area. SI unit of pressure is Pascal, which is equivalent to \(1 \mathrm{~N}\) force acting per sq. meter.

It is given by, \(\mathrm{P=\frac{F}{A}}\)

Its unit can also be derived from the formula as \({\mathrm N} / {\mathrm m}^2\).

\(\mathrm{Kg}\)-\(\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^2\) is the derived unit of force.

1 Pascal \(=\frac{\mathrm F}{\mathrm A}=\frac{\mathrm {m a}}{\mathrm A}=\frac{\mathrm{K g m / s^2}}{\mathrm m^2}={\mathrm {Kg}} /({\mathrm m}\).\({\mathrm s}^2)\).

1 light-year \(=9.46 \times 10^{12} \mathrm{~km}\).
Which of the following has the unit Candela?
Candela (Cd) is the SI unit of luminous intensity. Luminous intensity is a measure of the amount of visible light emitted from a point source per unit time per unit solid angle.

Dimension of force = Dimension of mass \(\times\) Dimension of acceleration \(=[\mathrm{M \times LT^{-2}]=[M L T^{-2}}]\)

Now, 

Dimension of pressure \(=\frac{\text {Dimension of force }}{\text {Dimension of area}}=\frac{\left[\mathrm{MLT}^{-2}\right]}{\left[\mathrm{L}^2\right]}=\left[\mathrm{ML}^{-1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]\)

Again,

Stress \(=\frac{\text { Force applied }}{\text { Area }}\)

Dimension of stress \(=\frac{\left[\mathrm{M L T^{-2}}\right]}{[\mathrm L^2]}=[\mathrm{M L^{-1} T^{-2}}]\).

Dimension of strain \(=\frac{\text {Change in dimension }}{\text {Initial dimension }}=\frac{[\mathrm{L}]}{[\mathrm{L}]}=\) A dimensionless quantity

So, pressure and stress has same dimensions.
If \(C\) and \(R\) represent capacitance and resistance respectively, then the dimensions of \(R C\) are:

\(\mathrm{R}\) is resistance and \(\mathrm{C}\) is capacitance.

We know that,

\(\mathrm{R}=\mathrm{V} / \mathrm{I}\) (where \(\mathrm{V}\) is the potential difference and I is current)

\(\mathrm{C}=\mathrm{q} / \mathrm{V}\) (where \(\mathrm{q}\) is a charge)

Unit of \(\mathrm{RC}=\frac{\mathrm{v}}{1} \times \frac{\mathrm{q}}{\mathrm{v}}=\frac{\mathrm{q}}{1}=\frac{\mathrm{q}}{(\mathrm{g})}=\mathrm{t}\)

So, the dimension of RC is \(\left[\mathrm{M}^{0} \mathrm{L}^{0} \mathrm{T}^1\right]\).
What are the dimensions of angular momentum?

We know that,

\( \mathrm{L}=\mathrm{I} \times \omega=\mathrm{r} \times \mathrm{p}\)

Where, \(\mathrm{L}=\) angular momentum, \(\mathrm{I}=\) moment of inertia, \({\omega}=\) angular momentum, \(\mathrm{r}=\) distance and \(\mathrm{p}=\) linear momentum \(=(\mathrm{m} \times \mathrm{v})\).

Now,

Dimensional formula of \(({r})=[L]\),

Dimensional formula of \(({p})=\left[\mathrm{M L T}^{-1}\right]\),

- Therefore, the dimensional formula of \(L\) is \(=[\mathrm{L}] \times\left[\mathrm{MLT}^{-1}\right] \)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{L}=\left[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-1}\right]\)

\(\therefore\) Dimensional formula of angular momentum \(L\) is \(\left[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{T}^{-1}\right]\).
The dimensional formula for the modulus of rigidity is:

Dimensional formula ofm modulus of rigidity \(=\frac{[\mathrm{M L T^{-2}}]}{[\mathrm{L^2}]}=[\mathrm{M L^{-1} T^{-2}}]\)
The unit of surface tension may be expressed as:

The property of liquid surfaces to shrink into the minimum surface area possible is known as surface tension.

T \(= \frac{F}{L}\)

SI unit of surface tension = Newton / meter = \(\frac{\mathrm N}{\mathrm m}\) = \(\mathrm{Nm}^{-1}\)
If \(V\) denotes the potential difference across the plates of a capacitor of capacitance \(c\), the dimensions of \(\mathrm{CV}^2\) are:

We know charge on plates \( Q=C \cdot V \Rightarrow C=\frac{Q}{V}\) 

Also, work done \(W=V \cdot Q \Rightarrow V=W / Q\)

So, \(C=\frac{Q^2}{W}=\frac{(I t)^2}{W} \quad\left[\begin{array}{l}I \rightarrow \text { current } \rightarrow \text { ampere } \\ t \rightarrow \text { time } \rightarrow \text { seconds }\end{array}\right]\)

\(\Rightarrow C=\frac{\left[A^2 T^2\right]}{\left[M L T^{-2} \times L\right]}=\frac{\left[A^2 T^4\right]}{\left[M L^2\right]}=\left[M^{-1} L^{-2} T^4 A^2\right]\)

Now,

\(V  =\frac{\omega}{Q}=\frac{\left[M L^2 T^{-2}\right]}{[A T]} \Rightarrow V^2=\frac{\left[M^2 L^4 T^{-4}\right]}{\left[A^2 T^2\right]} \)

\(\Rightarrow V^2=\left[M^2 L^4 T^{-6} A^{-2}\right] \)

\(C \cdot V^2  =\left[M^{-1} L^{-2} T^4 A^2\right]\times \left[M^2 L^4 T^{-6} A^{-2}\right]=\left[M L^2 T^{-2}\right]\)

Let us consider the inductor \(L\) and current passing through the inductor is \(I\). Then the energy possessed by the inductor is \(\frac{1}{2} L I^2\).

As this also same as that of energy so both have same dimensional formula

Now the energy is simply same as that of work and work is the product of force and displacement i.e.

\(W=F \times S\)

As the dimensional formula of the force \(=\left[M L T^{-2}\right]\)

And the dimensional formula of length is \(=[L]\)

Then the dimensional formula of the work or energy is \(=\left[M L^2 T^{-2}\right]\)

So, the dimensional formula of \(L I^2\) is \(\left[M L^2 T^{-2}\right]\)
A system of units uses force (F), acceleration (A) and time (T) as their fundamental physical quantities. The dimension of length in the system is:

An athletic coach told his team that muscle times speed equals power. What dimensions does he view for muscle?

According to the question,

Muscle \(\times\) speed \(=\) power

\(\Rightarrow \text {Muscle }=\frac{\text {Power }}{\text {Speed }}\)

So, dimension of muscle \(=\frac{\left[\mathrm{M^1 L^2 T^{-3}}\right]}{\left[L^1 T^{-1}\right]}=\left[\mathrm{M L T^{-2}}\right]\)
The pair having the same dimensions is:

Angular momentum = \(mvr=\frac{kg-m^{2}}{s}=[M L^{2} T^{-1}]\)

Work \(=\) Force \(\times\) displacement = \(ma\times d = \frac{kg-m^{2}}{s^2}=[M L^{2} T^{-2}]\)

Torque \(\tau=\) Force \(\times\) perpendicular distance = \(\frac{kg-m^{2}}{s^2}=[M L^{2} T^{-2}]\)

Potential energy \(= mgh = kg-m^{2}/s^{2}= [M L^{2} T^{-2}]\)

Linear momentum \(p=mv=kg-m/s= [M LT^{-1}]\)

Kinetic energy \(= \frac{1}{2} mv^{2}=\frac{kg-m^{2}}{s^2}= [M L^{2} T^{-2}]\)

Velocity \(= \frac{d}{t} = \frac{m}{s} = [M L T^{-1}]\)

So, the pair of Work, torque having the same dimensions.

If velocity \( v\), acceleration \(\mathrm A\) and force \(\mathrm F\) are chosen as fundamental quantities, then the dimensional formula of angular momentum in terms of \(v\) \(\mathrm A\) and \(\mathrm  F\) would be:

We know that,

\( [\mathrm{F}]=\left[\mathrm{MLT}^{-2}\right]\)

\([{v}]=\left[\mathrm{LT}^{-1}\right] \)

\([\mathrm{A}]=\left[\mathrm{LT}^{-2}\right]\) 

and \([{\vec{L}]=\left[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-1}\right]}\)

Where \(\vec{L}\) is the angular momentum let

\([\vec{L}]=[\mathrm{F}]^{\mathrm{a}}[{v}]^{\mathrm{b}}[\mathrm{A}]^{\mathrm{c}}\)

\(\Rightarrow\left[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-1}\right]=\left[\mathrm{MLT}^{-2}\right]^{\mathrm{a}}\left[\mathrm{LT}^{-1}\right]^{\mathrm{b}}\left[\mathrm{LT}^{-2}\right]^{\mathrm{c}}\)

\(\Rightarrow\left[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-1}\right]=\left[\mathrm{M}^{(\mathrm{a})} \mathrm{L}^{(\mathrm{a}+\mathrm{b}+\mathrm{c})} \mathrm{T}^{(-2 \mathrm{a}-\mathrm{b}-2 \mathrm{c})}\right]\)

By analysing , we get

\( a=1 \)

\( a+b+c=2 \)

\( 2 a+b+2 c=1 \)

By solving these equations, we get

\(\mathrm{a}=1, \quad \mathrm{~b}=3 \mathrm{c}=-2\)

So, \(\left[ \mathrm{L}\right]=\left[{\mathrm F v}^3 \mathrm{A}^{-2}\right]\)
Dimensions of the following three quantities are the same:

Stress \(=\frac{F}{A}=\left[M L^{-1} T^{-2}\right] \) 

Co. efficient of elasticity \(=\frac{\text {Stress}}{\text {stain}}\)

\(=\frac{\frac{{F}}{{A}}}{\frac{\Delta L}{L}}=[M L^{-1} T^{-2}]\)

So, Dimensions of pressure, stress, coefficient of elasticity are same.

If the speed of light (c), acceleration due to gravity ( \(g\) ) and pressure (p) are taken as the fundamental quantities, then the dimension of gravitational constant is:

Dimension of gravitational constant \(\mathrm{G}=\mathrm{M}^{-1} \mathrm{~L}^3 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\)

Speed of light \({[\mathrm{c}]=\left[\mathrm{LT}^{-1}\right]} \)

Gravity \({[\mathrm{g}]=\left[\mathrm{LT}^{-2}\right]} \)

Pressure \({[\mathrm{p}]=\left[\mathrm{ML}^{-1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]}\)

On equating dimensions

\({\left[\mathrm{M}^{-1} \mathrm{~L}^3 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]=\left[\mathrm{LT}^{-1}\right]^\alpha\left[\mathrm{LT}^{-2}\right]^\beta\left[\mathrm{ML}^{-1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]^\gamma} \)

By comparison 

\(\gamma=-1\)

\(3=\alpha+\beta-\gamma =3 \)

\(\alpha+\beta=2\cdots (1) \)

And \(-\alpha-2 \beta-2 \gamma = -2\)

\(\alpha+2 \beta=4 \cdots (2)\)

Solving eq. (1) and (2) we get,

\(\alpha=0, \beta=2\)

\(\therefore\) Dimension \(=\mathrm{c}^{0} \mathrm{g}^2 \mathrm{p}^{-1}\)
If the time period \((T)\) of vibration of a liquid drop depends on surface tension ( \(S\) ), radius \((r)\) of the drop and density ( \(\rho\) ) of the liquid, then the expression of \(T\) is:

Dimensional formula of, Time period \([T]=\left[M^0 L^0 T^1\right]\)

Surface tension\([\mathrm{S}]=\left[\mathrm{ML}^{\circ} \mathrm{T}^{-2}\right]\)

Radius \([r]=\left[M^{\circ} L T^0\right]\)

Density \([\rho]=\left[M^1 L^{-3} T^0\right]\)

Let us suppose the relation is

\([T]=\left[k \rho^{\mathrm{a}} \mathrm{r}^{\mathrm{b}} \mathrm{S}^{\mathrm{c}}\right] \)

\(\Rightarrow\left[M^0 L^0 T^1\right]=\left[M^1 L^{-3} T^0\right]^a \times\left[M^0 L T^0\right]^b \times\left[M L^0 T^{-2}\right]^c \)

\( \Rightarrow\left[M^0 L^0 T^1\right]=\left[M^{(a+c)} L^{(-3 a+b)} T^{(-2 c)}\right] \)

On comparing, we get,

\(a+c=0 \cdots(i)\)

\(-3 a+b=0 \cdots(ii)\)

\(-2 c=1\cdots(iii)\)

On solving these equations, we get,

\(a=\frac{1}{2}, b=\frac{3}{2}\) and \(c =\frac{-1}{2}\)

Thus,

\(T=k \rho^a r^b S^c \Rightarrow T=k \sqrt{\rho r^3 / S}\)

We know that,

Electric Current \(I=\frac{q}{t}\)

or \(I=\frac{[Q]}{[T]}\)

Dimensional formula of electric current \(I=\left[M^0 L^0 T^{-1} Q\right]\)
The fundamental physical quantities that have same dimensions in the dimensional formulae of torque and angular momentum are:

Angular momentum \(=m v r=\frac{k g-m^2}{s}=[M L^2 T^{-1}]\)

Torque \(\tau=\) Force \(\times\) perpendicular distance \(=\frac{k g-m^2}{s^2}=[M L^2 T^{-2}]\)

Both have the same dimensional unit of mass \(M\) and length \(L\). So, The fundamental physical quantities that have same dimensions in the dimensional formulae of torque and angular momentum are mass and length.
If pressure \(P\), velocity \(v\) and time \(T\) are taken as fundamental physical quantities, the dimensional formula of force is:

\( F=P^\alpha v^\beta T^\gamma \)

or \(\left[M^1 L^1 T^{-2}\right]=\left[M^\alpha L^{-\alpha+\beta} T^{-2 \alpha-\beta+\gamma}\right] \)

i.e. \(\left[M^1 L^1 T^{-2}\right]=\left[M^\alpha L^{-\alpha+\beta} T^{-2 \alpha-\beta+\gamma}\right]\)

Hence we have,

\(\alpha=1,-\alpha+\beta=1 \text { and }-2 \alpha-\beta+\gamma=-2\)

Solving these we get,

\(\alpha=1, \beta=2, \gamma=2 \)

\(\Rightarrow F=Pv ^2 T^2\)

Which of the following represents the dimensions of Farad?

Farad is the unit of capacitance.

We know that

Capacitance \(=\frac{\text {Charge }}{\text { Voltage }}=\frac{I \times t}{\frac{\omega}{ q}} \) 

\(C=\frac{(I \times t) \times q}{\omega}=\frac{(I \times t)^2}{\omega} \)

\( C=\frac{[A T]^2}{\left[M L^2 T^{-2}\right]}=\left[M^{-1} L^{-2} T^4 A^2\right]\)
The dimensions of \(\mathrm{B}^2 \mathrm{~L}^2 \mathrm{C}\) (where \(\mathrm{B}\) is magnetic field, \(\mathrm{L}\) is length and \(\mathrm{C}\) is capacitance) is same as that of:

The dimension \(\mathrm{B}=\mathrm{MT}^{-2} \mathrm{~A}^{-1}\)

Dimension of \(\mathrm{C}=\mathrm{M}^{-1} \mathrm{~L}^{-2} \mathrm{~T}^4 \mathrm{A}^2\)

Dimension of \(\mathrm{L}=\mathrm{L}\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{B}^2 \mathrm{~L}^2 \mathrm{C}=[\mathrm{M}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-4} \mathrm{~A}^{-2}] \times [\mathrm{~L}^2] \times [\mathrm{M}^{-1} \mathrm{~L}^{-2} \mathrm{~T}^4 \mathrm{~A}^2]  \)

\(=[\mathrm M \mathrm L^{0} \mathrm{T}^0 \mathrm{A}^0]=M =\) Dimension of Mass
The dimensional formula for strain is same as that for:

The strain is a dimensionless quantity because it is a ratio of two similar quantities, namely lengths, area or volume. 

The angle is considered to be a dimensionless physical quantity as it is measured in radians and thus is the ratio of two lengths. So, the angle has the same dimensional formula as strain because both of them are dimensionless.

Which of the following is a dimensionless quantity?

A dimensionless quantity is the one for which no physical dimension is assigned. It is also known as a bare, pure, or scalar quantity or also as a quantity of dimension one.

Work and energy both are having the same dimensions as \(\left[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^2\right]\). 

The ratio \(\frac{\text { Energy }}{\text { Work }}\) will be a dimensionless quantity.
Which of the following is a dimensional constant?

Refractive Index is defined as the relative speed at which light moves through a material with respect to its speed in vacuum. As both the values belong to the same quantity (speed), units get nullified.So the Refractive Index is a dimensionless quantity.

If \(C\) is the value of the capacitance of a capacitor filled with a given dielectric and \(C_0\) is the capacitance of an identical capacitor in a vacuum, the dielectric constant, symbolized by the Greek letter kappa, \(\kappa\), is simply expressed as :

\(\kappa=C / C_0\)

The dielectric constant is a number without dimensions.

Relative density of a substance is defined as the density of a substance divided by the density of water. So, it is a pure ratio and has no dimensions. Therefore, relative density is dimensionless.

A gravitational coupling constant is a constant characterizing the gravitational attraction between a given pair of elementary particles. Therefore, the dimension of the gravitational constant is \([M^{-1} L^3 T^{-2}]\).
Does not depend on the method of measurement
Is more in SI system than in CGS system
Directly proportional to the fundamental units of mass, length and time

The SI base units are larger than their CGS counterparts. For example, 1 meter is equal to 100 centimeters, and 1 kilogram is equal to 1000 grams. This means that in the SI system, the base units inherently represent larger quantities compared to the CGS system. So, the magnitude of any physical quantity is more in SI system than in CGS system.
If the unit of length and force be increased four times, then the unit of energy is:

Let, the unit of Length \(=L\), and Unit of Force \(=F\).

Now, energy \((E)\) can be expressed in terms of length and force. 

\(E=F \cdot d\)

Where \(E=\) energy, \(F=\) force, \(d=\) distance (which is directly related to length)

Now, according to question, if both the units of length and force are increased four times:

The new unit of length \(=4 L\) and new unit of force becomes \(=4 F\)

Then new energy \(E^{\prime}=(4 F) \cdot(4 d)=16(F \cdot d)=16 E\)

So, the unit of energy \(\left(E^{\prime}\right)\) increases 16 times when both the unit of length and force are increased four times.

The tesla (T) is the unit of measurement for magnetic flux density or magnetic induction, which quantifies the strength of a magnetic field. One tesla is defined as the magnetic flux density resulting from a one newton per square meter (1 N/m2) force acting on a conductor carrying a current of one ampere, perpendicular to the magnetic field.
Which of the following is different from others by units?

Poisson's ratio is a dimensionless quantity. It's the ratio of the relative contraction strain (or transverse strain) to the relative extension strain (or axial strain), in the direction of the applied force. Since it's a ratio of similar quantities, it doesn't have any units.

Phrase difference unit - degree or radian

Mechanical equivalent unit - joules per calorie or calories per joule(depending on the convention)

Loudness of sound unit - decibels (dB)

So, when \(\mathrm L\) and \(\mathrm R\) are respectively the inductance and resistance, then the dimensions of \(\frac{\mathrm L}{\mathrm R}\) will be \([\mathrm{M}^0 \mathrm{~L}^0 \mathrm{~T}]\).

Which one of the following quantities has dimensions different from the remaining three?
Product of voltage and charge per unit volume

Energy density \(=\frac{\text { Energy }}{\text {Volume }}=\frac{[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}]}{[\mathrm{~L}^3]}=[\mathrm{ML}^{-1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}]\)

Force per unit area \(=\frac{[\mathrm{MLT}^{-2}]}{[\mathrm{~L}^2]}=[\mathrm{ML}^{-1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}]\)

Product of the charge per unit volume and voltage

\(=\mathrm{Q} \frac{(\mathrm{IT}) \mathrm{V}}{\text { Volume }}=\frac{[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}]}{[\mathrm{~L}^3]}=[\mathrm{ML}^{-1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}]\)

Which of the following quantities does not have Nm–2 as the unit?

Strain does not have Nm–2 as its unit. Strain is a dimensionless quantity because it represents the ratio of the change in length (or deformation) to the original length of the object. Since it's a ratio of lengths, it doesn't have any units.
Which of the options has two quantities that have different dimensions?

Coefficient of friction and Reynolds no. have no dimensions. So, their dimensions are same and can be represent as \(=\mathrm{[M^0L^0 {T}^0]}\)

Latent heat \(=\frac{\text { Energy }}{\text {Mass }}=\frac{[\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~L}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}]}{[\mathrm{M}]}=[\mathrm{L}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}]\)

Gravitational potential \(=\frac{G M}{r}=\frac{\text {Force }}{\text {Mass }} \times r=\frac{[\mathrm{M^1 L^1 T^{-2}}]}{[\mathrm M^1]} \times \mathrm {[L^1]=[L^2 T^{-2}]}\)

So, the dimensions of both are same.

Curie \(=\) frequency of light wave \(=[\mathrm{M}^{0} \mathrm{L}^{0} \mathrm{T}^{-1}]\)

So, the dimensions of both are same.

Planck's constant \(=[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-1}]\)

Torque \(=[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}]\)

So, the dimensions of both are not same.
The dimensions of \(\frac{B^2}{2 \mu_0}\), where \(B\) is magentic field and \(\mu_0\) is the magnetic permiability of vaccum, is:

The quantity of \(\frac{B^2}{2 \mu_0}\) is the energy density of magnetic field.

\(\Rightarrow\left[\frac{B^2}{2 \mu_0}\right]=\frac{\text { Energy }}{\text { Volume }}\)

\(\Rightarrow\left[\frac{B^2}{2 \mu_0}\right] \frac{\text { Force } \times \text { displacement }}{(\text { length })^3}\)

\(\Rightarrow\left[\frac{B^2}{2 \mu_0}\right]=\left[\frac{\left[M L T^{-2}\right][L]}{[L^3]}\right] \)

\(\Rightarrow\left[\frac{B^2}{2 \mu_0}\right]=[M L^{-1} T^{-2}]\)
________ is the international unit of measuring Energy.

Joule is the international unit of measuring Energy. It is part of the International System of Units (SI), which is the modern form of the metric system. 

The joule is defined as the amount of work done when a force of one newton is applied over a distance of one meter in the direction of the force. Mathematically, 1 joule \(=\) 1 newton \(\times \)1 meter.
Lux is unit of which physical quantity?
The lux is indeed the derived International System of Units (SI) unit of illumination, which measures the amount of luminous flux (light) incident on a surface per unit area.
What are the dimensions of gravitational potential?

The dimensional formula of the mass \(=[M]\)

The dimensional formula of the work done \([\mathrm{W}]=\left[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]\)

The dimensional formula of the gravitational potential is derived as,

\([U]=\frac{\left[\mathrm{M L^2 T^{-2}}\right]}{[\mathrm M]}=\left[\mathrm{M^0 L^2 T^{-2}}\right]\)

So, the dimensional formula of the gravitational potential is \(\left[\mathrm{M^0 L^2 T^{-2}}\right]\).
The unit of magnetic dipole moment is:

Magnetic dipole moments have dimensions of energy divided by magnetic flux density or current times area.

The magnetic dipole moment is given by:

\(\mu=\mathrm{N} \text { i A }\)

\(\mathrm{N}\) is the no. of turns which has no unit, \(\mathrm{A}\) is the area of the coil with unit square meter, and I is current in the coil with unit ampere. So the unit of \(\mu\) is the ampere-meter2.
What is the dimensional formula of strain?

The ratio of change in configuration to the original configuration is called strain. As the strain is the ratio of two like quantities, it has no units and no dimensions. Its dimension can be expressed as \([\mathrm{{M}^0 {L}^0 {T}^0}]\).
The unit Joule/coulomb is the same as:

The potential difference between two points in an electric field may be defined as the amount of work done in moving a unit positive charge from one point to the other against the electrostatic force i.e.,

Electric potential \((\mathrm{V})=\frac{\text { Work done (W) }}{\text { Charge }(\mathrm{q})}\)

We know that, SI unit of work done is joule and the SI unit of charge is the coulomb, then

\(1 \mathrm {V=\frac{J}{C}}\)

So, Joule/coulomb is the same as \(1 \mathrm{~V}\).
The unit of surface tension may be expressed as:

The property of liquid surfaces to shrink into the minimum surface area possible is known as surface tension.

Surface tension \(= \frac{\mathrm F}{\mathrm L} \) units \(=\mathrm{Nm}^{-1} \)

\(=(\mathrm N \mathrm{m}) / \mathrm{m}^2=\text { Joule } / \mathrm{m}^2\) = Joule metre-2
The dimension of \(\frac{\mathrm{h}}{\mathrm{e}}\) is the same as of (here \(h\) is Planck's constant and \(e\) is electronic charges):

Plancks constant \((\mathrm{h})\) has joule-seconds. dimensions are \(=\left[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-1}\right]\) electron charge (e) will have \(\mathrm{[TI]}\)

Dimension for \(\mathrm{{h} / {e}}\) will be \(=[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2} \mathrm{I}^{-1}]\)

From the given options,

Dimension for magnetic moment \(=\left[\mathrm{L}^2 \mathrm{~A}\right]\)

Dimension for magnetic flux \(=\left[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2} \mathrm{I}^{-1}\right]\)

Dimension for electric flux \(=\left[\mathrm{ML}^3 \mathrm{~T}^{-3} \mathrm{I}^{-1}\right]\)

Dimension for electric field strength \(=\left[\mathrm{MLT}^{-3} \mathrm{I}^{-1}\right]\)

Both magnetic flux and \(\mathrm{{h} / {e}}\) will have same dimensions.

Backlash error also called as play or lash (by mechanical engineers) is mostly encountered when we try to move the instrument back and forth rapidly i.e. when we are changing direction of motion of the instrument. Backlash error is present in Vernier calipers, screw gauge and Spherometer.

If energy of photon is \(\mathrm{E} \propto \mathrm{h}^{\mathrm{a}} \mathrm{c}^{\mathrm{b}} \lambda^{\mathrm{d}}\). Here, \(h=\) plank's constant, \(c=\) speed of light, \(\lambda=\) wavelength of photon. Then the values of \(a, b\) and \(d\) are:

\(\mathrm{E} \propto \mathrm{h}^{\mathrm{a}} \mathrm{c}^{\mathrm{b}} \lambda^{\mathrm{d}}\)

or \(\mathrm{E=k h^a c^b \lambda^d}\cdots (1)\)

Here

\({[\mathrm{E]=\left[M^{1} L^2 T^{-2}\right]}} \)

\({[\mathrm{h]=\left[M^{1} L^2 T^{-1}\right]}} \)

\({[\mathrm{C]=\left[L^{1} T^{-1}\right]} }\)

\({[\mathrm{\lambda]=\left[M^0 L^{1} T^{0}\right]}}\)

From these terms and equation (1)

Hence

\({\left[M^1 L^2 T^{-2}\right]= k\left[M^1 L^2 T^{-1}\right]^a \times \left[M^0 L^1 T^{-1}\right]^ b} \times \left[M^0 L^1 T^0\right]^d\)

On Compairing:

\( a=1, b=1,  d=-1\)
Which of the following pairs does not have similar dimensions?

Surface Tension \((T)=\frac{\text { Force }}{\text { Length }} \ldots\). (1)

Since, Force \(=\) Mass \(\times\) Acceleration

And, Acceleration \(=\frac{\text { velocity }}{\text { time }}=\left[\mathrm{LT}^{-2}\right]\)

\(\therefore\) The dimensional formula of force \(=[\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~L}^1 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}] \ldots\) (2)

On substituting equation (2) in equation (1) we get,

Surface Tension \((T)=\frac{\text { Force }}{\text { Length }}\)

Or, \(\mathrm{T}=\frac{\left[\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~L}^1 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]}{\left[\mathrm{L}^1\right]}=[\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}]\)

Therefore, surface tension is dimensionally represented as \(\left[\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]\)

Tension is defined as the magnitude of force.

\(\therefore\) Demension of Tension \(=\) Dimension of Force

So, dimension of tension \(=[\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~L}^1 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}]\)

So the dimension of tension and surface tension is different.
What is an international (SI) unit of electric current?
Ampere is the international (SI) unit of electric current. It is defined as one coulomb per second, where a coulomb (symbol: C) is the unit of electric charge.

A small steel ball of radius \(r\) is allowed to fall under gravity through a column of a viscous liquid of coefficient of viscosity \(\eta\). After some time the velocity of the ball attains a constant value known as terminal velocity \(\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{T}}\). The terminal velocity depends on the mass of the ball \(\mathrm{m}\),\(\eta\), \(\mathrm{r}\) and acceleration due to gravity \(\mathrm{g}\). Which of the following relations is dimensionally correct?

The dimension of terminal velocity \(v_T\) is,

\(\left[{V}_{{T}}\right]=\left[L T^{-1}\right]\cdots(1)\)

From the formula of drag force,

\( F_D=6 \pi\eta r v_T \)

\(\Rightarrow[\eta]=\frac{\left[F_D\right]}{\left[6 \pi r v_T\right]} \)

\(\Rightarrow[\eta]=\frac{\left[{MLT}^{-2}\right]}{[L]\left[L T^{-1}\right]}=\left[{ML}^{-1} {~T}^{-1}\right]\)

Taking option (A)

\(\frac{[\mathrm{mg}]}{[\eta r]}=\frac{\left[M L T^{-2}\right]}{\left[M L^{-1} T^{-1} \times L\right]}=\left[L T^{-1}\right]\)

From (1), this option matches the dimension of \({v}_{{T}}\).
To change units from one system to another
To check the consistency of a dimensional equation
To derive the relation between physical quantities in physical phenomena

Dimensional analysis is a fundamental aspect of measurement and is applied in real-life physics. We make use of dimensional analysis for three prominent reasons:

  • To check the consistency of a dimensional equation
  • To derive the relation between physical quantities in physical phenomena
  • To change units from one system to another
Which of the following units denotes the dimensions \(\mathrm{ML}^2 / \mathrm{Q}^2\), where \(\mathrm{Q}\) denotes the electric charge?

Weber \(=\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2} \mathrm{I}^{-1} =M L^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2} \mathrm{Q}^{-1} \mathrm{~T}=\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-1} \mathrm{Q}^{-1}\left(\mathrm{I}=\mathrm{QT}^{-1}\right)\)

Henry \(\mathrm{H}\) is \(\mathrm{SI}\) unit of inductance.

\( \mathrm{H}=\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2} \mathrm{I}^{-2}\) and \(\mathrm{I}=\mathrm{QT}^{-1} \)

So \(\mathrm{H}=\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2} \mathrm{Q}^{-2} \mathrm{~T}^2=\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{Q}^{-2}\)
In SI unit system, pascal is the unit of:
The force per unit area is called pressure. The SI unit of pressure is the pascal (Pa).
Which of the following is the dimension of power?

We know that,

Pressure \(P=\frac{W}{t}\)

Where, \(\mathrm{P}=\) power, \(\mathrm{W}=\) work done and \(t=\) time.

Now,

Dimensional formula of work \((\mathrm{W})=\left[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]\)

Dimensional formula of time \((t)=\left[T^1\right]\)

\(\mathrm{P=\frac{M L^2 T^{-2}}{T^1}=\frac{M L^2}{T^3}}\)

\(\therefore\) The dimensional formula of power \(\mathrm{P}\) is \(\left[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-3}\right]\).
Which of the following is not a physical quantity?

The Kilogram (kg) represents the unit of a physical quantity and not the physical quantity. The kilogram is a unit of measurement for the physical quantity of mass. It represents the base unit of mass in the SI system.
A force \(F\) is given by \(F=a t+b t^2\), where \(t\) is time. What are the dimensions of \(a\) and \(b\)?

\(\mathrm{F}=\mathrm{at}+\mathrm{bt}^2\) where \(\mathrm{t}\) is time.

For this equation to be dimensionally correct, the each term in the right hand side should have the dimensions of \(\mathrm{F}\).

Dimensional formula of \(\mathrm{F}=\left[[\mathrm{MLT}^{-2}]\right]\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{aT}=\left[[\mathrm{MLT}^{-2}]\right] \)

\(\Rightarrow \text { Dimension of } \mathrm{a} \text { is }\left[[\mathrm{MLT}^{-3}]\right]\)

And \(\Rightarrow \mathrm{bT}^2=\left[[\mathrm{MLT}^{-2}]\right]\)

\(\Rightarrow\) Dimension of \(\mathrm{b}\) is \(\left[\mathrm{MLT}^{-4}\right]\)

So, the dimensions of \(a\) and \(b\) are \([M L T^{-3}]\) and \([M L T^{-4}]\).
A motion which repeat itself after an equal interval of time
A motion which does not repeat itself after an equal interval of time
A motion in which body is under acceleration
A motion in which body is at rest

Periodic motion: A motion which repeats itself after an equal interval of time is known as periodic motion.

For example: A minute hand of a clock come back to its original state after every 60 min is a great example of periodic motion. Similarly, the function which repeats its value after a fixed interval of time is termed as a periodic function.

If the second hand of a clock is in a periodic motion, then its frequency of rotation is_______________.

If the second hand of a clock is in a periodic motion, then its frequency of rotation is 16.6× 10-3 Hz.

The time period for completing one complete rotation of a second hand, \(T=1 m =60 sec\) Thus the frequency of rotation in our case will be \(f=\frac{1}{T}=\frac{1}{60}=0.0166=16.6 \times 10^{-3}\)

If the argument 'ωt' of the periodic function f(t) = A cos(ωt + φ) is increased by integral multiple of ______ radians, the value of the function remains the same.

Periodic motion: A motion that repeats itself after a period is called periodic motion. f(t) = A sin(ωt+ϕ)

Where f(t) is the position at any time t, A is amplitude, t is time, and ω is the angular frequency. 

Amplitude (A): The maximum displacement from the mean position is called amplitude.

frequency (f): The no. of oscillations in one second is called frequency.

Time period (T): The time is taken to complete one oscillation is called time period.

Angular frequency (ω) is given by: \(\omega=\frac{2 \pi}{T}\) (where T is the time period)

Since the given function is cosine function, so if we multiply it with an integral multiple of 2π then there will be no effect.
If the length of the pendulum is increased then what will be the effect on its time period?

For a simple pendulum, the time period of swing of a pendulum depends on the length of the string and acceleration due to gravity. 

\(T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{1}{ g }}\)

From the above equation, it is clear that the period of oscillation is directly proportional to the length of the arm and inversely proportional to acceleration due to gravity.

Thus, an increase in the length of a pendulum arm results in a subsequent increase in the period of oscillation given a constant gravitational acceleration.

\(e ^{-\omega t} \Rightarrow\) Non-periodic function

\(2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{1}{\omega t}} \Rightarrow\) Non-periodic function

\(\sin \omega t+\cos 2 \omega t+\sin 4 \omega t \Rightarrow\) periodic function

Distance covered by the body from A to E = AB + BC + CD + DE = X + X + X + X= 4X

In simple harmonic motion the acceleration is proportional to:

Simple harmonic motion is a special type of periodic motion or oscillation where the restoring force is directly proportional to the displacement and acts in the direction opposite to that of displacement.

Example: Motion of an undamped pendulum, undamped spring-mass system.

Force (F) = - k x

But according to Newton second law, F = ma 

Therefore, \(a=\frac{-k x}{m}\)

\(\Rightarrow v _{\max }= aw\)

\(\Rightarrow \omega=\frac{2 \pi}{T}\)

By equation 1 and equation 2,

\(\Rightarrow v_{\max }=a \frac{2 \pi}{T}\)
A particle executing simple harmonic motion of amplitude 5 cm has maximum speed of 31.4 cm/sec. The frequency of its oscillation is:

Given maximum speed \(v=31.4 cm / sec\)

So, maximum kinetic energy will be

\( K=\frac{1}{2} m v^2 \)

\(\Rightarrow K_m=\frac{1}{2} m(31.4)^2\)...(1)

amplitude \(A=5 cm\)

Also, the expression for maximum kinetic energy is

\(K_m=\frac{1}{2} m \omega^2 A^2\)

Putting \(A=5\)

\(K_m=\frac{1}{2} m \omega^2(5 cm )^2\)...(2)

Equating Eq (1) and (2)

\( \frac{1}{2} m \omega^2(5 cm )^2=\frac{1}{2} m(31.4)^2 \)

\( \Rightarrow \omega^2=\frac{31.5^2}{5^2}=\left(\frac{31.5}{5}\right)^2\)

\( \Rightarrow \omega=6.3 \)

\( \Rightarrow 2 \pi f =6.3 \)

\( \Rightarrow f=\frac{6.3}{2 \pi}=1 hz\)
The amplitude of SHM executed by a spring is 5 m and the spring constant is K. If the amplitude is doubled then find the percentage variation of kinetic energy:

Given: \(A_1=5 m , A_2=2 \times A_1=2 \times 5=10 m\)

The kinetic energy \(K_1\) for the displacement \(A_1\) is given by

\(\Rightarrow K_1=\frac{1}{2} k \times 25=25 \times \frac{k}{2}=12.5 k\)

The kinetic energy \(K _2\) for the displacement \(A _2\) is given by

\(\Rightarrow K_2=\frac{1}{2} k \times 10^2=100 \times \frac{k}{2}=50 k\)

The percentile change is given by

\(\Rightarrow \% \text { change }=\frac{K_2-K_1}{K_1} \times 100\)

Substitute the given values in the above equation and it can be rewritten as

\( \Rightarrow \% \text { change }=\frac{50 K-12.5 K}{12.5 K} \times 100 \)

\( \Rightarrow \% \text { change }=3 \times 100=300 \%\)
