The angular acceleration of a particle moving along a circular path with uniform speed is:
such as cannot be predicted from the given information

During uniform motion, the change in angular velocity is zero i.e.,

\(\Rightarrow \Delta \omega=0\)

Then the equation of angular acceleration becomes

\(\Rightarrow \alpha=\frac{\Delta \omega}{\Delta t}=\frac{0}{\Delta t}=0 m / s ^2\)
______________ motion is the projection of uniform circular motion on a diameter of the circle in which the latter motion takes place.

Simple Harmonic Motion (SHM): Simple harmonic motion is a special type of periodic motion or oscillation where the restoring force is directly proportional to the displacement and acts in the direction opposite to that of displacement.

Simple harmonic motion is the projection of uniform circular motion on a diameter of the circle in which the latter motion takes place.
The equation of acceleration for a particle executing simple harmonic motion is given by \(a(t)=-\omega^2 A \sin (\omega t+\varphi)\). Find equation of velocity.

Simple harmonic motion occurs when the restoring force or acceleration is directly proportional to the displacement from equilibrium or mean position.

\(F \alpha-x\)

Where \(F =\) force and \(x =\) the displacement from equilibrium.

Equation of velocity in a simple harmonic motion:

\(v=A \omega \cos (\omega t+\phi)\)

where \(v\) is the velocity at any time \(t, A\) is amplitude, \(t\) is time, and \(\omega\) is the angular frequency.

Equation of acceleration in a simple harmonic motion:

\(v=A \omega^2 \sin (\omega t+\phi)\)

\(a(t)=-\omega^2 A \sin (\omega t+\varphi)\)

integrating both sides with respect to 't'

\(\int a \cdot d t=\int-\omega^2 A \sin (\omega t+\varphi) \cdot d t \)

\( v=\frac{A \omega^2 \cos (\omega t+\varphi)}{\omega} \)

\( v=A \omega \cos (\omega t+\varphi)\)
What is the maximum acceleration of a particle executing SHM?

We know that equation of acceleration in terms of displacement in SHM is given by:

a = - ω2x

And magnitude of a will be max at x = A or -A

So ​max = Aω2
In the simple harmonic motion, the velocity of a particle lags acceleration by ______.

Equation of velocity

\( \Rightarrow v = A \omega \cos (\omega t+\phi) \)

\(\Rightarrow v = A \omega \sin (\omega t +\phi+\frac{\pi }{ 2})\)

Phase of displacement \(=\omega t+\phi+\frac{\pi }{2}\)

Equation of acceleration is

\(\Rightarrow a=-A \omega^2 \sin (\omega t+\phi) \)

\( \Rightarrow a=A \omega^2 \sin (\omega t+\phi+\pi)\)

Phase of acceleration \(=\omega t+\phi+\pi\)

Difference between phase of acceleration and phase of velocity

\(\Rightarrow \Delta \phi=(\omega t+\phi+\pi)-(\omega t+\phi+\frac{\pi }{ 2})=\frac{\pi }{ 2}\)  or \(90^{\circ}\)

So velocity lags acceleration by \(90^{\circ}\).
A simple harmonic motion has amplitude A and time period T. The maximum velocity will be:

Since the total energy remains conserved. We can say that,

Maximum Kinetic Energy that is (at the mean position) = Maximum Potential energy( at the extreme position)

\( K=\frac{1}{2} m \omega^2 A^2\)

\( \Longrightarrow \frac{1}{2} m v^2=\frac{1}{2} m \omega^2 A^2\)

\(\Longrightarrow \frac{1}{2} m v^2=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\frac{2 \pi}{T}\right)^2 A^2\)

Canceling \(m\) from both sides and taking the square root, we get

\(v=\left(\frac{2 \pi}{T}\right) A\)=\(2 \pi \frac{A}{T}\)
A car, starting from rest, is moving with a constant acceleration \(3 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\). Find the distance travelled by this car in \(10 \mathrm{~s}\).

Given \(\mathrm{U}=0 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{sec}\) and \(\mathrm{a}=3 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{sec}^2\)

By the second equation of motion, the distance covered by the car in the first 10 seconds is given as,

\(\Rightarrow s=U t+\frac{1}{2} a t^2\)

\(\Rightarrow s_{10}=(0 \times 3)+\frac{1}{2}\left(3 \times 10^2\right)\)

\(\Rightarrow s_{10}=150 \mathrm{~m}\)

The slope of the distance-time graph not only provides the speed of the object but also provides the direction.

If the graph line is increasing, then the object is moving in a positive direction.

If the graph line is decreasing, then the object is moving in the negative direction.

A constant slope depicts constant speed, while a changing slope means that the speed is changing (accelerating or decelerating).
A car, initially at rest travels \(20 {~m}\) in 4 secalong a straight line with constant acceleration. Find the acceleration of car?

Equation of motion : The mathematical equations used to find the final velocity, displacements, time, etc of a moving object without considering force acting on it are called equations of motion.

\(\mathrm{V}=\mathrm{u}+\mathrm{at}\)

So \(a=\frac{(v-u)}{t}\)
A ball is dropped from a height of \(80 \mathrm{~m}\). The distance travelled by it in the fourth second will be___________.

Given that:

The ball is dropped from \(80 \mathrm{~m}\) height, so initial velocity \((\mathrm{u})=0 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

Acceleration is due to gravity \((a)=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\)

and \(n=4\)

For nth second, \(S_n=u+\frac{a}{2(2 n-1)}\)

Distance travelled in 4th second \(\left(S_4\right)=0+\frac{10}{2(2 \times 4-1)}=35 \mathrm{~m}\)

A truck initially at rest travels a distance of \(70 \mathrm{~m}\) in 7 seconds and the motion continues in the same manner. If the body executes a uniformly accelerated motion, then acceleration (a) is (approx.):

Given \(S=70 \mathrm{~m}, t=7 \mathrm{sec~} u=0 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

The equation of motion connecting displacement, initial velocity, and time is given by

\(\Rightarrow S=u t+\frac{1}{2} a t^2\)

substituting the given values the above equation becomes

\(\Rightarrow 70=0 \times 7+\frac{1}{2} a \times 7^2\)

\(\Rightarrow a=\frac{70 \times 2}{7 \times 7}=\frac{20}{7}=2.85 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\)
In negative acceleration, the velocity of a body_____________.

The direction of acceleration is determined by the general principle that if an object is slowing down, the acceleration is in the opposite direction of the motion.

Hence, with negative acceleration, the velocity of a body decreases .

The negative sign of acceleration shows that the velocity of the body is decreasing per unit of time.
Negative acceleration occurs in the opposite direction of:

The direction of acceleration is determined by the general principle that if an object is slowing down, the acceleration is in the opposite direction of the motion.

Therefore, from this principle, it becomes clear that when an object is slowing down, the acceleration is in the opposite direction of velocity. This is a negative acceleration.
A body starts from rest and travels with a uniform acceleration of \(20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\). Calculate the time taken by the body to cover a distance of \(90 \mathrm{~m}\).

Given that:

Acceleration \((\mathrm{a})=20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\)

Distance traveled \((\mathrm{S})=90 \mathrm{~m}\)

Initial Velocity \((\mathrm{u})=0\)

To find the time taken \((\mathrm{t})\) to cover \(90 \mathrm{~m}\).

Equation of motion states that:

\(S=u t+\frac{1}{2} a t^2\)

\(90=0 \times t+\frac{1}{2} \times 20 \times t^2\)

\(t^2=9\)

Time taken \((t)=3 \mathrm{sec}\)
The slope of an acceleration-time graph gives:

The slope of an acceleration time graph equals the ratio of change in acceleration for the time interval considered.

Slope \(=\frac{\Delta a}{\Delta t}=\) rate of change of acceleration = jerk
A body starts from rest and travels with an acceleration of 2 m/s². After t seconds its velocity is 10 m/s. Then t is:

Given that a body starts from rest and travels with an acceleration of 2 m/s². After t seconds its velocity is 10 m/s.

From the law of acceleration we know that

\(a=\frac{v-u}{t}\)

where a is the acceleration.

v is the final velocity after some time.

u is the initial velocity.

t is the time.

Here, a=2 m/s²

v=10m/s

The body start from rest so, u=0

We have to find out the value of t.

Putting the values of a and v in the above equation we get

\(2=\frac{10}{t}\)

\(t=\frac{10}{2}\)

\(\mathrm{t}=5\)

So, the value of \(t\) is 5 second.

A particle starts from rest with a constant acceleration. At a time \(t\) second, the speed is found to be \(100 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) and one second later the speed becomes 150 \(\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\). The value of acceleration and the distance travelled during the \((\mathrm{t}+1)^{\mathrm{th}}\) second will be respectively:

Given: Velocity at \(\mathrm{sec}=100 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\), Velocity at \((\mathrm{t}+1) \mathrm{sec}=150 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

Velocity at time \(\mathrm{t}\) is \(100 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}=\mathrm{a} \times \mathrm{t} \quad \ldots . .1\)

Velocity at time \((\mathrm{t}+1)\) second is \(150 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}=\mathrm{a} \times(\mathrm{t}+1) \quad \ldots .2\)

From equation (1) and (2)

Acceleration \((a)=50 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\)

Now consider the interval \(t\) second to \((t+1)\) second, time elapsed \(=1 \mathrm{~s}\)

Initial Velocity \(=100 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

Final velocity \(=150 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\).

Applying equation of motion

\(v^2=u^2+2 a s\)

\(\therefore(150 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s})^2=(100 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s})^2+2\left(50 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\right) \mathrm{x}\)

\((22500-10000)=100 x\)

\(\mathrm{x}=125 \mathrm{~m}\).
If position of a particle \(\mathrm{X}\) is directly proportional to \(\mathrm{t}^2\) then:

It is given that \(x \propto t^2\)

It is given that \(X \propto t^2\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{X}=\mathrm{kt}^2\)

Differentiate the above equation w.r.t time, then

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d(X)}{d t}=v=\frac{d\left(k t^2\right)}{d t}=2 k t\)

Therefore velocity will be variable. Hence option 1 is incorrect.

Differentiate the above equation again w.r.t time, then

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d(v)}{d t}=a=\frac{d(2 k t)}{d t}=2 k\)

Therefore, acceleration will be constatnt.
The velocity of a body depends on time according to the equation \(v=20+0.1 t^2\). The body is moving with-

Given: \(\mathrm{v}=20+0.1 \mathrm{t}^2\)

\(a=\frac{d v}{d t}=0+0.2 t\)

\(\because a \propto t\)

\(\therefore\) Body is in non uniform acceleration.
If body having initial velocity zero is moving with uniform acceleration \(8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{sec}^2\), then the distance travelled by it in fifth second will be:

Distance travelled in \(n^{\text {th }}\) second \(=u+\frac{a}{2}(2 n-1)\)

Distance travelled in \(5^{\text {th }}\) second \(=0+\frac{8}{2}(2 \times 5-1)=36 m\)

An alpha particle enters a hollow tube of \(4 \mathrm{~m}\) length with an initial speed of \(1 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{s}\). It is accelerated in the tube and comes out of it with a speed of \(9 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{s}\). The time for which it remains inside the tube is:

Initial speed, \(\mathrm{u}=1 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{s}=1000 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

Final speed, \(v=9 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{s}=9000 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

By using the relation

\(v^2=u^2+2 \text { as }\)

\((9000)^2=(1000)^2+2 \times a \times 4\)

\(a=10^7 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\)

\(\therefore\) the time for which the particle remains in the tube

\(\mathrm{v}=\mathrm{u}+\mathrm{at}\)

\(\text { or } \mathrm{t}=\frac{\mathrm{v}-\mathrm{u}}{\mathrm{a}}=\frac{9000-1000}{10^7}\)

\(=8 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~s}\).

Displacement \(\mathrm{y}\) (in \(\mathrm{m}\) ) of a body varies with time \(\mathrm{t}\) ( in sec) as: \(\mathrm{y}=\frac{-2}{3} \mathrm{t}^2+16 \mathrm{t}+2\) How long does the body take to come to rest?

The displacement is given as: \(\mathrm{y}=\mathrm{ut}+\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{at}^2\)

where, \(\mathrm{u}\) is the initial velocity and \(\mathrm{a}\) is the acceleration.

Comparing with given expression: \(\mathrm{y}=16 \mathrm{t}-\frac{2 \mathrm{t}^2}{3}+2\),

\(u=16 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}, \mathrm{a}=-\frac{4}{3} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\)

As, \(\mathrm{v}=\mathrm{u}+\) at, where \(\mathrm{v}\) is final velocity.

Taking \(\mathrm{v}=\mathrm{o}\), the time taken for body to come to rest.

\(0=16-\frac{4}{3} t \Rightarrow t=12 \mathrm{sec}\)
A truck and a car are moving with equal velocity. If equal retarding force is applied to each of them on applying the brakes, both will stop after a certain distance. Then:
Truck will cover less distance before rest
Car will cover less distance before rest

Using 3rd equation of motion,

v2−u2=2as

Putting v=0,

u2=2as (negative sign in a cancels negative sign with u)

And putting \(a=\frac{f}{m}\), where \(f\) is retarding force

Stopping distance \(s=\frac{u^2 \mathrm{~m}}{2 f}\)

The mass of the truck is greater than that of the car. Hence when velocity is the same, then the car will cover less distance as the stopping distance is directly proportional to mass.
A ball is thrown up in the sky, at what position will the instantaneous speed be minimum?
After covering one fourth of the whole trajectory

When the ball rises up, there will be a point where it will be in the state of instantaneous rest. At the this position the speed of the ball will be 0. Speed is maximum at the initial and final points.

A bird flies with a speed of 10 km/hr and a car moves with uniform speed 8 km/hr. Both start from B to A at the same instant (BA = 40 km). The bird after reaching A flies back immediately to meet the approaching car. Once it reaches the car, it flies back to A. The bird repeats this until both the car and the bird reach A simultaneously. What is the total distance flown by the bird?

Total time taken by car, \(\mathrm{T}=\frac{\mathrm{s}}{\mathrm{v}}=\frac{40}{8}=5 \mathrm{hrs}\)

Total distance flown by the bird, \(\mathrm{s}^{\prime}=\mathrm{v}^{\prime} \mathrm{T}=10 \times 5=50 \mathrm{~km}\)
If a car travels \(\frac{2}{5}\) th of the total distance with a speed v1 and \(\frac{3}{5}\) th of the distance with a speed v2. The average speed is given by:

Time taken to cover \(\frac{2}{5} t h\) distance \(t_1=\frac{2}{5} \frac{s}{v_1}\)

Time taken to cover \(\frac{3}{5}\) th distance \(t_2=\frac{3}{5} \frac{s}{v_2}\)

\(V_{m g}=\frac{s}{t_1+t_2}\)

\(=\frac{{s}}{\frac{2 s}{5 v_1}+\frac{3 s}{5 v_2}}\)

\(=\frac{5 v_1 v_2 s}{s\left(2 v_2 s+3 v_1 s\right)}\)

\(\frac{5 v_1 v_2}{3 v_1+2 v_2}\)

A particle of unit mass undergoes one-dimensional motion such that its velocity varies according to \(v(x)=\beta x^{-2 n}\), where \(\beta\) and \(n\) are constants and \(x\) is the position of the particle. The acceleration of the particle as a function of \(x\), is given by:

Given \(V=\beta x^{-2 n}\)

we know, \(a=v \frac{d v}{d x}\)

\(a=\beta x^{-2 n} \cdot \frac{d\left(\beta x^{-2 n}\right)}{d x}\)

\(=\beta x^{-2 n} \cdot-2 n \beta x^{-2 n-1}\)

\(=-2 n \beta^2 x^{-2 n-2 n-1}\)

\(a=-2 n \beta^2 x^{-4 n-1}\)
Consider an object in uniformly accelerated motion. If the velocity-time graph intersects the time axis, what does it represent?
If the velocity-time graph intersects the time axis, it implies that the object has zero velocity at that particular time. This might occur when the object changes its direction.
In a displacement-time graph for uniformly accelerated motion, what geometric shape does the graph form?
The displacement-time graph for uniformly accelerated motion forms a parabolic shape. This is because the displacement is proportional to the square of time ( \(\left.s \propto t^2\right)\).
If a velocity-time graph is a straight line with a positive slope, what does it indicate about the object's motion?
A positive slope on a velocity-time graph indicates a constant and positive acceleration. The steeper the slope, the greater the acceleration.
An object covers equal distances in equal intervals of time. What type of motion is this?
In uniform motion, an object covers equal distances in equal intervals of time. The speed remains constant throughout the motion.
In uniform motion, what is the relationship between the average velocity \(\left(v_{\text {avg }}\right.\) ) and the instantaneous velocity \((v)\) over any time interval?
In uniform motion, the instantaneous velocity remains constant, and thus, the average velocity is equal to the instantaneous velocity.
An object moves with a velocity function \(v(t)=4 t^2-2 t\). What is the displacement function \(x(t)\), and what does it represent?

The displacement is the integral of the velocity function. Integrating \(v(t)=\) \(4 t^2-2 t\) with respect to \(t\) gives \(x(t)=\frac{4}{3} t^3-t^2+C\), where \(C\) is the constant of integration, representing constant acceleration.
What does the term "instantaneous velocity" refer to?
Average velocity over a small time interval.
Velocity at a specific instant or moment.
Average velocity over a large time interval.
Instantaneous velocity refers to the velocity of an object at a particular instant or moment, capturing its exact speed and direction at that point.
If an object moves along a straight line, and its velocity-time graph is a horizontal line, what can be said about its instantaneous velocity?
A horizontal line on a velocity-time graph indicates constant velocity, and therefore, the instantaneous velocity remains constant.
The World Meteorological organization says atmospheric pressure in New York has fallen by a large amount. What does it indicate?

If at a place atmospheric pressure fall by a large amount, it means air at place has moved upward side and there is vacuum condition (low pressure.)

  • The air from other places where pressure is high comes to take this place.
  • The lower the pressure at a place the higher the speed of air to fill the place.
  • So when atmospheric pressure in New York has fallen by a large amount, the air will come here with very high speed.
  • Therefore a storm condition will be there.
What is the mass of one liter of cottonseed oil of density \(926 kg / m ^3\) ?

Given, \(\rho=926 kg / m ^3, V=1\) litre

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{1000} m^3 \Rightarrow 1 \times 10^{-3} m^3 \Rightarrow \rho=\frac{m}{V} \Rightarrow m=\rho \times v=0.926 kg\)
If ice at \(0^{\circ}\) Celsius in a beaker melts and temperature rises to \(10^{\circ}\), the water level in the beaker:

From the above theoretical portion, we can clearly say that the volume of water is minimum at \(4^{\circ} C\).

So when temperature increases from \(0^{\circ} C\) to \(4^{\circ} C\), the volume decreases or falls. After that when the temperature increases from \(4^{\circ} C\) to beyond, the volume increases or rises in the beaker.

So upon increasing temperature from \(0^{\circ} C\) to \(10^{\circ} C\), the volume of water first falls then rises in the beaker.
If the pressure increases, the bulk modulus of elasticity:
Bulk modulus is the property of a material. It just relates to the pressure and volume change of the material. The bulk modulus remains constant.

The density of ice is \(0.9168 g / cm ^3\).

The density of water is \(1 g / cm ^3\).

The ice is less dense than the water, so it will float over water.
A deep-sea diver may hurt his eardrum during diving because of:

In normal condition or at standard pressure (normal atmospheric pressure in air ) inside eardrum and outside pressure is the same, this means force exerted on both side of eardrums are same.

Now if we go underwater, then pressure outside eardrums will be greater than that of inside.

And this will create a pressure difference between inside and outside of eardrums, because of this water will exert force on eardrum.

Hence as deep-sea diver further goes deep inside, water pressure will keep on increases which will cause permanent damage to its eardrums because of this pressure difference.
A hydraulic lift has two pistons with area \(1 m ^2\) and \(0.25 m ^2\). What is the force exerted by the smaller piston when \(40 N\) is placed on the larger piston?

From Pascal's Law, the pressure inside the liquid will be equal at every place. So the pressure at \(A\) and \(B\) will be equal.

\(P_A=P_B\)

Pressure \(=\frac{\text { Force }}{\text { Area }} \)

\( \frac{F_1}{A_1}=\frac{F_2}{A_2} \)

\( \frac{F_1}{0.25}=\frac{40}{1} \)

\( F _1=10 N \)
The main reason why the walls of a dam made thicker at the bottom than the top is:
It reduces the cost of construction of dam.
It prevents seepage from the bottom of the dam.
Pressure due to water is highest at the bottom of the dam.
To reduce the amount of material required to construct the dam.

The pressure due to fluid is directly proportional to the height of the water column. Hence, pressure increases with an increase in depth from the water surface.

To withstand this pressure the walls of the dam are constructed thicker at the bottom than at the top.

The height of an earthen dam is \(15 m\). The maximum height of water column that the dam can hold is \(10 m\). Calculate the pressure at the bottom of the dam, if the dam is filled to its maximum capacity. (Take acceleration due to gravity as 10 \(m / s ^2\) ).

Given data,

Height of the water column(h) \(=10 m\)

Acceleration due to gravity ( g )\(=10 m / s ^2\)

We know that,

Density of water \((\rho)=1000 kg / m ^3\)

Hence, Pressure due to water \((P)=1000 \times 10 \times 10 Pa\)

\( \Rightarrow P=100000 Pa =100 \times 10^3 Pa \)

\(\Rightarrow P=100 kPa\)

Which of the following statements about Pascal's principle is true for the fluid's pressure?

A. It is valid only for incompressible fluids

B. It explains why light objects float

C. It explains why the pressure is greater at the bottom of a lake than at the surface

D. It is valid only for objects that are less dense than water

The pressure in a closed volume of fluid is the same as every point of the vessel. Objects float by the Archimedes principle.

The pressure difference at the bottom of the lake is due to hydrostatic pressure is more at the bottom. Pascal law is valid for objects immersed in any confined liquid. So No statement is correct.
The pressure at the bottom of a tank containing a liquid does not depend on:

Hydrostatic pressure depends on the depth of the point below the surface \((h)\), nature of liquid \((\rho)\), and acceleration due to gravity (g).

Hydrostatic pressure is independent of the amount of liquid, the shape of the container or the crosssectional area.
Which of the following is based on Pascal's law?
Hydraulic Lift: The lift that uses pascal's law and used to lift objects with the help of fluid is called hydraulic lift. It works on Pascal's law.
The device used to measure the flow speed of the incompressible fluid is called:

The device used to measure the flow speed of the incompressible fluid is called the Venturi meter. 

Venturi-meter: It is a device that is used to measure the flow speed of an incompressible liquid. It consists of a broad diameter tube and a small constriction at the middle.
Mercury is used in barometer because of its:
Mercury Barometer: It is a device used to measure atmospheric pressure. So, mercury barometer is a device used to measure atmospheric pressure and mercury is used in it because of its high density.
The principle behind the _______________ is seen in the carburetor where the fuel is sucked into the chamber.

The carburetor of an automobile has a Venturi channel (nozzle) through which air flows with high speed.

The pressure is then lowered at the narrow neck and the petrol (gasoline) is sucked up in the chamber to provide the correct mixture of air to fuel necessary for combustion.
Can Bernoulli's equation is used to describe the flow of water through the rapid in a river?

No, Bernoulli's equation cannot be used to describe the rapid flow of water in a river because the rapid flow is turbulent and not streamlined. Bernoulli's equation is applicable to streamline the flow of a fluid.

Streamline flow is the type of flow in which each particle of the liquid passing a given point moves along a straight path and has the same velocity or we can say that fluid velocity remains constant at any point of the streamline.
The maximum velocity up to which fluid motion is streamline is known as __________ velocity.

Critical velocity: It is the maximum velocity up to which fluid motion is streamlined. If the velocity of the fluid is low than critical velocity it acts like a streamline flow otherwise it will act as turbulent flow.

If the velocity of flow is less than critical velocity, the rate of flow of fluid depends basically on the viscosity of the fluid.

If the velocity of flow is more than critical velocity, the rate of the flow depends on the density and not on the viscosity.

From the above discussion, the maximum velocity up to which fluid motion is streamline is known as critical velocity.
Which of the following is correct regarding Brownian motion?
It is a streamline motion of molecules
It is a random movement of molecules
Due to gravity, movement of particles in downward direction.

Brownian motion: The random movement of very small particles (microscopic) in a fluid, because of the continuous interaction of particles with molecules of the surrounding medium is called Brownian motion.
With the increase in velocity of air, air pressure:

Bernoulli's equation states that the summation of pressure head, kinetic head, and datum/potential head is constant for steady, incompressible, rotational, and non-viscous flow.

In other words, an increase in the speed of the fluid occurs simultaneously with a decrease in pressure or a decrease in the fluid's potential energy i.e. the total energy of a flowing system remains constant until an external force is applied. With the increase in velocity of air, air pressure decreases.
Which of the following limitation is correct for Bernoulli's Equation?
It is only applicable for streamline flow of a fluid and not applicable for turbulent flow.
It is only applicable for turbulent flow of a fluid but not applicable for streamline flow.
It is only applicable for streamline flow of a fluid as well as for turbulent flow.

"It is only applicable for turbulent flow of a fluid but not applicable for streamline flow." is correct statement.

Streamline flow/Laminar flow is the type of flow in which each particle of the liquid passing a given point moves along a straight path and has the same velocity or we can say that fluid velocity remains constant at any point of the streamline

Turbulent flow is those type of flow in which velocity exceeds a certain value and the path as well as velocity continuously start changing which means they don't remain constant.
Ram's father got an heart attack. The doctor was explaining him the process inside the body that leads to heart attack. He must have explained him using:

A heart attack can be explained by Bernoulli's principle. The artery may get constricted due to the accumulation of plaque on its inner walls. In order to drive the blood through this constriction, a greater demand is placed on the activity of the heart.

The speed of the flow of the blood in this region is raised which lowers the pressure inside and the artery may collapse due to the external pressure.

The heart exerts further pressure to open this artery and forces the blood through. As the blood rushes through the opening, the internal pressure once again drops due to the same reasons leading to a repeat collapse. This may result in a heart attack.

The reading of the pressure meter attached with a closed pipe is \(3.5 \times 10^5 Nm ^{-2}\). On opening the valve of the pipe the reading of the pressure meter is reduced to \(3.0 \times 10^5 Nm ^{-2}\). Calculate the speed of the water flowing in the pipe.

If a liquid is flowing through a horizontal tube, \(h\) remains constants and we can write it as:

\( P+\frac{1}{2} \rho v^2=\) constant 

\( P+.5 \rho v^2=\) constant 

Before opening the valve initial pressure \(p_1=3.5 \times 10^5 Nm ^{-2}, v_1=0\) (velocity before opening the pipe) After opening the pipe final pressure \(p _2=3.0 \times 10^5 Nm ^{-2}, v _2=\) ? (velocity after opening the pipe) In horizontal flow, \(h\) remains constants and we can write as \(P+\frac{1}{2} \rho v^2=\) constant ( density of the water is \(\left.10^3 kg / m ^3\right)\)

Hence we can say that P.E remains unchanged. so by Bernoulli's Equation we can write as \(p_2+\frac{1}{2} \rho v^2=p_2+\frac{1}{2} \rho v_1^2\) on putting the value in equation we get,

\(3.0 \times 10^5+ \frac{1} { 2} \times 10^3 v _2^2=3.5 \times 10^5+\frac{1 }{ 2 }\times 10^3 \times(0)^2\) on solving we get

\(\frac{1} { 2} \times 10^3 \times v_2^2=(3.5-3.0) \times 10^5=0.5 \times 10^5\)

\(v _2^2=2 \times 0.5 \times 10^2=100\)

\(v _2=10 ms ^{-1}\)
Energy form of Bernoulli's principle, It is the sum of __________________________ and ______________.
Pressure Energy, Kinetic energy and Mechanical energy
Pressure Energy, Kinetic energy and Hydroelectric energy
Pressure Energy, Kinetic energy and Rotational energy
Pressure Energy, Kinetic energy and Potential energy

Energy form of Bernoulli's principle, It is the sum of Pressure Energy, Kinetic energy and Potential energy.

Bernoulli's Principle states that the sum of the pressure energy, kinetic energy, and potential energy per unit volume of an incompressible, non-viscous fluid in a streamlined flow remains constant.


It can be expressed as Mathematically

\(P+\frac{1}{2} \rho v^2+\rho g h=\) constant where \(P\) is pressure in the fluid, \(\rho\) is the density of the fluid, \(h\) is the mean height, \(g\) is the acceleration due to gravity.

The above formula is based on the law of Conservation of Energy.
Find the height \(H\) to which water will rise if \(v =4 m / s\). (Pressure at \(A\) and \(B\) is atmospheric pressure)

Bernoulli's Principle basically states energy conservation for fluids.

\(P+\frac{1}{2} \rho v^2+\rho g h=\text { const. }\)

Using Bernoulli's Principle at Points A and B.

\(P_A+\frac{1}{2} \rho v_A^2+\rho g h_A=P_B+\frac{1}{2} \rho v_B^2+\rho g h_B\)

\(P _{ A }= P _{ B }\) (Since both are at the atmospheric level)

\( \frac{1}{2} \rho v_A^2+\rho g h_A=\frac{1}{2} \rho v_B^2+\rho g h_B\)

\( \frac{1}{2} v_A^2+g h_A=\frac{1}{2} v_B^2+g h_B\)

At point \(B\) there will be no velocity. So \(v_B=0\)

At point \(A\) taking ground position, so \(h_A=0 ; h_B=H\)

\( \frac{1}{2} v_A^2+g \times 0=\frac{1}{2} 0^2+g h_B \)

\( \frac{1}{2} v_A^2=g h_B \)

\(\frac{1}{2} 4^2=10 \times H \)

\( H =0.8 m\)

So water rise up to 0.8 m.
Bernoulli's equation is true when velocity of the fluid particles is uniform

Option (A) is correct as we know the limitation of Bernoulli's theorem is- it is valid for a particle having a uniform velocity.

Option (B) is correct CGS unit of viscosity is poise

Option (C) is correct Equation of continuity is \(A_1 V_1 \rho_1=A_2 V_2 \rho_2\).

Here \(\rho_1=\rho_2\) So, we can say that \(A _1 V _1= A _2 V _2\)

So, all three options are correct that's why Option (D) is followed.

There is an opening of \(5 cm ^2\) at the bottom of a tank. If the height of water in the tank is \(5 m\), then at what rate (in \(m ^3 / s\) ) will water flow out from this opening? (use \(g =10 m / s ^2\) )

Given,

Area \((A)=5 cm =5 \times 10^{-4} m ^2\) and \(h =5 m\)

The relation between the flow rate and the radius is given:

\( \Rightarrow Q =\)  (Area of opening) \(\times\) (Velocity of water)

\( \Rightarrow Q = A \times \sqrt{2} gh\)

\( \Rightarrow Q=5 \times 10^{-4} \times \sqrt{2 \times 10 \times 5}\)

\( \Rightarrow Q =5 \times 10^{-4} \times 10=5 \times 10^{-3} m ^3 / s\)
In a container, water is filled up to height \(H\). If we make a hole opening at height \(h\) (as shown in the figure), find the velocity of water coming out from this hole.

Using Bernoulli's Principle at hole opening and at the free surface of the container

At both places, pressure is atmospheric pressure \(P _0\)

At the free surface, velocity will be zero because when liquid comes out of the hole, the free surface will not move or move very little.

\( P_0+\frac{1}{2} \rho v_1^2+\rho g h_1=P_0+\frac{1}{2} \rho v_2^2+\rho g h_2\)

\( \frac{1}{2} \rho v_1^2+\rho g h_1=\frac{1}{2} \rho v_2^2+\rho g h_2 \)

\( \frac{1}{2} v_1^2+g h_1=\frac{1}{2} v_2^2+g h_2\)

\(\Rightarrow\) velocity at surface is zero i.e. \(v_1=0\) and velocity at opening is \(v , v _2= v\)

\(\Rightarrow h _1= H ; h _2= h\)

,\(\frac{1}{2} 0^2+g H=\frac{1}{2} v^2+g h\) \(\frac{1}{2} v^2=g(H-h)\)

\( v=\sqrt{2 g(H-h)}\)
______________ equation relates the pressure difference between two points in a pipe to changes in Kinetic as well as potential energy.

Bernoulli's principle: For a streamlined flow of an ideal liquid in a varying cross-section tube the total energy per unit volume remains constant throughout the fluid.

This means that in steady flow the sum of all forms of mechanical energy in a fluid along a streamline is the same at all points on that streamline.

From Bernoulli's principle

\(P+\frac{1}{2} \rho v^2+\rho g h=\) constant 

i.e., \(P_1+\frac{1}{2} \rho v_1^2+\rho g h_1=P_2+\frac{1}{2} \rho v_2^2+\rho g h_2\)
A small hole of area of cross-section 2 mm2 is present near the bottom of a fully filled open tank of height 2 m. Taking g = 10 m/s2, the rate of flow of water through the open hole would be nearly:

Now the rate of flow \((Q)\) can be given as

\( Q=A \times v=A \sqrt{2 g h}\)

\( =2 \times 10^{-6} \times \sqrt{2 \times 10 \times 2}\)

Rate of flow \(Q=12.6 \times 10^{-6} m ^3 / s\)
An ideal liquid is flowing through a pipe of varying cross section area, the velocity of flowing liquid
will increase where cross section area decrease
will decrease where cross section area decrease
initially will be maximum and later decrease continuously

The flow of liquid (Q) is the same at every point in the tube.

⇒ Q = Av = const.

⇒ Av = const.

\(\Rightarrow v \propto \frac{1}{A}\)

So if the cross-section area of the pipe decreases, the velocity will increase and vice versa.
A disc of mass \(2 {~kg}\) and radius \(0.2 {~m}\) is rotating with angular velocity \(30 {rad} / {s}\). What is angular velocity, if a mass of \(0.25 {~kg}\) is put on the periphery of the disc?

Angular momentum in the absence of any external torque remains constant,

\( L=I \omega=\) (constant) 

\(\Rightarrow I_1 \omega_1=I_2 \omega_2 \)

\(\therefore \frac{1}{2} M r^2 \omega_1=\frac{1}{2}(M+2 m) r^2 \omega_2 \cdots { (i) } \)

Here, \(M=2 {~kg}, m=0.25 {~kg}, r=0.2 {~m} \)

\(\omega_1=30 {~rad} / {s}\)

Hence, we get after putting the given values in Eq. (i)

\( \frac{1}{2} \times 2 \times(0.2)^2 \times 30 =\frac{1}{2} \times(2+2 \times 0.25)(0.2)^2 \times \omega_2 \)

\(\Rightarrow 1.2=0.05 \omega_2 \)

\(\therefore \omega_2=24 {~rad}/{s}\)

An electric motor exerts a constant torque \(10 {~N}-{m}\) on a grind stone mounted on a shaft. Moment of inertia of the grind stone about the shaft is \(2 {~kg}-{~m}\). If the system starts from rest find the work done in \(8 {~s}\).

We know that the relation between torque (\(\tau)\) and the angular acceleration \((\alpha)=\frac{\tau}{1}=\frac{10}{2}=5 {~rad} /{s}^2\)

Also by the rotational equation of motion,

\(\omega=\omega_0+a t=5(8)=40 {~rad}/{s}\quad\)  (As starting from rest \(\omega_0=0\)

We know that, work done(W) is equal to change in Kinetic energy(K.E),

\(W=\Delta K E=\frac{1}{2}I \omega^2-0=\frac{1}{2} \times 2 \times(40)^2=1600 {~J}\)
The ratio of the radii of gyration of a circular disc about a tangential axis in the plane of the disc and of a circular ring of the same radius about a tangential axis in the plane of the ring is:

Moment of inertia of a disc about tangent in the plane of the disc

\(=\frac{1}{4} M R^2+M R^2=\frac{5}{4} M R^2 \)

\(\therefore M K^2=\frac{5}{4} M R^2 \)

or \(K=\frac{\sqrt{5}}{2} R\)

Again, moment of inertia of ring about tangent in the plane of the ring \(=\frac{1}{2} M R^2+M R^2=\frac{3}{2} M R^2\)

Now, \(M K^{\prime 2}=\frac{3}{2} M R^2\)

or \(K^{\prime}=\sqrt{\frac{3}{2}} {R}\)

Again, \(\frac{{K}}{{K}^{\prime}}=\frac{\sqrt{5}}{2} \times \sqrt{\frac{2}{3}}=\frac{\sqrt{5}}{\sqrt{6}}=\sqrt{5}: \sqrt{6}\)
Angular momentum of a particle of linear momentum \(\vec{p}\) and at a distance \(\vec{r}\) from the origin is:

Let the particle of \(m\) mass rotates about a fixed axis, then the angular momentum is given by a cross product of its position vector and linear momentum

\(L=M \times v \times r=\vec{p} \times \vec{r}\)

The resultant vector of the cross product of two vectors is also a vector. So, angular vector momentum is a vector quantity. The value of angular momentum:

\(L=\vec{r} \times \vec{p}\)

Four spheres of diameter \(2 a\) and mass \(M\) are placed with their centres on the four corners of a square of side \(b\). Then moment of inertia of the system about an axis about one of the sides of the square is:

The four spheres of diameter \(2 a\) or radius \(a\) are placed at the corners of the square of side \(b\).


Let us consider the first sphere which is the one at the top left corner. The moment of inertia of the sphere about the axis \(A_1\) is given by \(I_{1}^{'}=\frac{2}{5} M a^2\). 

According to parallel axis theorem, the moment of inertia of an object about an axis is equal to the sum of moment of inertia about a parallel axis passing through the centre of mass of the object and the product of mass of the object and square of the distance between the parallel axes. 

\(I=I_{c m}+M d^2\). 

The moment of inertia of the sphere about the \((A_2)\) axis \((I_1)=I_1{ }^{'}+M d^2 \)

\(\Rightarrow I_1=\frac{2}{5} M a^2+M b^2\)

Similarly, as the bottom left sphere is identical to sphere both physically and according to position, the moment of inertia of the bottom left sphere \((I_2)=\frac{2}{5} M a^2+M b^2\)

Now, for the spheres on the right side of the square, the moment of inertia of both will be same and will be equal to \(I_3=I_4=\frac{2}{5} M a^2\).

Now, the moment of inertia of the system will be the sum of all the moment of inertias, that is:

\(I_{\text {system }}=I_1+I_2+I_3+I_4 \)

\(\Rightarrow I_{\text {system }}=\frac{2}{5} M a^2+M b^2+\frac{2}{5} M a^2+M b^2+\frac{2}{5} M a^2+\frac{2}{5} M a^2 \)

\(\therefore I_{\text {system }}=\frac{8}{5} M a^2+2 M b^2\)

Therefore, the moment of inertia of the system about an axis about one of the sides of the square is \(\frac{8}{5} M a^2+2 M b^2\).
An object is rotating about a fixed point. The kinetic energy of the object is \(E\) and its angular momentum is \(L\). Then which of the following is true?

Angular momentum \((L)=I \times \omega\cdots(1)\)

Rotational kinetic energy, \((E)=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^2 \Rightarrow \omega=\sqrt{\frac{2 E}{I}} \cdots(2)\)

Substituting (2) in (1) we get

\(L=I \times \sqrt{\frac{2 E}{I}}=\sqrt{2 E I}\)

So, \({L} \propto \sqrt{E}\)
The radius of gyration of a rod of length '\(L\)' rotating about an axis perpendicular to the rod at its mid-point is:

Given:

\(L=\) length of rod, \(r=\) Radius of gyration,

The moment of inertia of any uniform rod of length \(L\) and Mass \(M\) about the axis is given by

\( I=\frac{M L^2}{12}\cdots(1)\)

If \(r\) is the radius of the thin rod axis, then the equation of moment of inertia is given by

\(I=M r^2\cdots(2)\)

On equating above two-equation, we get

\(\Rightarrow M r^2=\frac{M L^2}{12} \)

\(\Rightarrow r=\sqrt{\frac{L^2}{12}}=\frac{L}{\sqrt{2} 3} \)

\(\Rightarrow r=\frac{L}{2 \sqrt{3}}\)

So, the radius of gyration of the rod is \(r=\frac{L}{2 \sqrt{3}}\)
The distance between the centres of carbon and oxygen atoms in the carbon monoxide gas molecules is \(1.12 \times 10^{-10} {~m}\). Find the distance of centre of mass of molecules from carbon atom.

Let \(m_1\) and \(m_2\) be the masses of carbon and oxygen atom respectively. Let '\(d\)' be the distance of separation between the center of carbon and oxygen atoms.

Let \({x}_1\) be the position of the carbon and \({x}_2\) be the position of the oxygen atom

\({x}_{{cm}}=\frac{{m}_1 {x}_1+{m}_2 {x}_2}{{~m}_1+{m}_2} \cdots(1)\)

Now, \({x}_1=0 ~m\) and \(x_2=1.12 \times 10 { }^{-10}{~m}\)

\({m}_1\) mass of carbon atom \(=12 {~U}\) and \(\mathrm{m}_1\) mass of oxygen atom \(=16 {~U}\)

\({x}_{{cm}}=\frac{12 \times 0+16 \times 1.12 \times 10^{-10}}{12+16} \)

\({x}_{{cm}}=0.64 \times 10^{-10} {~m}\)

So, the position of center of mass of \(\mathrm{CO}\) molecule with respect to carbon atom \(=0.64 \times 10^{-10}{~m}\)

Two spheres each of mass \(M\) and radius \(\frac{R}{2}\) are connected with a massless rod of length \({R}\) as shown in the figure. The moment of inertia of the system about an axis ( \(Y Y^{\prime}\) ) passing through the centre of one of the spheres and perpendicular to the rod is:

According to parallel axis theorem, \(({I})={I}_0+{Md}^2\)

Momemt of inertia of farthest sphere is \((I_1)=\frac{2}{5} M\left(\frac{R}{2}\right)^2+M(2 R)^2\)

Momemt of inertia of nearest sphere is \((I_2)=\frac{2}{5} M\left(\frac{R}{2}\right)^2\)

Momemt of inertia of massless rod is \((I_3)=0\)

Moment of inertia of system is given by, \((I)=I_1+I_2+I_3\)

\((I)=\frac{2}{5} M\left(\frac{R}{2}\right)^2+M(2 R)^2+\frac{2}{5} M\left(\frac{R}{2}\right)^2=4 M R^2+\frac{1}{5} M R^2=\frac{21}{5} M R^2\)
An electric motor has a power rating of \(3.3 {~kw}\). If its motor turns at a rate of 120 \({rev} /{min}\) the torque of the shaft of the electric motor required for the purpose will be nearly:

We know that, 

\({P}={\tau} \omega\)

Where \({\tau}=\) torque and \(\omega=\) angular velocity

Here,

Power \(({P})=3.3 {~kW}=3300 {~W}\)

Angular velocity \((\omega)=120{~rev} / {min}=(120 \times \frac{2 \pi} {60}){~rad} / {s}=4 \pi {~rad} / {s}\)

Torque \((\tau)=\frac{P}{\omega}=\frac{3300}{4 \pi}=263 {~Nm}\)

A stationary horizontal disc is free to rotate about its axis. When a torque is applied on it, its kinetic energy as a function of \(\theta\), where \(\theta\) is the angle by which it has rotated, is given as \({k} \theta^2\). If its moment of inertia is \(I\) then the angular acceleration of the disc is:

A net torque acting upon an object will produce an angular acceleration of the object according to

\({\tau}={I} \alpha\)

Where, \(\tau=\) torque, \(I=\) Moment of inertia and \(\alpha=\) angular acceleration

Work done by the torque is responsible for the change in kinetic energy.

\(\therefore \tau=\frac{{dE}}{{d} \theta}=\frac{d\left(K \theta^2\right)}{d \theta} \)

\(\therefore {I} \alpha=2 {~K} \theta \)

\(\therefore \alpha=\frac{2 {k} \theta}{{I}}\)

Thus, the angular acceleration of the disk is \(\alpha=\frac{{2k}}{ {I}} \theta\)
If the length of the effort arm is increased without changing the length of the load arm in the lever, then the mechanical advantage of the lever will:

Mechanical advantage is defined as the ratio of the load applied on the lever to the effort applied.

\( M A=\frac{F_1}{F_2}=\frac{d_2}{d_1}\)

Where \(d_1=\) length of the load arm and \(d_2=\) length of the effort arm

If the length of the load arm is fixed,

\({MA} \propto {d}_2\cdots(1)\)

From equation 1 it is clear that mechanical advantage is directly proportional to the length of the effort arm if the length of the load arm is fixed.

Therefore if the length of the effort arm is increased without changing the length of the load arm in the lever, then the mechanical advantage of the lever will increase.
Fulcrum is a point in the lever at which:

An ideal lever is essentially a light (i.e. of negligible mass) rod pivoted at a point along its length. This point is called the fulcrum.


If two forces \(F_1\) and \(F_2\) are acting on the lever as shown in the figure at distances \(d_1\) and \(d_2\) respectively from the fulcrum, then from the rotational equilibrium,

\({F}_1 {~d}_1={F}_2 {~d}_2 \)

Load arm \(\times\) Load \(=\) Effort arm \(\times\) Effort
If the Earth is compressed to half of its radius and its mass remains the same, then the day will be of:

The moment of inertia of Earth \((I)=\frac{2}{5} M R^2\)

where, \(M=\) mass, \(R=\) radius

Angular speed is given as \((\omega)=\frac{2 \pi}{T}\)

In process of the sinking of the earth, no external torque is applied

Mass is same but radius is changed. 

So, \(I_1 \omega_1=I_2 \omega_2\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{2}{5} M R^2\left(\frac{2 \pi}{T}\right)=\frac{2}{5} M R^{\prime 2}\left(\frac{2 \pi}{T^{\prime}}\right)\)

\(\Rightarrow\left(\frac{R^2}{T}\right)=\left(\frac{R'^2}{T^{\prime}}\right)\)

The new radius \({R}^{\prime}=\frac{R}{2}\)

\(\left(\frac{R^2}{T}\right)=\left(\frac{(\frac{R^{\prime}}{2})^2}{T^{\prime}}\right)\)

\(\Rightarrow T^{\prime}=\frac{T}{4}\)

\({T}\) is \(24 {~hr}\) in normal conditon.

So, \(T^{\prime}=\frac{24}{4} {~hr}=6 {~hr}\)
The net torque acting on the rigid body is represented as:
Division of rotational inertia and of the body and angular acceleration
Multiplication of rotational inertia and of the body and angular acceleration
Summation of rotational inertia and of the body and angular acceleration
Subtraction of rotational inertia and of the body and angular acceleration

The cross product of force and the distance of force from point of action is called torque. 

\({T}={I} \alpha\)

The net force acting on a body is defined as the product of mass and acceleration of the body. In a similar way, the net torque is defined as the product of the moment of inertia (rotational inertia) and angular acceleration. The net torque acting on the rigid body is represented as multiplication of rotational inertia and of the body and angular acceleration.
Sphere, disc and ring are allowed to roll down on an inclined plane from its top, then order in which they reach at the bottom will be:

We know that, 

Moment of inertia \((I) = m r^2\)

We know that when a body moves downward it gets accelerated.

Moment of inertia of ring \(=m r^2\)

Moment of inertia of disc \(=\frac{m r^2}{2}\)

Moment of inertia of sphere \(=\frac{2 m r^2}{5}\)

As the moment of inertia is the resistance to the rotational motion, thus we see that the object with the least moment of inertia will reach the bottom first because it will accelerate fast.

So the order of moment of inertia is,

Ring > Disc > Sphere 

Therefore the order in which they reach the bottom is \(=\) Sphere, Disc, Ring
The ratio of the radii of gyration of a circular disc to that of a circular ring, each of same mass and radius around their respective axes is:

Moment of inertia of circular disk \((I_{c d})=\frac{1}{2} M R^2\)

Moment of Inertia of Circular ring \((I_{cr})= M R^2\)

The radius of the gyration of a body about an axis is the effective distance from the axis where the whole mass can be assumed to be concentrated keeping the moment of Inertia the same.

\({I}={MK}^2\)

Finding Radius of gyration ( \({K}_{{cd}}\) ) for a circular disk

\({M}\left({K}_{{cd}}\right)^2=\frac{{MR}^2}{2} \)

\(\Rightarrow {K}_{{cd}}=\frac{{R}}{\sqrt{2}}\cdots(1)\)

Finding a Radius of gyration \({K}_{{cd}}\) for a circular ring

\({M}\left({K}_{{cr}}\right)^2={MR}^2 \)

\(\Rightarrow {K}_{{cr}}={R}\cdots(2)\)

Finding the ratio of the Radius of Gyration from disk to ring

\(\frac{K_{c d}}{K_{c r}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\)

So, the required ratio \(=1: \sqrt{2}\)
The moment of inertia of a uniform circular disc of radius \(R\) and mass \(M\) about an axis passing from the edge of the disc and normal to the disc is:

The moment of inertia of the circular disc about the central axis (AB), \({I}_{{z}}=\frac{M R^2}{2}\)

From parallel axis theorem, the moment of inertia about an axis passing from the edge of the disc, \({I}={I}_{{C}}+{Mh}^2\)

From the figure, \({h}={R}\)

\(\Rightarrow I_Z+M R^2=\frac{M R^2}{2}+M R^2=\frac{3}{2} M R^2\)
A sphere of mass \(10{~kg}\) and radius \(0.5 {~m}\) rotates about an axis passing through the tangent at a point on its surface. The moment of inertia of the sphere about the tangent is:

Mass of the sphere, \(M=10 {~kg}\)

The radius of the sphere, \(R=0.5 {~m}\)

Consider a point \({P}\) on the surface of the sphere and a tangent passing through it as shown. Let the moment of inertia about this tangent be \({I}\).


We know, the moment of inertia about the central axis of a sphere,

\(I_C=\frac{2}{5} M R^2\)

Using the parallel axis theorem,

\({I}=\mathrm{I}_{{C}}+{Mh}^2\)

From the figure, \(h=R\)

\(\Rightarrow I=I_C+M R^2 \)

\(\Rightarrow I=\frac{2}{5} M R^2+M R^2=\frac{7}{5} M R^2=\frac{7}{5} \times 10 \times(0.5)^2 \)

\( \Rightarrow I=3.5 {~kg-m}^2\)
The parallel axis theorem can be applied to:
Any two parallel axes of rotation lying in the plane of the body.
Any two parallel axes of rotation of which one must pass through the centre of mass of the body.
Any two parallel axes of rotation of which one must lie within the body.

The moment of inertia of a body about an axis parallel to the body passing through its center is equal to the sum of moment of inertia of the body about the axis passing through the center and product of the mass of the body times the square of the distance between the two axes.

\(I=I_{\text {com }}+M x^2\), 

Where \(I=\) Total moment of inertia of the body, \(I_{\text {com }}=\) The moment of inertia about the center of mass, \(M=\) is mass, \(x=\) The perpendicular distance from an axis passing from center of mass.

The parallel axis theorem can be applied to any of two parallel axes of which one must pass through the center of mass of the body.
The moment of inertia of a disc with respect to its diameter is \(I\). Then the moment of inertia with respect to an axis passing through its circumference and parallel to diameter is:

The moment of inertia of the disc along its diameter \(({I})=\frac{M R^2}{4}\cdots(1)\)

Let the moment of inertia with respect to an axis passing through its circumference and parallel to the diameter be \(I'\).

Using parallel axis theorem, 

\({I}^{\prime}={I}+{mh}^2={I}+{MR}^2\cdots(2)\)

From eq.(1), 

\({MR}^2=4 {I}\)

Substituting in (2),

Moment of inertia with respect to an axis passing through its circumference and parallel to the diameter, \(I^{\prime}=I+4I=5I\)
Angular velocity of a minute hand clock is:

Angle covered by the minute hand in one complete rotation \(=2 \pi\) radian

Time taken to cover \(2 \pi\) radian : 

\(1\) hour \(={3 6 0 0}\) seconds

Angular velocity, \((\omega)=\frac{\text { angle }}{\text { time }}=\frac{d \theta}{d t}\)

Angular velocity, \((\omega)=\frac{2 \pi}{3600}=\frac{\pi}{1800} {~rad}/{s}\)
The initial angular velocity of an object is \(10 {~rad}/{s}\). After 10 seconds the angular velocity becomes \(20 {~rad}/{s}\). Find the angular acceleration of the object.

Angular acceleration \((\alpha)=\frac{\omega_f-\omega_i}{t}\)

where, \(\alpha=\) angular acceleration, \(\omega_{{f}}=\) final angular velocity, \(\omega_{{i}}=\) initial angular velocity , and \(t=\) time

Given,

Initial angular velocity \((\omega_{{i}})=10 {~rad} /{s}\)

Final angular velocity, \((\omega_{{f}})=20  {~rad} /{s}\)

time, \(t=10\) second

So, angular acceleration, \((\alpha)=\frac{(20-10)}{10} {~rad} /{s^2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \alpha=1 {~rad} /{s^2}\)
What kind of motion is called spin?
Spin is translational motion of an object about its own axis.
Spin is translational motion of an object about an axis parallel to the axis of the object.
Spin is rotational motion of an object about an axis parallel to the axis of the object.
Spin is the rotational motion of an object about its center of mass.
Spin is rotational motion of an object about an axis parallel to the axis of the object. Spin is the rotational motion of an object about its center of mass.
The angular velocity of an object whose angular acceleration is zero will be:

Angular velocity is the velocity associated with objects moving in a curved path. While on a curved path, the displacement is the change in angle about the point of rotation or curved motion.

Angular velocity, \((\omega)=\frac{\text { angle }}{time}=\frac{d \theta}{d t}\)

Angular acceleration is the rate of change of angular velocity with time. It is given by

\((\alpha)=\frac{d \omega}{d t}=\frac{d^2 \theta}{d t^2}\)

If the angular acceleration is zero, \(\alpha=0\)

\((\alpha)=\frac{d \omega}{d t}=0\)

Therefore angular velocity \((\omega)\) of an object whose angular acceleration is zero will be constant.
A wheel of moment of inertia \(0.40 {~kg}-{m}^2\) is making 2100 rotations per minute. The wheel is brought to a complete stop in \(2\) seconds. The angular acceleration of the wheel is:

Angular velocity in terms of RPM (revolutions per minute)

\(\omega=\frac{2 \pi f}{60}\)

where \(\omega\) is in terms of radian per second and \(f\) is in revolution per minute.

Angular acceleration (\(\alpha\)): The rate of change of angular velocity is known as angular acceleration.

The relation between \(\alpha\) and changing \(\omega\) is given by:

\(\omega_1=\omega_0+\alpha t\)

where \(\omega_1=\) Final angular velocity, \(\omega_0=\) Initial angular velocity \(\alpha=\) Angular acceleration.

\({f}_0=2100 {~rpm}, {f}_1=0 {~rpm}, {t}=2 {~sec}\).

\(\omega_0=\frac{2 \pi\times f_0}{60}=\frac{2 \pi\times 2100}{60}=70 \pi \)

\(\omega_1=0 \)

\(\omega_1=\omega_0+\alpha t \)

\(0=70 \pi+\alpha \times 2 \)

\(\alpha=-35 \pi \) radians/second \({ }^2\) or \(35 \pi \) radians/second \({ }^2\)
The correct relationship between the angular velocity \((\omega)\) and linear velocity \((V)\) of an object is:

Angular velocity \((\omega)=\frac{{d} \theta}{{dt}}\)

where, \(\omega=\) angular velocity in radian per second, \({d} \theta=\) small angular displacement in radian, and \({dt}=\) small time in second.

Relation of angular velocity with linear velocity (\(V)=\omega \times r\)

where, \({V}=\) linear velocity of the object in metre per second, \(\omega=\) angular velocity of the object in radian per second, and \(r=\) radius of the circle in which the body is moving in metre.
Particle undergoes uniform circular motion. About which point on the plane of the circle, the angular momentum of the particle will remains conserved?

As we know, the centripetal force is a force required to move a body uniformly in a circle. This force acts along the radius and towards the centre of the circle.

Conservation of Angular Momentum: If the total external torque on a system is zero, its angular momentum remains constant.

We know that \(L=I \times \alpha=T_{\text {net }}\)

Where, \({L}=\) angular momentum, \(\alpha=\) angular acceleration, \({I}_{\text {net }}=\) Net external torque.

If \({T}_{\text {net }}=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{{d} L}{dt}=0\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{L}=\) constant 

The torque of this force about the centre is zero. So, angular momentum about the centre remains conserved.
Moment of inertia of a fan is \(0.06 {~kg}-{m}^2\). If its angular speed is increased from 0 to 5 revolution/sec. Then its maximum angular momentum in M.K.S. unit is:

We know that, 

Angular momentum \((L)=I \omega\)

Given \(L=0.06 \mathrm{~kg}-\mathrm{m}^2, \omega_1=0 {~rev}/{sec}=0 {~rad} / {sec}\), and \(\omega_2=5 {~rev} / {sec}=5 \times 2 \pi=10 \pi\) \({rad} /{sec}\)

\(\omega_1=\) minimum angular velocity and \(\omega_2=\) maximum angular velocity

The maximum angular momentum in M.K.S. unit is

\( L=I \omega_2\)

From the above equation, it is clear that the angular momentum will be maximum for maximum angular velocity

\(\Rightarrow L=0.06 \times 10 \pi=0.6 \pi\) (Maximum angular momentum)
When a horizontal disc is rotated about its vertical axis and sand is dropped on it, then its angular velocity will:

According to the law of conservation of angular momentum, the total angular momentum of the body about that axis remains constant i.e., if the moment of inertia of the body increases then angular velocity and vice-versa. When the sand is dropped at the center, the total mass of the system increase hence the moment of inertia \((I)\) increases as \({I}={mr}^2\).

When sand is poured on a rotating disc, the moment of inertial of the disc will increases, but the angular momentum of the disc will remains constant, and hence its angular velocity will decreases.
The scalar product of two vectors has a magnitude that is proportional to (consider \(\theta\) as angle between two vectors):

The scalar product of two vectors has a magnitude that is proportional to (consider \(\theta\) as angle between two vectors) \(\operatorname{Cos} \theta\).

The dot product or scalar product is the sum of the products of the corresponding entries of the two sequences of numbers. It is the product of the Euclidean magnitudes of the two vectors and the cosine of the angle between them.

Let the two vectors are \(A\) and \(B\) then dot the Product of the two vectors:

\(\mathrm{A} \cdot \mathrm{B}=|\mathrm{A}||\mathrm{B}| \cos \theta\)

Where \(|A|=\) Magnitude of vectors \(A\) and \(|B|=\) Magnitude of vectors \(B\) and \(\theta\) is the angle between \(\mathrm{A}\) and \(\mathrm{B}\)

Two balls are projected simultaneously with the same speed from the top of a towerone upwards and the other downwards. If they reach the ground in \(6 \mathrm{~s}\) and \(2 \mathrm{~s}\), the height of the tower is:

Lets consider u initial velocity of the ball

\(\mathrm{s}=\mathrm{ut}+\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{gt}^2\)

\(\mathrm{~s}=2 \mathrm{u}+\frac{1}{2} \times 10 \times 2^2 \)

\(\mathrm{~s}=2 \mathrm{u}+20 \ldots \ldots .(1)\)

Time taken to come back at projection point is \(6-2=4 \mathrm{sec}\)

Time to reach the maximum point is \(\frac{4}{2}=2 \mathrm{sec}\) at the maximum height final velocity is zero, \(\mathrm{v}=0 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

\(\mathrm{v}=\mathrm{u}-\mathrm{gt} \)

\(\mathrm{o}=\mathrm{u}-2 \times 10 \)

\(\mathrm{u}=2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

From equation 1, we get

\(\mathrm{s}=2 \times 20+20=60 \mathrm{~m}\)
Which of the following is not a vector quantity?

The physical quantities which have both magnitude and direction and obey the laws of vector addition are called vector quantities or vectors. Examples: Displacement, velocity, acceleration, force, momentum, Impulse, etc.

Temperature is not a vector quantity. It is a scaler quantity.

A body travelling in a clockwise direction, moves uniformly with a speed of \(5 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\) in a circle of radius \(25 \mathrm{~m}\).


From the given figure the angular velocity at point \(B\) and \(C\) are ____________ if man starts from point \(A\).

Angular displacement at point \(B\) and \(C(\theta)=\pi / 2\) and \(\pi\)

Linear velocity, \(v=5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

Radius of circular track, \(\mathrm{R}=25 \mathrm{~m}\)

We know that,

\(v=r \omega \Rightarrow \omega=\frac{v}{R}\)

Hence for both \(\mathrm{B}\) and \(\mathrm{C}\) radius and linear velocity remains the same, which means the angular acceleration will remain same for both point \(B\) and \(C\)

\(\omega=5 / 25=0.2 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}\)
The horizontal range will be minimum if the angle of projection is:

Horizontal range is the horizontal distance travelled by a body during the time of flight.


\(\Rightarrow R=\frac{u^2 \sin 2 \theta}{g}\)

As we know that \(\sin \theta\) is maximum at \(90^{\circ}\). Therefore horizontal range will maximum at \(45^{\circ}\).

\(\Rightarrow R=\frac{u^2 \sin 2 \times 45^{\circ}}{g}=\frac{u^2 \sin 90^{\circ}}{g}=\frac{u^2}{g}\)

When \(\theta=90^{\circ}\), then the horizontal range will be

\(\Rightarrow R=\frac{u^2 \sin 2 \times 90^{\circ}}{g}=\frac{u^2 \sin 180^{\circ}}{g}=\frac{u^2 \sin \left(90^{\circ}+90^{\circ}\right)}{g}=\frac{u^2 \cos 90^{\circ}}{g}=0 \quad\) [As, \(\left.\cos 90^{\circ}=0\right]\)

The horizontal range will be minimum if the angle of projection is \(90^{\circ}\).

If the two opposing forces act on an object, the net force acting on it is the:

If the two opposing forces act on an object, the net force acting on it is the difference between two forces. 

The net force is the vector sum of the forces acting on an object. The net force is always directed in the direction of the larger force among the forces acting on an object.

Let the two opposing forces acting on an object \(B\) be \(F_1\) and \(F_2\).


Consider the forces to the upward direction as positive and that to the downward direction as negative. From the diagram, the net force \(=\left(+F_1\right)+\left(-F_2\right)=F_1-F_2 \Rightarrow\) difference between the forces.
Keeping the speed of projection constant, the angle of projection is increased from \(0^{\circ}\) to \(90^{\circ}\). Then the horizontal range of the projectile:
Increases up to \(45^{\circ}\) and remains unaltered thereafter

The horizontal range of a projectile is given by

\(\Rightarrow R=\frac{u^2 \sin 2 \theta}{g}\)

From the above equation it is clear that

\(\Rightarrow {R} \propto \operatorname{Sin} 2 \theta\)

- From the above equation, it is clear that \(2 \theta\) will increase till the value becomes one

\(\Rightarrow \operatorname{Sin} 2 \theta=1 \)

\(\Rightarrow \theta=\sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) \)

\(\Rightarrow \theta=45^0\)

The horizontal range of the projectile increases up to \(45^{\circ}\) and then decreases afterward.

If \({A}_{{x}}, {A}_{{y}}, {A}_{{z}}\) are the rectangular component of \(\vec{A}\) and \(\hat{{i}}, \hat{{j}}\) and \(\hat{{k}}\) are the unit vector along \({X}, {Y}\), and \({Z}\) axis respectively, then

\( \vec{A}={A}_{{x}} \hat{i}+{A}_y \hat{j}+{A}_z \hat{{k}} \)

\( |\vec{A}|=\sqrt{Ax^2+A y^2+A z^2}\)

\(\vec{A}=3 \hat{i}+2 \hat{j}\) and \(\vec{B}=\hat{i}-2 \hat{j}+3 \hat{k} \)

\(\vec{A}+\vec{B}=3 \hat{i}+2 \hat{j}+\hat{i}-2 \hat{j}+3 \hat{k}=4 \hat{i}+0 \hat{j}+3 \hat{k}\)

To find the magnitude it can be written as

\(\mathrm{A}=\sqrt{A^2+B^2}\)

\(|\vec{A}+\vec{B}|=\sqrt{4^2+3^2}=\sqrt{25}=5\)
If a body is moving in a projectile motion, which of the following quantity will not change?

Projectile motion is a kind of motion that is experienced by an object when it is projected near the Earth's surface and it moves along a curved path under the action of gravitational force. In the horizontal direction, the body moves under no acceleration. So the horizontal velocity of the body will not change.
Which of the following is a vector quantity?

The physical quantities which have both magnitude and direction and obey the laws of vector addition are called vector quantities or vectors.

The angular momentum of a system can be given by the cross product of momentum and distance from the origin and thus it is a vector quantity because it has both magnitude and direction.
If a coin is tossed at an angle of vertically upward with initial velocity 'u' is \(10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\), what will be the maximum height if we consider air resistance as zero?

Given that,

initial velocity, \(u=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

The angle from a vertical surface, \(\theta=90^{\circ}\)

The maximum height \((\mathrm{H})\) of a projectile is given by:

\(H=\frac{u^2 \sin ^2 \theta}{2 g}\)

\(=\frac{10^2 \times \sin ^2 90^{\circ}}{2 \times 10}=\frac{100}{20}\)

\(H=5 \mathrm{~m}\)

We know that,

According to question,

\({u} \cos \theta=\sin \theta \)

\(\tan \theta=4 \)
