If vectors \(\vec{a}\) and \(\vec{b}\) are given as:

\(\vec{a}=5 \vec{i}+6 \vec{j}+3 \vec{k} \)

\(\vec{b}=6 \vec{i}-2 \vec{j}-6 \vec{k}\)

Which of the following statements is correct?

For vectors to be mutually perpendicular or orthogonal the dot product of the vectors must be zero.

So, \(\vec{a} \cdot \vec{b}=0\)

Given,

\(\vec{a}=5 \vec{i}+6 \vec{j}+3 \vec{k}\) and \(\vec{b}=6 \vec{i}-2 \vec{j}-6 \vec{k} \)

\(\Rightarrow \vec{a} \cdot \vec{b}=(5 \times 6)+(6 \times(-2))+(3 \times(-6))=30-12-18=0\)

Means vector \(a \&\) vector \(b\) are mutually perpendicular.

A vector \(\vec{X}\), when added to the resultant of the vectors \(\vec{A}=3 \hat{i}-5 \hat{j}+7 \hat{k}\) and \(\vec{B}=2 \hat{i}+4 \hat{j}\) - \(3 \hat{k}\) gives a unit vector along \(Y\) axis, Find the vector \(\vec{X}\).

Resultant of \(\vec{A}\) and \(\vec{B}\) is

According to the vector law of addition

\(\mathrm{R}=\vec{A}+\vec{B}\) where \(\vec{A}=3 \hat{i}-5 \hat{j}+7 \hat{k}\) and \(\vec{B}=2 \hat{i}+4\hat{j}-3 \hat{k}\) 

On putting the value we get

\({R}=(3 \hat{i}-5 \hat{j}+7 \hat{k})+(2 \hat{i}+4 \hat{j}-3 \hat{k})=-5\hat{i}+2 \hat{j}-4 \hat{k}\)

Unit vector along \({Y}\) axis \(=\hat{j}\)

So the required vector

\(\vec{X}=\hat{j}-\vec{R}, \hat{j}-(5 \hat{i}-\hat{j}+4 \hat{k})\) where \((\mathrm{R}=5 \hat{i}-2\hat{j}+4 \hat{k})=-5 \hat{\imath}+2 \hat{\jmath}-4 \hat{k}\)

So,  the vector \(\vec{X}\) will be \(-5 \hat{i}+2 \hat{\jmath}-4 \hat{k}\)
The motion of object with respect to other moving or stationary object is called:

The motion of object with respect to other moving or stationary object is called relative velocity. It is the velocity of an object in the rest frame of another object. For example, a boat crosses a river that is flowing at some rate, or an airplane encountering wind during its motion.
A person swims across a river at the speed of \(4 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\). The speed of the river is \(3 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\). Find the actual velocity of the person?

Given that velocity of a swimmer in the river \(\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{mw}}=4 \hat{j} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

The actual velocity of river water \(\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{w}}=3 \hat{i} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

Let the actual velocity of the swimmer is \(\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{m}}\)

\( \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{mw}}=\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{m}}-\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{w}} \)

\( 4 \hat{j}=\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{m}}-3 \hat{j} \)

\( \overrightarrow{V_m}=4 \hat{j}+3 \hat{i} \)

\(\left|\overrightarrow{V_m}\right|=\sqrt{\left(4^2+3^2\right)=5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}}\)
having a magnitude of 1 and points in y-direction
having a magnitude of 1 and points in x-direction
having a magnitude of 1 and points in z-direction
having a magnitude of 1 and points in any chosen direction

A unit vector is a vector having a magnitude of 1 and points in any chosen direction. The only purpose of a unit vector is to specify the direction of the force vector along a line with respect to the origin, hence why it's magnitude is only one. The total force in three dimensions is the magnitude of its components, and the individual forces are the coordinate forces divided by its magnitude.
An arbitrary vector \(\vec{A}\) in a plane can be expressed in terms of its \(\mathrm{x}\) and \(\mathrm{y}\) components by the equation:

In a two-dimensional coordinate system, any vector can be broken into \(\mathrm{x}\)-component and \(\mathrm{y}\)-component.

Vector \(\vec{A}\) can be represented as

\(\vec{A}=A_x \hat{i}+A_y \hat{j}\)

Where \(A_x\) is component in direction of x-axis and \(\hat{i}\) is a unit vector in same direction of \(x\)-axis

And \(A_y\) is component in direction of y-axis and \(\hat{j}\) is a unit vector in same direction of \(y\)-axis
If a copper block and a wooden block of the same volume drop from the same height, ____________ if we ignore the air resistance.
The wooden block will hit the ground first
The copper block will hit the ground first

Rate of acceleration is independent of the mass of any object. Thus, in this case, although the Volume of copper and wood are the same these two block will have different mass since the density of copper is greater than wood hence the mass of copper block will be greater than wooden. But the rate at which these two block are falling will be same since gravitational acceleration acting on both the block are equal. So, both the block will hit the ground simultaneously, only if air drag is zero.
Which of the following is a scalar quantity?

The physical quantities which have only magnitude and no direction are called scalar quantities or scalars. A scalar quantity can be specified by a single number, along with the proper unit. Examples: mass, volume, density, time, temperature, electric current, luminous intensity, etc. So, all of the given options are correct.

The greatest and the least resultant of two forces acting at a point are \(29 \mathrm{~N}\) and \(5 \mathrm{~N}\) respectively. if each force is increased by \(3 \mathrm{~N}\). Find the resultant of two new forces acting at the right angle to each other.

According to vector law of addition,

\(\vec{R}=\vec{A}+\vec{B} \)

\(R=\sqrt{A^2+B^2+2 A B \cos \theta}\)

\(R=\sqrt{P^2+Q^2+2 P Q \cos \theta}\)

Greatest Resultant \(=P+Q=29 \mathrm{~N}\)

Least Resultant \(=P-Q=5 \mathrm{~N}\)

\(2 \mathrm{P}=34, \mathrm{P}=17 \mathrm{~N}, \mathrm{Q}=12 \mathrm{~N}\)

When each force is increased by \(3 \mathrm{~N}\), new forces are:

\(p=P+3=17+3=20 N, q=Q+3=12+3=15 N\)

As the new force act at a right angle to each other, their Resultant:

\( R=\sqrt{P^2+Q^2+2 P Q \cos \theta} \)

\(\theta=90^{\circ} \)

\(R=\sqrt{20^2+15^2}=\sqrt{625}=25N\)
The magnitude of two forces acting perpendicular to each other will be:
Less than the magnitude of individual forces.
More than the magnitude of individual forces.
Sum of the magnitude of individual forces.

Let the forces acting perpendicular to each other are \(F_1\) and \(F_2\) and the angle between \(\mathrm{F}_1\) and \(\mathrm{F}_2, \theta=90^{\circ}\)

By using parallelogram law of vectors addition, we have

\( F_{\text {res }}=\sqrt{F_1^2+F_1^2+2 F_1 F_2 \cos \theta} \)

\( F_{\text {res }}=\sqrt{F_1^2+F_2^2+2 F_1 F_2 \cos 90^0} \)

\( F_{\text {res }}=\sqrt{F_1^2+F_2^2} \)

\( F_{\text {res }}=\sqrt{F_1^2+F_2^2} \)

\( \Rightarrow F_{\text {res }}>F_1\)

or \(F_{\text {res }}>F_2\)

So, the magnitude of two forces acting perpendicular to each other will be sum of the magnitude of individual forces.

A car is traveling at a speed of \(20 \mathrm{~m/s}\) due north along the highway makes a rightangle turn to a slide road that heads due east. It takes the 50 s for the car to complete the turn. At the end of \(50 \mathrm{~sec}\), the car has a speed of \(15 \mathrm{~m/s}\) along the side road. Determine the magnitude of average acceleration during this time.

The initial velocity of the car is \(\overrightarrow{O A}=20 \mathrm{~m/s}\) due to North

The final velocity of the car is \(\overrightarrow{O B}=15 \mathrm{~m/s}\), due to East


\(\overrightarrow{O A}+\overrightarrow{A B}=\overrightarrow{O B}, \overrightarrow{A B}=\overrightarrow{O B}-\overrightarrow{O A}\)

\({v}_2-{v}_1=\) Change in velocity

\(\left|{v}_2-{v}_1\right|=\mathrm{AB}=\sqrt{O A^2+O B^2}=\sqrt{20^2+15^2}=\sqrt{625}=25 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

Average Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity per unit of time.

\(\frac{\left|\overrightarrow{v_2}-\overrightarrow{v_1}\right|}{t}=\frac{25}{50}=0.5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

So, the magnitude of average acceleration over the \(50 \mathrm{~s}\) interval is \(0.5\mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

An athlete completes one round of a circular track of diameter \(200 \mathrm{~m}\) in \(40\) seconds. What will be the distance covered and the displacement respectively at the end of \(2\) minutes \(20\) seconds?

The diameter of the circular track, \(D=200 \mathrm{~m}\)

One complete round takes, \(t=40 \mathrm{~s}\)

Distance to be covered in \(2 \mathrm{~min} 20 \mathrm{~s}\)

Length of circular track \(=2 \pi R=\pi D=3.14 \times 200=628 \mathrm{~m}\)

Number of rounds completed by the athlete in \(2\) minutes \(20\) seconds \(=\frac{140}{40}=3.5\)

Distance covered in \(2\) minutes \(20\) seconds \(=\frac{7}{2} \times 628 \mathrm{~m}=2198 \mathrm{~m}\)

The displacement of the athlete after \(3\) complete rounds in \(120\) seconds is zero and after three rounds he is able to complete half of the track in the remaining time, therefore, the displacement is equal to the diameter of the circular track i.e. \(200 \mathrm{~m}\).
Find the value of \(\mathrm{x}\) if vector \(\vec{A}=x \hat{i}+0.5 \hat{j}-0.2 \hat{k}\) is a unit vector.

The magnitude of a vector \(\vec{A}=a \hat{i}+b \hat{j}+c \hat{k}\) is given by:

\(|\vec{A}|=\sqrt{a^2+b^2+c^2 } \)

Given that \(\vec{A}=x \hat{i}+0.5 \hat{j}-0.2 \hat{k}\)

Since this is a unit vector, So its magnitude will be 1 .

\(|\vec{A}|=1\)

Magnitude fo vector \(\mathrm{A}\)

\( |\vec{A}|=\sqrt{ x^2+0.5^2+(-0.2)^2 }\)

\(1=\sqrt{ x^2+0.5^2+(-0.2)^2 }\)

\( 1=x^2+0.5^2+(-0.2)^2 \)

\(1=x^2+0.25+0.04\)

\(x=\sqrt{0.71}\)
May be a vector or a scalar.
Will be another vector in the same direction of the original vector or just opposite to it
Will be another vector with a direction complete different from previous vector.

A scalar multiplied by a vector will be another vector in the same direction of the original vector or just opposite to it.

If a vector \(\vec{A}\) is multiplied by a scalar \(\lambda=2\) then we get another vector \(\vec{B}\) such that \(\vec{B}=2 \vec{A}\).

The magnitude of \(\vec{B}\) is twice the magnitude of \(\vec{A}\) while the direction of \(\vec{B}\) is same as that of \(\vec{A}\). 

If the vector \(\vec{A}\) is multiplied by a scalar \(\lambda=-2\), then the new vector is such that \(\vec{B}=-2 \vec{A}\). The magnitude of \(\vec{B}\) is again twice the magnitude of \(\vec{A}\) but the direction is opposite to that of \(\vec{A}\).
An insect is crawling over a plane surface with acceleration \(\vec{a}=a_x \hat{i}+a_y \hat{j}\). The resultant value of acceleration is given by:

Let the velocity of an object moving in a two-dimensional plane is \({v}_0\) at the time \(({t})=0\) and \({v}\) at time \({t}\).

Acceleration \(=\frac{\text { change in velocity }}{\text { time taken }}\)

\(\Rightarrow a=\frac{v-v_0}{t}\)

For an insect is crawling over a plane surface with acceleration \(\vec{a}=a_x \hat{i}+a_y \hat{j}\), The resultant value of acceleration is given by:

\(a=\sqrt{\left(a_x^2+a_y^2\right)}\)
Which among the following can become negative?

The physical quantities which have both magnitude and direction and obey the laws of vector addition are called vector quantities or vectors. A vector quantity is specified by a number with a unit and its direction. Examples Displacement, velocity, force, momentum, etc.

The rate of change in displacement is called velocity. It is a vector quantity that can be negative, positive, or zero.
If a projectile is thrown with velocity ' \(v\) ' and making an angle ' \(\theta\) ' with the \(x\)-axis then the vertical component of velocity is given by which of the following formula?

The above figure shows a body projected with an initial velocity \({v}\), making an angle \(\theta\) with the horizontal direction.  The horizontal component of velocity is \(v \operatorname{cos} \theta\) and vertical component of velocity is \(v \sin \theta\).

The equation of motion connecting final velocity \((\mathrm{V})\), Initial velocity(u) is given by:

\(\Rightarrow {v}={u}+{at}\cdots(1)\)

Under the influence of gravity Equation1 Changes to

\(\Rightarrow {v}={u}-{gt}\cdots(2)\)

Equation \(2\) in the case of \({Y}\)-axis is given by

\(\Rightarrow {v}_{{y}}={v}_{{o}} \sin \theta-{gt}\)
Tensile or compressive stress can also be termed as___________.

Since due to tensile stress and compressive stress, there is a change in length or in the longitudinal direction. (as shown in the figure) These both stress are known as longitudinal stress.

These both stress are known as longitudinal stress.
Which of the following is the correct formula to calculate bulk modulus of a material?

Bulk Modulus: Bulk Modulus is a constant that describes how resistant a substance is to compression.

Bulk Modulus of Elasticity: The ratio of normal stress to the volumetric strain within the elastic limit.

Bulk modulus:

\(\mathrm{B}=\frac{\Delta \mathrm{P}}{\frac{\Delta \mathrm{V} }{ \mathrm{V}}}\)

\(\mathrm{P}=\) pressure 

\(\mathrm{V}=\) volume 

\(\begin{aligned} & K=\frac{\text { Normal stress }}{\text { Volumatric strain }} \\ & \mathrm{K}=\frac{\mathrm{FV}}{(\mathrm{A} \cdot \Delta \mathrm{V})}=\frac{(\Delta \mathrm{p} \cdot \mathrm{V})}{(\Delta \mathrm{V})}\end{aligned}\)
Ratio of change in length to original area
Ratio of change in dimension to original dimension

The ratio of change in length to original length is called Longitudinal strain. It is a type of strain.

The ratio of change in the dimension to the original dimension of the body is known as strain.

Force per unit area is called pressure.

The change in the length of a body is said longitudinal deformation.
Which of the following force is necessary to generate shear stress?

Shear stress: Force \(F_{\|}\)applied along the object's parallel surface divided by the cross-section area \(A\) of the surface on which the parallel force is acting.

Shear Stress \(=\frac{\mathrm{F}_{\|}}{\mathrm{A}}\)

From the definition of shear stress, it is clear that to calculate the shear stress we take force parallel to the area of the surface.

Force perpendicular to surface area is taken to calculate normal stress (not shear stress).
The elastic behaviour of solids can be understood by_______________.

Atoms in the solid can be taken as the ball in the spring ball model.

The intermolecular force between the molecules of the solid can be taken as spring force in the spring ball model.

When there will be an external force, the balls (molecules) will be displaced and the length of the spring will be increase or decrease.

Hence a force will generate that will tend to make balls (molecules of the solid) back to the original position.

So spring ball system can be used to understand the molecular phenomenon of the elastic solids.
What happens to the elasticity of a material when it gets hammered?

On hammering a material, the crystal breaks up into smaller units. The smaller units together resist deformation.

This increases the binding inside the material and provides greater resistance to the deforming forces. Thus, the elasticity increases on hammering.
Which of the following statement defines the term 'deformation' regarding elastic material?
working of friction between the two surfaces
increase in temperature of molecules due to heating
the atoms or molecules of the body are displaced from their equilibrium positions

Each molecule in the elastic solids is acted upon by the forces because of neighboring molecules.

When an external force is applied, the molecules inside it are displaced from their equilibrium positions (fixed points of lattice points) causing a change in intermolecular and interatomic distances. Overall the shape or size of the body is changed. This makes the body to get deformed.

So when there is a change in distance between molecules of an object, deformation occurs.
Which of the following affects the elasticity of a material?

Temperature: With a rise in temperature, the molecules vibrate vigorously due to increased kinetic energy. This causes a decrease in intermolecular forces. Hence, the elasticity decreases with a rise in temperature.

Annealing: It is the process of heating a material and cooling them slowly. The material loses its elastic properties on heating. This results in a decrease in the elasticity of the material.

Impurities: The impurities added to a material affects its molecular binding. Depending on the type of impurity added, elasticity can increase or decrease.

Hence, all the given factors affect the elasticity of a material.
the materials that are deformed when force is applied but regain its shape when force is removed
the materials that are permanently deformed when force is applied

If you apply force to a lump of putty or mud, they get permanently deformed. Also, they have no tendency to regain their previous shape. This property is called plasticity and such materials are called plastic material.
The stress generated on a body is_____________.

The Stress generated in a body is restoring force (F) per unit area (A).

Stress \(=\frac{\mathrm{F}}{\mathrm{A}}\)
The strain produced by hydraulic pressure is called________________.
Strain can not be produced by hydraulic pressure

The strain produced by hydraulic stress is volumetric strain. Shear strain is generated by shear stress.

Longitudinal stress is generated either due to tensile stress or due to compressive stress.
If two wire \(P\) and \(Q\) are streched by equal load and the radius of \(P\) is two times the radius of \(Q\) then the stress on \(P\) will be:

Given ,

Force of wire \(P=\) Force on wire \(Q\) and Radius of \(P\left(r_p\right)\) \(=2 r_Q\)

From the above, it is clear that stress is written as:

\(\Rightarrow\) Stress \(=\frac{\operatorname{Force}(F)}{\operatorname{Area}(A)}\)

Since stress is inversely proportional to the area, and the area is proportional to the square of the radius.

Therefore, stress is the directly proportional square of the radius.

Now the ratio of the stress of both wire can be expressed as:

Stress for wire \({P}\) is,

\(\Rightarrow S_P=\frac{\text { Force }}{\pi r_P^2}=\frac{\text { Force }}{4 \pi r_Q^2} \)...(1)

Stress for wire \(Q\) is,

\(\Rightarrow S_Q=\frac{\text { Force }}{\pi r_Q^2} \)...(2)

On diving equation 1 and 2, we get

\(\Rightarrow \frac{S_P}{S_Q}=\frac{1}{4}\)

\(\Rightarrow S_P=\frac{1}{4} \times S_Q\)

Therefore, stress on \(P\) is one-fourth the stress on \(Q\).
If a force of \(10 \mathrm{~N}\) acts on a body of mass \(5 \mathrm{~kg}\) and crosssectional area \(10000 \mathrm{~cm}^2\). The value of shear stress will be:

Given: Force on the body \((F)=10 \mathrm{~N}\) and Area of the body \((\mathrm{A})=\) \(10000 \mathrm{~cm}^2=1 \mathrm{~m}^2\)

Hence, the value of shear stress will be \(\Rightarrow \sigma=\frac{F}{A}=\frac{10}{1}=10 \mathrm{Nm}^{-2}\)

Shear stress \((\sigma)=10 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^2\)
A bar of square cross section of side ' \(s\) ' is acted upon by a load \(P\). If this load is inclined at an angle of \(60^{\circ}\) with the axis of the bar, the tensile stress will be:

Tensile force \(=\mathrm{P} \cos \theta=\mathrm{P} \cos 60^{\circ}=\frac{{P}}{2}\)

Cross sectional area, \(\mathrm{A}=\mathrm{s} \times \mathrm{s}=\mathrm{s}^2\)

Tensile stress, \(\sigma=\frac{\text { Tensile force }}{\text { Area }}=\frac{\frac{P }{ 2}}{s^2}=\frac{P}{2 s^2}\)
According to Hook's law, if stress is increased the ratio of stress to strain will__________.

According to Hooke's law, we know that

stress \(=\mathrm{k} \times\) strain

\(k=\frac{\text { stress }}{\text { strain }}\)

Here \(k\) is the ratio of stress and strain and this ratio is the property of the material and is constant. So if we increase the stress value, the ratio of stress and strain (proportionality constant k) will not change because it remains constant.
Which of the following is/are correct regarding Hooke's law?
Beyond elastic limit, Hook's law is not applicable

Hooke's law is applicable only for solids (not for liquids or gases).

Hooke's law is not a universal law because it works up to the proportionality limit only.

It does not work after the elastic limit point because after that point the curve is not linear.

So all the statements are correct.

A wire is stretched by \(5 {~mm}\) when it is pulled by a certain force. If another wire of the same material but of double-length and double diameter is stretched by the same force, the increase in the length of the other wire will be :

Let the force acting on the material be \(F\), and \(Y\) be Young's modulus of the material. Assuming that the force is acting on the cross-section of the wire,

Wire - 1

Length of wire \(=l_1\)

The radius of wire \(=r_1\)

Change in length, \(\Delta l_1=5 \mathrm{~mm}\)

Young's modulus, \(\mathrm{Y}=\frac{\frac{F }{A}}{\frac{\Delta l_1 }{ l_1}}=\frac{\frac{F }{ \pi r_1^2}}{\frac{\Delta l_1 }{ l_1}}.....(1)\)

Wire - 2

Length of wire \(=l_2=2 \times l_1\)

Radius of wire \(=r_2=2 \times r_1\) ( \(\because\) as diameter doubles radius also get doubled \(=2 \times r\) )

Change in length \(=\Delta {l}_2\)

Young's modulus, \(\mathrm{Y}=\frac{\frac{F }{ A}}{\frac{\Delta l_2 }{ l_2}}=\frac{\frac{F }{ \pi r_2^2}}{\frac{\Delta l_2 }{ l_2}}=\frac{\frac{F }{ \pi\left(2 r_1\right)^2}}{\frac{\Delta l_2 }{ 2 l_1}}\)

Equating (1) and (2) we get

\(\frac{\frac{F }{ \pi r_1^2}}{\frac{\Delta l_1 }{ l_1}}=\frac{\frac{F }{ \pi\left(2 r_1\right)^2}}{\frac{\Delta l_2 }{ 2 l_1}}\)

\(\frac{l_1}{\Delta l_1}=\frac{2 l_1}{\Delta l_2} \times \frac{1}{4}\)

\(\Rightarrow \Delta l_2=\frac{1}{2} \Delta l_1=\frac{5}{2}=2.5 \mathrm{~mm}\)
A typical stress-strain curve help us to understand_________________.
how a given material deforms when we increase the strain
how a given material produces strain with increase in pressure
how a given produces strain with increasing temperature
how a given material deforms with increasing loads

Option (A): There is no mention of stress. The strain and deformation both give the same meaning.

Option (B) and option (C): The stress-strain curve does not give any information about temperature and pressure.

Option (D): A stress-strain curve is made by applying load on a material cylinder and we see how it deforms at different loads.

By seeing its behaviour, we make the curve and get the stress-strain curve. Hence, a typical stress-strain curve helps us understand how a given material deforms with increasing loads.
What does it mean, if the stress-strain curve is linear for a material?

According to Hook's law

stress \(=k \times\) strain

It is the same as the straight line \(y=m x\).

Stress is on the \(y\)-axis, strain is at the \(x\)-axis, and \(k\) is slope \(m\).

So straight line on a stress-strain curve represents that material is following Hook's law.
Which material has the maximum Young's modulus?

The Young's Moduli of some materials is:
Substance

Young's Modulus

Aluminium70
Copper110
Iron190
Steel200
Glass65
Lead13
Concrete30
Wood13
Bone9
From the above table, it is clear that iron has the maximum Young's modulus.
The modulus of elasticity is dimensionally equivalent to:

Modulus of elasticity, \(Y=\frac{\text { stress }}{\text { strain }}\)

The strain is defined as the deformation per unit dimension of the body, in the direction of the applied force.

The strain is the ratio of two like quantities. Thus, it will have no dimensions.

So, the modulus of elasticity will have the same unit as stress.

Thus, the modulus of elasticity is dimensionally equivalent to stress.

An increase of \(0.1 \%\) in the length of a wire of cross-section \(10^{-6} \mathrm{~m}^2\) causes tension of \(1 \times 100 \mathrm{~N}\) in the wire. The Young's modulus of the material of the wire is:

Given \(\% d l=0.1 \%, A=10^{-6} \mathrm{~m}^2\) and \(P=100 \mathrm{~N}\)

We know that,

\(\Rightarrow \% d l=\frac{d l}{l} \times 100\)

\(\Rightarrow \% d l=\frac{d l}{l} \times 100=0.1\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d l}{l}=10^{-3}\)

By Hooke's law,

\(\Rightarrow \sigma=E \epsilon\)

\(\Rightarrow E=\frac{\sigma}{\epsilon}\)

\(\Rightarrow E=\frac{\frac{p}{A}}{\frac{d l}{t}}\)

\(\Rightarrow E=\frac{100}{10^{-5} \times 10^{-3}}\)

\(\Rightarrow E=10^{11} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^2\)

A load of \(3 \mathrm{kN}\) acts on a beam of length \(100 \mathrm{~m}\) and area \(10 \mathrm{~m}^2\). The load causes deformation of \(3 \mathrm{~cm}\) to the beam. The Young's modulus of the material of the beam is:

Given: Force applied \((F)=3 \mathrm{kN}=3 \times 10^3 \mathrm{~N}\), Area of the beam \((A)=10 \mathrm{~m}^2\), Original length \((L)=100 \mathrm{~m}\), and Change in length, \(\Delta \mathrm{L}=3 \mathrm{~cm}=0.03 \mathrm{~m}\)

Young's modulus \((Y)\) is given as

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow Y=\frac{\frac{F }{ A}}{\frac{\Delta L }{ L}} \\ & \Rightarrow Y=\frac{3 \times 10^3 \times 100}{10 \times 0.03} \\ & \Rightarrow Y=10^6 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^2\end{aligned}\)
Which of the following process increases the elasticity of the material?

When the material is hammered crystal breaks into smaller units. Thus, it increases the elastic property. 

While in the annealing process crystals are uniformly oriented to form a large crystal which decreases the elastic property.
Which type of modulus is present in liquid?

The bulk modulus is present in the liquid.

The measure of how resistant a substance is to its compression is called bulk modulus. It is the ratio of the infinitesimal pressure increase to the resulting relative decrease of the volume.
If the length of the wire is doubled and its area of cross section is decreased to half, then its resistance:

If the length of the wire is doubled and its area of cross section is decreased to half, then its resistance will increases four times.

Step 1: Initial Resistance

\(R=\rho \frac{l}{A}\)

Step 2: Final Resistance

Final length \(\ell^{\prime}=2 \ell\)

Final cross-section \(\mathrm{A}^{\prime}=\frac{\mathrm{A}}{2}\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{R}^{\prime}=\rho \frac{\ell^{\prime}}{\mathrm{A}^{\prime}}=\frac{\rho \cdot 2 \ell}{\frac{\mathrm{A}}{2}}=4 \rho \frac{\ell}{\mathrm{A}}=4 \mathrm{R}\)
If Y, K and η are the values of Young's modulus, bulk modulus and modulus of rigidity of any material respectively. Choose the correct relation for these parameters.

We know that Young's modulus is given as:

\(Y=3 K(1-2 \sigma)\)

\(\Rightarrow \sigma=\frac{1}{2}\left(1-\frac{Y}{3 K}\right)\)

Also, \(Y=3 \eta(1+\sigma)\)

\(\Rightarrow \sigma=\frac{Y}{2 \eta}-1\)

From (1) and (2) we have-

\(\frac{1}{2}\left(1-\frac{Y}{3 K}\right)=\frac{Y}{2 \eta}-1\)

\(\Rightarrow 1-\frac{Y}{3 K}=\frac{Y}{\eta}-2\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{Y}{3 K}=3-\frac{Y}{\eta}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{K}=\frac{\eta Y}{9 \eta-3 Y}\)
If the longitudinal strain of a iron rod is 0.01 and its Poisson ratio of 0.2, then the lateral strain will be:

Given-

Longitudinal strain = 0.01

Poisson ratio = 0.2

Since Poisson's ratio \(=\frac{\text { Lateral strain }}{\text { Longitudinal strain }}\)

⇒ Lateral strain = (0.2)(0.01) = 0.002
The average depth of the pacific ocean is about 4000 m. If the bulk modulus of the water is 2 × 109 N/m2, then find the volumetric strain of water at the bottom of the ocean. (Take g = 10 m/sec2)

Given density of water \(\rho=1000 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^3, \mathrm{~h}=4000 \mathrm{~m}, \mathrm{~g}=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{sec}^2\) and \(B=2 \times 10^9 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^2\)

We know that the pressure exerted by a \(4000 \mathrm{~m}\) column of water on the bottom layer of the pacific ocean is given as,

⇒ P = ρgh

⇒ P = 1000 × 10 × 4000

⇒ P = 4 × 107 N/m2...(1)

We know that the bulk modulus is given as,

\(\Rightarrow B=-\frac{P}{\left(\frac{\Delta V}{V}\right)}\)...(2)

Where \(\mathrm{P}=\) hydraulic stress, \(\frac{\Delta V}{V}=\) volumetric strain

By equation 1 and equation 2,

\(\Rightarrow \) Volumetric Strain \(=\frac{\Delta V}{V}=\frac{P}{B}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\Delta V}{V}=\frac{4 \times 10^7}{2 \times 10^9}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\Delta V}{V}=2 \times 10^{-2}\)
What force is required to stretch a wire of \(1 \mathrm{~cm}^2\) in cross-section to double its length? Given \(Y=2 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^2\)

Given - Area \((A)=1 \mathrm{~cm}^2=10^{-4} \mathrm{~m}^2, L_1=l, L_2=2 l\)

\(\Delta {l}={L}_2-{L}_1={l}\)

As we know, the Young modulus is

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow Y=\frac{F l}{A \Delta l} \\ & \Rightarrow F=\frac{Y A \Delta l}{l} \\ & \Rightarrow F=\frac{2 \times 10^{11} \times 10^{-4} \times l}{l}=2 \times 10^7 \mathrm{~N}\end{aligned}\)
Which of the following wave doesn't need any medium to travel?

A sound wave needs a medium to travel. Light is an example of Electromagnetic waves. It doesn't need any medium to travel. Sound waves travel due to compression and rarefaction. Sound waves, water waves, and waves in a string are mechanical waves that require the medium to travel.

Rahul is doing an experiment with the spring by fixing its one end on the wall and another end is free. In the experiment, he pushes the spring and release due to which some wave is created. What is the type of this wave?
When spring is pushed and release due to compression and rarefaction the constituent particle moves along the direction of the force. So, the wave produced are longitudinal in nature.
Which of the following is not a type of electromagnetic wave?

Sound Wave needs a medium to travel.

A light wave is an Electromagnetic wave. Gamma Ray is an example of Electromagnetic Waves. Microwave is an example of electromagnetic waves.
Ram is playing with a rope by fixing its one end to the wall and move another end in the upward and the downward direction due to which sinusoidal waves are produced. The waves are of which type?

When Ram is moving the free end in an upward and downward direction then the constituent particle oscillates in an upward and downward direction while the waves move towards the end which is fixed to the wall. The direction of propagation is perpendicular to the direction of particle oscillate.

So, the waves that are produced due to the upward and downward motion of rope are transverse in nature.
Which of the following relationship is incorrect? ( \(k\) is wave number, \(\lambda\) is wavelength, \(T\) is time period, \(w\) is angular frequency, and \(v\) is wave speed)

We know that

\(\frac{1 }{ \lambda}=\frac{k }{ 2 \pi }\)

\(k=\frac{2 \pi }{\lambda}\)...(i)

Also \(\omega=2 \pi f\)...(ii)

\(f=\frac{1 }{ T}\)...(iii)

From (ii) and (iii) we get

\(\omega=\frac{2 \pi }{ T}\)...(iv)

We know the relation

\(f \times \lambda=v \)

\(f=\frac{v }{ \lambda} \)...(v)

From (v) and (ii) we get

\(\omega=\frac{2 \pi v }{ \lambda}\)...(vi)

From (i) and (vi) we get

\(\omega= kv\)
Amit filled a cylindrical pipe with air in which one end is having a movable piston. He moves the piston first in the right direction then in the left direction. Which type of waves is produced?

When Amit moves the piston in the right direction and then in the left direction. It creates a pulse of pressure that pushes its adjacent layer in forward and then backward direction and the waves which produced travel along with the direction of particle moves. So, the waves produced are longitudinal Waves.
Which of the following statement is incorrect regarding transverse wave?
Direction of disturbance and direction of propagation is always perpendicular.
Direction of disturbance and direction of propagation is always parallel.
Transverse wave are generally form in a medium that can sustain shearing strain.

In the transverse wave, the direction of disturbance and direction of propagation is always perpendicular. Electromagnetic waves are transverse in nature. Transverse wave generally forms in a medium that can sustain shearing strain.
Two waves \(y_1=a \cdot \sin (\omega t)\) and \(y_2=a \cdot \sin (\omega t+\phi)\) are moving in the same direction, if both the waves are superimposed then the amplitude of the resultant wave is:

If two waves are given as,

\(\Rightarrow y _1= a \cdot \sin (\omega t ) \)

\(\Rightarrow y _2= a \cdot \sin (\omega t +\phi)\)

By the principle of superposition, the resultant wave is given by,

\(\Rightarrow y = y _1+ y _2 \)

\(\Rightarrow y = a \cdot \sin (\omega t )+ a \cdot \sin (\omega t +\phi) \)

\(\Rightarrow y=2 a \cdot \cos \frac{\phi}{2} \sin \left(\omega t+\frac{\phi}{2}\right)\)

By equation 1 the amplitude of the resultant wave is given as,

\(\Rightarrow A=2 a \cdot \cos \frac{\phi}{2}\)

Two similar waves ' \(x\) ' and ' \(y\) ' of amplitude 'a' are moving in the same direction and superimposed. If the wave ' \(y\) ' is lagging behind the wave ' \(x\) ' by one-fourth of the cycle, then the amplitude of the resultant wave is equal to:

Given \(a _{ x }= a _{ y }= a\), and \(\phi=\frac{\pi}{2}\)

We know that when two similar waves are superimposed, the amplitude of the resultant wave is given as,

\(\Rightarrow A=2 a \cdot \cos \frac{\phi}{2} \)

\(\Rightarrow A=2 a \cdot \cos \frac{\pi}{4} \)

\(\Rightarrow A=\sqrt{2} a\)

Two harmonic waves \(y _1= a \cdot \sin ( kx -\omega t )\) and \(y _2= a \cdot \sin ( kx -\omega t +\phi)\) are moving in the same direction, if both the waves are superimposed then the initial phase angle of the resultant wave is:

Two harmonic waves are,

\(\Rightarrow y _1= a \cdot \sin ( kx -\omega t ) \)

\(\Rightarrow y _2= a \cdot \sin ( kx -\omega t +\phi)\)

Where \(\phi=\) phase difference between \(y _1\) and \(y _2\).

By the principle of superposition, the net displacement is given by,

\(\Rightarrow y=2 a \cdot \cos \frac{\phi}{2} \sin \left(k x-\omega t+\frac{\phi}{2}\right)\)...(1)

By equation 1 it is clear that the initial phase angle of the resultant wave is \(\frac{\phi}{2}\).

The phase difference between two similar waves is \(\phi\). Both the waves are moving in the same direction and superimposed. If the resultant wave has zero displacements everywhere at all times, then the value of \(\phi\) is:

Let two similar waves of phase difference \(\phi\) are given as

\(\Rightarrow y _1= a \cdot \sin ( kx -\omega t ) \)

\(\Rightarrow y _2= a \cdot \sin ( kx -\omega t +\phi)\)

By the principle of superposition, the net displacement is given by,

\(\Rightarrow y=2 a \cdot \cos \frac{\phi}{2} \sin \left(k x-\omega t+\frac{\phi}{2}\right) \)...(1)

If the resultant wave has zero displacements everywhere at all times, then by equation 1,

\(\Rightarrow y =0 \)

\(\Rightarrow 2 a \cdot \cos \frac{\phi}{2} \sin \left(k x-\omega t+\frac{\phi}{2}\right)=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow \phi=\pi \)

The ratio of the intensity of two waves is \(4: 1\). If both the waves are superimposed in the same phase then the intensity of the resultant wave is \(x\) and if both the waves are superimposed in the opposite phase then the intensity of the resultant wave is \(y\). Find the ratio of \(x\) to \(y\).

Given \(\frac{I_1}{I_2}=\frac{4}{1}\)

We know that when two waves are superimposed in the same phase, the intensity of the resultant wave is maximum.

Maximum intensity is given as,

\(\Rightarrow I_{\max }=\left(\sqrt{I_1}+\sqrt{I_2}\right)^2\)...(1)

We know that when two waves are superimposed in the opposite phase, the intensity of the resultant wave is minimum.

Minimum intensity is given as, \(\Rightarrow I_{\text {min }}=\left(\sqrt{I_1}-\sqrt{I_2}\right)^2\)...(2)

By dividing equation 1 and equation 2,

\(\Rightarrow \frac{I_{\max }}{I_{\min }}=\frac{x}{y}=\frac{\left(\sqrt{I_1}+\sqrt{I_2}\right)^2}{\left(\sqrt{I_1}-\sqrt{I_2}\right)^2} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{x}{y}=\frac{\left(\sqrt{\frac{I_1}{I_2}}+1\right)^2}{\left(\sqrt{\frac{I_1}{I_2}}-1\right)^2} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{x}{y}=\frac{9}{1}=9:1\)
The equation of a wave is given by \(y=25 \sin (500 t-40 x)\). Which of the statement is incorrect?

Given that:

\(y=25 \sin (500 t-40 x)\)

By comparing give equation with general equation we get

\(A =25 ; \omega=500 rad / sec ; k =40\)

We know that \(\omega=2 \pi f\) where \(f=\frac{v }{ \lambda}\)

\(\omega=\frac{2 \pi v }{ \lambda}\)

We also know that \(k =\frac{2 \pi }{ \lambda}\)

\(\omega=v k \)

\(T=\frac{1 }{ f} \)

\(\omega=2 \pi f \)

\(f=\frac{\omega }{ 2 \pi}=\frac{500 }{ 2 \pi} \)

\(f=79.57 Hz \)

\(\omega=v k \)

\(v=\frac{\omega }{k}=\frac{500 }{ 40}=12.5 m / sec \)

\(T=\frac{1 }{ 79.57}=0.012 sec \)

\(k=\frac{2 \pi }{ \lambda} \)

\(\lambda=\frac{2 \pi }{ k}=\frac{2 \pi }{ 40}=0.157\)
A medium undergoes a shearing strain can produce:

Longitudinal Waves generally propagate in such a medium that can sustain compressive strain. Transverse Waves generally propagate in such a medium that can sustain shearing stress. Electromagnetic Waves are transverse in nature.
In an experiment teacher told Raj to create a sinusoidal wave whose speed is 600 \(m / s\), the amplitude is \(30 mm\) and the wavelength is \(2 \pi\). The correct equation of wave given by Raj is:

Given that:

\(A =30 mm , v =600 m / s \text {, and } \lambda=2 \pi\)

We know that \(\omega=2 \pi f\) and \(f=v / \lambda\)

\(\omega=\frac{2 \pi v }{ \lambda}\)

We also know that \(k = \frac{2 \pi }{ \lambda}\)

\(\omega=\frac{(2 \pi \times 600) }{(2 \pi)}=600 \)

\(k =\frac{ 2 \pi }{ 2 \pi}= 1\)

By putting the value of \(\omega\) and \(k\) in the general equation of wave we get

\(y=30 \sin (600 t-x)\)
Medium undergoes a compressive strain can produce:

Longitudinal Waves generally propagate in such a medium that can sustain compressive strain. Transverse Waves generally propagate in such a medium that can sustain shearing stress. Electromagnetic Waves are transverse in nature.
A plane progressive wave is given by the equation \(y=\cos (2 \pi t-\pi x)\). Find the equation of the wave with a triple of the amplitude. (All other factors are same)

Given that:

\(y=\cos (2 \pi t-\pi x)\)

By comparing a given equation with a general equation we get

\(A=1 ; \omega=2 \pi ; k=\pi\)

Now the new wave equation has triple the amplitude that's mean:

\(A ^{\prime}=3 \times 1 \)

\(A ^{\prime}=3\)

The new wave equation with triple amplitude of the initial one:

\(y=3 \cos (2 \pi t-\pi x)\)

The displacement ( \(y\) ) of a wave travelling in the \(x\)-axis direction is given by \(y=10^{-}\) \(4 \sin (600 t-2 x+\frac{\pi }{ 3})\) metre, where \(x\) expressed in metre and \(t\) in second. what is the speed of the wave motion in \(m / s\) ?

Given that:

\(y=10^{-4} \sin (600 t-2 x+\frac{\pi }{ 3})\)

By comparing the above equation with the general equation we get

\(a=10^{-4} ; \omega=600 ; k=2 ; \phi=\frac{\pi }{ 3}\)

We know that \(\omega=2 \pi f\) and \(f=\frac{v }{ \lambda}\)

\(\omega=\frac{2 \pi v }{ \lambda}\)

Also \(k=\frac{2 \pi }{ \lambda}\)

\(\lambda=\frac{2 \pi }{ k} \)

\(\omega=v k \)

\(v =\frac{\omega }{ k} =\frac{600 }{ 2}= 3 0 0 m / s\)
A plane progressive wave is given by the equation \(y=0.25 \cos (2 \pi t-2 \pi x)\). Find the equation of a wave having half the frequency and travelling in opposite direction.

Given that:

\(y=0.25 \cos (2 \pi t-2 \pi x)\)

By comparing the given equation with a general equation we get,

\(A=0.25 ; \omega=2 \pi ; k=2 \pi\)

We know that \(\omega=2 \pi f\)

But now the frequency is reduced to half that's is

\(f^{\prime}=\frac{f }{ 2} \)...(1)

\(\omega^{\prime}=2 \pi f^{\prime}=\frac{2 \pi f }{ 2}=\frac{\omega }{ 2 }\)

\(\omega^{\prime}=\pi \)...(2)

We also know that \(k =\frac{2 \pi }{ \lambda}\)

if frequency is reduced to half then wavelength is:

\(f \times \lambda=v \)

\(f^{\prime} \times \lambda^{\prime}=v \)

\(\lambda^{\prime}=\frac{v }{ f^{\prime}}\)

By putting value of \(f^{\prime}\) from eq (1) we get

\(\lambda^{\prime}=\frac{2 v }{ f }\)

\(\lambda^{\prime}=2 \lambda \)...(3)

\(k^{\prime}=\frac{2 \pi }{ \lambda^{\prime}} \)...(4)

By putting value of \(\lambda^{\prime}\) in (4) we get

\(k^{\prime}=\pi\)...(5)

Now the new wave equation whose frequency is half of the initial one and in opposite direction is given by:

\(y=0.25 \cos (\pi t+k x)\)

So, correct answer is option (B).
A longitudinal wave is travelling with the speed of \(500 m / s\). Find its wavelength if the frequency of wave is \(25 Hz\).

Given that \(v=500 m / s\), Frequency \(=25 Hz\)

Wavelength \((\lambda)=\frac{ \text{Velocity (v) }}{ \text{Frequency (f)}}=\frac{500 }{ 25}\) 

\(\lambda=20\) meters
When two waves of the same amplitude \(\left( a _0\right)\) are superposed, the resultant wave have amplitude \(\sqrt{  2 a_0}\). What is the phase difference between the two waves?

Given that \(A _1= A _2= a _0\) and \(A =\sqrt{2 a _0}\)

We know that

\(A=\sqrt{  A_1^2+A_2^2+2 A_1 A_2 \cos \phi} \)

\(\sqrt{  2 a_0}=\sqrt{  a_0^2+a_0^2+2 a_0 a_0 \cos \phi} \)

\(2 a_0^2=2 a_0^2+2 a_0^2 \cos \phi \)

\(1=1+\cos \phi \)

\(0=\cos \phi \)

The phase difference between the two waves \(=\frac{\pi}{2}\)
A wave is travelling in positive \(X\)-direction with Amplitude \((A)=0.2 m\), velocity \(( v )=\) \(360 m / s\) and wavelength \((\lambda)=60\). Find the expression for the wave.

\(A=0.2 m ; v =360 m / s ; \lambda=60 m\)

We know that \(k =\frac{2 \pi }{ \lambda}\)

\(k=\frac{2 \pi }{ 60}\)

We also know that \(\omega=2 \pi f\) and \(f=\frac{v }{ \lambda}\)

So, \(\omega=\frac{2 \pi v }{ \lambda}=\frac{(2 \pi \times 360) }{60}=2 \pi 6\)

Now put the value of \(k\) and \(\omega\) in the general equation of motion in positive \(x\)-axis we get

\(y=0.2 \sin (2 \pi 6 t-2 \pi \frac{x }{ 60}) \)

\(y=0.2 \sin [2 \pi(6 t-\frac{x }{ 60})]\)

A wave travelling along the \(x\)-axis is described by the equation \(y=0.005 \cos (\alpha x-\beta t)\) If the wavelength and the time period of the wave are \(0.08 m\) and 2 seconds respectively. Find the values of \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\).

\(y=0.005 \cos (\alpha x-\beta t) \)

\(\alpha= k \) and \( \beta=\omega\)

\(\alpha=\frac{2 \pi }{ \lambda} \)

\(\beta=\frac{2 \pi }{ T} \)

\(\alpha=\frac{2 \pi }{ 0.08 }\)

\(\alpha=25 \pi \)

\(\beta=\frac{2 \pi }{ 2 }\)

\(\beta=\pi\)
Divya and Rahul is standing with a string holding tight each end. Rahul generate a wave that is given by, \(y=25 \sin (4 \pi t+2 \pi x)\). The velocity of wave is:

Given that:

\(y=25 \sin (4 \pi t+2 \pi x)\)

\(\omega=\frac{2 \pi v }{ \lambda} \)...(2)

\(\omega=v k \)

Given that \(v=340 m / s\), Frequency \(=100 KHz =100000 Hz\)

Wavelength \((\lambda)= \frac{Velocity (v) }{ Frequency (f)}=\frac{340 }{ 100000}\)

\(\Lambda=0.0034\) meters \(=3.4 mm\)
A plane progressive wave is represented by the equation \(y=0.25 \cos (2 \pi t-2 \pi x)\). Find the equation of the wave with double the amplitude and travelling in opposite direction.

By comparing a given equation with a general equation we get,

\(A=0.25 ; \omega=2 \pi ; k=2 \pi\)

\(A=2 \times 0.25=0.5 \) unit 

The new wave equation has the opposite direction of the initial one.
