Speed of sound wave is __________ in seawater concerning tap water.

Higher bulk modulus means the faster speed of sound. So, in seawater sound travel faster than tap water.

Although the density of seawater is higher than tap water bulk modulus plays a major role.
The speed ' \(v\) ' of transverse waves on a stretched string of linear mass density ' \(\mu\) ' and tension ' \(T\) ' is equal to:
The speed of transverse waves on a stretched string is given by \(v =\sqrt{\frac{ T }{\mu}}\)
The speed of transverse waves on a stretched string is given by \(v=\sqrt{ (\frac{T }{X})}\), where ' \(T\) ' is tension in the string and the unknown term ' \(X\) ' is:

The speed of transverse waves on a stretched string is given by \(v=\sqrt{ (\frac{T }{ X})}\).

Here \(X\) is mass per unit length or linear density of string.

Bulk modulus of elasticity (B): It is the ratio of Hydraulic (compressive) stress (p) to the volumetric strain \((\frac{\Delta V }{ V })\).

Young's modulus: Young's modulus a modulus of elasticity, applicable to the stretching of wire, etc., equal to the ratio of the applied load per unit area of the cross-section to the increase in length per unit length.

Density: The mass per unit volume is called denisty.
A uniform rope of mass \(m\) and length \(L\) hangs from a ceiling. The speed of transverse waves in the rope at a point at a distance \(x\) from the lower end of the rope is:

Let \(\mu\) is the mass per unit length of the roap.

The speed of transverse waves on a stretched string is given by \(v=\sqrt{ (\frac{T }{ \mu})}\).

At a distance \(x\) from the lower end, we will find tension which will be

\(T=\mu g x\)

So, using \(v =\sqrt{\frac{ T }{\mu}}\) (Speed of transverse wave on a string)

\(v =\sqrt{\frac{\mu gx }{\mu}}\)

\(v =\sqrt{g x}\)
An ideal gas is heated at constant pressure so as to triple its volume. Find the increased temperature of the gas if initial temperature of gas is \(27^{\circ}\) C.

Pressure is constant \(P _{2}= P _{1}\)

Volume is doubled \(V _{2}=3 V _{1}\)

\(T _{1}=27^{\circ}\) C \(=273+27=300 K\), \(T _{2}=?\)

Ideal gas equation,

\(PV = nRT\), \(n =\frac{P V}{R T}\)

During the whole process, no. of moles will not change.

So, \(n_{1}=n_{2}\)

\(\frac{P_{1} V_{1}}{R T_{1}}=\frac{P_{2} V_{2}}{R T_{2}}\)

\(\frac{P_{1} V_{1}}{300 R}=\frac{\left(P_{1}\right)\left(3 V_{1}\right)}{R T_{2}}\)

\(\frac{1}{300}=\frac{3}{T_{2}}\)

\(T_{2}=900 K\)
A vessel contains two non-reacting gases Helium and Neon. The ratio of their partial pressure is \(5 : 2\). Find the ratio of the number of molecules of helium and Neon.

The volume and temperature are the same for the two gases.

Given the ratio of partial pressure \(\frac{n_{1}}{n_{2}}=\frac{5}{2}\)

We know that:

\(P _{1} V = n _{1} R T \text { and } P _{2} V = n _{2} RT\)

Where, \(P\) is pressure, \(V\) is volume, \(T\) is temperature, \(n\) is no. of mole and \(R\) is the universal gas constant

\(\frac{P_{1}}{ P _{2}}=\frac{n_{1}}{n_{2}}=\frac{5}{2}=2.5\)

If \(N _{1}\) and \(N _{2}\) are the numbers of molecules of and \(N\) is the Avogadro's number, then:

\(\frac{n_{1}}{n_{2}}=\frac{\frac{N_{1}}{N}}{\frac{N_{2}}{N}}=\frac{5}{2}\)

Thus, the ratio of the number of molecules of helium and Neon is \(\frac{5}{2}\).
Some gases like Hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen behaves as an ideal gas at:

Some gases like Hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen behaves as an ideal gas at low Pressure and High Temperature.

An ideal gas is a gas that obeys the law of the Ideal Gas Equation.

\(PV = nRT\)

While deriving the ideal gas equation, the following assumptions should be considered:

  • The size of the ideal gas molecules is negligibly small.
  • There must be no force of attraction among the molecules of the gases.
  • Ideal gas work at Low Pressure and High Temperature.
Which of the following is the unit of universal gas constant?

From the ideal gas law, the universal gas constant \(R=\frac{P V}{n T}\)

Unit of Pressure \((P)=\) \(\mathrm{Nm}^{-2}\)

Unit of Temperature \((T)=\)  \(\mathrm{K}\) 

Unit of Volume \(({V})=\)  \(\mathrm{m}^3\)

Unit of Number of moles \(({n})=\)  \(\mathrm{mol}\)

Substituting the units in (1),

\( R=\frac{\left(\mathrm{Nm}^{-2}\right)\left(\mathrm{m}^3\right)}{(\mathrm{mol})(\mathrm{K})}=\mathrm{Nm} \mathrm{mol}^{-1} \mathrm{~K}^{-1}\)

So, \(\mathrm{NmK}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\) is the unit of \({R}\).

\(\mathrm{Nm}\) is also the unit of energy and can be denoted by joules \((J)\). Thus, \(\mathrm{JK}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\) is also a unit of \({R}\).

An erg is a unit of energy equal to \(10^{-7}\) joules. So, \(\mathrm{{erg} K^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}}\) is a unit of \({R}\). Thus, all the given options are correct.
The pressure of an ideal gas undergoing isothermal change is increased by \(10 \%\). The volume of the gas must decrease by about:

Here isothermal process is given,

Temperature \(( T )=\) constant

\(PV = n R T =\) constant

\(P _{1} V _{1}= P _{2} V _{2} \quad \ldots\) (1)

Where, \(P _{1}\) is initial pressure, \(P _{2}\) is final pressure, \(V _{1}\) is initial volume and \(V _{2}\) is final pressure.

Since, pressure is increased by \(10 \%\)

Final pressure \(\left(P_{2}\right)=P+P \times 10 \%=1.1 P\)

Use equation (1);

\(P _{1} V _{1}= P _{2} V _{2}\)

\(P \times V _{1}=1.1 P \times V _{2}\)

\(V _{2}= \frac{V _{1}}{1.1}=\frac{10 V_{1} }{11}\)

Decrease in volume \((\Delta V )= V _{1}- V _{2}= V_{1} -\frac{10 V_{1}}{11}= \frac{V_{1}}{11}\)

\(\%\) Decrease in volume \(=\frac{\Delta V}{V_{1}} \times 100=\frac{V_{1}}{11 V_{1}} \times 100=9.09 \approx 9 \%\)

A stainless steel chamber contains Argon gas at a temperature \(T\) and pressures \(P\). The total number of Argon atoms in the chamber is \(n\). Now Argon gas in the chamber is replaced by \(CO _{2}\) gas and the total number of \(CO _{2}\) molecules in the chamber is \(\frac{n}{2}\) at the same temperature \(T\). The pressure in the chamber now is \(P ^{\prime}\). Which one of the following relations holds true? (Both the gases behave as ideal gases.)

Both Argon and \(CO _{2}\) are ideal gases. So, we can apply the ideal gas equation.

For Argon: The temperature is \(T\), pressure is \(P\), and the number of molecules is \(n\), and volume \(( V )\) is the same for both the gases.

Use ideal gas equation:

\(PV = nRT \quad \ldots (1)\) 

For \(CO _{2}\): The temperature is \(T\), Pressure is \(P ^{\prime}\), number of molecules are \(\frac{n}{2}\) and Volume \(( V )\)

Apply Ideal gas equation:

\(P ^{\prime} V=\left(\frac{n}{2}\right) RT\quad \ldots(2)\)

Equation (2) divided by (1):

\(\frac{P ^{\prime}}{P} = \frac{n}{2}\)

\(P^{\prime}=\frac{P}{2}\)
The mean free path for electron drift increases with:

Mean free path is defined as the average distance an electron travels between two successive collisions. As the impurity increases an electron suffers more collisions because of impurity atoms. As purity increases, there are fewer collisions, and the mean free path increases.
At \(27^{\circ}\) C a gas is compressed suddenly such that its pressure becomes \(\frac{1}{8}\) of original pressure. Final temperature will be \(\left( \gamma =\frac{5}{3}\right)\):

Given: 

\(T _{1}=27+273=300\) K, \(\gamma =\frac{5}{3}, P _{2}=\frac{1}{8} P _{1}\)

Since gas is compressed suddenly, gas is undergone an adiabatic process.

In the adiabatic process,

\(P V^{\gamma}=\) constant

We also know that:

\(T ^{ V } P ^{1- \gamma}=\) Constant

\(T _{1} v P _{1}{ }^{1- \gamma }= T _{2} vP _{2} ^{1- \gamma}\)

Where, \(T_{1}\) is the initial temperature, \(T_{2}\) is the final temperature \(P_{1}\) is the initial pressure, \(P_{2}\) is the final pressure and \(\gamma\) is the adiabatic constant.

\(\frac{P_{1}^{1-\gamma}}{P_{2}^{1-\gamma}}=\frac{T_{2}^{\gamma}}{T_{1}^{\gamma}}\)

\(\left(\frac{P_{1}}{P_{2}}\right)^{1-\gamma}=\left(\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}\right)^{\gamma}\)

\(\left(\frac{P_{1} \times 8}{P_{1}}\right)^{1-\left(\frac{5}{3}\right)}=\left(\frac{T_{2}}{300}\right)^{\frac{5}{3}}\)

\(T _{2}=130.58 K\)

\(T _{2}=130.58-273=-142.42^{\circ} C\)

Thus, The final temperature will be \(-142^{\circ} C\).
An ideal gas has pressure \(P\) and the kinetic energy of the unit volume of the gas is \(E\). \(P\) and \(E\) are related as:

The given gas is ideal and therefore obeys the ideal gas equation: \(PV = n R T \quad \ldots\) (1)

Where, \(P\) is the pressure of the gas, \(V\) is the volume of the gas, \(n\) is the number of moles, \(T\) is the temperature and \(R\) is the universal gas constant.

The kinetic energy per unit volume of this gas, \(E =\frac{3}{2} n R T \quad \ldots\) (2)

From (1), the pressure per unit volume \(( V =1\) unit), \(P = nRT\quad \ldots\) (3)

Substituting (3) in (2) we get,

\(E =\frac{3}{2} P\)

\(\Rightarrow P =\frac{2}{3} E\)
The mean free path of gas molecules is proportional to \(n ^{\text {th }}\) power of diameter of molecules. Here \(n\) is:

We know that:

The distance travelled by a gas molecule between two successive collisions is known as a free path. It is given as:

\(\lambda=\frac{\text { Total distance travelled by a gas molecule between successive collisions }}{\text { Total number of collisions }}\)

During two successive collisions, a molecule of gas moves in a straight line with constant velocity, and the mean free path of a gas molecule is given by:

\(\lambda=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2} \pi n d^{2}} \quad \dots\) (1)

Where, \(n=\) number of molecules per unit volume and \(d=\) diameter of a molecule

From equation (1) we get,

\( \lambda \propto d^{-2}\)

So, \(n ^{\text {th }}\) power of diameter of molecules \(= -2\)
In Maxwell Boltzmann distribution, the fraction of gas molecules having energy between \(E\) and \(E + dE\) is proportional to:

Maxwell Boltzmann distribution for velocity is given by:

\(n(E) d E=\frac{2 \pi N}{V(\pi k T)^{\frac{3}{2}}} E^{\frac{1}{2}} e^{-\frac{E}{k T}} dE\)

Where, \(n=\) number of molecules, \(T=\) temperature, \(k=\) Boltzmann constant, and \(E=\) energy

From the above equation, it is clear that the fraction of gas molecules having an energy between \(E\) and \(E + d E\) is proportional to \(E^{\frac{1}{2}} \exp \left(-\frac{E}{k T}\right)\).
If temperature of the gas is increased to three times, then its root mean square velocity become:

The rms speed of any homogeneous gas sample is given by:

\(V_{rms}=\sqrt{\frac{3 R T}{M}}\) \(\quad \cdots (1)\)

Where, \(R =\) universal gas constant, \(T =\) temperature and \(M =\) Molecular mass

Here, \(M\) and \(R\) is constant,

On increasing the value of T by 3 in equation (1) we get,

\(V _{ rms } \propto \sqrt{3 T }\)

If the temperature is increased to \(3\) times, then \(V _{ rms }\) is increased by \(\sqrt{3}\) times.
The total internal energy of a mole of a rigid diatomic gas is:

The molar specific heat capacity of a gas at constant volume is defined as the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of 1 mol of the gas by \(1^{\circ} C\) at the constant volume.

\(C_{v}=\left(\frac{\Delta Q}{n \Delta T}\right)\)

The molar specific heat of a gas at constant pressure is defined as the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of \(1 mol\) of the gas by 1 \({ }^{\circ} C\) at the constant pressure.

\(C_{p}=\left(\frac{\Delta Q}{n \Delta T}\right)\)

The ratio of the two principal specific heat is represented by \(\gamma\).

\(\therefore \gamma=\frac{C_{p}}{C_{v}}\)

The value of \(\gamma\) depends on the atomicity of the gas.

The total internal energy of a mole of a rigid diatomic gas is,

\(U=\frac{5}{2} R T\)

A piece of glass of mass 100 g heated at \(350^{\circ}\) C is placed in 1 kg of water at \(23.6^{\circ}\) C. What is the final recorded temperature of the system? (The specific heat capacity of the glass = 0.8 J/g\(^{\circ}\) C and specific heat capacity of water = 4.0 J/g\(^{\circ}\) C).

Given: mass of glass \(m_{1}=100\) g, initial temperature \(t_{1}=350^{\circ}\) C, specific heat capacity of the glass \(c _{1}=0.8\) J/g\(^{\circ}\) C and mass of water \(m _{2}=1\) kg \(=1000\) g, final temperature \(t _{2}=23.6^{\circ}\) C, specific heat capacity of water \(C _{2}=4.0\) J/g\(^{\circ}\) C

Let the final temperature of the system will be \(x ^{\circ}\) C.

Heat lost by glass = Heat gained by water

\(m_{1} c_{1}\left(t_{1}-x\right)=m_{2} c_{2}\left(x-t_{2}\right)\)

\(100 \times 0.8 \times(350-x)=1000 \times 4.0(x-23.6)\)

\(350-x=50(x-23.6)\)

\(51 x=1530\)

\(\Rightarrow x=30^{\circ}\) C

Calculate the ratio \(\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{P}} / \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{V}}\) of oxygen from the following data. Speed of sound in oxygen at \(0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=318 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\), molecular weight of oxygen \(=32 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{mol}\) and the gas constant \(\mathrm{R}=8.3\) \(\mathrm{J} / \mathrm{mol}\) - K.

Speed of sound in oxygen at \(0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=318 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\), molecular weight of oxygen \(=\) \(32 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{mol}\)

\(\mathrm{V}=\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{p}} / \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{v}} \)

\(\Rightarrow \gamma=\frac{M v^2}{R T}=\frac{32 \times 10^{-3} \times 318^2}{8.3 \times 273}=1.428\)
According to the law of equipartition of energy, the energy of the molecule of a gas depends on the:

According to the law of equipartition of energy, for any dynamic system in thermal equilibrium, the total energy for the system is equally divided among the degree of freedom with each degree of freedom having average energy equal to \(\frac{1}{2} k_B T\).

Where \({k}_{{B}}=\) Boltzmann constant and \({T}=\) absolute temperature

If the degree of freedom of a molecule is \(n\), then its total energy is given as,

\( E=n \times \frac{1}{2} k_B T\)

By equation (1) we can say the energy of the molecule of a gas depends on the degree of freedom and temperature.
In gases of monoatomic molecules, find the ratio of the two specific heat of gases \(\frac{C_{p}}{C_{v}}\).

For monoatomic:

Degree of freedom \(=3\)

For monoatomic molecules,

\(\frac{C_{p}}{C_{v}}=1+\frac{2}{f}\)

Where, \(C_{p}\) is the specific heat at constant pressure, \(C_{v}\) is the specific heat at constant volume and \(f\) is the degree of freedom.

\(\frac{C_{p}}{C_{v}}=1+\frac{2}{3}\)

\(\frac{C_{p}}{C_{v}}=\frac{5}{3} \approx 1.66\)
The ratio of the root mean square speed, average speed and maximum possible speed for a gas will be:

Root mean square velocity of Gaseous particles: Root mean square velocity (RMS value) is the square root of the mean of squares of the velocity of individual gas molecules. It is given by,

\(V_{r m s}=\sqrt{\frac{3 R T}{M}}\)

Average velocity: It is the arithmetic mean of the velocities of different molecules of a gas at a given temperature. It is given by,

\(V_{a v}=\sqrt{\frac{8 R T}{\pi M}}\)

Most probable velocity: It is the velocity possessed by maximum fraction of molecules at the same temperature. It is given by,

\(V_{p}=\sqrt{\frac{2 R T}{M}}\)

The required ratio between these parameters are,

\(\sqrt{\frac{3 R T}{M}}: \sqrt{\frac{8 R T}{\pi M}}: \sqrt{\frac{2 R T}{M}}\)

By Canceling all constant terms from the above expression we have,

\(\sqrt{3}: \sqrt{\frac{8}{\pi}} : \sqrt{2} =1.732 : 1.596 : 1.414\)
If one mole of Carbon contains \(x\) atoms, then the number of atoms in \(12\) g of Magnesium is:

1 mole of \(C=x\) atoms \(=N_{A}\) atoms.

We know that \(N _{ A }\) = the number of atoms present in \(12\) grams of Carbon-12

So, \(x = N _{ A }\)

The atomic mass of \(Mg\) is \(24\) g/mol i.e., 1 mole of Mg \(=24\) g \(= x\) atoms

The number of moles in \(12\) g of Mg \(=\frac{12}{24}=0.5\) moles

1 mole of \(Mg \rightarrow x\) atoms

\(0.5\) mole of \(Mg \rightarrow 0.5 x\) atoms

Therefore, \(12 g\) of Magnesium has \(0.5 x\) atoms.
Choose the incorrect statement regarding root mean square speed of a molecule.
rms speed is dependent of mass of molecules
If molecular weight of molecule increases then rms speed decreases

The rms speed of any homogeneous gas sample is given by:

\(V_{r m s}=\sqrt{\frac{3 R T}{M}}\)

From the above discussion it is clear that:

\(V _{ rms } \propto \sqrt{T}\)

\(V_{r m s} \propto \frac{1}{\sqrt{M}}\)

On decreasing the temperature, the rms speed  increases, and on increasing the molecular mass of the molecules the rms speed decreases.
Which of the following statements about kinetic theory of gases is wrong?
The molecules of a gas are in continuous random motion.
The molecules do not interact with each other except during collisions.
The collisions amongst the molecules are of short duration.

The kinetic theory of gases is based on the assumptions that:

  1. The gas is composed of a large number of identical molecules moving in random directions, separated by distances that are large compared with their size.
  2. The molecules undergo perfectly elastic collisions (no energy loss) with each other and with the walls of the container, but otherwise do not interact.
  3. The transfer of kinetic energy between molecules takes place in the form of heat.

From the above, it is clear that the molecules of the gases undergo perfectly elastic collisions.
A mono atomic molecule free to move in space has how many translational degrees of freedom?

For a monoatomic gas,

The number of particle in the system \((A) = 1\)

The number of relations among the particles \((R) = 0\)

The number of degrees of freedom,

\(N = 3A - R = 3\)

So, a monoatomic molecule free to move in space has three translational degrees of freedom.
The ratio of \(\frac{C_{p}}{C_{v}}\) for a rigid diatomic gas is? \(C_{p}\) and \(C_{v}\) are molar specific heats at constant pressure and constant volume respectively)

The relation between the ratio of \(C _{ p }\) and \(C _{ v }\) with a degree of freedom \(f\) is given by,

\(\gamma=\frac{C_{p}}{C_{v}}=1+\frac{2}{f}\)

Diatomic gas has 5 degrees of freedom,

\(\gamma=1+\frac{2}{5}=\frac{5+2}{5}=\frac{7}{5}\)
If a material have less specific heat then it means that ________.
More amount of energy is needed to increase its temperature
Less amount of energy is needed to increase its temperature
More amount of energy is needed to change its state
Less amount of energy is needed to change its state

If a material have less specific heat then it means that less amount of energy is needed to increase its temperature.

The specific heat capacity (S) of a substance is defined as the amount of heat (\(\Delta Q\)) per unit mass of the substance that is required to raise the temperature

\((\Delta T)\) by \(1^{\circ} C\)

i.e., \(S=\frac{\Delta Q}{m \Delta T}\)

And the unit of Specific heat is \(J/g ^{\circ} C\) and \(Cal/g^{\circ} C\)

Here, \(S =\) specific heat of material, \(\Delta Q=\) heat exchange

\(\Delta T =\) change in temperature, \(m =\) unit mass of material

Thus, if specific heat of a material is less it means that the less amount of energy is needed to increase its temperature.
If the temperature of \(10\) g of mercury (of specific heat capacity \(140\) Jkg\(^{-1}\) K\(^{-1})\) is to be raised from \(0^{\circ}\) C to \(100^{\circ}\) C then how much heat (in J) is required?

Mass \((m)=10\) g \(=\frac{10}{1000}\) kg \(=0.01\) kg

Initial temperature \(\left(T_{1}\right)=0^{\circ} C\)

Final temperature \(\left(T_{2}\right)=100^{\circ} C\)

Heat absorbed (Q) =?

specific heat capacity (C) \(=140\) J/(kg K)

We know that, heat absorbed is given by,

\(Q=m C \Delta T\)

\(Q=0.01 \times 140 \times(100-0)=140\) J

If the gas particles are of diameter '\(d\)', average speed '\(v\)', number of particles per unit volume '\(n\)', then the average distance between two successive collisions, called the mean free path is ______.

The distance travelled by a gas molecule between two successive collisions is known as a free path.

\(\lambda=\frac{\text { Total distance travelled by a gas molecule between successive collisions }}{\text { Total number of collisions }}\)

During two successive collisions, a molecule of gas moves in a straight line with constant velocity, and the mean free path of a gas molecule is given by,

\(\lambda=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2} \pi n d^{2}}\)

Where, \(n=\) number of molecules per unit volume and \(d=\) diameter of a molecule

From the above, it is clear that the average distance between two successive collisions called the mean free path is \(\lambda=\frac{1}{\pi n d^{2}}\).
If a gas is in equilibrium, then:
Speed of all the molecules remain constant
Average speed of all the molecules remains constant
Equilibrium is not possible for the gases

The gas is full of activity and the equilibrium is a dynamic one. In dynamic equilibrium, molecules collide and change their speeds during the collision. Only the average properties are constant. So, if a gas is in equilibrium, then the average speed of all the molecules remains constant.
According to Kinetic molecular theory of gases, which of the following postulate is true:
There exists force of attraction between the particles of a gas at ordinary temperature and pressure
At any particular time, different particles in the gas have same speeds
Particles of gas move in straight line

According to Kinetic molecular theory of gases:

  • There is no force of attraction between the particles of a gas at ordinary temperature and pressure.
  • Collisions of gas molecules are perfectly elastic.
  • At any particular time, different particles in the gas have different speeds and hence different kinetic energies.
  • Particles of gas move in straight line.
Which one of the following is not an assumption in the kinetic theory of gases?
The volume which is occupied by the gas molecules is almost negligible
The force of attraction between the molecules is negligible

Kinetic theory assumes that molecules are very small in size relative to the distance between molecules. The collision between molecules is an elastic collision, that means there is no net loss of kinetic energy. The force of attraction between the molecules is also very less almost negligible. Gas particles are rapid, continuous and random motion. So all molecules of gas do not have same speed.
The average kinetic energy per molecule of 2 gases is the same. Which of the following is likely to be the same for both gases?

The formula gives the average kinetic energy per molecule K of a gas,

\(K =\frac{3 RT }{2}\)

\(K \propto T\)

Where, R is the universal gas constant and T is the absolute temperature of the gas.

According to this relation, the average Kinetic energy of the molecule of a gas is directly proportional to the absolute temperature.
If three balls are dropped simultaneously from the top of a tower, then the acceleration of the centre of mass of the three balls during the motion:
Depends on the masses and velocities of the three balls
Depends on the velocities of the three balls

\(a_{1}=a_{2}=a_{3}=g\) (gravitational acceleration)

The three balls are falling under gravity, so the acceleration of all the three balls will be equal to the gravitational acceleration.

We know that the total mass of a system of particles times the acceleration of its centre of mass is equal to the vector sum of all the forces acting on the system of particles.

\({Ma}={m}_{1} {a}_{1}+{m}_{2} {a}_{2}+\ldots+{m}_{{n}} {a}_{{n}} \quad \ldots\) (1)

Where, \(m_{1}, m_{2}, \ldots, m_{n}=\) mass of the particles, and \(a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}=\) acceleration of the particles. By equation (1), the acceleration of the centre of mass of the three balls is given as,

\({Ma}={m}_{1} {a}_{1}+{m}_{2} {a}_{2}+{m}_{3} {a}_{3}\)

\(\Rightarrow a=\frac{m_{1} g+m_{2} g+m_{3} g}{m_{1}+m_{2}+m_{3}}\)

\(\Rightarrow a=\frac{\left(m_{1}+m_{2}+m_{3}\right) g}{\left(m_{1}+m_{2}+m_{3}\right)}\)

\(\Rightarrow {a}={g}\)
The X- coordinates of the particles of a system of bodies whose centre of mass is at origin will be?
Positive for some particles and negative for other particles

If the centre of mass is at the origin, this means that some particles will be towards the left of the centre of mass and some towards the right of the centre of mass. The particles towards the left of centre of mass will have a negative value of X-coordinate whereas those towards the right will have a positive value of X-coordinate.

In this case, the particles can not have always positive values of X-coordinates or always negative values of X-coordinates separately because the particles are uniformly distributed about the centre of mass of the body.
Two bodies of masses \(5 {~kg}\) and \(10 {~kg}\) are moving towards each other with equal velocities of \(15 {~m/sec}\). Find the velocity of the centre of mass.

\({m}_{1}=5 {~kg}\), \({m}_{2}=10 {~kg}\), \({v}_{1}=15 {~m} / {sec}\) and \({v}_{2}=-15 {~m} / {sec}\)

We know that if a system of particles have n particles and all are moving with some velocity, then the velocity of the centre of mass is given as,

\(v=\frac{m_{1} v_{1}+m_{2} v_{2}+\ldots+m_{n} v_{n}}{m_{1}+m_{2}+\ldots+m_{n}} \quad \dots\) (1)

Where, \(m_{1}\) is mass of first particle, \(m_{2}\) is mass of second particle, \(v_{1}\) is velocity of first particle, \(v_{2}\) is velocity of second particle.

By equation (1) the velocity of the centre of mass is given as,

\(v=\frac{m_{1} v_{1}+m_{2} v_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}\)

\(\Rightarrow v=\frac{(5 \times 15)+(10 \times(-15))}{5+10}\)

\(\Rightarrow v=\frac{(5-10) \times 15}{15}\)

\(\Rightarrow v=-5 {~m} / {sec}\)
A wheel is rolling on a plane surface as shown. The centre of the wheel moves with a speed \(v_{0}\). Then the speed of the particle at \(P\) is:

The motion of the wheel is combined with rolling and translation. 

The speed of the center of the wheel \(=v_{0}\)

Since the point \({P}\) is on the rim of the wheel, \({v}_{0}={R} \omega\)

Thus, the speed of the particle at \({P}, {v}={r} \omega\)

Where, \({v}\) is velocity, \({r}\) is radius, \(\omega\) is angular velocity


Using Pythagoras theorem, \(r=\sqrt{R^{2}+R^{2}}=\sqrt{2} R\) 

Therefore, speed at \({P}={r} \omega=\sqrt{2} {R} \omega=\sqrt{{2}} {v}_{0}\)
A particle is in circular motion in a vertical plane. If the direction of the velocity at the top most point is towards the east, then the direction of angular velocity is towards:

Since the circular motion is in the vertical plane, it is the plane of east-west and north-south will be the horizontal plane.

The direction of angular velocity is perpendicular to the plane of rotation. Thus, the angular velocity will be along the north-south direction.


Given that linear velocity is directed towards the east. So, on using the right-hand thumb rule for vector product, the direction of angular velocity will be towards the north.
A rotating wheel has angular speed \({f}_{0}\) rpm. What is the angular speed in radian per second?

Given that \({f}_{0}\) is the angular speed in rpm.

Angular speed in radian per minute.

\(\omega_{0}=2 \pi \mathrm{f}_{0}\)

Angular speed in radian per second.

\(\omega_{0}=\frac{2 \pi f_{0} }{ 60}\)

A flywheel of mass \(6000 {~kg}\) starts from rest and gets up to a speed of \(20 {~rad} / \mathrm{s}\) in 2 minutes. The radius of gyration of the wheel is \(100 {~cm}\). The average torque exerted on the flywheel is:

Mass \({M}=6000 {~kg}\), \(\omega_0=0 {~rad} / {s}\), Angular speed \((\omega)\) after \(2 {~min}=20 {~rad} /{s}\)

Time \({t}=2 {~min}=120 {~s} \)

\({k}=100 {~cm}=1 {~m} \)

We know that, 

\(\omega=\omega_0+{\alpha t} \)

\(20=0+{\alpha} \times 120 \)

\({\alpha}=\frac{20}{120} =0.1666{~rad}/{s}^2\)

We know that:

\({I}={M} \times{k}^2\)

Where, \({I}\) is moment of inertia, \({M}\) is mass\

\({I}=6000 \times 1^2=6000 {~kg}-{m}^2\)

Now, \(T={I}\times \alpha \)

Where \({T}\) is torque, \({I}\) is moment of inertia, \({\alpha}=\) angular acceleration.

\({T}=6000 \times 0.1666  =1000 {~Nm}\)
If a solid disc was rotating along the x-y axis as shown below, in such case the direction of torque will be:

From the above-given explanation also from the given data, we can express the equation of torque as shown below

Torque, \(\vec{\tau}=\vec{r} \times \vec{F}\)

And the direction of torque can be predicted using right-hand thumb rule, in which curled finger represents the direction of force and thumb represents the direction of torque as shown below,


So, from this, we can see that the direction of torque will be along the positive x-axis.

A couple of \(10^{5}\) Nm is applied to a fly wheel of mass \(10 \mathrm{~kg}\) and radius of gyration \(50 \mathrm{~m}\). The angular acceleration of the wheel in \(\mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\) is:

Torque, \(\mathrm{T}=10^{5}\) Nm

Mass, \(\mathrm{m}=10 \mathrm{~kg}\)

The radius of gyration, \(r=50 \mathrm{~m}\)

Moment of inertia,

\(\mathrm{I}=\mathrm{mr}^{2}=10 \times 50^{2}=25000 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{2}\)

Torque, \(\mathrm{T}=\mathrm{I} \times\alpha\)

\(\) Angular acceleration, \(\alpha=\frac{T}{I}\)

\(=\frac{10^{5}}{25000}=4~\mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\)

A door of \(1.6 {~m}\) wide requires a force of \(1 {~N}\) to be applied at the free end to open or close it. The force that is required at a point \(0.4 {~m}\) distant from the hinges for opening or closing the door is:

Given that initially Force \(\vec{F}=1 {~N}\) and distance from the hinge \(\vec{{r}}=1.6 {~m}\)

Later \(\vec{r}=0.4 {~m}\) and Required Force \(\vec{F}=\) ?

We know that the formula of torque \(\vec{T}\) is given by:

\(\vec{T}=\vec{r} \times \vec{F}\) (initial force)

\(=1.6 \times 1=1.6 {~Nm}\)

Putting the above value in the formula of torque, we get:

\(1.6=0.4 \times \vec{F}\) (required Force)

\(\Rightarrow\vec{F}=4 N\)
\(120 {~N}\) of force is required to open a nut using a spanner of length \(10 {~cm}\). If another spanner of length \(6 {~cm}\) is used to open the same nut, what amount of force has to applied?

The opening of a nut using a spanner works on the principle of torque. When a force is applied through a spanner, the fixed point lies where the nut is positioned. As a result, a turning effect is produced on the nut which helps in its opening or tightening.

The angle between force and moment arm is 90∘ when maximum torque is produced.


Length of the spanner \(=\) moment arm, \(r_1=10 {~cm}=0.1 {~m}\)

Force applied \(=120 {~N}\)

We Know that:

\(\tau=r_1 \times F\)

Where, \(\tau\) is torque, \(r_1\) is lenght of spanner and \(F\) is Force

\(\tau=0.1 \times 120=12 {~N}-{m}\)

To open the nut using another spanner, the same torque has to be produced.

Lenght of the second spanner, \(r_2=6 \mathrm{~cm}=0.06 \mathrm{~m}\)

\(\tau=r_2 \times F \)

\(12=0.06 \times F \)

\(\Rightarrow F=200 {~N}\)
Moment of inertia, rotational kinetic energy, and angular momentum of a body is \(I, E\), and \(L\) respectively then:

We know that:

\(K E=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}\)

Angular momentum, \(L=I \times \omega\quad \ldots(1)\)

Roational kinetic energy, \(E=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}\) 

Where I is Moment of inertia, and \(\omega\) is angular momentum

\(\omega=\sqrt{\frac{2 E}{I}} \quad \ldots(2)\)

Substituting (2) in (1) we get

\(\mathrm{L}=I \times \sqrt{\frac{2 E}{I}}=\sqrt{(2 EI)}\)

A rod of length (L) \(15 {~m}\) is rotating about an axis passing through its one end and velocity at a point which is at \(\frac{L }{ 3}\) distance from the axis is \(15 {~m} / {s}\). Find the linear velocity of the free end of the rod.

Length of the rod \({L}=15 \mathrm{~m}\)

Linear velocity at \(\frac{L }{ 3}\) is \((v)=15 {~m} / {s}\)

Let \(\omega\) is the angular velocity of the rod about the given axis of rotation.


We know that:

\(v=\omega \times L\)

At \(\frac{L} { 3}\),

\(v=\omega\times\frac{L} { 3}=15\)

So, \(\omega=\frac{45 } {L}  {rad} / {s}\)

Now for free end:

\({v}^{\prime}=\omega L=(\frac{45 }{L}) \times {L}=45 {~m} / {s}\)
A string is wound round a hollow cylinder of mass \(3 {~kg}\) and radians \(40 {~cm}\). The string is pulled with a force of 50 Newton. The angular acceleration of cylinder will be:
\(41.66 {~rad/s}^{2}\)
\(10 {~rad/s}^{2}\)
\(15 {~rad/s}^{2}\)
\(35 {~rad/s}^{2}\)

Force applied \((F)=50 {~N}\)

Mass \((m)=3 {~kg}\)

Radius \((r)=40 {~cm}=0.4 {~m}\)

Torque \((\tau)=F \times r=50{~N} \times 0.4 {~m}=20 {~N} {~m}\)

Moment of inertia is given by:

\(I={mr}^2 \)

\(=3 {~kg} \times 0.4 {~m} \times 0.4 {~m}=0.48 {~kg} {~m}^2\)

Angular acceleration is given by:

\(a=\frac{\tau}{I}=\frac{20 \mathrm{Nm}}{0.48} =41.66 {~rad/s}^{2}\)
Find the radius of gyration of a disc of mass \({M}\) and radius \({R}\) rotating about an axis passing through the center of mass and perpendicular to the plane of the disc.

In terms of the radius of gyration, the moment of inertia is \({I}={M} {K}^{2}\)

So, \({M} {K}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} {MR}^{2}\) 

\(\Rightarrow {K}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} {R}^{2}\) 

\(\Rightarrow {K}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} {R}\),

\(\Rightarrow K=\frac{1}{1.414} {R}=0.707 {R}\)

From a circular disc of radius \({R}\) and mass \(9 {M}\), a small disc of mass \({M}\) and radius \(\frac{R}{3}\) is removed concentrically. The moment of inertia of the remaining disc about an axis perpendicular to the plane of the disc and passing through its centre is:

The radius of full disc \(={R}\)

Mass of full disc \(=9 {M}\)

The radius of removed disc \(=\frac{R }{3}\)

Mass of removed disc \(=M\)

From the formula of moment of Inertia, we get,

\({I}_{1}=\frac{1} { 2}{ {M}_{1} {R}_{1}^{2}}=\frac{1 }{ 2} \times 9 {M} \times {R}^{2}=\frac{9 }{ 2} {MR}^{2}\) ( Full disc) 

\({I}_{2}=\frac{1 }{ 2}{ {M}_{2} {R}_{2}^{2}}=\frac{1 }{ 2} \times \mathrm{M} \times(\frac{R}{ 3})^{2}=\frac{{MR}^{2} }{ 18}\)

Therefore, the moment of inertia of the remaining portion of the disc about \({O}\) is.

\({I}={I}_{1}+{I}_{2}={MR}^{2}[\frac{9} { 2}+\frac{1 }{ 18}]=\frac{41}{ 9}{MR}^{2}\)

A thin disc and a thin ring, both have mass \({M}\) and radius \({R}\). Both rotate about axes through their centre of mass and are perpendicular to their surfaces at the same angular velocity. Which of the following is true?
The ring and the disc have the same kinetic energy
Kinetic energies of both the bodies are zero since they are not in linear motion

Moment of inertia of the ring about an axis passing through centre and perpendicular to its plane is given by-

\(I_{\text {ring }}=M R^{2}\)

Moment of inertia of the disc about an axis passing through centre and perpendicular to its plane is given by-

\(I_{d i s c}=\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}\)

As we know that mathematically rotational kinetic energy can be written as:

\(K E=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}\)

Where, \(\omega\) is angular velocity

According to question, that angular velocity of thin disc and a thin ring is same. Thus, Kinetic energy is depends on to moment of inertia. Therefore, a body having more moment of inertia will have more kinetic energy and vice versa.

So, from equation it is clear that, \(I_{\text {ring }}>I_{\text {disc }} ;\) so, \(K_{\text {ring }}>K_{\text {disc }}\)

\(\therefore\) The ring has higher kinetic energy.
If the mass and moment of inertia of a solid sphere and spherical shell are the same, the ratio of their radii will be:

Moment of inertia of a solid sphere \(I_s=\frac{2}{5} m r^{2}\)

Moment of inertia of a hollow sphere \(I_h=\frac{2}{3} m r^{\prime 2}\)

Let radius of solid sphere is \({r}\), and hollow sphere is \({r}^{\prime}\)

Since, moment of inertia is equal, therefore, on equating both the moment of inertia of spheres, we get:

\(\frac{2}{5} m r^{2}=\frac{2}{3} m r^{\prime2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{5} r^{2}=\frac{1}{3} r^{\prime2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{r^{2}}{r^{\prime 2}}=\frac{5}{3}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{r}{r^{\prime}}=\frac{\sqrt{5}}{\sqrt{3}}\)

So, the required ratio is \(\sqrt{5}: \sqrt{3}\).

Four identical thin rods each of mass \({M}\) and length \({l}\), form a square frame. Moment of inertia of this frame about an axis through the centre of the square and perpendicular to its plane is:

Mass of each rod \(=M\)

Length of each \({rod}=l\)


Moment of inertia about an axis passing through the center of the rod, \({I}_{{C}}=\frac{M l^{2}}{12}\)

Moment of inertia of the rod about an axis through the center of the square and perpendicular to its plane:

Here, \(h=\frac{l}{2}\)

By using parallel axis theorem, Moment of Inertia \( I=I_{{C}}+{m}\left({h}^{2}\right)\)

\(=\frac{M l^{2}}{12}+M\left(\frac{l}{2}\right)^{2}\)

\(=\frac{M l^{2}}{12}+\frac{M l^{2}}{4}=\frac{M l^{2}}{3}\)

Moment of inertia due to all four rods \(=4 \times {I} =4 \times \frac{M l^{2}}{3}\)

\(=(\frac{4 }{ 3}) {Ml}^{2}\)

The moment of inertia of a rod of mass \({M}\) and length \({l}\) about an axis passing through its centre and perpendicular to its length is \(0.084\) \({M} {l}^{2}\). Then the moment of inertia of the rod about an axis passing through one of its ends and parallel to the given axis will be:

Moment of inertia about the axis through the centre of the road, \({I}_{{C}}=0.084 {~M} {l}^{2}\)

The distance between the central axis and the axis passing through one of its ends parallelly, 

\(h=0.5l\)


Using the parallel axis theorem, Moment of Inertia \(I =I_{C}+M h^{2}=0.084 M l^{2}+M(0.5l)^{2}\) 

\(=(0.084+0.25) {~M} {l}^{2}\)

\(=0.334 {~Ml}^{2}\)
The moment of inertia of a body is always minimum about an axis parallel to its:

From the parallel axis theorem, the moment of inertia about any other parallel axis passing through the axis of the center of mass (Centroidal axis):


Moment of inertia about \(P_{1}\) axis:

\(I=I_{c o m}+M x_{1}^{2}\)

And moment of inertia about \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\)

\(I=I_{{com}}+{M} {x}_{2}{ }^{2}\)

Where \(I\) is a total moment of inertia of the body, \({I}_{\text {com }}\) is the moment of inertia about the center of mass, \({M}\) is mass, \({x}_{2}\) is the perpendicular distance from an axis passing from center of mass.

So it is clear that the moment of inertia about any parallel axis from the Centroidal axis is more than the moment of inertia about the Centroidal axis.
According to principal of moments, a body will be in rotational equilibrium if:
Algebraic sum of the moments of all forces acting on the body, about a fixed point is infinity.
Algebraic sum of the moments of all forces acting on the body, about a fixed point is a non zero finite quantity
Algebraic sum of the moments of all forces acting on the body, about a fixed point is zero.

According to the principle of moments, also known as the principle of torque equilibrium, a body will be in rotational equilibrium if the algebraic sum of the moments (or torques) of all forces acting on the body about a fixed point is zero. This principle is based on the fact that an object will remain at rest or continue in uniform rotation unless acted upon by an external torque. When the net torque acting on an object is zero, it will remain in rotational equilibrium.
If angular position of a rigid body changes with time as \(\theta=4 t^{3}-12 t-14\) then the angular velocity of the body at time \(t=1 {sec}\) is:

The expression for the angular position, \(\theta=4 t^{3}-12 t-14\)

\(\) Angular position, \(\theta=4 t^{3}-12 t-14\)

Now,

Instantaneous angular velocity is given as-

\(\omega=\frac{d \theta}{d t}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d \theta}{d t}=\frac{d\left(4 t^{3}-12 t-14\right)}{d t}=12 t^{2}-12\)

\(\therefore \omega=12 t^{2}-12\)

Now,

Angular velocity at \({t}=1 {~sec}\),

\(\omega=12(1)^{2}-12=0\)

\(\therefore \omega=0\)

A thin circular ring of mass \({M}\) and radius \({R}\) is rotating about its axis with a constant angular velocity \(\omega\). Two objects each of mass '\({m}\)' are attached gently to the opposite ends of a diameter of the ring. The ring will now rotate with an angular velocity:

\(M_{1}=M, M_{2}=2 m, R_{1}=R_{2}=R(l e t)\), initial velocity \(\left(\omega_{1}\right)=\omega\) and final velocity \(\left(\omega_{2}\right)=\omega^{\prime}\)

We have a thin circular ring of mass \({M}\) and radius \({r}\) and it is rotated at constant angular velocity \(\omega\)

The initial moment of inertia is of the circular ring is,

\(I_{1}=M_{1} R_{1}^{2}=M R^{2}\)..............(1)

The initial momentum of the circular ring is,

\(L=I_{1} \omega=M R^{2} \omega\)

When another ring of the same mass is put on the \(1^{st }\) rotating ring, then the final moment of inertia is,

\(I_{2}=M R^{2}+2 m R^{2}=(M+2 m) R^{2}\)

Final momentum of the circular ring is

\(L^{\prime}=I_{2} \omega^{\prime}=(M+2 m) R^{2} \omega^{\prime}\)

Since, there is no external torque acting on this system, this means that angular momentum of the system will be conserved.

Thus, by conservation of angular momentum,

\({L}={L}^{\prime}\)

\(\Rightarrow {MR}^{2} \omega=({M}+2 {~m}) {R}^{2} \omega^{\prime}\)

\(\Rightarrow \omega^{\prime}=\frac{M R^{2} \omega}{(M+2 m) R^{2}}=\frac{M \omega}{M+2 m}\)
Which of the following condition is/are true for rolling of disc without slipping on an incline plane of inclination \(\theta\).

Disc will begin to slip when:

\({f}=\mu {N}\)

As there is no motion in a direction normal to the inclined plane:

\({N}={Mgcos} \theta\)

Applying Newton's Second Law to the linear motion of the center of mass, the net force on the cylinder rolling down the inclined plane is:

\(F=M a=M g \sin \theta-f \quad \dots\) (1)

It is only the force of friction \(f\) wich expert torque \(\tau\) on the cylinder and makes it rotate with angular acceleration. It acts tangentially at the point of contact \({P}\) and has lever arm equal to \(R\).

Putting the value of \({f}\) in equation (1), we get,

\({Ma}={Mg} \sin \theta-\frac{I \alpha}{R^{2}}={a}={g} \sin \theta-\frac{I \alpha}{M R^{2}}={a}+\frac{I \alpha}{M R^{2}}={g} \sin \theta\)

Moment of Inertia of the solid cylinder about its axis \(=\frac{{MR}^{2} }{ 2}\)

By putting value, \(I= \frac{1}{2} M R^{2}\), we get,

\({a}=\frac{g \sin \theta}{1+\frac{I}{M R^{2}}}=\frac{2}{3} {~g} \sin \theta\) \(\quad \ldots\) (2)

Clearly, the linear acceleration of a solid cylinder rolling down an inclined plane is less than the acceleration due to gravity \((a<g)\)

The linear acceleration of the cylinder is constant for a given inclined plane and is independent of its mass \(M\), and Radius \(R\).

However, for a hollow cylinder.

\({I}={MR}^{2}\), the value of a would decrease to \(\frac{1 }{ 2}{~g} \sin \theta\)

From equation (1), the value of the force of friction is,

\(f=M g \sin \theta-Ma\) 

By putting the value of a from equation (2), we get,

\(f={Mgsin} \theta-M \times\frac{ 2} { 3}(g \sin \theta)=\frac{1 }{ 3}({Mgsin} \theta)\)

if \(\mu_{{s}}\) is the coefficient of friction between the cylinder and the inclined plane, then

\(\mu_{{s}}=\frac{f} {N}=\frac{\frac{1}{3} {Mg} \sin \theta}{M g \cos \theta}=\frac{1} { 3} \tan \theta\)

Therefore, \(\mu_{{s}}>\frac{1} { 3}(\tan \theta)\) or \(\mu_{{s}}=\frac{1} { 3(\tan \theta)}\)

A solid sphere of radius \(R\) is rolling on a horizontal plank with velocity \(V^{'}\). The plank itself is moving with velocity \(V_{}\) on the ground. What is the relationship between \(V^{'}\) and \(V\)?

When an object is rolling on a plane without slipping, the point of contact of the object with the plane does not move.

A rolling object's velocity \(V\) is directly related to its angular velocity \(\omega\).

Mathematically it is expressed as \({V}=\omega {R}\)

Where \(R=\) the object's radius and \(V=\) its linear velocity.


In pure rolling motion, the point of contact (bottom-most point) moves with velocity

\(V_{p}=\text { velocity of point } P=V\)

\(\Rightarrow V_{p}=\left(V^{\prime}-\omega R\right)=V\)

\(\Rightarrow V^{\prime}=V_{p}+\omega R\)

Where, \({V}^{\prime}=\) linear velocity of solid sphere

\({V}=\) velocity of planck
The linear momentum of the body is increased by \(30 \%\). Calculate the percentile change in the kinetic energy of the particle if the mass of the particle is constant.

The increase in linear momentum \(=30 \%\), \({K}=\) Initial kinetic energy

\({K}_{1}\) = The new kinetic energy after the change in the momentum

\({P}_{1}=\) The new momentum after the increase, and \({P}=\) initial momentum

The percentage increase in the momentum can be represented as

\( {P}_{1}=1.30 {P}\)

The corresponding increase in the kinetic en energy is given by,

\( KE_{1}=\frac{P_{1}^{2}}{2 M}=\frac{(1.30 P)^{2}}{2 M}=\frac{1.69 P^{2}}{2 M}=1.69 \frac{P^{2}}{2 M}\)

\(\Rightarrow KE_{1}=1.69 K E\)

The change in Kinetic energy is given by

\( \Delta{KE}={KE}_{1}-{KE}=1.69 {KE}-{KE}=0.69 {KE}\)

\(\Rightarrow\) Change in percentile \(=0.69 \times 100=69 \%\)
A body of mass \(1 {~kg}\) undergoes a change in velocity from \(2 {~m} / {s}\) to \(3 {~m} / {s}\) in \(2\) seconds, when a force is applied to it. The rate of change of linear momentum will be:

When the velocity of a body changes, the linear momentum also changes.

The rate of change of linear momentum is proportional to the applied force (Newton's second law of motion).

So, the rate of change of linear momentum is given as:

\(\frac{d p}{d t}=\frac{m\left(v_{2}-v_{1}\right)}{t}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d p}{d t}=\frac{1 \times(3-2)}{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d p}{d t}=0.5 N\)
The moment of inertia of a thin rod of mass \({M}\) and length \({L}\) about an axis through one of its ends and perpendicular to length is:

The moment of inertia of the rod when the axis is perpendicular to it and passes through its center \((I_{c})=\frac{M L^{2}}{12}\)

The distance between the center of mass \({I}_{{c}}\) and one end of a rod \(({x})=\frac{L} { 2}\) 

Use parallel axis theorem:

The moment of inertia about one end \(({I})={I}_{{c}}+{M} {x}^{2}\)

\(=\frac{{ML}^{2}} { 12}+{M}(\frac{L} {2})^{2}\)

\(=\frac{{ML}^{{2 }}}{3}\)
A sphere of mass \(5 {~kg}\) and radius \(30 {~cm}\) is rolling down an inclined plane of inclination \(45^{\circ}\). Calculate acceleration with which the sphere rolls down?

Considering a spherical body of mass \({M}\) and radius \({R}\) rolling down a plane inclined at an angle \(\theta\) to the horizontal, as shown in the figure having acceleration with which the spherical rolls down.


\({a}=\frac{2}{3} g \sin \theta\)

Where \({g}\) is the acceleration due to gravity, \(\sin \theta\) is the angle by which the body rolls down

Where \({M}=5 {~kg}, {R}=30{~cm}=0.3 {~m}\)

By putting the value we get:

\(a=\frac{2}{3} g \sin \theta \)

\(a=\frac{2}{3} \times 9.8 \times(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}})=4.62 {~m/s}^{2}\)

When a system is taken from state '\(x\)' to state '\(y\)' then \(30 \mathrm{~kJ}\) of heat flows into the system and the system does \(10 \mathrm{~kJ}\) of work. When the system is returned from state '\(\mathrm{y}\)' to state '\(\mathrm{x}\)' along another path, then work done on the system is \(8 \mathrm{~kJ}\). What is the amount of heat liberated?

We know that:

First law of thermodynamics for a process is given by

\(\delta Q=d U+\delta W\)

When the system is taken from state \({x}\) to state \({y}\) then:

\(\mathrm{Q}_{x-y}=+30 \mathrm{k} J, W_{x-y}=+10 \mathrm{k} \mathrm{J}\)

Then from first law of thermodynamics,

\(\delta Q=d U+\delta W \)

\(+30 k J=d u_{x-y}+10 \mathrm{~kJ} \)

\( d u_{x-y}=30-10 \)

\( d u_{x-y}=20 \mathrm{k} J\)

Now,

When the system is taken from state \({y}\) to state \({x}\) then:

\(W_{y-x}=-8 \mathrm{~kJ} \text { and }\)

\(\mathrm{d} U_{y-\mathrm{x}}=-20 \mathrm{~kJ} [\because\left(U_{y}-U_{x}\right)=-\left(U_{x}-U_{y}\right)]\)

Then from first law of thermodynamics

\(\delta Q=d U+\delta W \)

\(Q_{y-x}=-20-8 \)

\(\therefore Q_{y \cdot x}=-28 \mathrm{~kJ}\)

Here negative sign indicates that heat is being liberated.

A reversible Carnot engine works between the temperature of \(1000 \mathrm{~K}\) and \(300 \mathrm{~K}\). Heat supplied to the engine by \(1000 \mathrm{~K}\) reservoir is \(250 \mathrm{~kJ}\). Now the work obtained by this engine is supplied to the refrigerator which works between the temperature limits of \(270 \mathrm{~K}\) and \(300 \mathrm{~K}\). The COP of the refrigerator is \(50 \%\) of the COP of the reversible refrigerator then find out the heat rejected by the refrigerator (in \(\mathrm{kJ}\) ) at the reservoir which is at \(300 \mathrm{~K}\).

Given:

For engine

\(\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{L}}=300 \mathrm{~K} \text { and } \mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}}=1000 \mathrm{~K} \text { and } \mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{s}}=250 \mathrm{~kJ}\)

Now, The efficiency of the Carnot engine is given by:

\(\eta=1-\frac{T_{L}}{T_{H}}\)

Where \(\boldsymbol{T}_{\mathrm{L}}=\) temperature of the low-temperature reservoir and \(\boldsymbol{T}_{\mathrm{H}}=\) temperature of the high-temperature reservoir.

\(=1-\frac{300}{1000}=0.7\)

Again, The efficiency of an engine is given by:

\(\eta=\frac{W_{n e t}}{Q_{\text {supplied }}} \)

Where \(\mathrm{W}_{\text {net }}=\) Net work done by the engine and \(\mathrm{Q}_{\text {supplied }}=\) Heat supplied to the engine.

\(\therefore \mathrm{W}_{\text {net }}=\eta \times \mathrm{Q}_{\text {supplied }}\)

\(=0.7 \times 250 \)

\(\therefore \mathrm{W}_{\text {net }}=176 \mathrm{k} \mathrm{J}\)

Now this work is supplied to the refrigerator,

For refrigerator,

\(\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{L}}=270 \mathrm{~K} \text { and } \mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}}=300 \mathrm{~K}\)

COP of a reversible refrigerator is given by:

\(C O P=\frac{T_{L}}{T_{L}-T_{H}}\)

Where, \(T_{L}=\) Temperature of the evaporator and \(T_{H}=\) Temperature at which heat is rejected.

\(\therefore C O P=\frac{270}{300-270}=9\)

Now,

The actual COP is \(60 \%\) of the ideal COP

\(\therefore \text { COP }_{\text {actual }}=9 \times 0.5=4.5\)

Again,

\(C O P=\frac{\text { Desired Effect }}{\text { Work Input }} \)

\(\Rightarrow 4.5=\frac{\text { Desired } E f \text { fect }}{175 \mathrm{~kJ}} \)

\( \text { Desired effect }=4.5 \times 175 \)

\(=787.6 \mathrm{~kJ}\)

\(\) The heat rejected to the \(300 \mathrm{~K}\) reservoir by the refrigerator \(=787.6+176=962.6 \mathrm{~kJ}\)

In an adiabatic chamber, two blocks of the same mass and heat capacity comes in contact with each other. One is at a temperature of \(500 \mathrm{~K}\) and the other one is at \(1000 \mathrm{~K}\). Find the value of entropy change if the system attains thermodynamic equilibrium. Take (mass \(\left.=2 \mathrm{~kg}, \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{p}}=1 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \mathrm{K}\right)\)

Given:

\(T_1=500k,~T_2=1000k,~T_f=750k\)

\(m=2,~C_p=1\)

According to the question:

Heat lost by block \(1=\) Heat gained by block 2

\(\therefore m C_{p}\left(T_{1}-T_{f}\right)=m C_{p}\left(T_{f}-T_{2}\right) \)

\(\therefore T_{f}=\frac{T_{1}+T_{2}}{2}=750 K\)

Now,

\((\Delta s)_{\text {total }}=(\Delta s)_{\text {block } 1}+(\Delta s)_{\text {block } 2} \)

\(=m C_{p} \ln \left(\frac{T_{f}}{T_{1}}\right)+m C_{p} \ln \left(\frac{T_{f}}{T_{2}}\right) \)

\(=m C_{p}\left(\ln \left(\frac{T_{f}}{T_{1}}\right)+\ln \left(\frac{T_{f}}{T_{2}}\right)\right) \)

Put all given values in above equation:

\((\Delta s)_{\text {total }}=2 \times 1 \times\left[\ln \left(\frac{750^{2}}{500 \times 1000}\right)\right] \)

\((\Delta s)_{\text {total }}=0.2355 ~{k J}/{K}\)

A gas is compressed at constant pressure from \(0.3 \mathrm{~m}^{3}\) and \(0.1 \mathrm{MPa}\) to \(0.15 \mathrm{~m}^{3}\). There is a transfer of heat of \(35 \mathrm{~kJ}\) from gas during the process. Find the change in internal energy during the process.

Given:

\(\mathrm{P}=0.1 \mathrm{MPa}=0.1 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~Pa}\)

\(\mathrm{~V}_{1}=0.3 \mathrm{~m}^{3}\)

\(\mathrm{~V}_{2}=0.15 \mathrm{~m}^{3}\)

\(\mathrm{dQ}=-35 \mathrm{~kJ}\)

Work done in constant pressure process is given by:

\(\mathrm{dW}=\mathrm{P}\left(\mathrm{V}_{2}-\mathrm{V}_{1}\right)\) [where \(P\) is pressure, \(V_{2}\) is final volume and \(V_{1}\) is initial volume]

Put given values in above formula:

\(\mathrm{dW}=0.1 \times 10^{6}(0.15-0.3) \)

\(=-0.015 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~J}\)

\(=-15 \mathrm{~kJ}\)

Now, According to first law of thermodynamics:

\(\mathrm{dQ}=\mathrm{dU}+\mathrm{dW} \)

\(-35=\mathrm{d} \mathrm{U}-15\)

\(\mathrm{d} \mathrm{U}=-20kJ\)
Figure shows the \(P-V\) diagram of an ideal gas. The work done by the gas in the process ABCDA is:

Given:

Work done = Area of Parallelogram ABCDA

Area of parallelogram \(=\frac{1 }{ 2} \times(\) Sum of parallel sides \() \times\) height

Work done \(=\) Area of Parallelogram \(A B C D A=\frac{1 }{ 2} \times(A B+C D) \times B C\)

\(\frac{ 1 }{ 2} \times(V+2 V) \times P\)

\(=1.5 P V\)
Two blocks that are at different temperatures are brought into contact with each other and allowed to reach a final state of thermal equilibrium. The final temperature attained is specified by:

Two blocks that are at different temperatures are brought into contact with each other and allowed to reach a final state of thermal equilibrium. The final temperature attained is specified by 'Zeroth law of thermodynamics'.

There are 4 laws to thermodynamics:

1. Zeroth law of thermodynamics:

2. First law of thermodynamics

3. Second law of thermodynamics

4. Third law of Thermodynamics

Zeroth law of thermodynamics:

If two thermodynamic systems are each in thermal equilibrium with a third, then they are in thermal equilibrium with each other.
Since no heat interaction takes place in a adiabatic process, hence temperature of a ideal gas will going to be:

Since no heat interaction takes place in a adiabatic process, hence temperature of a ideal gas will going to be 'Can increase or decrease'.

Adiabatic process:

  • When a thermodynamic system undergoes a change in such a way that no exchange of heat takes place between Systems and surroundings, the process is known as an adiabatic process.
  • In adiabatic process system goes to a change is state by work interaction only.

From first law of thermodynamics,

\(\delta{ Q}=\Delta U+\delta W\)

For an adiabatic process \(\delta Q=0\)

i.e., \(0=\Delta U+\delta \mathrm{W}\)

\(\Rightarrow \delta W=-\Delta U \)

\(\Delta U=m C_{\mathrm{v}}(\Delta T) \)

\(\Rightarrow \delta{ W}=-m C_{v}(\Delta T)\)

So if work is added to the system i.e., \({\delta} \mathrm{W}=-\mathrm{ve}\), then \((\Delta \mathrm{T})=+\) ve, temperature of the gas will increase.

and work is done by the system i.e. \(\delta W=-\)ve then \((\Delta T)=-\) ve, temperature of the gas will decrease.
A reversible heat engine operates using three thermal reservoirs with temperatures as shown in following figure. If \(Q_{1}=Q_{2}\), the efficiency of engine is:
For a heat engine operating on a Carnot cycle, the work output is \(\frac{1}{ 4}{\text {th }}\) of the heat rejected to the sink. The thermal efficiency of the engine would be:

Given:

\(\mathrm{W}_{\text {net }}=\frac{Q_{2}}{4}\)

The fraction of heat input \(\left(Q_{1}\right)\) that is converted to net-work output \(\left(W_{n e t}\right)\) is a measure of performance of a heat engine and is called thermal efficiency.

\(\mathrm{Q}_{1}\) is the heat taken from the source \(\left(T_{H}\right)\) and \(Q_{2}\) is the heat transferred to the sink \(\left(T_{L}\right)\) ). Net-work done by the engine, \(\mathrm{W}_{\text {net }}=\mathrm{Q}_{1}-\mathrm{Q}_{2}\).

\(\frac{Q_{2}}{4}=Q_{1}-Q_{2}\)

\(\frac{Q_{2}}{Q_{1}}=\frac{4}{5}\)

\(\eta_{\text {thermal }}=\frac{\text { Work output }}{\text { Heat input }}=\frac{W}{Q_{1}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{Q_{1}-Q_{2}}{Q_{1}}=1-\frac{Q_{2}}{Q_{1}}\)

\(\eta_{\text {thermal }}=1-\frac{4}{5}\)

\(\Rightarrow 20 \%\)
Change in entropy (in \(\mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} . \mathrm{K})\) in a reversible adiabatic process is:

Change in entropy (in \(\mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} . \mathrm{K})\) in a reversible adiabatic process is 0.

Adiabatic process:

When a thermodynamic system undergoes a change in such a way that no exchange of heat takes place between the system and surrounding, the process is known as an adiabatic process.

\(\Delta \mathrm{Q}=0\)

The change in entropy is,

\(\Delta S=\frac{\Delta Q}{T}\)

Where, \(\Delta \mathrm{Q}=\) Heat exchange, \(\mathrm{T}=\) temperature of the system

For a reversible adiabatic process

\(d S=\frac{d Q}{T}=0\)
For which of the following situations, zeroth law of thermodynamics will not be applicable?
\(50 \mathrm{cc}\) of water at \(25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) is mixed with \(150 \mathrm{cc}\) of water at \(25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)
\(500 \mathrm{cc}\) of milk at \(15^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) is mixed with \(100 \mathrm{cc}\) of water at \(15^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)
