In \(10 \mathrm{cc}\) of water at \(20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) is mixed with \(10 \mathrm{cc}\) of sulphuric acid at \(20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) there is no thermal equilibrium between the components of the mixture because there will be a spontaneous ionic reaction which highly exothermic in nature.
The direction of a natural process is dictated by the __________ law of thermodynamics.

The direction of a natural process is dictated by the second law of thermodynamics.

Second law of thermodynamics - The entropy of an isolated system not in equilibrium will tend to increase over time, approaching a maximum value at equilibrium.

\(\Delta \mathrm{S}=\frac{\Delta \mathrm{Q} }{ \mathrm{T}} \)

\(\Delta \mathrm{S}_{\text {Total }}=\Delta \mathrm{S}_{\text {system }}+\Delta \mathrm{S}_{\text {surrounding }}\)

The second law of thermodynamics introduces the concept of entropy. The second law of thermodynamics deals with the direction taken by natural or spontaneous processes.
If hot water and cold water are mixed, then the entropy of the system will:
May increase/Decrease depending on initial temperature of hot water and cold water

If hot water and cold water are mixed, then the entropy of the system will Increase.

Entropy

It can be defined as a measure of the degree of molecular disorder/randomness existing in the system.

We know that,

\(\rho=\frac{P}{R T}\)

Density and Temperature are inversely related at constant Pressure.

Initially, hot water has a lower density and cold water has a higher density. Due to the density differences, hot water floats above cold water. Due to temperature differences heat transfer takes place within the mixture from hot water to cold water. Molecules of hot water start moving downwards and molecules of cold water start moving upwards as they lose and gain heat respectively. Thus, the mixture comes in motion as a result of buoyancy force originated from variation in fluid density.
It is impossible for a heat engine to produce net work in a complete cycle if it exchanges heat only with bodies at a single fixed temperature
It is impossible to construct a device which, operating in a cycle will produce no effect other than the transfer of heat from a cooler to hotter body

Kelvin-Plank statement: It is impossible for a heat engine to produce net work in a complete cycle if it exchanges heat only with bodies at a single fixed temperature.


For heat engine to operate, the working fluid has to exchange heat with a heat sink as well with the heat source.

If \(\mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{L}}=0\), then \(\eta=1-\frac{Q_{L}}{Q_{H}}=1\)

Therefore, the second law claims that no heat engine can be \(100 \%\) efficient. So, \(\mathrm{W}=\mathrm{Q}\) (is impossible)

There will be always some heat loss to the surrounding. \(\mathrm{W}=\mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{H}}-\mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{L}}\) (is possible)

As \(\left(Q_{H}-Q_{L}\right) \geq 0\) so \(W_{\text {cycle }} \geq 0\)
The weight of the diesel engine, compared to similar petrol engine is

The weight of the diesel engine is 2 to 3 times greater compared to similar petrol engine.

  • Diesel engines or (C.I.Engines) are heavier than petrol engines (S.I.Engines) because of the large compression ratio in the case of diesel engines. The reason for the large compression ratio being compression ignition i.e. in diesel engines, ignition takes place by the high temperature developed by the compression since there is no spark plug like in petrol or S.I.Engine.
  • Also, the flashpoint at which fuel gets ignited is more in the case of diesel engines so the compression ratio needs to be sufficient enough to produce that self-ignition temperature of the fuel for the combustion to take place.
  • Compression ratio (r): It is defined as the ratio of volume before compression to the volume after compression.

\(r=\frac{\left(V_{c}+V_{s}\right)}{V_{c}}\)

where \(\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{C}}\) and \(\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{S}}\) are clearance and swept volume respectively.

  • The value of the compression ratio for diesel engines lies between \(16: 1\) to \(22: 1\) whereas for the petrol engine it lies between \(6: 1\) to \(12: 1\).
A system is in thermal equilibrium with its environment if:
The temperatures of the system and environment are equal
The pressures in the system and environment are equal
The chemical potentials of the system and environment are equal

A system is in thermal equilibrium with its environment if the temperatures of the system and environment are equal.

Thermal equilibrium: It is a condition/state in which all parts of a system are at the same temperature. Two objects are in thermal equilibrium if they are in close contact and there is no net flow of thermal energy between them. 

For this condition to happen, the two closely contact objects must be at the same temperature. From the definition of thermal equilibrium, a system is in thermal equilibrium with its environment if the temperatures of the system and environment are equal.
If __________ between the system and the surroundings, the process is adiabatic.
heat flows but matter does not flow
matter flows but heat does not flow

If neither heat nor matter flows between the system and the surroundings, the process is adiabatic.

Adiabatic wall:

An adiabatic wall is an insulating wall that does not allow the flow of heat energy between the system and its surroundings or between two systems.

It is found that \(\left(N_{A}, V_{A}\right)\) will be in equilibrium with any other possible pair of values. \(\left(\mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{B}}, \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{B}}\right)\)

Diathermic wall:

A diathermic wall is a conducting wall, which allows heat energy to flow between the system and its surroundings or between two systems.

From above it is clear that if neither heat nor matter flows between the system and the surroundings, then the process is adiabatic.

Thermocouple, thermometer is based on Seebeck effect.

Seebeck effect

  • If two different metal wires are joined to form a closed circuit and two junctions are kept at different temperatures, a small emf is set up in the circuit in a definite direction. This effect is called a thermoelectric effect or Seebeck effect.
  • The emf developed in the circuit is called thermal emf or Seeback emf and the current called thermoelectric current.
Two bodies in contact are said to be in thermal equilibrium when:
No work is done by the bodies
When one of the body has a higher temperature
No heat flow occurs between the two bodies

Two bodies in contact are said to be in thermal equilibrium when no heat flow occurs between the two bodies.

Thermal equilibrium: Thermal equilibrium is a condition when two surfaces in physical contact have no exchange of heat between them.

  • Heat flows from an object of higher temperature to an object of lower temperature.
  • So, temperature governs the direction of heat flow.
  • When no heat flow occurs, it is to be inferred that the surfaces are at the same temperature.
300 gm of water at \(25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) is added to \(100 \mathrm{gm}\) of ice at \(0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\). Final temperature of the mixture is:

Given:

\(m_1=300 ~gm\), \(T_0=25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\), \(m_2=100 \mathrm{gm}\)

We know that latent heat of fusion of ice is \(79.7 \mathrm{Cal}\) per gram.

Let final temperature be \(\mathrm{T}\).

Then

\(\mathrm{m}_{1} \mathrm{~S} \Delta \mathrm{T}=\mathrm{m}_{2} \mathrm{~L} \)

Put the given values in above formula:

\(300 \times 1 \times(25-\mathrm{T})=100 \times 75 \)

\(\Rightarrow (25-\mathrm{T})=\frac{100 \times 75}{300} \)

\(\Rightarrow 25-\mathrm{T}=25 \)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{~T}=0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

After that total energy left \(=4.7 \times 100=470\)

Total mass of water \(=400 \mathrm{~g}\)

Amount of water again converted into ice

\(m=\frac{\text{ total energy left }}{\text{ latent heat of fusion of ice}}\)

\(\mathrm{m}=\frac{470}{79.7} \)

\(\mathrm{~m}=5.9 \mathrm{~g}\)

Thus whole mass is converted into water at \(0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\), and about \(5.9\) gwater is again converted into ice whose temperature is also \(0{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\).

After achieving the temperature of \(0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\), latent heat of fusion is required firstly for conversion of water into ice then further lowering of temperature is possible. So the final temperature will be \(0{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\).
Which of the following equation correctly represents work done by adiabatic expansion?

\(\frac{P_{1} V_{1}-P_{2} V_{2}}{\gamma-1}\) correctly represents work done by adiabatic expansion.

An adiabatic process is a thermodynamic process in which there is no exchange of heat between the system and surrounding, that is, the heat remains constant.

For an adiabatic process, We follow the Poisson's Law.

\(P V^{\gamma}=\) constant

\(T V^{\gamma-1}=\) constant

\(\frac{T^{\gamma}}{P^{\gamma-1}}=\) constant

For adiabatic process, \(\Delta Q=0\)

Now according to the first law of thermodynamics \(\Delta Q=\Delta W+\Delta U\), so if \(\Delta Q=0\).

This means that for adiabatic process the system performs Work \((\Delta \mathrm{W})\) based on the bases of internal energy since \(\Delta \mathrm{W}=-\Delta \mathrm{U}\) from the above equation

For the adiabatic process, the work done by the system is given as

\(W=\frac{P_{1} V_{1}-P_{2} V_{2}}{\gamma-1}=\frac{n R\left(T_{1}-T_{2}\right)}{\gamma-1}\)

Here \(\mathrm{R}\) is gas constant, \(\mathrm{n}\) is molar mass and \(\gamma=\frac{C_{P}}{C_{V}}\), where \(\mathrm{Cp}\) and \(\mathrm{Cv}\) are specific heat at constant pressure and volume. (as we had discussed in topic Heat and temperature)

Here,

\(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{2}=\) initial and final pressure

\(\mathrm{V}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{V}_{2}=\) initial and final volume,

\(\gamma =\) adiabatic index

\(W=\) work done
During an adiabatic expansion of 2 mole of gas, the change in internal energy was, found \(-50 \mathrm{~J}\). The work done during the process:

Given:

\(\Delta \mathrm{U}=-50 \mathrm{~J}\) and \(\mathrm{Q}=0 \mathrm{~J}\) (Adiabatic process)

The first law of thermodynamics: This law states that the total heat given or taken out of the system will always be equal to the work done and change in the internal energy of the system.

\(\Rightarrow \Delta Q=\Delta W+\Delta U\)

The work done during the process

\(\Rightarrow 0=\Delta W-50 \)

\(\Rightarrow \Delta W=50 J\)

Here work done is positive so we can conclude that the system is doing work on the surrounding.
A monoatomic gas is suddenly compressed to \(\left(\frac{1}{8}\right)^{t h}\) of its initial volume adiabatically. The ratio of its final pressure to the initial pressure is:

Given:

\(\gamma=\frac{5 }{ 3}\) and \(V_{2}=\frac{V_{1} }{ 8}\)

For an ideal gas undergoing an adiabatic process at room temperature,

\( P_{1} V_{1}^{\gamma}=P_{2} V_{2}^{\gamma} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{P_{1}}{P_{2}}=\left(\frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}}\right)^{\gamma} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{P_{1}}{P_{2}}=\left(\frac{1V_{1}}{8V_{1}}\right)^{\frac{5}{3}}\)

\(=1:32\)
For a gas of non rigid diatomic molecules, the value of \(\gamma=\frac{C_{P}}{C_{V}}\) is:

Given:

Diatomic molecule, so \(\mathrm{f}=5\)

Molecular specific heat at constant volume \(\mathbf{C}_{\mathrm{v}}=\mathrm{f} \frac{R}{ 2}\)

Molecular specific heat at constant volume \(C_{p}=C_{v}+R=(2+f) \frac{R }{ 2}\)

where \(\mathrm{f}\) is the degree of freedom.

For monoatomic molecule \(\mathrm{f}=3\)

For diatomic molecule \(f=5\)

\(\gamma=\frac{C_{P}}{C_{V}}=\frac{7}{5}\)
A Carnot heat pump works between \(27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) and \(327^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\). What will be its COP?

Given:

\(T_{1}=327^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=600 \mathrm{~K}, \mathrm{~T}_{2}=27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=300 \)

COP of Carnot Heat pump \(=\frac{T_{1}}{T_{1}-T_{2}}\)

\( C O P=\frac{600}{600-300}=\frac{600}{300}=2\)

COP of Carnot heat pump \(=2\)
In a vapor compression refrigeration system, the sub-cooling of refrigerant in the condenser results in:
Decrease in the size of the condenser
Increase in the size of the evaporator
Increase in the size of the compressor

• In a vapor compression refrigeration system, the sub-cooling of refrigerant in the condenser results in increase in the size of the evaporator.
  • Sub cooling is the process of cooling the liquid refrigerant below the condensing temperature for a given pressure.
  • The difference between the saturation temperature and the temperature of sub cooled liquid at that pressure is called Degree of sub cooling.
  • Subcooling is beneficial as it increases the refrigeration effect by reducing the, throttling loss at no additional specific work input.
  • Also, subcooling ensures that only liquid enters the throttling device leading to its efficient operation.
Domestic refrigerator working on vapour compression cycle uses the following type of expansion device.

Domestic refrigerator working on vapour compression cycle uses the 'Capillary tube' of the expansion device.

  • The capillary tube is one of the most commonly used throttling devices in domestic refrigerators, deep freezers, water coolers, and air conditioners. Capillary tubes have very small internal diameters and very long lengths and they are coiled to several turns so that they would occupy less space (compact). They are easy to manufacture, cheap and compact.
  • When the refrigerant leaves the condenser and enters the capillary tube, its high pressure drops down suddenly due to the very small diameter of the capillary tube and the long length gives more friction head and drops pressure further.
  • The decrease in pressure leads to the cooling of the refrigerant and the low-temperature refrigerant can take the heat from the room.
Which is the desirable physical property of refrigerant?

'Low boiling point' is the desirable physical property of refrigerant.

The characteristics of a good refrigerant should have the following properties.

1. Low boiling point

2. High latent heat value

3. Low freezing point

4. Non-flammable and non-toxic

5. High di-electric strength

6. Not affected by moisture

7. Non-corrosive to metals

8. Mixes well with compressor oil
In a refrigeration system, why are expansion devices located closer to the evaporator?
To avoid the flow of the refrigerant
To ease the flow of the refrigerant

In a refrigeration system, 'To minimise the heat gain', expansion devices are located closer to the evaporator.

Refrigeration system:

  • A refrigeration system contains a minimum of four key components i.e., compressor, condenser, expansion valve, and evaporator.
  • The purpose of the expansion device is to rapidly reduce the pressure of the refrigerant in the refrigeration cycle.
  • This allows the refrigerant to rapidly cool before entering the evaporator.
  • An expansion device is located closer to the evaporator in order to minimize heat gain.
  • The most common devices are capillary tubes, thermal expansion valves, electronic expansion valves.
If the volume of most air with \(50 \% \mathrm{RH}\) is isothermally reduced to half its original volume then relative humidity of moist air becomes:

Given:

\(\phi_{1}=50 \%\)

Relative humidity is given by

\(\phi=\frac{P_{v}}{P_{v s}}\)

where \(\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{v}}\) is pressure of water vapour and \(\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{vs}}\) is pressure of water vapour at saturation point.

So,

\(\frac{\phi_{2}}{\phi_{1}}=\frac{P_{v_{2}}}{P_{v 1}} \)

Since volume is reduced to half so the pressure has become twice.

\(P_{v _2}=2 P_{v _1} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\phi_{2}}{\phi_{1}}=2 \)

\(\Rightarrow \phi_{2}=2 \phi_{1} \)

Put the value of \(\phi_{1}\) in above equation:

\(\phi_{2}=2 \times 50\%\)

\(= 100 \%\)
A ball is thrown with an initial velocity of \(20 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\). Find the time of flight by the body. (Take \(\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\) )
4s
5s
6s
7s

Let a be the acceleration of the ball, u be the initial velocity, v be the final velocity and t be the time taken.

Initially the ball was moving in the upward direction. At maximum height, velocity will be zero, (v = 0). At that point, the ball will change the direction of motion and fall downwards.

Since, acceleration due to gravity is opposite to motion, a=−10ms−2

From first equation of motion, v=u+a

⇒0=20+(−10)t

⇒t=2s

Thus, the ball takes 2s to reach the top. Similarly to reach the ground from the top point is also 2s. Thus total time or time of flight is 4s.
In the first 10s of a body’s motion, the velocity changes from 10 m/s to 20m/s. During the next 30s the velocity changes from 20m/s to 50m/s. What is the average acceleration in m/s2?

Average acceleration is the total change in velocity by the total change in time. Here, total change in velocity = 50-10 = 40m/s, and total change in time = 30+10 =40s. Therefore, average acceleration = 1 m/s2.
A coin and a bag full of rocks are thrown in a gravity less environment with the same initial speed. Which one of the following statements is true about the situation?
Both will travel with the same speed
Under the application of no external force like gravity, the acceleration is zero. Hence, both the objects will move with the same initial velocity.
How many variables are required to fully describe a system in uniformly accelerated motion?

To fully characterize the system in uniformly accelerated motion, at least three variables are required. They may include displacement, time, initial velocity, final velocity, and constant acceleration.

This can also be determined using the equations of motion. They are:

\(v = u + at\)

\(s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^2\)

\(2as = v^2 – u^2\)

To determine the value of any variable, at least three known quantities must be used.
A car moves for 60s covering a distance of 3600 m with zero initial velocity. What is the acceleration in m/s2?

Here we will use the second equation of motion, 
\(s = ut +( \frac{1}{2})at^2\).
Here, u = 0, s = 3600, t = 60s.
\(3600 = 0 +( \frac{1}{2})a60^2\).
a = 2 m/s2.
Displacement \(y\) (in \(m\) ) of a body varies with time \(t\) (in sec) as: \(y=\frac{-2}{3} t^2+16 t+2\). How long does the body take to come to rest?

The displacement is given as: \(\mathrm{y}=\mathrm{ut}+\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{at}^2\) where, \(u\) is the initial velocity and \(a\) is the acceleration. Comparing with given expression: \(\mathrm{y}=16 \mathrm{t}-2 \mathrm{t}^2 / 3+2, \mathrm{u}=16 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}, \mathrm{a}=-\frac{4}{3} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\)

As, \(v=u+\) at, where \(v\) is final velocity.

Taking \({v}={0}\), the time taken for body to come to rest.

\(0=16-\frac{4}{3} t\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{t}=12 \mathrm{sec}\)
At t = 0, an arrow is fired vertically upwards with a speed of 98 ms-1. A second arrow is fired vertically upwards with the same speed at t = 5 s. Then,
the two arrows will be at the same height above the ground at t = 10 s
the two arrows will reach back to their starting points at t = 20 s and t = 30 s
the ratio of the speed of the first arrow and that of the second arrow at t = 20 s will be 2 : 1
the maximum height attained by either arrow will be 980 m

\(\begin{aligned} & \mathrm{s}=\mathrm{ut}+\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{at}^2 \\ & \Rightarrow 98 \mathrm{t}-\frac{1}{2} 9.8 \mathrm{t}^2=98(\mathrm{t}-5)-\frac{1}{2} 9.8(\mathrm{t}-5)^2 \\ & \Rightarrow \mathrm{t}^2-(\mathrm{t}-5)^2-100=0 \\ & \Rightarrow 10 \mathrm{t}=125 \\ & \mathrm{t}=12.5 \mathrm{~s}\end{aligned}\)

Now, total time for first arrow will be

\(\mathrm{s}=\mathrm{ut}+\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{at}^2\)

\(\Rightarrow 98 \mathrm{t}-\frac{1}{2} 9.8 \mathrm{t}^2=0\)

\(t(t-20)=0\)

\(\mathrm{t}_1=20 \mathrm{~s}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{t}_2=25 \mathrm{~s}\)

(Now at \(\mathrm{t}=20 \mathrm{~s}\) )

\(\mathrm{v}=\mathrm{u}+\text { at }\)

\(\mathrm{v}_1=98 \quad \mathrm{v}_2=98 \frac{1}{2}\)

\(\frac{\mathrm{v}_1}{\mathrm{v}_2}=\frac{2}{1}\)

\(\mathrm{v}_1: \mathrm{v}_2=2: 1\)

The acceleration of a particle starting from rest varies with time according to the relation a = kt + c, where k and c are constants of motion.

    The velocity v of the particle after a time t will be:

We know that \(\mathrm{a}=\frac{\mathrm{dv}}{\mathrm{dt}}\) so change in velocity in time interval \(\mathrm{dt}\) will be \(d v=a d t\)

Integrating it for \(\int_{v=0}^{\mathrm{V}} \mathrm{dv}=\int_{\mathrm{t}=0}^{\mathrm{t}}(\mathrm{kt}+\mathrm{c}) \mathrm{dt}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\mathrm{k} \mathrm{t}^2+\mathrm{ct}\right)\)

Two trains each of length \(50 \mathrm{~m}\) are running with constant speeds on parallel tracks while moving in the same direction one overtakes the other in \({4 0}\) seconds and while moving in the opposite direction one crosses the other in 20 seconds. The speeds of trains will be:

Let the speeds be \(v_1\) and \(v_2\).

While moving in same direction, relative speed \(=\mathrm{v}_1-\mathrm{v}_2\), and in opposite direction, it is \(\mathrm{v}_1+\mathrm{v}_2\).

Thus, we have Dist \({ }_{\text {rel }}=v_{\text {rel }} \times t\)

\(2 \times 50=40\left(v_1-v_2\right)=20\left(v_1+v_2\right)\)

Or, \(\mathrm{v}_1-\mathrm{v}_2=2.5\) and \(\mathrm{v}_1+\mathrm{v}_2=5\)

Solving them, we have, \(\mathrm{v}_1=3.75\) and \(\mathrm{v}_2=1.25\)

The driver of train A moving at a speed of \(30 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) sights another train \(B\) moving on the same track at a speed of \(10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) in the same direction. He immediately applies brakes and achieves a uniform retardation of \(2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) To avoid collision, the minimum distance between the trains must be:

Given,

\(V_A=30 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) (velocity of \(A\) )

\(V_B=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) (velocity of \(B\) )

Retardation of \(A=2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

To, find the minimum distance to avoid the collision.

So, To avoid a collision, as both are on the same track and in the same direction then the final velocity of \(A\) must be equal to the velocity of B. i.e \(V_f\) of \(A=V_B\)

As we know,

\(=v_f^2=u_i^2-2 a S\)

\(\therefore(10)^2=(30)^2-2 \times(2) \times S\)

\(\therefore 4 S=900-100\)

\(S=\frac{800}{4}=200 \mathrm{~m}\)

So, the Minimum distance should be \(200 \mathrm{~m}\).
A body moving in a straight line with constant acceleration of 10 ms-2 covers a distance of 40 m in the 4th second. How much distance will it cover in the 6th second?

Given,

\(a=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\)

As we know,

Distance covered by the body in the \(n^{\text {th }}\) second is given by

\(S_n=u+\frac{1}{2} a(2 n-1)\)

According to question,

\(\mathrm{S}_4=u+\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{a}(8-1)\)

\(=\mathrm{u}+\frac{7}{2} \mathrm{a}\)

Or, \(40=u+\frac{7}{2} \times 10\)

Or, \(u=40-35\)

\(=5 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\)

Distance covered by the body in \(6^{\text {th }}\) second

\(\mathrm{s}_6=5+\frac{1}{2} \times 10 \times(12-1)\)

Which gives \(s_6=60 \mathrm{~m}\).

A body moving in a straight line with an initial velocity of \(5 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) and a constant acceleration covers a distance of \(30 \mathrm{~m}\) in the \(3^{\text {rd }}\) second. How much distance will it cover in the next 2 seconds?

Distance covered in \(\mathrm{n}^{\text {th }}\) second is given by,

\(S_n=u+a\left(n-\frac{1}{2}\right)\)

Distance covered in \(3^{\text {rd }}\) second is given by,

\(30=5+a\left(3-\frac{1}{2}\right)\)

\(\Rightarrow a=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\)

Distance covered in \(4^{\text {th }}\) second is given by,

\(\mathrm{S}_4=5+10\left(4-\frac{1}{2}\right)=40 \mathrm{~m}\)

and \(S_5=5+10\left(5-\frac{1}{2}\right)=50 \mathrm{~m}\)

\(\therefore\) Distance covered in next two seconds

\(=\mathrm{S}_4+\mathrm{S}_5=40+50=90 \mathrm{~m}\)

A body, starting from rest and moving with a constant acceleration, covers a distance \(S_1\) in the \(4^{\text {th }}\) second and a distance \(S_2\) in the \(6^{\text {th }}\) second. The ratio \(\frac{S_1}{S_2}\) is:

According to the 4th equation of motion,

Distance covered by a particle in nth second is given by,

\(S(n+h)=u+\left(\frac{a}{2}\right) \times(2 n-1)\)

In the first case, nth is the \(4^{t h}\) second.

\(\mathrm{S}_1\left(4^{\text {th }}\right)=0+\left(\frac{a}{2}\right) \times(2 \times 4-1)=\frac{7 a}{2}\)

In the second case, nth is the 6th second,

\(\mathrm{S}_2\left(6^{\text {th }}\right)=0+\left(\frac{a}{2}\right) \times(2 \times 6-1)=\frac{11 a}{2}\)

Ratio of \(\frac{\mathrm{S}_1}{\mathrm{~S}_2}=\frac{7 a}{2} \times \frac{2}{11 a}=\frac{7}{11}\)

Or \(\mathrm{S}_1: \mathrm{S}_ 2=7: 11\)

A car starting from rest is accelerated at a constant rate \(\alpha\) until it attains a speed \(v\). It is then retarded at a constant rate \(\beta\) until it comes to rest. The average speed of the car for its entire journey is:

The distance \(s_1\) covered by the car during the time it is accelerated is given by \(2 a s_1=v^2\), which gives \(s_1=\frac{v^2}{2 a}\). The distance \(s_2\) covered during the time the car is decelerated is similarly given by \(s_2=\frac{\mathrm{v}^2}{2 \beta}\)

Therefore, the total distance covered is

\(s=s_1+s_2=\frac{v^2}{2}\left(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{\beta}\right) \ldots \ldots \text { (i) }\)

If \(t_1\) is the time of acceleration and \(t_2\) that of deceleration, then \(v=a t_1=\beta t_2 \Rightarrow \mathrm{t}_1=\frac{\mathrm{v}}{a}\) and \(\mathrm{t}_2=\frac{\mathrm{v}}{\beta}\)

Therefore, the total time taken is

\(t=t_1+t_2=v\left(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{\beta}\right) \ldots \ldots\)(ii)

From (i) and (ii), the average speed of the car is given by,

\(\frac{\text { Total distance }}{\text { Total time }} \frac{s}{t}=\frac{v}{2}\)
The displacement of a body from a reference point is given by \(\sqrt{x}=2 t+3\), where \(\mathrm{x}\) is in metres and \(t\) is in seconds. This shows that the body is:

From the given equation we can find the time of the motion

\(t=x^{\frac{1}{2}}+3\)

Since the displacement is the function of time and distance.,

We can write it as,

\(f(t)=(t-3)^2\)

On differentiating the above equation we get the velocity,

\(\mathrm{v}(\mathrm{t})=2(\mathrm{t}-3)\)

At origin the velocity is zero so the time after the initiation of motion the velocity becomes zero at \(3\) sec So the displacement is zero and the body is at rest.
The displacement of a body from a reference point is given by: \(\sqrt{x}=2 t+3\), where \({x}\) is in metres and \({t}\) is in seconds. What is the initial velocity of the body?

Given,

Taking square both side

\(\begin{aligned} & (\sqrt{x})^2=(2 t+3)^2 \\ & x=(2 t+3)^2 \\ & x=(2 t)^2+(3)^2+2(2 t)(3) \\ & x=4 t^2+12 t+9\end{aligned}\)

Taking derivative both sides relative to " \(t\) "

\(\begin{aligned} & \frac{d x}{d t}=2(4 t)+12 \\ & \frac{d x}{d t}=8 t+12\end{aligned}\)

We know that, \(v=d x / d t\)

So, \(v=8 t+12\)

at \(t=0\)

\(v=8(0)+12\)

\(v=12 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

So, the initial velocity is \(12 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\).

The distance \(x\) covered by a body moving in a straight line in time \(t\) is given by:

\(x^2=t^2+2 t+3\)

The acceleration of the body will vary as:

Displacement \((\mathrm{x})\) of a particle is related to time \((\mathrm{t})\) as \(x=a t+b t^2-c t^3\), where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are constants of motion. The velocity of the particle, when its acceleration is zero, is given by:

The displacement of a particle is given by:

\(x=a t+b t^2-c t^3\)

Where,

\(a, b\) and \(c\) are constants of motion,

Velocity,

\(\begin{aligned} & v=\frac{d x}{d t} \\ & v=\frac{d\left(a t+b t^2-c t^3\right)}{d t} \\ & v=a+2 b t-3 c t^2\end{aligned}\)

Acceleration,

\(\begin{aligned} & a=\frac{d v}{d t} \\ & a=\frac{d\left(a+2 b t-3 c t^2\right)}{d t} \\ & a=2 b-6 c t\end{aligned}\)

When \(a\) is 0 ,

\(\begin{aligned} & 2 b-6 c t=0 \\ & t=\frac{b}{3 c}\end{aligned}\)

Put the value of \(t\) in equation (1) as:

\(\begin{aligned} & v=a+\frac{2 b^2}{3 c} \\ & v=a+\frac{b^2}{3 c}\end{aligned}\)

So, the velocity of the particle when its acceleration is zero is given by \(a+\frac{b^2}{3 c}\).
The position of an object moving in a straight line can be specified with reference to:

To describe motion along a straight line, we can choose an axis, say X-axis, so that it coincides with the path of the object. We then measure the position of the object with reference to a conveniently chosen origin, say O, Positions to the right of O are taken as positive and to the left of O, as negative.
Position to the right of the origin is taken as positive and to the left as negative.
Position to the left of the origin is taken as positive and to the right as negative.

To describe motion along a straight line, we can choose an axis, say X-axis, so that it coincides with the path of the object. We then measure the position of the object with reference to a conveniently chosen origin, say O,  Positions to the right of O are taken as positive and to the left of O, as negative.
the distance from origin to maximum point
the total length of the path traversed by an object
the distance from origin to minimum point

The path length is defined as the total length of the path traversed by an object.

Unlike displacement, which is the total distance an object travels from a starting point, the path length is the total distance travelled, regardless of where it travelled.

Total time of travel \(=40 \mathrm{~min}\)

Speed \(=5 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}\) and \(7.5 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}\)

From home to market, the time taken is time = \(\frac{d}{v}=\frac{2.5}{5}=\frac{1}{2} h r=30 \mathrm{~min}\).

He returns back with speed of \(7.5 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}\) in rest of time, that is, 10 minutes.

He returns back with speed of 7.5 km/h in rest of time, that is, 10 minutes.

\(\begin{aligned} & \text { Distance }=7.5 \times \frac{10}{60}=1.25 \mathrm{~km} \\ & \text { Average speed }=\frac{\text { Total distance }}{\text { Total time }} \\ & =\frac{(2.5+1.25) \mathrm{km}}{\left(\frac{49}{60} \mathrm{hr}\right.} \\ & =\frac{45}{8}=5.625 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr} .\end{aligned}\)

The acceleration a (in \(\mathrm{ms}^{-2}\) ) of a body, starting from rest varies with time \(t\) (in s) following the equation \(a=3 t+4\). The velocity of the body at time \(t=2 \mathrm{~s}\) will be:

Given, \(a=3 t+4\)

\(\Rightarrow \quad \frac{d v}{d t}=3 t+4\)

\(\therefore \quad \int_0^v d v=\int_0^t(3 t+4) d t\)

\(\Rightarrow \quad v=\frac{3}{2} t^2+4 t\)

At \(t=2 \mathrm{~s}\)

\(v=\frac{3}{2}(2)^2+4(2)=14 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\)
The position \(x\) of a particle varies with time \(t\) as \(x=a t^2-b t^3\). For what value of \(t\) acceleration is zero?

Given, position \(x=a t^2-b t^3\).

Velocity is

\(v=\frac{d x}{d t}=\frac{d\left(a t^2-b t^3\right)}{d t}=2 a t-3 b t^2\)

Acceleration is

\(\begin{aligned} & \vec{a}=\frac{\overrightarrow{d\left(2 a t-3 b t^2\right)}}{d t} \\ & \Longrightarrow a=\frac{d\left(2 a t-3 b t^2\right)}{d t}=2 a-6 b t\end{aligned}\)

If acceleration is zero, then

\(\begin{aligned} & 2 a-6 b t=0 \\ & \Rightarrow 6 b t=2 a \\ & \Rightarrow t=\frac{a}{3 b}\end{aligned}\)

There is a simple pendulum hanging from the ceiling of a lift. When the lift is standstill, the time period of the pendulum is \(T\). If the resultant acceleration becomes \(\frac{g }{ 4}\), then the new time period of the pendulum is:

We know that:

Time period of a simple pendulum of length \(l\), is given by:

\(T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{l}{g}} \ldots(\mathrm{i})\)

Where, \(g\) is acceleration due to gravity.

When \(g^{\prime}=\frac{g}{4}\)

New, time period is

\(T^{\prime}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{l}{\frac{g}{ 4}}} \ldots(\mathrm{ii})\)

Dividing Eq. (ii) by Eq. (i), we get

\(\frac{T^{\prime}}{T}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{\frac{g}{ 4}}}=2\)

\(\Rightarrow T^{\prime}=2 T\)

Therefore, new time period becomes twice of the original value.

Two waves represented by \(\mathrm{y}_{1}=10 \sin (2000 \pi \mathrm{t})\) and \(\mathrm{y}_{2}=10 \sin (2000 \pi \mathrm{t}+\frac{\pi }{ 2})\) are superimposed at any point at a particular instant. The resultant amplitude is:

Given:

\(\mathrm{y}_{1}=10 \sin (2000 \pi \mathrm{t})\).....(1)

\(\mathrm{y}_{2}=10 \sin (2000 \pi \mathrm{t+\frac{\pi}{2}})\).....(2)

\(\mathrm{y}=a \sin((\omega t+ \phi)\).....(3)

On comparing (1) and (2) with (3).

\(\mathrm{a}_{1}=10, \mathrm{a}_{2}=10\) and \(\phi= \frac{\pi}{2}=90^{\circ}\)

The resultant amplitude A of two waves of amplitudes \(a_{1}\) and \(a_{2}\) at a phase difference of \(\phi\) is:

\(A=\left(a_{1}^{2}+\right.\) \(\left.\mathrm{a}_{2}^{2}+2 \mathrm{a}_{1} \mathrm{a}_{2} \cos \phi\right)^{\frac{1 }{ 2}}\).....(4)

Substituting all given value in (4).

\(A=\left(10^{2}+\right.\) \(\left.10^{2}+2 ×10 × 10 \cos 90^{\circ}\right)^{\frac{1 }{ 2}}\)

\(=10\sqrt{2}\)

\(=14.1\)

A piece of wood has dimensions \(a, b\) \(c\) Its relative density is \(d\). It is floating in water such that the side \(c\) is vertical. It is now pushed down gently and released. The time period is:

We know that:

Time period of SHM of small vertical oscillations in a liquid is given by:

\(T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{l}{g}}\), where \(l\) is the length of cube/cylinder dipped in the water.

So according to law of floatation,

weight of the cube \(=\) weight of the water displaced

\(a b c \times d \times g=b c l \times l \times g\)

\(\Rightarrow l=d a\)

\(\Rightarrow T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{d a}{g}}\)
A particle starts S.H.M. from the mean position. Its amplitude is \(A\) and time period is \(T\). At the time when its speed is half of the maximum speed, its displacement \(y\) is:

The relation between angular frequency and displacement is given as

\(\mathrm{v}=\omega \sqrt{\mathrm{A}^{2}-\mathrm{x}^{2}}\).....(1)

Suppose

\(\mathrm{x}=\mathrm{A} \sin \omega \mathrm{t}\)

On differentiating the above equation w.r.t. time we get

\(\frac{\mathrm{dx}}{\mathrm{dt}}=\mathrm{A} \omega \cos \omega \mathrm{t}\)

The maximum value of velocity will be \(v_{\max}=A \omega\)

The displacement for the time when speed is half the maximum is given as

\(\mathrm{v}=\frac{\mathrm{A} \omega}{2} \)

\(\mathrm{~A}^{2} \omega^{2}=4 \omega\left(\mathrm{A}^{2}-\mathrm{x}^{2}\right)\)

By substituting the value in \((1)\) we get the displacement as:

\(\mathrm{x}=\frac{\mathrm{A} \sqrt{3}}{2}\)

Two particles execute SHM of the same amplitude and frequency along the same straight line. If they pass one another when going in opposite directions, each time their displacement is half their amplitude, the phase difference between them is:

We know that:The equation for SHM is:

\(\mathrm{y}=\operatorname{Asin}(\omega+\phi)\)

As the displacement is half of the amplitudes so:\(\left(\mathrm{y}=\frac{\mathrm{A}}{2}\right)\)

or \(\frac{\mathrm{A}}{2}=\mathrm{A} \sin (\omega \mathrm{t}+\)\(\phi) \)

\((\omega t+\phi)=\frac{1}{2} \)

\(\therefore \omega \mathrm{t}+\phi=30^{\circ} \text { or } 150^{\circ}\)

Since the two particles are going in opposite directions, the phase of one is \(30^{\circ}\) and that of the other \(150^{\circ} .\)

So the phase difference between the two particles:

\(=150^{\circ}-30^{\circ}\)

\(=120^{\circ}\)

\(=\frac{2 \pi}{3}\)

A simple pendulum has a length \(l\) and the mass of the bob is \(m\). The bob is given a charge \(q\) coulomb. The pendulum is suspended between the vertical plates of a charged parallel plate capacitor. If \(E\) is the electric field strength between the plates, the time period of the pendulum is given by

Time period of simple pendulum in air

\(T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{l}{g}}\)

 

When it is suspended between vertical plates of a charged parallel plate capacitor, then acceleration due to electric field,

\(a=\frac{q E}{m}\)

This acceleration is acting horizontally and acceleration due to gravity is acting vertically. So, effective acceleration

\(g^{\prime}=\sqrt{g^{2}+a^{2}}\)

\(=\sqrt{g^{2}+\left(\frac{q E}{m}\right)^{2}}\)

Thus, \(T^{\prime}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{l}{\sqrt{g^{2}+\left(\frac{q E}{m}\right)^{2}}}}\)

The time period of a simple pendulum is \(T\). When the length is increased by \(10 \mathrm{~cm}\), its period is \(T_{1}\). When the length is decreased by \(10 \mathrm{~cm}\), its period is \(T_{2}\). Then, relation between \(\mathrm{T}, \mathrm{T}_{1}\) and \( \mathrm{~T}_{2}\) is:

The time period for simple harmonic motion is given by:

\(T=\frac{2 \pi}{\omega}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{l}{g}} \Rightarrow T \propto \sqrt{l} \)

\(l \propto T^2 \)

\((l+10) \propto T_1^2 \)

\((l-10) \propto T_2^2\)

We can compare that \((I+10)+(I-10)=2 l\)

\(2 T^2=T_1^2+T_2^2\)

A clock that keeps correct time at \(25^{\circ} C\) has a pendulum made of metal. The temperature falls to \(0^{\circ} C .\) If the coefficient of linear expansion of the metal is \(1.9 \times 10^{-5}\) per \(^{\circ} C\), then find the number of seconds the clock gains per day.

Given that a clock keeps correct time at \(25^{\circ} C\). So initial temperature \(\theta_{1}=25^{\circ} C\).

The pendulum is made of metal. We need to find the number of seconds gained per day by the clock when the temperature falls to \(0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\).

So final temperature \(\theta_{2}=0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

So, \(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}=25-0=25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

The relation connecting gain or loss in time and the change in temperature is given as:

\(\Delta t=\frac{1}{2} \times \alpha \times \Delta \theta \times t\).....(1)

Where \(\Delta t\) is the gain or loss in time.

\(\alpha\) is the coefficient of linear expansion.

\(\Delta \theta\) is the change in temperature and \(\mathrm{t}\) is the time.

\(\alpha\) is given as \(1.9 \times 10^{-5}\) per \({ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

We need to calculate the gain of time per day.

Thus \(t=24 \times 60 \times 60 \mathrm{~s}\)

Change in temperature is \(\Delta \theta=25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

Now substitute all the given values in the equation (1).

\(\Delta t=\frac{1}{2} \times 1 \cdot 9 \times 10^{-5} \times 25 \times 24 \times 60 \times 60 \)

\(\therefore \Delta t=20.520\) seconds / day
A girl swings on cradle in a sitting position. If she stands what happens to the time period of girl and cradle?

A girl swings on the cradle in a sitting position. If she stands then the time period of girl and cradle will decrease.

The time period, \(T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{l}{g}}\) where \({l}\) is the length of simple pendulum. On standing the effective length of the pendulum measured from the point of suspension decreases. So, the time period of the cradle decreases.

A simple spring has length \(l\) and force constant \(k\). It is cut into two spring of length \(l_{1}\) and \( l_{2}\) such that \(l_{1=} n l_{2}[n\) is an integer\(]\) the force constant of the spring of length \(l_{2}\) is:

It is given that spring has a length of \(l\).

The force constant of the spring is \(k\).

Then the spring is cut into two springs of length \(l_{1}\) and \(l_{2}\)

Relationship between \(l_{1}\) and \(l_{2}\) is given as

\(l_{1}=n l_{2}\)

Where, \(\mathrm{n}\) is an integer.

We need to find the force constant of the spring of length \(l_{1}\)

We know that the length of a spring and force constant are inversely related.

So, we can write it as

\(l \propto \frac{1}{k} \)

\(\Rightarrow l=\frac{c}{k}.....(1)\)

Where \(c\) is a constant of proportionality.

Let \(k_{1}\) be the force constant of spring with length \(l_{1}\) and \(k_{2}\) be the force constant of spring with length \(l_{2}\).

Then we can write

\( l_{1}=\frac{c}{k_{1}}.....(2)\)

And

\( l_{2}=\frac{c}{k_{2}}.....(3)\)

We know that the total length \(l\) is the sum of \(l_{1}\) and \(l_{2}\).

\( l=l_{1}+l_{2} \)

\(\Rightarrow l=l_{1}+\frac{l_{1}}{n} \)

\(\because l_{1}=n l_{2}\)

Substituting the value of \(l\) and \(l_{1}\) from equation (1) and (2), we get

\(\frac{c}{k}=\frac{c}{k_{1}}+\frac{c}{n k_{1}}\)

Now let us solve for \(k_{1}\).

\( \frac{1}{k}=\frac{1}{k_{1}}+\frac{1}{n k_{1}} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{k}=\frac{n+1}{n k_{1}} \)

\(\Rightarrow k_{1}=\frac{n+1}{n} k\)

This is the value of the spring constant of length \(l_{1}\).

A point particle of mass \(0.1 \mathrm{~kg}\) is executing SHM of amplitude \(0.1 \mathrm{~m}\). When the particle passes through the mean position, its \(\mathrm{KE}\) is \(8 \times 10^{-3} J\). The equation of motion of this particle, if its initial phase of oscillation is \(45^{\circ}\).

Given:

A point particle of mass \(0.1 \mathrm{~kg}\) is executing SHM of amplitude \(0.1 \mathrm{~m}\).

\(\mathrm{KE}\) = \(8 \times 10^{-3} J\)

Initial phase of oscillation = \(45^{\circ}=\frac{\pi}{4}\)

We know that:

\(\mathrm{KE}\) at mean position \(=\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} a^{2}\)

According to the question:

 \(\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} a^{2}=8 \times 10^{-3}\).....(1)

Put all the given values in (1).

\(\omega=\left(\frac{2 \times 8 \times 10^{-3}}{m a^{2}}\right)^{1 / 2}\)

\(=\left[\frac{2 \times 8 \times 10^{-3}}{0.1 \times(0.1)^{2}}\right]^{1 / 2}\)

\(=4\)

Equation of SHM is,\(y=a \sin (\omega t+\theta)\)

\(=0.1 \sin \left(4 t+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\)
A body of mass \(0.01 \mathrm{~kg}\) executes SHM about \(x=0\), under the influence of force shown in the figure the period of the SHM is:

From the given graph, slope of F-x graph is k.

 \(k=\frac{F}{x}\)

\(=\frac{80}{0.2}\)

\(=400 \mathrm{Nm}^{-1}\)

\(m=0.01\)

\(T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{m}{k}}\)

\(=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{0.01}{400}}\)

\(=\frac{\pi}{100}\)

\(=0.03142 \mathrm{~s}\)

The length of an elastic string is a metre when the longitudinal tension is \(4 \mathrm{~N}\) and \(\mathrm{b}\) metre when the longitudinal tension is \(5 \mathrm{~N}\). The length of the string in the metre when longitudinal tension is \(9 \mathrm{~N}\) is:

Let \(\mathrm{L}\) is the original length of the wire and \(\mathrm{k}\) is force constant of wire.

Final length \(=\) initial length \(+\) elongation

\(\mathrm{L}^{\prime}=\mathrm{L}+\frac{\mathrm{F}}{\mathrm{k}}\)

For first condition \(\mathrm{a}=\mathrm{L}+\frac{4}{\mathrm{k}} \quad\).....(i)

For second condition \(\mathrm{b}=\mathrm{L}+\frac{5}{\mathrm{k}}\)......(ii)

By solving Eqs. (i) and (ii), we get

\(\mathrm{L}=5 \mathrm{a}-4 \mathrm{~b} \text { and } \mathrm{k}=\frac{1}{\mathrm{~b}-\mathrm{a}}\)

Now, when the longitudinal tension is \(9 \mathrm{~N}\). length of the string.

\(=\mathrm{L}+\frac{9}{\mathrm{k}}=5 \mathrm{a}-4 \mathrm{b}+9(\mathrm{~b}-\mathrm{a}) \)

\(=5 \mathrm{~b}-4 \mathrm{a}\)
The variation of potential energy of harmonic oscillator is as shown in figure. The spring constant is:

We know that:

The Potential energy of the harmonic oscillator is given by \(\mathrm{PE}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{kx}^{2}\)

However, there can be initial potential energy, which is a constant.

Thus, the generalized potential energy of a harmonic oscillator is:

\(\mathrm{PE}=\mathrm{V}_{0}+\) \(\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{kx}^{2}\).....(1)

From the given figure,

At \(\mathrm{x}=0, \mathrm{PE}=0.01 \mathrm{~J}=V_{0}\)

At \(\mathrm{x}=0.02 \mathrm{~m}, \mathrm{PE}=0.04 \mathrm{~J}\)

Substituting in the general form of Potential energy, we have \(\mathrm{V}_{0}=0.01 \mathrm{~J}\)

Put all the given values in (1).

Thus, \(0.01+\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{k}(0.02)^{2}=0.04 \)

\( \mathrm{k}=150 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}\)
If a simple pendulum is taken to a place where g decreases by \(2 \%\) then the time period:

We know that time period of simple pendulum is:

\(T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{l}{g}}\)

Taking log in both sides:

\(\log T=\log 2+\log \pi+\frac{1}{2} \log l-\frac{1}{2} \log g\)

Differentiating it we get

\(\frac{d T}{T}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{d l}{l}-\frac{1}{2} \frac{d g}{g}=-\frac{1}{2} \frac{d g}{g}(\therefore l\) is constant \()\)

\(\%\) change in time period

\(=\frac{d T}{T} \times 100=-\frac{1}{2} \frac{d g}{g} \times 100 \)

\(=-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{-2}{100}\right) \times 100\)

\(=1 \% \) (increase)

Displacement of a particle executing simple harmonic motion is represented by \(\mathrm{Y}=\) \(0.08 \sin \left(3 \pi \mathrm{t}+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\) metre. Then calculate:

(a) Time period.

(b) Initial phase

(c) Displacement from mean position at \(\mathrm{t}=\frac{7}{36}\) sec.

Given:

Displacement equation is given as \(\mathrm{Y}=0.08 \sin \left(3 \pi \mathrm{t}+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\)

On comparing with \(\mathrm{Y}=\mathrm{A} \sin (\mathrm{\omega t}+\pi)\)

We get, \(\mathrm{\omega}=3 \pi\) and \(\phi=\frac{\pi}{4}\)

Time period \(\mathrm{T}=\frac{2 \pi}{\mathrm{\omega}}\)

\(=\frac{2 \pi}{3 \pi}\)

\(=\frac{2}{3} \mathrm{~s}\)

Initial phase \(\phi=\frac{\pi}{4}\)

\(\text { At } \mathrm{t}=\frac{7}{36} \mathrm{~s} \)

\( \mathrm{Y}=0.08 \sin \left(3 \pi \times \frac{7}{36}+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\)

\(=0.08 \sin (\frac{5 \pi }{ 6}) \)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{Y}=0.08 \times 0.5\)

\(=0.04 \mathrm{~m}\)
Two waves of wavelength \(2 \mathrm{~m}\) and \(2.02 \mathrm{~m}\) respectively moving with the same velocity superimpose to produce 2 beats per sec. The velocity of the wave is:

When two waves having small differences in their frequency superpose each other there is a periodic variation in the intensity of the sound i.e., the amplitude of the sound rises and falls. The number of such variations heard per second is called the beat frequency.

The beat frequency is given by,

\(v_{B E A T}=v_{1}-v_{2} \ldots(1)\), where \(\mathrm{v}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{v}_{2}\) are the frequency of the two waves that are superposed.

In the question, the wavelengths of the two superposing waves are given to us. Let us write the wavelength in terms of their frequency using equation (1).

\(v_{1}=\frac{\mathrm{V}}{2 }\) and \(v_{2}=\frac{\mathrm{V}}{2.02 \mathrm{}}\) the velocity of both the waves i.e., \(\mathrm{V}\) is the same since they are moving together.

Now let us substitute the frequency of both the waves in equation 2 to determine the velocity of the wave.

\(v_{B E A T}=v_{1}-v_{2} \)

\(\Rightarrow v_{B E A T}=\frac{V}{2}-\frac{V}{2.02} \)

\(\Rightarrow 2=\operatorname{V}\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{2.02}\right) \)

\(\Rightarrow 2=V(0.5-0.495049) \)

\(\Rightarrow V=\frac{2}{4.95 \times 10^{-3}}\)

\(=0.404 \times 10^{3}\)

\(=404 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)
Intensity at any point due to interference of two waves will be maximum, when path difference at that point is:

We know the relation

\(I \propto\left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+2 a_{1} a_{2} \cos \phi\right)\)

For intentisity to be maximum

\(\cos \phi=+1 \)

\(\text { or } \quad \phi=2 n \pi \)

\(\text { where } \quad n=0,1,2, \ldots \ldots . . \)

\(\therefore \text { Path difference } \)\((\Delta)=\frac{\lambda}{2 \pi} \times \text { phase difference }( \phi)\)

\(\Delta=\frac{\lambda}{2 \pi} \times \phi \)

Put all the given values in above equation:

\(\Delta=\frac{\lambda}{2 \pi} \times 2 n \pi\)

\(\Delta=n \lambda\)

Two sine waves having unequal amplitudes and a phase difference of \(\frac{\pi}{2}\), are travelling along \(\mathrm{x}\) and \(\mathrm{y}\)-axis respectively. When they superimpose, the resultant wave will be:

The equation of the two superimposing waves can be give by:

\(\mathrm{y}_{1}=\mathrm{a}_{1} \sin (\omega \mathrm{t})\)

\(\mathrm{y}_{2}=\mathrm{a}_{2} \sin (\omega \mathrm{t}+ \frac{\pi}{ 2})=\mathrm{a}_{2} \cos (\omega \mathrm{t})\)

So, the equation of the resultant wave is:

\(\mathrm{y}=\mathrm{y}_{1}+\mathrm{y}_{2}\)

\(=\mathrm{a}_{1} \sin (\omega \mathrm{t})+\mathrm{a}_{2} \cos (\omega \mathrm{t})\).....(1)

Assuming \(\omega t=\phi, \mathrm{a}_{1}=\mathrm{a} \cos (\phi)\) and \(\mathrm{a}_{2}=\mathrm{a} \sin (\phi)\),

Put all values in (1).

\(\mathrm{a}_{1}^{2}+\mathrm{a}_{2}^{2}=\mathrm{a}^{2}\left(\sin ^{2}(\phi)+\cos ^{2}(\phi)\right)=\mathrm{a}^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{a}=\sqrt{\mathrm{a}_{1}^{2}+\mathrm{a}_{2}^{2}}\)

Three waves of equal frequency having amplitudes \(10 \mu \mathrm{m}, 4 \mu \mathrm{m}, 7 \mu \mathrm{m}\) arrive at a given point with successive phase difference of \(\frac{\pi}{2}\) radian. The amplitude of the resultant wave is:

The amplitude of the waves are:

\(\begin{aligned} a_{1} &=10 \mathrm{\mu m} \\ a_{2} &=4 \mathrm{\mu m} \\ a_{3} &=7 \mathrm{\mu m} \end{aligned}\)

The Phose differenve between \(1^{st}\) and \(2^{\text {nd }}\) wave is \(\frac{\pi}{2}\) and that between \(2^{\text {nd }}\) and \(3^{rd}\) wave is \(\frac{\pi}{2}\). Therefore , phose differente between \(1^{st}\) ond \(3^{r d}\) is \(\pi\). Combining \(1^{st}\) and \(3^{rd}\) their resultant amplitude is given by:

\(A_{1}^{2} =a_{1}^{2}+a_{3}^{2}+2 a_{1} a_{3} \cos \phi \)

\(\text { or } A_{1} =\sqrt{10^{2}+7^{2}+2 \times 10 \times 7 \cos \phi} \)

\(=\sqrt{100+49-140} \)

\(=\sqrt{9}\)

\(=3 \mathrm{\mu m}\)

Now Combining this with \(2^{\text {nd }}\) wave we have, the resultant amplitude:

\(A^{2} =A_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+2 A_{1} a_{2} \cos \frac{\pi}{ 2} \)

\( = \sqrt{3^{2}+4^{2}+2 \times 3 \times 4 \cos 90^{\circ}}\)

\(=\sqrt{9+16} \)

\(=5 ~\mu m\)

It is found that when two waves of same intensity from two coherent sources superimpose at a certain point, then the resultant intensity is equal to the intensity of any one wave. This means that the phase difference between the two waves at that point is:

The intensity of the resultant wave varies with amplitude of resultant wave as proportionally to square of amplitude. Intensity of resultant wave is defined as:

\(I=I_{1}+I_{2}+2 \sqrt{I_{1} I_{2}} \cos \delta\) (where \(\left.\delta=\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda}\right)\), \(\delta\) is the phase difference and \(\Delta x\) is the path difference between waves.

As given in the question the intensity of the waves are equal then \(I_{1}=I_{2}=I_{0}\). Substitute the value in the equation of intensity.

\(I=I_{0}+I_{0}+2 \sqrt{I_{0}^{2}} \cos \delta\)

\(\Rightarrow I=4 I_{0} \cos ^{2} \frac{\delta}{2}\)

Now it is given the resultant intensity is equal to the intensity of one wave only then \(I=I_{0}\), substituted in the above equation.

\(I_{0}=4 I_{0} \cos ^{2} \frac{\delta}{2}\)

\(\frac{1}{4}=\cos ^{2} \frac{\delta}{2} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2}=\cos \frac{\delta}{2} \)

\(\Rightarrow \cos \frac{\pi}{3}=\cos \frac{\delta}{2} \)

\(\therefore \delta=\frac{2 \pi}{3}\)

The phase difference between the waves is \(\frac{2 \pi}{3}\).
The apparent wavelength of light from a star moving away from the earth is \(0.02 \%\) more than the actual wavelength. What is the velocity of star?

Given:

\(C=3 \times 10^{8}  \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\)

\(\Delta \lambda=0.02 \%\)

We know that wavelength is expressed as \(\lambda\). So now the change in the wavelength is given as follows:

\(\frac{\Delta \lambda}{\lambda}=\frac{v}{C}\)

Here \(v\) is the velocity and \(C\) represents the speed of light. Hence we can express \(\mathrm{v}\) as:

\(v=\frac{\Delta \lambda}{\lambda} C\)

Now we have to put the values in the above expression, to get:

\(v=\frac{0.02}{100} \times 3 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~ms}^{-1} \)

\(v=60 \mathrm{kms}^{-1}\)

Closed O.P. and an open O.P. of same length produce 2 beats/sec. When they are set into vibrations together in fundamental mode. The length of open pipe is now halved and that of closed pipe is doubled. The number of beats produced will be:

For a closed organ pipe, the frequency of fundamental mode is \(\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{\mathrm{v}}{4 \mathrm{~L}_{\mathrm{c}}}\).

where \( v\) is velocity of sound in air and \(L_{c}\) is length of the closed pipe. For an open pipe, the frequency of fundamental mode is:

\(\mathrm{f}_{0}=\frac{\mathrm{v}}{2 \mathrm{~L}_{0}}\) Where \(\mathrm{L}_{0}\) is length of open pipe

\(\because \mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{c}}=\mathrm{L}_{0}\) (given)

\(\mathrm{f}_{0}=2 \mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{c}} \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots .(1)\)

\(\mathrm{f}_{0}-\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{c}}=2 \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots(2)\)

Solving (1) and (2) we get \(\mathrm{f}_{0}=4,\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{c}}=2\)

When length of open pipe is halved, its frequency of fundamental mode is:

\(\mathrm{f}_{0}^{\prime}=\frac{\mathrm{v}}{2\left(\frac{\mathrm{L}_{0}}{2}\right)}=2 \mathrm{f}_{0}\)

\(=2 \times 4=8\)

When Length of closed pipe is doubled, its frequency

\(\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{c}}^{\prime}=\frac{\mathrm{v}}{4\left(2 \mathrm{~L}_{\mathrm{c}}\right)}\)

\(=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{1}{2} \times 2 =1\)

Number of beats produced per second

\(=\mathrm{f}_{0}^{\prime}-\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{c}}^{\prime}\)

\(=8-1\)

\(=7\)

Two sources \(A\) and \(B\) are sounding notes of freq. \(680 \mathrm{~Hz}\). A listener moves from \(A\) to \(B\) with a constant velocity \(u\). If the speed of sound is \(340 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\), what must be the value of \(u\) so that he hears 10 beats \(/ \mathrm{s}\).

Given:

\(n=680\) m/s

Speed of sound (v) = \(340\) m/s

Listener go from \(\mathrm{A} \rightarrow \mathrm{B}\) with velocity (u) let the apparent frequency of sound from source A by listener:

\(\mathrm{n}^{\prime}=\mathrm{n} \frac{\mathrm{v}-\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{a}}}{\mathrm{v}+\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{s}}} \)

\(\mathrm{n}^{\prime}=680 \frac{340-\mathrm{u}}{340+0}\)

The apparent frequency of sound from source B by listener:

\(\mathrm{n} "=\mathrm{n} \frac{\mathrm{v}+\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{A}}}{\mathrm{v}-\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{S}}}\)

\(=680 \frac{340+\mathrm{u}}{340-0}\)

But listner hezear 10 beats prer second.

\(n^{''}-n^{'}=10\)

\(\Rightarrow 680 \frac{340+\mathrm{u}}{340}-680 \frac{340-\mathrm{u}}{340}=10\)

\(\Rightarrow 2340+\mathrm{u}-340+\mathrm{u}=10\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{u}=2.5 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\)
Which band does the \(3 \times 10^{9} \mathrm{~Hz}\) to \(3 \times 10^{10} \mathrm{~Hz}\) frequency range fall into?

High-frequency band have \(3 \times 10^{9} \mathrm{~Hz}\) to \(3 \times 10^{10} \mathrm{~Hz}\) frequency range.

The only spectrum of electromagnetic waves that we can see is the visible spectrum. It consists of 7 major colours pertaining to different wavelengths of visible light. But there are many more frequencies and wavelengths at which these waves operate like the radio waves, X-rays and gamma rays. The electromagnetic spectrum defines an order of the frequencies of these waves.

The classes of electromagnetic waves, as mentioned in the question, range as:

  • High frequency band: \(3 \mathrm{MHz}\) to \(30 \mathrm{MHz}\).
  • Super-high frequency band: \(3 \mathrm{GHz}\) to \(30 \mathrm{GHz}\)
  • Ultra-high frequency band: \(300 \mathrm{MHz}\) to \(3 \mathrm{GHz}\)
  • Very high frequency band: \(30 \mathrm{MHz}\) to \(300 \mathrm{MHz}\)
  • Here, \(1 \mathrm{MHz}=10^{6} \mathrm{Hz}\) and \( 1 \mathrm{GHz}=10^{9} \mathrm{~Hz}\)

The frequency range that we need to identify in our question is \(3 \mathrm{MHz}\) to \(30 \mathrm{MHz}\). From the above distinction we can see that this lies in the high frequency band. This also lies in the major class of radio waves.
\(\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{s}}\) is the velocity of sound in air and \(\mathrm{C}\) is the R.M.S. velocity, then:

The velocity of sound in air is given by:

\(\mathrm{C_s}=\sqrt{\frac{\gamma \mathrm{RT} }{ \mathrm{M}}}\).....(1)

where \(\gamma\) is the degree of freedom

\(\mathrm{T}=\text { temperature } \)

\(\mathrm{M}=\text { mass }\)

According to the kinetic theory of gases, The rms velocity of sound is given by:

\(\mathrm{C}=\sqrt{\frac{3 \mathrm{RT} }{ \mathrm{M}}}\).....(2)

Dividing equation (1) and (2) we get:

\(\frac{\mathrm{C_s} }{ \mathrm{C}}=\sqrt{\frac{\gamma}{ 3} }\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{C_s}=\mathrm{C} \sqrt{ \frac{\gamma }{ 3}}\)
The loudness and pitch of a sound depends on:

The loudness and pitch of a sound depends on intensity and frequency.

Loudness depends upon intensity and pitch is depends upon frequency higher the amplitude of the sounder. The louder the sound is and the higher the frequency of the sound waves, the higher the pitch of the sound will be. Amplitude is the maximum displacement of vibration so, large-amplitude produces loud sound as large vibration produces a louder sound.
The ratio of densities of nitrogen and oxygen is \(14: 16\). The temperature at which the speed of sound in nitrogen will be same at that in oxygen at \(55^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) is:

Given:

The ratio of densities of nitrogen and oxygen is \(14: 16\).

The temperature at which the speed of sound in nitrogen will be same at that in oxygen at \(55^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\).

\(T_{N}\) = Temperature of nitrogen

\(T_{o}\) = Temperature of oxygen

The velocity of the sound in nitrogen is given by:

\( \mathrm{v}=\sqrt{\frac{\gamma \mathrm{RT}}{\mathrm{M}}} \)

\(\Rightarrow  \frac{\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{N}}}{\mathrm{T}_{0}}=\frac{\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{N}}}{\mathrm{M}_{0}} \)

\(\Rightarrow  \frac{\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{N}}}{273+55}=\frac{14}{16}=\frac{7}{8}\)

Therefore, the temperature at which speed of nitrogen will be same as that of oxygen will be:

\(T_{N}=(273+55) \times \frac{7}{8}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{N}}=287 \mathrm{~K}=14^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

Velocity of sound waves in air is \(330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) for a particular sound wave in air, a path difference of \(40 \mathrm{~cm}\) is equivalent to phase difference of \(1.6 \pi\). The frequency of this wave will be:

Given:

Velocity of sound waves in air (V) = \(330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

Path difference = \(40 \mathrm{~cm}\)

Phase difference = \(1.6 \pi\)

Velocity of sound waves \(=330 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

\(\Delta \phi=\mathrm{K} \Delta \mathrm{x} \).....(1)

\(\Delta \phi=\text { phase difference } \)

\(\mathrm{K}=\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda}\)

\(\Delta \mathrm{x}=\) Path difference

Putting the values given in question in (1)

\(1.6 \pi=\frac{2 \pi}{\lambda}\left(\frac{40}{100}\right) \)

\(\Rightarrow \lambda=\frac{2 \pi}{1.6 \pi} \times \frac{40 \times 10}{100}\)

\(=\frac{1}{2}\)

Now,

\(\mathrm{V}=\mathrm{f} \lambda\)

\(330=\mathrm{f}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) \)

\(\mathrm{f}=660 \mathrm{~Hz}\)
Two waves of amplitude \(A_{1}\) and \(A_{2}\) respectively and equal frequency travels towards the same point. The amplitude of the resultant wave is:
\(\mathrm{A}_{1}+\mathrm{A}_{2}\)
\(\mathrm{A}_{1}-\mathrm{A}_{2}\)
Between \(\mathrm{A}_{1}+\mathrm{A}_{2}\) and \(\mathrm{A}_{1}-\mathrm{A}_{2}\)
Can not say

Two waves of amplitude \(A_{1}\) and \(A_{2}\) respectively and equal frequency travels towards the same point. The amplitude of the resultant wave is always between \(\mathrm{A}_{1}+\mathrm{A}_{2}\) and \(\mathrm{A}_{1}-\mathrm{A}_{2}\).

If the two waves are in constructive phase, then the resultant amplitude will be equal to

\(\mathrm{A}=\mathrm{A}_{1}+\mathrm{A}_{2} \) (maximum)

If they are in destructive phase, then

\(\mathrm{A}=\mathrm{A}_{1}-\mathrm{A}_{2}\)

Therefore the resultant amplitude will be always between \(\mathrm{A}_{1}+\mathrm{A}_{2} \) and \( \mathrm{~A}_{1}-\mathrm{A}_{2}\).

The resultant will depend on their phase difference.
Two gases, carbon monoxide \((\mathrm{CO})\) and nitrogen \(\left(\mathrm{N}_2\right)\) at the same temperature, have kinetic energies \(\mathrm{E}_1\) and \(\mathrm{E}_2\) respectively. Then:

The gases carbon monoxide \((\mathrm{CO})\) and nitrogen \(\left(\mathrm{N}_2\right)\) are diatomic, so both have equal kinetic energy at same temperature \(=\frac{5}{2} \mathrm{kT}\).

So, \(\mathrm{E}_1=\mathrm{E}_2\)

We know that,

\( \mathrm{PV}=\mathrm{nRT} \)

\(\mathrm{n}=\frac{\mathrm{PV}}{\mathrm{RT}} \)

\(\mathrm{PV}=\frac{\mathrm{N}}{\mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{A}}} \mathrm{RT}\)

where \(\mathrm{N}=\) no of molecules

\(\mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{A}}=\) Avogadro's number

\(\mathrm{PV}=\mathrm{NT} \frac{\mathrm{R}}{\mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{A}}}\)

But \(\frac{\mathrm{R}}{\mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{A}}}=\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{B}}\) is Boltzman constant

\(\therefore \mathrm{PV}=\mathrm{NK}_{\mathrm{B}} \mathrm{T}\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{N}=\frac{\mathrm{PV}}{\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{B}} \mathrm{T}}\)

So, \(\frac{\mathrm{PV}}{\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{B}} \mathrm{T}}\) represents the number of molecules.
Boyle’s law is applicable for which of the following process?

The relation between pressure and volume of gas is:

\(V \propto \frac{1}{P}\)

We can write this equation as \(P V=\mathrm{k} \cdots(1)\) 

where \(\mathrm{k}\) is constant.

For an ideal gas, \(P V=n R T \ldots\) (2) where \({n}\) is the amount of gas \({R}\) is the gas constant and \({T}\) is the temperature of the gas. Comparing equation 1 and 2 we can say that, \(n R T=k\) which is a constant.

So, Boyle's law is obeyed only when the temperature is constant and any thermodynamic process carried out at constant temperature is called isothermal process.
When an ideal gas is compressed adiabatically, its temperature rises the molecules on the average have more kinetic energy than before. The kinetic energy increases:
Because of collisions with moving parts of the wall only.
Because of collisions with the entire wall.
Because the molecules gets accelerated in their motion inside the volume.
Because of redistribution of energy amongst the molecules.

When an ideal gas is compressed adiabatically, its temperature rises the molecules on the average have more kinetic energy than before. The kinetic energy increases because of collisions with moving parts of the wall only.

The collisions between the ideal gas molecules and the moving part of the wall is elastic, therefore kinetic energy of the molecules colliding with it increases. Since the compression is done adiabatically, the work done on the gas increases kinetic energy of the molecules. Hence the molecules on average have more kinetic energy as compared to what they originally had.
Which of the following gases has maximum \(rms\) speed at a given temperature?

The \(rms\) speed of the gas is given by:

\(v_{r m s}=\sqrt{\frac{3 R T}{M}}\)

It means that the \(rms\) speed is inversely proportional to the molecular mass. Therefore, the gas with the lowest molecular mass will have maximum \(rms\) speed.

Hydrogen has the lowest molecular mass as compared to other gases. So, it will have maximum \(rms\) speed.
If the diatomic gas molecule is not rigid but has in addition a vibrational mode, then for this gas:

Given:

The diatomic gas molecule is not rigid -but has in addition a vibration mode.

Now degrees of freedom for the diatomic molecule becomes \(f=(3 N-K)+1\)

For diatomic molecule \(r=2\), Constraint \(k=0\) 1 is added because of a vibration mode.

so \(f=(3 \times 2-0)+1=6+1=7\)

Now, internal energy \(u=\frac{1}{2} f R T =\frac{7}{2} R T \quad[\because f=7]\)

Now, \(C_v=\left(\frac{d u}{d t}\right)_v=\frac{7}{2} R\)

we know, \(C_p-C_v=R \Rightarrow C_p=C_v+R=\frac{7}{2} R+R\)

\(\Rightarrow C_p=\frac{9}{2} R\)

so, \(\gamma=\frac{C_p}{C_V}=\frac{\frac{9}{2} R}{\frac{7}{2} R}=\frac{9}{7}\)

\( \Rightarrow \gamma =\frac{9}{7}\)

So all of the given options are true for the diatomic gas molecule.
For hydrogen gas \(C_P-C_V=a\) and for oxygen gas \(C_P-C_V=b\) then the relation between \(a\) and \(b\) is (where \(C_P\) and \(C_V\) are gram specific heats).

Relation between specific heats per unit mass:

\({C}_{{P}}-{C}_{{V}}={r}=\frac{{R}}{{M}}\)

Hence, \(r=\frac{R}{M}\)

Here, \({M}\) is molecular weight

Hydrogen:

\( C_P-C_V=a \)

\(\Rightarrow a=\frac{R}{M}=\frac{R}{2}\)

Oxygen:

\({C}_{{P}}-{C}_{{V}}={b} \)

\(\Rightarrow {b}=\frac{{R}}{{M}}=\frac{{R}}{32}\)

Ratio of \(a\) and \(b\):

\(\frac{{a}}{{b}}=\frac{\frac{R}{2}}{\frac{R}{32}}=16\)

Hence, \({a}=16 {b}\)
The mean square speed of the molecules of a gas at absolute temperature \(\mathrm T\) is proportional to:
The collisions of the molecules of an ideal gas are:

According to kinetic theory of gases the collision of molecule with the walls of container of an ideal gas are elastic. An elastic collision is a collision in which there is no net loss in kinetic energy in the system as a result of the collision. Both momentum and kinetic energy are conserved quantities in elastic collisions.
The average K.E. of a gas molecule at \(27^{\circ} {C}\) is \(6.21 \times 10^{-21}{~J}\). Its average K.E. at \(227^{\circ}\) will be:

We know that, 

\(E=\frac{1}{2} k T\)

\(\Rightarrow 6.21 \times 10^{-21}=\frac{1}{2} k \times(273+27)\)

\(\Rightarrow 6.21 \times 10^{-21}=150 {~K}\)

\(\Rightarrow k=\frac{6.21 \times 10^{-21}}{150}\) 

Therefore at \(227^{\circ}\), the value of \(E\) is

\(E=  \frac{1}{2} \times \frac{6.21 \times 10^{-21}}{150}(273+227) \)

\(E=10.35 \times 10^{-21} {~J}\)
Volume versus temperature graphs for a given mass of an ideal gas are shown in figure. At two different values of constant pressure. What can be inferred about relation between \(P_1\) and \(P_2\)?

As we know, ideal gas equation is given by

\({PV}={nRT}\cdots(i)\)

From the given equation, it shows \(V \propto T\) as \(n, R\) and \(P\) are constant.

So,

\(\frac{{V}}{{T}}=\) constant

Therefore, from (i) equation we have,

\(V=\frac{n R T}{P} \cdots(ii)\)

Differentiate equation (ii) with respect to \(T\).

\(\frac{d V}{d T}=\frac{n R}{P}\cdots(iii)\)

From equation (iii) it shows,

Greater the magnitude of \(\frac{d V}{d T}\), smaller will be the pressure values

Therefore,

\(\frac{d V}{d T} \propto \frac{1}{P}\)

So, the relation between \(P_1\) and \(P_2\) is \(P_1>P_2\).

Suppose a container is evacuated to leave just one molecule of a gas in it. Let \(v_{{av}}\) and \({v}_{{rms}}\) represent the average speed and the \(rms\) speed of the gas. The relation between the average speed and the \(rms\) speed of the gas is:

We know that,

\(v_{{av}}=\frac{v_1+v_2+v_3+\ldots+v_n}{n} \)

\(v_{{rms}}=\sqrt{\frac{v_1^2+v_2^2+v_3^2+\ldots+v_n^2}{n}}\)

Let us suppose \(v_0\) is the speed of one molecule

So, \(v_1=v_0\)

\(n=1\)

\(\therefore v_{{av }}=v_0 \cdots(1)\)

and \(v_{ {rms }}=v_0 \cdots(2)\)

From equation (1) and (2), we can see

\({v}_{{av}}={v}_{{rms}}\)
Vapour is injected at a uniform rate in a closed veseel which was initially evacuated. The pressure in the vessel:

When the vapour is injected into the evacuated vessel, the pressure of the vessel starts to increase. As the pressure is increased and reaches the saturated vapour pressure, the vapour starts to condense beyond this. Therefore, after a particular instant, the pressure of the container becomes constant.
The average momentum of the molecule in a sample of an ideal gas depends on:

The average momentum of a molecule in the sample in an ideal gas is zero.

We know momentum is defined as the product of the mass and velocity of the particle in motion. According to the kinetic theory of ideal gas, gas molecules are always in random motion. Due to this random motion, the average velocity will be zero because velocity is a vector quantity. Since velocity have direction when in random motion, all the components of velocity will cancel out each other, and it will be zero on average.
The mean free path of molecules of a gas, (radius '\(r\)') is inversely proportional to:

After the collision of molecules, the direction of the molecule changes so the path actually zigs and zags the total path length divided by the number of collisions is the mean free path.

Formula for Mean free path is

\(\lambda=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2} \pi d^2 n} \)

Using \(d=2 r \)

\(\lambda=\frac{1}{4 \sqrt{2} \pi r^2 n} \)

\(\lambda \propto \frac{1}{r^2}\)

So, The mean free path of molecules of a gas, (radius '\(r\)') is inversely proportional to \({r^2}\).
The mean free path '\(\lambda\)' of a gas molecule, as given by Maxwell, is related to its radius '\(a\)':

The distance travelled by a gas molecule between two successive collisions is known as a mean free path.

\(\lambda=\frac{\text { Total distance travelled by a gas molecule between successive collisions }}{\text { Total number of collisions}}\)

During two successive collisions, a molecule of gas moves in a straight line with constant velocity, and the mean free path of a gas molecule is given by

\( \lambda=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2} \pi n d^2}\)

As we know, \(d=2 a\), where \(a=\) radius of a molecule

The mean free path of a gas molecule is given by

\(\Rightarrow \lambda=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi n(2 a)^2}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2} . 4 \pi n a^2}\)
If the gas particles are of diameter \(d\), average speed \(v\), number of particles per unit volume \(n\), then the term \(n \pi d^2 v\) represents:
The volume a particle sweeps in time \(t\)
The time between two successive collisions on average
The average distance between two successive collisions, also called the mean free path

The volume swept by the molecules in small time \(\Delta t\), in which molecules will collide with it is

\( V=\pi d^2 \bar{v} \Delta t\)

Where \(d=\) distance between the centre of two molecules, \(\bar{v}=\) average speed of the molecules

If \({n}\) is the number of molecules per unit volume of the gas, then the collision suffered by the molecule in time \(\Delta \mathrm{t}\) is \(\pi d^2 \bar{v} \Delta t \times n\)

The rate of collisions in time \({t}\) \(= \frac{\text { Number of collisions }}{\text { sec }}=\frac{n \pi d^2 \bar{v} \Delta t}{\Delta t}=n \pi d^2 \bar{v}\)
The relation between mean free path \(\lambda\) and the pressure \(P\) of any gas is:

We know that, 

During two successive collisions, a molecule of gas moves in a straight line with constant velocity, and the mean free path of a gas molecule is given by 

\(\lambda=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2} \pi n d^2}\cdots(1)\)

If \({n}\) is the number of molecules per unit volume.

\(n=\frac{\rho}{m}=\frac{P}{K_B T}\cdots(2)\)

Here \(\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{B}}\) is Boltzman Constant, \(\mathrm{P}\) is pressure, \(\mathrm{T}\) is temperature

Now if we put (2) in (1) we get

\(\lambda=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2} \pi n d^2} \)

\(\Rightarrow \lambda=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2} \pi\left(\frac{P}{K_B T}\right) d^2} \)

\(\Rightarrow \lambda=\frac{K_B T}{\sqrt{2} \pi(P) d^2}\)

\(\mathrm{K}\) is constant, \(\mathrm{T}\) is the temperature which is constant for isothermal Gas.

\(\lambda \propto \frac{1}{P}\)

So, the relation between mean free path \(\lambda\) and the pressure \(P\) of any gas is \(\lambda \propto p^{-1}\).
The kinetic energy of molecular motion appears as:

According to kinetic energy theory, if we increase the temperature of a gas, it will increase the average kinetic energy of the molecule, which will increase the motion of the molecules. This increased motion increases the outward pressure of the gas.

The average kinetic energy of translation per molecules of the gas is related to temperature by the relationship:

\(K E=\frac{3}{2} {k_B} T\)

Where \(\mathrm{E}=\) kinetic energy, \({k_B}=\) Boltzmann constant and \(\mathrm{T}=\) temperature

From the above equation, it is clear that the average kinetic energy of the gas molecule is directly proportional to the absolute temperature of the gas.
For an ideal gas '\(\alpha_v\)' (coefficient of volume expansion) is equal to:

The ideal gas law is given by

\( {PV}={nRT} \cdots(1)\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{T}=\frac{n R}{P V}\)

From equation (1), it is clear that at constant pressure, temperature and volume are the only two terms that can vary, hence the equation (1) can be rewritten as

\( {P} \Delta {V}={nR} \Delta {T}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\Delta V}{\Delta T}=\frac{n R}{P}\cdots(2)\)

The L.H.S of the equation represents the rate of change of volume with respect to change in temperature, so it is the coefficient of volume expansion i.e.,

\( \alpha_V=\frac{\Delta V}{V \Delta T}\)

\(\therefore\) Equation 2 can be written as

\(\Rightarrow \alpha_V=\frac{n R}{P V}=\frac{1}{T}\)
Which of the following state of the matter have two specific heats?

The molar specific heat capacity of a gas at constant volume is defined as the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of \(1 \mathrm{~mol}\) of the gas by 1 \({ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) at the constant volume.

\(C_v=\left(\frac{\Delta Q}{n \Delta T}\right)\)

The molar specific heat of a gas at constant pressure is defined as the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of \(1 \mathrm{~mol}\) of the gas by 1 \({ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) at the constant pressure.

\(C_p=\left(\frac{\Delta Q}{n \Delta T}\right)\)

The ratio of the two principal specific heat is represented by \(\gamma\).

\(\therefore \gamma=\frac{C_p}{C_v}\)

The value of \(\gamma\) depends on the atomicity of the gas.

So, it is clear that gas has two specific heats.
For a mole of a solid, the total energy is equal to:

According to the theorem of equipartition of energy per molecule of gas, the energy of one molecule is given by,

\( E=\frac{1}{2} k_B T\cdots(1)\)

The total energy of a mole of solid is given by

\( E=\frac{1}{2} k_B T \times N_A\cdots(2)\)

Here  \(-\mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{A}}=\) Avogadro number, \(\mathrm{k}_{\mathrm{B}}=\) Boltzmann constant, \(\mathrm{T}=\) Temperature, and \(\mathrm{F}=\) Degrees of freedom

We know \(\mathrm{R}=\mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{A}} \times \mathrm{k}_{\mathrm{B}}\) applying this to equation 2

\( E=\frac{1}{2} R T\)

An unconstrained rigid solid body in space has six degrees of freedom, therefore

\( E=6 \times \frac{1}{2} R T=3 R T\)

If \(\Delta Q\) stands for the amount of heat absorbed or rejected by a substance of '\(\mu\)' moles when it undergoes a temperature change \(\Delta T\), then \(\frac{\Delta Q}{(\mu \Delta T)}\) is equal to:

The molar specific heat capacity of a substance is defined as the amount of heat that is needed to raise the temperature of 1 mole of the substance through \(1^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\).

i.e., molar specific heat capacity, i.e., \(S=\frac{\Delta Q}{\mu \times \Delta T}\)

Where,  \(\Delta \mathrm{Q}=\) heat exchange, \(\Delta \mathrm{T}=\) change in temperature, \(\mu=\) mass in moles

Two vessels having equal volume contain molecular hydrogen at one atmosphere and helium at two atmosphere pressure respectively. If both samples are at the same temperature the mean velocity of hydrogen molecule is:

Root-mean-square of the velocity of a gas is 

\(V_{r m s}=\sqrt{\frac{3 R T}{M}}\) 

Where \(\mathrm{M}\) is molecular weight of the gas

Here,

\(\frac{\left(V_{r m s}\right)_{H_2}}{\left(V_{\text {rms }}\right)_{H e}}=\sqrt{\frac{M_{H_e}}{M_{H_2}}}=\sqrt{\frac{4}{2}}=\sqrt{2}\)
Is the sum total of kinetic and potential energies
Is the total kinetic energy of randomly moving molecules
Is the total kinetic energy of gas molecules

At a given temperature, the pressure of a container is determined by the number of times gas molecules strike the container walls. If the gas is compressed to a smaller volume, then the same number of molecules will strike against a smaller surface area; the number of collisions against the container will increase, and, by extension, the pressure will increase as well. Increasing the kinetic energy of the particles will increase the pressure of the gas.

So, the internal energy of a gas Is the total kinetic energy of randomly moving molecules.
The mean free path for air molecule with average speed \(18.5 \mathrm{~m/s}\) at STP is: ( Take, \(\mathrm{d}=2 \times 10^{-10} \mathrm{~m}\) and \(\mathrm{n}=2.7 \times 10^{25} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}\) )

Given, number density of the air molecule,

\(n=2.7 \times 10^{25} / \mathrm{m}^3\)

diameter of the air molecule, \(d=2 \times 10^{-10} \mathrm{~m}\) mean free path, \(\lambda=\)?

We know that, mean free path,

\(\lambda=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2} n \pi d^2}\)

\(=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2} \pi \times 2.7 \times 10^{25}\left(2 \times 10^{-10}\right)^2}=2.9 \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{~m}\)
Avogadro's number is the number of molecules in:
One litre of a gas at NTP

Avogadro's number is the number of molecules in one mole of a gas.

Avagadro's number defines the number of particles present in one mole of any substance as a fixed value \(6.022 \times 10^{23}\). This numeric value is called Avogadro's number. The number of units present in one mole of any substance is called Avogadro's number or Avogadro's constant. The units may be electrons, ions, atoms, or molecules, depending on the character of the reaction and the nature of the substance.
According to the Dalton's atomic theory the smallest constituents of an element are:

According to the Dalton's atomic theory the smallest constituents of an element are atoms. He proposed the atomic theory to explain the laws of definite and multiple proportions obeyed by elements when they combine into compounds. The first law says that any given compound has, a fixed proportion by mass of its constituents. The second law says that when two elements form more than one compound, for a fixed mass of one element, the masses of the other elements are in the ratio of small integers.
The mean free path, in gases, is of the order of:
The average distance a molecule can travel without colliding is called the mean free path. The mean free path, in gases, is of the order of thousands of angstroms.
The statement "When gases combine chemically to yield another gas, their volumes are in the ratios of small integers", is related to the:

Avogadro's law, when combined with Dalton's theory explains Gay Lussac's law. According to Gay Lussac's law, when gases combine chemically to yield another gas, their volumes are in the ratios of small integers.
The rate of cooling of a solid body is directly proportional to- ( \(T\) is the temperature of the solid body, \(T_0\) is the temperature of the surrounding).

Newton's Law of Cooling: It states that the rate of cooling or rate of loss of heat is directly proportional to the difference in temperature of the body and temperature of the surrounding medium, Nature, and extent of the exposed surface.

Rate of loss of heat \(\propto\) Temperature difference between the body and surrounding,

Rate of loss of heat \(\alpha\left(T-T_0\right)\)
Which one among the following statement about thermal conductivity is correct

According to given condition,

among all three steel is a good conductor of electricity hence current can easily pass through it and have low resistance compared to wood and water hence it will have highest conductivity

whereas water may or may not conduct electricity depends upon amount of salts or impurity present but compared to wood it will have less resistivity hence it will have higher conductivity compared to wood but far less than iron.

Hence the correct order is Steel > water \(>\) wood
The boiling point of water in Fahrenheit scale is:

Given,

The boiling point of water in degree Celsius, \(\mathrm{C}=100^{\circ}\)

Whereas the relation between degree Celsius and Fahrenheit can be expressed as

\(\frac{F-32}{9}=\frac{C}{5}\)

\(\therefore F=\frac{9}{5} C+32=\frac{9}{5} \times 100^{\circ} C+32\)

\(F=180+32 \Rightarrow F=212^{\circ} \mathrm{F}\)
Which one among the following denotes the smallest temperature?

A liquid with coefficient of cubical expansion \(\gamma\) is contained in a vessel having coefficient of linear expansion \(\frac{\gamma}{3}\). When heated, what will happen to the level of the liquid in the vessel?
It may rise or fall depending upon the nature of the container

If linear expansion is \(\alpha\), then \(\gamma=3 \alpha\)

Here, \(a=\frac{Y}{3}\) so \(\gamma^{\prime}=3 \times \frac{Y}{3}\)

Thus, \(\gamma^{\prime}=\gamma\).

Hence, volume expansion remain unchanged.
The temperature determines the direction of net change of:
Energy of motion is called kinetic energy. When the molecules move or vibrate, they have a kinetic energy, and this is recorded as temperature.
Thermal equilibrium implies equality of temperature which depends upon the average molecular kinetic energy.
Two copper rods of same length, but of different diameters of cross section are given same amount of heat. Assuming no heat losses.
For large quantities of heat thick rod expands more and thin rod expands more for small quantities of heat

Heat given \(\mathrm{Q}=\mathrm{mS} \Delta \mathrm{T}\)

The mass of thin rod is less than thick rod, so the rise in the temperature will be higher for thin rod.

\(\Delta \mathrm{L}=\mathrm{L\alpha} \Delta \mathrm{T}\)

So the rise will be more for higher \(\Delta \mathrm{T}\). Thin rod will expand more.
A metallic ball has a spherical cavity at its center. If the ball is heated,the following happens to the cavity:
