The metal ball can be considered to be made up of several layers of thinner ones. On heating each of these layers will increase in radius. As the inner most layer also increases its radius, the volume inside it i.e. the volume of the hollow portion will also increase.
Why do two ice blocks join to form one block when pressed together?
Melting point of ice is lowered with increase in pressure
Melting point of ice increases with increase in pressure
Melting point of ice remains unchanged with increase in pressure
Melting point of ice is 0oC

When two ice cubes are pressed hard between the palms, the melting point of ice lowers which leads to the formation of a thin layer of water where they are pressed together. When the pressure is released , the ice cubes join together.
The running of fan makes us comfortable during summer because it:
enhances the rate of evaporation of perspiration

A fan produces a feeling of comfort because our perspiration or sweating evaporates rapidly. Our body tries to cool ourselves by releasing sweat through pores of our skin. And when we sit under the fan, the sweat of our body evaporates due to directed air upon us making our body cool.
Gas thermometers are more advantageous than liquid thermometers because of:

Since gases expand much more than liquids on changing the temperature, a gas thermometer is more sensitive than liquid thermometer even for a minute change in the temperature. Hence, the measurement made by a gas thermometer would be more precise and higher in accuracy. Gas thermometers are easier to design to measure a wider range of temperature than liquid thermometers.
An iron ball is heated. The percentage increase will be largest in

Since the radius increment is a linear expansion, which is directly proportional to the temperature change.

Similarly, the area change and volume change are directly proportional to the temperature change.

Density change \((\Delta d)=\) Mass \((m) /\) Change in volume \((\Delta V)\)

Since the density change is inversely proportional to volume change, so the density will have a minimum percentage increase and volume will have a maximum percentage increase.
What happens when pressure is raised on the surface of water?
Boiling point decreases and melting point increases.
Boiling point increases and melting point decreases.
If pressure on the surface of water increases,it's boiling point will increase, because of high pressure molecules come closer and require more heat to boil.
A beaker is completely filled with water at 4°C. It will overflow if
both heated above and cooled below 4°C respectively.
Water has minimum volume at 4°C, so if the water is heated above 4°C or cooled below 4°C, its volume increases. In other words, it expands and overflows in both the cases.
The top of lake is frozen as the atmospheric temperature is -10°C. The temperature at the bottom of the lake is most likely to be

The temperature at the bottom of the lake is likely to be around 4°C. This is because water reaches its maximum density at approximately 4°C. When the surface of a lake freezes, ice forms and acts as an insulator, preventing further heat exchange between the air and the water below. As a result, the water at the bottom of the lake tends to maintain a relatively constant temperature, which is often close to 4°C.
A liquid with coefficient of volume expansion \(\gamma\) is filled in a container of a material having coefficient of linear expansion \(\alpha\). If the liquid overflows on heating, then:

Volumetric coefficient of expansion of material is \(3 \alpha\).

As the system is heated liquid started flowing out of box, it means volumetric coefficient of expansion of liquid is greater then of the container.

So, \(\gamma>3 \alpha\).
The energy radiated by a black body is directly proportional to:

According to Stefan Boltzmann law, the amount of radiation emitted per unit time from area A of a black body at absolute temperature T is directly proportional to the fourth power of the temperature.

\(E \propto T^4\)

\( E=\sigma T^4\)
The energy that will be ideally radiated by a \(100 \mathrm{~kW}\) transmitter in 1 hour is:

A gamma ray, also known as gamma radiation. It is a penetrating form of electromagnetic radiation arising from the radioactive decay of atomic nuclei.

It consists of the shortest wavelength electromagnetic waves, typically shorter than those of X-rays. They are produced by the hottest and most energetic objects in the universe.

Therefore, radiation with maximum penetration power is gamma rays.

A black body at \(227^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) radiates heat at the rate of \(7 \mathrm{cal} / \mathrm{cm}^2 / \mathrm{s}\). At a temperature of \(727^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\), the rate of heat radiated in the same units will be:

Given that:

The heat radiated at \(227^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, \mathbf{E}_1=7 \mathrm{cal} / \mathrm{cm}^2 / \mathrm{s}\)

Initial temperature of the body, \(\mathrm{T}_1=227^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \Rightarrow(227+273) \mathrm{K}=\mathbf{5 0 0} \mathrm{K}\)

Final temperature of the body, \(\mathbf{T}_2=727^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \Rightarrow(727+273) \mathrm{K}=1000 \mathrm{~K}\)

From Stefan Boltzmann Law, \(E=\sigma T^4\)

\( E_1=\sigma\left(T_1\right)^4 \text { and } E_2=\sigma\left(T_2\right)^4 \)

\( \Rightarrow \frac{E_2}{E_1}=\left(\frac{T_2}{T_1}\right)^4 \)

\( \frac{E_2}{7}=\left(\frac{1000}{500}\right)^4\)

\(\therefore\) The rate of heat radiated at \(727^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=\mathrm{E}_2=7 \times 2^4=112 \mathrm{cal} / \mathrm{cm}^2 / \mathrm{s}\)
"Good absorber of heat is good radiator of heat also" is:

The fact that 'good absorbers of heat are good emitters' is based on Kirchoff's radiation law.

The Kirchoff's radiation law states that at a given temperature the coefficient of absorption of a body is equal to its coefficient of emission.
A black body can absorb radiations of:
A black body is an idealized physical body that absorbs all incident electromagnetic radiation of any wavelengths, regardless of frequency or angle of incidence.
A black body has maximum wavelength ' \(\lambda\) ' at \(2000 \mathrm{~K}\). Its corresponding wave length at \(3000 \mathrm{~K}\) will be:

Given maximum wavelength at \(T_1=2000 \mathrm{~K}\left(\lambda_1\right)=\lambda\)

We have to find wavelength at \(T_2=3000 \mathrm{~K}\left(\lambda_2\right)=\) ?

Putting these in Equation (1)

\(\lambda_2=\frac{\lambda}{3000}\times 2000\)

\(\Rightarrow \lambda_2=\frac{2 \lambda}{3}\)
What property of solids is responsible for their expansion when heated?

When solids are heated, they expand due to the increase in average kinetic energy of their molecules. The coefficient of linear expansion (option d) quantifies this change in length per unit original length per degree change in temperature.
Which factor contributes to the expansion of liquids with increasing temperature?

Liquids expand with increasing temperature. The coefficient of volume expansion measures the fractional change in volume per degree change in temperature. It is a crucial factor in understanding how liquids respond to temperature variations.
What happens to the kinetic energy of gas molecules during expansion?

In gases, when temperature increases, the kinetic energy of the gas molecules increases as well. This increased kinetic energy leads to an increase in the average speed of the molecules, causing the gas to expand.
How does the coefficient of linear expansion differ from the coefficient of volume expansion for a material?

The coefficient of volume expansion accounts for the change in volume per degree change in temperature for a material. It is related to the coefficient of linear expansion but is generally three times greater (assuming isotropic materials) because it involves expansion in multiple dimensions.
Heat transfer in liquid and gases takes place by:

Convection is the mode of heat transfer which occurs mostly in liquids and gases. In this method, heat transfer takes place through the actual motion of matter from one place within the body to the other.
The typical range of Prandtl number for water is:
The typical range of Prandtl number for water is 1.7-13.7.
Ratio of the kinetic energy of two cars \(A\) and \(B\) is \(1: 2\). When brakes are applied on both the cars to stop them, then the ratio of the work done required for car A to car B will be:

Given, \(K E_{1 A}: KE_{1 B}=1: 2\), and \(K E_{2 A}=KE_{2 B}=0\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{KE}_{1 \mathrm{~A}}: \mathrm{KE}_{1 \mathrm{~B}}=1: 2\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{KE}_{1 \mathrm{~A}}=\mathrm{K}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{KE}_{1 \mathrm{~B}}=2 \mathrm{~K}\)

The change in kinetic energy of car A is given as,

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow \Delta \mathrm{KE}_{\mathrm{A}}=\mathrm{KE}_{1 \mathrm{~A}}-\mathrm{KE}_{2 \mathrm{~A}} \\ & \Rightarrow \Delta \mathrm{KE} _{\mathrm{A}}=\mathrm{K}-0 \\ & \Rightarrow \Delta \mathrm{KE}_\mathrm{A}=\mathrm{K}....(1)\end{aligned}\)

So the work required to stop car A is given as,

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow W_A=\Delta K E_A \\ & \Rightarrow W_A=K.....(2)\end{aligned}\)

The change in kinetic energy of car B is given as,

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow \Delta \mathrm{KE}_{\mathrm{B}}=\mathrm{KE}_{1 \mathrm{~B}}-\mathrm{KE}_{2 \mathrm{~B}} \\ & \Rightarrow \Delta \mathrm{KE} _{\mathrm{B}}=2 \mathrm{~K}-0 \\ & \Rightarrow \Delta \mathrm{KE} _{\mathrm{B}}=2 \mathrm{~K}....(3)\end{aligned}\)

So the work required to stop car A is given as,

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow \mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{B}}=\Delta \mathrm{KE}_B \\ & \Rightarrow \mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{B}}=2 \mathrm{~K}......(4)\end{aligned}\)

By equation 2 and equation 4 ,

\(\Rightarrow \frac{W_A}{W_B}=\frac{k}{2 k}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{W_A}{W_B}=\frac{1}{2}\)
A body of mass \(m\) undergoes a change in speed from \(u\) to \(v\) by applying force \(\mathrm{F}\) and the body travels a distance of \(\mathrm{s}\). The work done by the force is:

Given that:

Mass \(=m\), Initial speed \(=u\), final speed \(=v\)

Force \(=\mathrm{F}\) and distance \(=\mathrm{s}\)

Work done \((W)=F s\)

Also, Work done will be given by work-energy theorem,

\(W=\frac{1}{2} m v^2-\frac{1}{2} m u^2=\Delta K\)

\(\text { So } W=\frac{1}{2} m\left(v^2-u^2\right)\)
The area of the force displacement curve gives:
Both work done and change in kinetic energy
Neither work done nor change in kinetic energy

The work done by the force is equal to the product of force and the displacement in the direction of the force.

The area of the force-displacement curve gives work done.

The work-energy theorem states that the net work done by the forces on an object is equal to the change in its kinetic energy.

So by the above explanation, we can say that the area of the force-displacement curve gives work done as well as the change in kinetic energy.
A truck is 8 times heavier than a car and is moving at half the speed of the car. The amount of work done required to stop the truck as compared to the car is:

The amount of work required to stop the truck will be equivalent to the kinetic energy possessed by the truck at that moment.

Work and energy have the same unit i.e. joule and can be equated.

Let \(m\) be the mass of the car and \(v\) its velocity.

KE of the car \(=\frac{1}{2} m v^2\)

Let \(\mathrm{m}^{\prime}\) and \(\mathrm{v}^{\prime}\) be the mass and velocity of the truck respectively.

Given that:

\(\mathrm{m}^{\prime}=8 \mathrm{~m}\) and \(v^{\prime}=\frac{1}{2} v\)

\(\mathrm{KE}\) of the truck \(=\frac{1}{2} m^{\prime} v^{\prime 2}=\frac{1}{2}(8 m)\left(\frac{v}{2}\right)^2=2 \times \frac{1}{2} m v^2=\) \(2 \times K E\) of the car.

Therefore, the amount of work done required to stop the truck is two times more.

A man displaced his trunk by \(10 \mathrm{~m}\) by applying a force of \(10 \mathrm{~N}\). In displacing the trunk the work done is \(50 \mathrm{~J}\), then the direction of force he makes with the direction of displacement:

Given - Force \((F)=10 \mathrm{~N}\), displacement \((\mathrm{s})=10 \mathrm{~m}\), and work done \((W)=50 \mathrm{~J}\)

Work done can be calculated as,

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{W}=\mathrm{Fs} \cos \theta\)

\(\Rightarrow 50=10 \times 10 \cos \theta\)

\(\Rightarrow \cos \theta=\frac{1}{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \theta=\cos ^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)=60^{\circ}\)

A bicyclist comes to a skidding stop in \(10 \mathrm{~m}\). During this process, the force on the bicycle due to the road is \(200 \mathrm{~N}\) and is directly opposed to the motion. The work done by the cycle on the road is:

The Displacement D, of the cycle, is \(10 \mathrm{~m}\)

The Frictional Force acting on the cycle is \(200 \mathrm{~N}\).

The Force that cycle applies will be equal to frictional force = \(200 \mathrm{~N}\).

\(\because\) The road does not move hence displacement of the road is zero,
If the velocity of a moving body is doubled (mass remaining constant), then the kinetic energy of the body increases by how many times?

The kinetic energy of an object is defined as the energy that it possesses due to its motion.

Thus, an object that has motion possesses kinetic energy.

The amount of kinetic energy that an object has depends upon two variables i.e. the mass \(({m})\) of the object and the speed ( \({v}\) ) of the object.

If the velocity of the moving body is doubled, then the kinetic energy becomes 4 times.

This is because the kinetic energy of a body is directly proportional to the square of its velocity when the mass of the body is kept constant.
A book is kept on a table. The kinetic energy of the book is:
Has a constant value other than zero.

A book kept on a table is in the state of rest. Hence, its velocity is zero.

Since kinetic energy is directly proportional to the velocity of a body, a body having zero velocity will have zero kinetic energy.
Find the ratio of magnitude of linear momentum, if two bodies A and B of mass \(9 \mathrm{Kg}\) and \(25 \mathrm{Kg}\) respectively are moving with equal kinetic energy.

Given that: \(\mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{A}}=9 \mathrm{Kg}, \mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{B}}=25 \mathrm{Kg}\), and \(\mathrm{KE}_{\mathrm{A}}=\mathrm{KE}_{\mathrm{B}}\)

The relation between the kinetic energy and the momentum is given as,

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{P}^2=2 \mathrm{mKE}\)

Momentum for body A is

\(\Rightarrow P_A^2=2 m_A \times K E_A^2=18 \times K E....(1)\)

Momentum for body B is

\(\Rightarrow P_B^2=2 m_B \times K E_B^2=50 \times K E\)

On dividing equation 1 and 2 , we get

\(\Rightarrow \frac{P_A}{P_B}=\sqrt{\frac{9}{25}}=\frac{3}{5}\)

\(\Rightarrow P_A: P_B=3: 5\)
Which of the following is also considered as the scalar form of Newton's second law of motion?

Newton's second law of motion relates acceleration and force at any instant of time.

From the derivation of the work-energy theorem, the second law of motion which deals with vector quantities is converted into the work-energy theorem where work and energy are scalar quantities.

Hence, Newton's second law for two or three dimensions is in vector form whereas the work-energy theorem is in scalar form.

Therefore, the work-energy theorem is considered as the scalar form of Newton's second law of motion.

A car of mass 1 tonne is moving with a speed of \(30 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\). It suddenly applies the brakes and stops after moving a certain distance \(d\). The frictional force between the tyres and road is \(F=\) \(\mathrm{k} \sqrt{\mathrm{x}}\) where \(\mathrm{x}\) is the distance covered. If \(\mathrm{k}=1000\), the distance \(\mathrm{d}\) covered by the car before stopping is-

Given that:

Mass, \(m=1\) tonne \(=1000 \mathrm{~kg}\)

Initial velocity, \(u=30 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

Final velocity, \(v=0 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

Here, friction does the work, and therefore work done is negative.

So, we can consider \({F}=-{k} \sqrt{{x}}\)

From the work-energy theorem,

\(\Rightarrow \Delta K=\int_{x_i}^{x_f} F d x\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} m\left(v^2-u^2\right)=\int_0^d-k \sqrt{x} d x\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} \times 1000 \times\left(0^2-30^2\right)=\int_0^d-1000 \sqrt{x} d x\)

\(\Rightarrow-450=\left[-\frac{2 x^{\frac{3}{2}}}{3}\right]_0^d\)

\(\Rightarrow 450=\frac{2 d^{\frac{3}{2}}}{3}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{d}=77 \mathrm{~m}\)

An object weighing \(600 \mathrm{~g}\) travelling in a straight line at the rate of \(5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\) has a velocity \(\mathrm{v}=\mathrm{ax}^{3 / 2}\) where \(\mathrm{a}\) is the acceleration and \(\mathrm{x}\) is the distance covered. The work done by the net force during its displacement from \(x=0 \mathrm{~m}\) to \(x=2 \mathrm{~m}\) is:

Given that:

Acceleration, \(a=5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\)

Mass, \(\mathrm{m}=600 \mathrm{~g}=0.6 \mathrm{~kg}\)

Velocity, \(v=a x^{\frac{3}{2}} \Rightarrow v=5 x^{\frac{3}{2}}\)

At \(\mathrm{x}=0, \mathrm{u}=5(0)^{\frac{3}{2}}=0\)

At \(x=2, v=5(2)^{\frac{3}{2}}=10 \sqrt{2}\mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

From work-energy theorem, \(W=\Delta K E\)

\(\Rightarrow W=\frac{1}{2} m\left(v^2-u^2\right)\)

\(\Rightarrow W=\frac{1}{2} \times 0.6 \times\left((10 \sqrt{2})^2-0^2\right)\)

\(\Rightarrow W=0.3 \times 200=60 \mathrm{~J}\)
If the potential energy of a particle is \(v=\frac{1}{2} k\left(\mathrm{x}^2+\mathrm{y}^2\right)\), then the force acting on the particle is:

Given Potential energy \(v=\frac{1}{2} k\left(\mathrm{x}^2+\mathrm{y}^2\right)\),

\(F=\frac{\partial v}{\partial x} \hat{i}+\frac{\partial v}{\partial y} \hat{j}\)

\(\begin{aligned} & \Longrightarrow F=-\left(\frac{\partial \frac{1}{2} k\left(x^2+y^2\right)}{\partial x} \hat{i}+\frac{\partial \frac{1}{2} k\left(x^2+y^2\right)}{\partial y} \hat{j}\right) \\ & \Longrightarrow F=-\frac{1}{2} k(2 x \hat{i}+2 y \hat{j}) \\ & \Longrightarrow F=-k(x \hat{i}+y \hat{j})\end{aligned}\)
For one dimensional motion, the force \(F(x)\) and the potential energy \(\mathrm{U}(\mathrm{x})\) are related as:

The potential energy is equal to negative work done in shifting an object from some reference point to a given position for conservative force.

In mathematical form, it is given as,

\(\mathrm{d} U(x)=-F(x) \mathrm{d} x\)

\(\therefore F(x)=\frac{-d U(x)}{d x}\)

where \(\mathrm{F}\) is the force in newton and \(\mathrm{dU} / \mathrm{dx}\) is change in potential energy per unit length.
A ball falls from a height of a \(20 \mathrm{~m}\), and then bounces back up to \(10 \mathrm{~m}\) height. The loss of energy is:

Given:

Let initial height before drop \(\left(h_1\right)=20 \mathrm{~m}\) and final after bounce \(\left(\mathrm{h}_2\right)=10 \mathrm{~m}\)

The potential energy of the ball before drop \(\left(P_1\right)\) is

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{P}_1=\mathrm{mgh}_1=20 \mathrm{gh}\)

The potential energy of the ball after bounce \(\left(P_2\right)\) is

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{P}_2=\mathrm{mgh}_2=10 \mathrm{gh}\)

As the ball is falling, its potential energy will decrease continuously until it reaches the ground and then it will start increasing after the bounce.

So the potential energy after dropping will be the fraction of initial potential energy.

The loss of energy is

\(\Rightarrow \Delta P \times 100=\frac{P_1-P_2}{P_1} \times 100\)

\(\Rightarrow \Delta P=\frac{20 g h-10 g h}{20 g h} \times 100=50 \%\)

An ice rock of mass \(50 \mathrm{~kg}\) falls from the height \(100 \mathrm{~m}\). What will be its speed when it reaches the height of \(10 \mathrm{~m} ?\left(\mathrm{~g}=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\right)\)

Given that the initial height is \(h_i=100 \mathrm{~m}\); final height \(h_f=10 \mathrm{~m}\); mass \(m=50 \mathrm{~kg}\)

Since the height is decreasing so there will be a loss in potential energy.

Loss in potential energy is

\(P E_f-P E_i=m g h_f-m g h_i\)

\(\Delta P E=50 \times 10 \times 100-50 \times 10 \times 10=45000 \mathrm{~J}=45 \mathrm{KJ}\)

Since there is the only gravitational force acting on the given system which is a conservative force. So total mechanical energy will be conserved.

So initial mechanical energy will be equal to final mechanical energy which means the lost potential energy will be converted into kinetic energy.

The gain in kinetic energy \(=\) loss in potential energy

The gain in kinetic energy \(={45} \mathrm{KJ}\)

Since initial kinetic energy is zero. (initial speed \(=0\) ).

Now speed (v) will be:

\(\frac{1}{2}\left(\mathrm{~m} \times \mathrm{v}^2\right)=45000\)

\(\mathrm{v}={4 2 . 4 2 \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { s }}\)
When a force of \(50 \mathrm{~N}\) is applied, a spring is compressed by 10 \(\mathrm{cm}\). Find the potential energy of the spring when it is compressed by \(20 \mathrm{~cm}\).

Given that \(F_s=50 \mathrm{~N}\) then \(x=10 \mathrm{~cm}=0.1 \mathrm{~m}\)

\(F_s=-k x\)

\(50=k \times 0.1\)

\(k=500 {~ N} / {m}\)

Now potential energy when compressed by \(20 \mathrm{~cm}\), i.e. \(0.2 \mathrm{~m}\) will be:

\(P E=\frac{1}{2} k x^2=\frac{1}{2} \times 500 \times(0.2)^2\)

\(P E=10 \mathrm{~J}\)

Which of the following statement is correct regarding spring force?

1. Spring force is a conservative force

2. It depends on the elongation of the spring

Statement 1: The force for which work done depends only on the endpoints, not the path is called a conservative force.

Here work done by the spring force is given by:

\(W=\frac{k x_1^2}{2}-\frac{k x_2^2}{2}\)

So work done by spring force depends only on the endpoints, not on the path of motion.

So spring force is a conservative force.

Statement 2: Spring force is given by \(F_s=-k x\)

It clearly depends on the elongation of the spring.

For more elongation, we need more force.

So both the statements are correct.
How much energy is equivalent to \(1 \mathrm{gm}\) of mass according to Einstein equation?

Given that \(\mathrm{m}=1 \mathrm{~g}=10^{-3} \mathrm{Kg}\)

They are related by the relation

\(E=m c^2\)

\(E=10^{-3} \times\left(3 \times 10^8\right)^2\)

\(E=9 \times 10^{13} \text { Joule }\)
Which of the following conversion is correct when a firecracker burst?
Potential energy is converted into light, sound and heat energy
Heat energy is converted into light and sound energy
Chemical energy is converted into light, sound and heat energy
Transformation of energy has not been determined for fire cracker

In the firecracker, the energy is stored in the form of chemical energy. When we ignite the cracker, it bursts and we hear sound with some light.

So the chemical energy stored in the firecracker is converted into light, sound, and heat energy. The total energy is conserved.
A block of mass \(20 \mathrm{~kg}\) is moving with velocity \(10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) on a rough horizontal surface. Maximum amount of heat that can be generated from this block is:

Given that \(m=20 \mathrm{~kg} ; \mathrm{v}=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

According to the law of conservation of energy, energy can neither be created nor be destroyed. It only transforms from one form to another form.

So maximum heat will be generated when this block's whole kinetic energy is converted into heat energy. 

So Maximum heat energy finally \(=\) total kinetic energy initially

Maximum heat energy finally \(=\)

\(\frac{1}{2} m v^2=\frac{1}{2} \times 20 \times 10^2=1000 J\)

Maximum heat generated \(=1000 \mathrm{~J}=1 \mathrm{~kJ}\)

A foce of \(20 \mathrm{~N}\) acts on a body of mass \(10 \mathrm{~kg}\) and the body moves \(2 \mathrm{~m}\) at an angle of \(45^{\circ}\) to the direction of the force in 4 second. The dissipated power is:

Given that, \(\mathrm{F}=20 \mathrm{~N}\), mass \((\mathrm{m})=10 \mathrm{~kg}\), displacement \((\mathrm{d})=2 \mathrm{~m}, \theta=45^{\circ}\), time \((t)=4\) seconds.

Work done \(=F d \cos \theta=20 \times 2 \times \cos 45^{\circ} \ldots \ldots .\left(\cos 45^{\circ}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)\)

\(W=20 \times \sqrt{2} \mathrm{~J}\)

\(P=W / t=20 \times \frac{\sqrt{2}}{4}\)

Power \((P)=5 \sqrt{2}\mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{s}\).
A car of mass \(m\) is moving with an acceleration a. Find the power of the engine of the car when the velocity of the car is \(\mathrm{v}\).

Given that:

Mass of the car \(=\mathrm{m}\)

Acceleration \(=\mathrm{a}\)

Velocity \(={v}\)

Force \(=\) mass \((\mathrm{m}) \times\) Acceleration \((\mathrm{a})=\mathrm{m}\) a

Power \((P)=F . v=m\) a \(v\)
Two identical balls are moving opposite to each other with the same speed. Which of the following is true if the collision is perfectly elastic?
Both the balls comes to rest after collision
The balls recoil with the same speed after collision
The first ball comes to rest and the second ball moves along a different direction after collision

Given that, \(\mathrm{m}_1=\mathrm{m}_2 ; \mathrm{v}_{1 \mathrm{i}}=\mathrm{v}\) and \(\mathrm{v}_{2 \mathrm{i}}=-\mathrm{v}\)

\(\text { Using, } m_1 v_{1 i}+m_2 v_{2 i}=m_1 v_{1 f}+m_2 v_{2 f}\)

\(\Rightarrow m v+m(-v)=m v_{1 f}+m v_{2 f}\)

\(\Rightarrow 0=m v_{1 f}+m v_{2 f}\)

\(\Rightarrow v_{1 f}=-v_{2 f}\)

Thus, the balls recoil at the same speed after the collision.
A massive ball moving with a speed 'u' collides with a tiny ball having a very small mass kept at rest. Then the speed of the second ball immediately after the impact will be :

Since the smaller ball is at rest initially, \(\mathrm{v}_{2 \mathrm{i}}=0\). Let \(\mathrm{v}_{2 \mathrm{f}}\) be the speed of the smaller ball after collision.

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{m}_1 \mathrm{v}_{1 \mathrm{i}}=\left(\mathrm{m}_1+\mathrm{m}_2\right) \mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{f}}\)

\(\Rightarrow v_{2 f}=\frac{2 m_1 v_{1 i}+v_{2 i}\left(m_2-m_1\right)}{m_1+m_2}=\frac{2 m_1 v_{1 i}+0\left(m_2-m_1\right)}{m_1+m_2}\)

\(\Rightarrow v_{2 f}=\frac{2 m_1 v_{1 i}}{m_1+m_2}\)

Since the mass of the smaller ball is very less, \(m_2<<m_1\). Therefore, \(m_1+m_2 \approx m_1\)

\(\Rightarrow v_{2 f}=\frac{2 m_1 v_{1 i}}{m_1}=2 v_{1 i}\)

Given that, \(\mathrm{v}_{1 \mathrm{i}}=\mathrm{u}\). Thus, \(\mathrm{v}_{2 \mathrm{f}}=2 \mathrm{u}\)
Which of the following perfectly defines the Impulse?
Force applied to a body for a small period of time

Impulse is the integral of a force, \({F}\), over the time interval, \({t}\), for which it acts.

Hence, force applied to a body for a period of time is what is called impulse.

Since force is a vector quantity, the impulse is also a vector quantity.

A ball is moving with a speed of \(5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) and collides with another ball moving with a speed of \(1 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) in the opposite direction. What will be the speed of the second ball if after the collision the first ball comes to rest and the coefficient of restitution is \(\frac{1}{3}\) ?

Given that \(\mathrm{u}_1=5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} ; \mathrm{u}_2=-1 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) (-ve due to opposite direction); \(\mathrm{v}_1=0 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) and \(\mathrm{v}_2=\) ? and \(e=\frac{1}{3}\)

We know that \({v}_2-{v}_{{1}}=-\mathrm{e}\left(\mathrm{u}_2-\mathrm{u}_1\right)\)

\(v_2-(0)=-\frac{1}{3}(-1-5)\)

\({v}_2=-2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) (here -ve means opposite to initial direction)

A ball of mass \(2 \mathrm{~kg}\) is moving with velocity \(15 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) and hits a wall and returns with some velocity. If the coefficient of restitution between wall and ball is \(\frac{2}{3}\), find loss in kinetic energy during the collision.

Given that \(1^{\text {st }}\) object is a wall and \(2^{\text {nd }}\) object is a ball and \(e=\frac{2}{3}\)

So, \(\mathrm{u}_1=\mathrm{v}_1=0 ; \mathrm{u}_2=15 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) and \(\mathrm{v}_2=\) ?

We know that \(\mathrm{v}_2-\mathrm{v}_1=-\mathrm{e}\left(\mathrm{u}_2-\mathrm{u}_1\right)\)

\({v}_2-0=-\frac{2}{3}(15-0)\)

\(v_2=-10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) (here -ve means opposite to initial direction)

Loss in Kinetic energy = Initial kinetic energy - final kinetic energy

Loss in Kinetic energy \(=\) \(\frac{1}{2} m u^2-\frac{1}{2} m v^2=\frac{1}{2} \times 2 \times 15^2-\frac{1}{2} \times 2 \times 10^2=125 J\)
An object of mass \(1 \mathrm{~kg}\) is moving a velocity \(10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\). Find the kinetic energy of the object.

Given:

Mass \((\mathrm{m})=1 \mathrm{~kg}\).

Velocity \((\mathrm{v})=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\).

The equation of Kinetic Energy is given by,

Kinetic Energy \(=\frac{1}{2} \times m \times v^2\)

KineticEnergy \(=\frac{1}{2} \times 1 \times 10^2=\frac{100}{2}=50 \mathrm{~J}\)

\(\therefore\) The Kinetic Energy of the object is \({5 0} {J}\).

A body of mass \(20 \mathrm{~kg}\) is dropped from a height of \(2 \mathrm{~m}\). If \(\mathrm{g}\) is taken to be equal to 10 \(\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^2\), the kinetic energy of the body, just before striking the ground, will be :

When the body is released from a height of 2 meters then all the potential energy will be converted to kinetic energy.

assuming base as a reference

\(\mathrm{mgh}+\mathrm{0}=\mathrm{K} . \mathrm{E} .+\mathrm{0}\)

so K. E. \(=400 \mathrm{~J}\)

A block of mass \(2\) kg rests on a rough inclined plane making an angle of \(30^\circ\) with the horizontal. The coefficient of static friction between the block and the plane is \(0.7\). The frictional force on the block is:

Given,

Mass \((m)=2\) kg, Coefficient of limiting friction \((\mu)= 0.7\)

Inclined plane making angle \((\theta)= 30^\circ\)

As we know,

The force applied on the body that is on the inclined plane is given as,

\(F = mg \sin \theta\)

\(\therefore F =2 \times 9.8 \times \sin 30^{\circ}=2 \times 9.8 \times \frac{1}{2}\)

\(=9.8\) N

The limiting friction force between the block and the inclined plane is given as,

\(f =\mu mg \cos \theta\)

\(\therefore f =0.7 \times 2 \times 9.8 \cos 30^{\circ}= 0.7 \times 2 \times 9.8 \times \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\)

\(=11.88\) N

Since the limiting friction force is greater than the force that tends to slide the body. So, the body will be at rest and the force of friction on the block is \(9.8\) N.

While teaching in a class Mayank ask a question on the equilibrium of particle as shown in the figure and ask the student to find the weight of a body, if T2 = 100 N. Shreya gives the correct answer. So, what is the answer given by Shreya?

As we know that the value of the horizontal component is always zero irrespective of the inclination of the body.

So, the Horizontal component will be,

\(T_{1} \cos 30^{\circ}=100 \cos 60^{\circ} \)

\(\therefore T_{1}=\frac{100 }{ \sqrt{3}} N\)

Vertical Component will be,

\(T_{1} \sin 30^{\circ}+100 \sin 60^{\circ}= W\)

By putting the value of \(T_{1}\) from above we get

\(\frac{100}{\sqrt{3}} \times \frac{1}{2}+100 \times \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}= W \)

\( \therefore W =\frac{200 }{ \sqrt{3}} N\)

Mayank is doing an experiment in the lab with a bob of mass 10 Kg and a string of 6 m. He tied a string with the laboratory roof and another end with the bob. He then tied another string at 3 m below the roof with the previous one as shown in the figure. Find the tension T1 in the string? g =10 m/s2

Given, 

m = 10 Kg

g = 10 m/s2

First draw the free body diagram of the given figure,

Now resolve all forces into a horizontal and a vertical component.

​Horizontal Component \(= 100 \cos45^\circ =100\times \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\)

\(= 50\sqrt{2} N\)

Vertical Component \(= 100\sin45^\circ=100\times \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\)

\(= 50\sqrt{2} N\)


For the system to be in equilibrium \(T_{1}\) must be equal to the horizontal component but the direction must be opposite.

Here the direction of \(T_{1}\) is reversed for balancing the horizontal component.

\( T _{2}=50 \sqrt{2 } N\)

\( T _{1}=-50 \sqrt{2} N\)

So, the value of \(T_{1}\) is \(-50 \sqrt{2} N\).(Negative sign only show the direction of \(T_{1}\).)
The relation between radius of curved road and banking angle is:

The phenomenon of raising the outer edge of the curved road compared to its inner edge is called banking of road.

As we know,

The velocity of the vehicle on a banked road can be expressed as,

\(v=\sqrt{rg\tan \theta}\)

\(\Rightarrow \tan \theta=\frac{v^{2}}{rg}\)

\(\Rightarrow \theta \propto \frac{1 }{ r}\)

The angle of banking depends on the speed of the vehicle, the radius of the curved road and the acceleration due to gravity (g) at that place. The angle of banking is the same for heavy and light vehicles. The angle of banking is inversely proportional to the radius (r) of curvature.
A circular road of 1000 m radius has a banking angle of 45°, the maximum safe speed of a car having a mass of 2000 kg will be (if the coefficient of friction between tyre and road is 0.5):

Given,

Radius, \(r=1000 m\), Banking angle, \(\theta=45^{\circ}\) 

Coefficient of friction, \(\mu=0.5\). Acceleration due to gravity, \(g=9.8 m/s^2\)

As we know,

Maximum safe velocity is calculated by,

\(v=\sqrt{\frac{r g(\tan \theta+\mu)}{1-\mu \tan \theta}} \)

\(\therefore v=\sqrt{\frac{1000 \times 9.8\left(\tan 45^{\circ}+0.5\right)}{1-0.5 \times \tan 45^{\circ}}} \)

\(\Rightarrow v=\sqrt{\frac{1000 \times 9.8 \times 1.5}{0.5}}\)

\(\Rightarrow v=\sqrt{29400}\)

\(\therefore v =172 m / s\)

A car is moving with a constant speed of \(10 m / s \) along a circular path of radius of \(10 m\) in a horizontal plane. A plumb is suspended from the roof of the car by a light rigid rod.  The angle subtended by the rod from the path is:

Given, 

Radius \((r)=10 m\), Velocity \((v)=10 m / s \), \( g =10 m / s ^{2}\)

Free body diagram of the given condition,


So, \(F _{\text {net }}=0\)

\(T \sin \theta=\frac{m v^{2} }{ r} \)...(1) 

\(T \cos \theta=m g \)...(2) 

Dividing the equation (1) and (2), we get

\(\frac{T \sin \theta}{T \cos \theta}=\frac{v^{2}}{r g}\)

Substituting all the values in the above equation, we get

\(\frac{T \sin \theta}{T \cos \theta}=\frac{(10)^2}{10 \times 10} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{T \sin \theta}{T \cos \theta}=\frac{100}{100} \)

\(\Rightarrow \tan \theta=1\)

\(\therefore \theta= 45^\circ\)

The angle subtended by the rod from the path is \(45^{\circ}\).
If a stone of mass m is rotated in a vertical circular path of radius \(1m\), the critical velocity will be: \(g=9.8 m/s ^{2}\)

The net force acting on a mass that is traveling in a vertical circle is composed of the force of gravity and the tension in the string.

\(\overrightarrow{F_{c}}=\overrightarrow{m g}+\overrightarrow{T} \)

\(\frac{\overrightarrow{m v^{2}}}{R}=\overrightarrow{m g}+\overrightarrow{T}\)

At the point, when the string losses its Tension and go slang, there should be enough gravitational force to make the body continue its motion in vertical plane. For this, the critical velocity should be maintained.

\(\frac{m v^{2}}{R}=m g \Rightarrow v ^{2}= Rg \)

\(\Rightarrow v =\sqrt{Rg}\)

Where \(R=\) radius of the circle in which the stone is moving but here it is the length of the string

Given,

\(R=1 m\), \(g=9.8 ms ^{-2}\)

\(\therefore v=\sqrt{1 \times 9.8}=3.13\)

So, the critical Velocity is \(3.13 m/s\).
The kinetic energy K of a particle moving along a circle of radius R depends on the distance covered is given as \(K = as ^{2}\). The force acting on the particle is:

Given,

\(K = as ^{2}\cdots(1)\)

Where \(K =\) kinetic energy, \(s =\) distance covered and \(a=\) acceleration.

Since the kinetic energy of the particle is changing, so we can say that the speed of the particle is also changing.

In a non-uniform circular motion, two forces will act on the particle \(F_{c}\) and \(F_{t}\). Where \(F_{c}=\) centripetal force and \(F_{t}=\) tangential force.

The centripetal force acts toward the center and the tangential force acts tangentially. So, the net force is given as,

\( F=\sqrt{F_{c}^{2}+F_{t}^{2}}\cdots(2)\)

Centripetal force is given as,

\( F_{c}=\frac{m v^{2}}{R}\cdots(3)\)

Where \(m=\) mass, \(R=\) radius and \(v=\) velocity

\(K = as ^{2} \) (Given)

We know that,

\( K=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}\cdots(4)\)

By equation (1) and equation (4), we get

\( mv ^{2}=2 as ^{2} \cdots(5)\)

By equation (3) and equation (5), we get

\( F_{c}=\frac{2 a s^{2}}{R}\cdots(6)\)

Tangential acceleration is given as,

\( a_{t}=\frac{d v}{d t} \Rightarrow a_{t}=\frac{d v}{d s} \cdot \frac{d s}{d t}\)

\(\Rightarrow v=\frac{d s}{d t}\)

By equation (5),

\( a_{t}=v \sqrt{\frac{2 a}{m}} \)

\(\Rightarrow a_{t}=\frac{2 a s}{m}\cdots(7)\)

The tangential force is given as,

\( F _{ t }= ma _{ t } \Rightarrow F _{ t }=2 as\cdots(8)\)

By equation (2), (6) and (8), we get

\( F=\sqrt{\left(\frac{2 a{s}^{2}}{R}\right)^{2}+(2 a s)^{2}}\)

\(\therefore F=2 a s\left[\frac{s^{2}}{R^{2}}+1\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}\) or \( F=2 a s\left[1+\frac{s^{2}}{R^{2}}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}\)
A book of mass \(10 kg\) is lying at the front desk of a classroom. coefficient of static friction is \(0.5\). A force of \(40 N\) is applied to the book. The book will:

Given,

Mass of the book \(( m )=10 kg\)

Coefficient of friction \(\left(\mu_{ s }\right)=0.5\)

External force applied \(( F )=\) \(50 N\)

Normal reaction force is given by,

\( N = mg \Rightarrow N =10 \times 9.8=98 N\)

Where \(g\) is the acceleration due to gravity.

Limiting force of friction is given by,

\( ( f_s )_{\max }=\mu_{ s } N =0.5 \times 98=49 N\)

As \(F<f _{ s }\), so the book will not move.
A body of mass 5 kg is placed on a rough horizontal surface. What is the maximum value of friction that can act on it? (Given μ = 0.3 and g = 10 m/s2)

Given,

Mass (m) = 5 kg

Coefficient of friction (μ) = 0.3

g = 10 m/s2

Free body diagram of the given condition,

In vertical direction forces are balanced.

∴ \(N = mg\)

The friction force is calculated by,

\(F = μ N =  μ mg\)

∴ \(F = 0.3 × 5 × 10 = 15\) N
The minimum external force needed to move a block kept on a rough surface is 250 N. Find the coefficient of friction between the surface and the block if the mass of the block is 40 kg. (g = 10 m/s2)

Given,

Applied force (F) = 250 N

Mass (m) = 40 kg

Normal (N) = mg = 40 × 10 = 400 N

Friction force (f) = μ N = 400 μ 

For moving the block, Applied (F) ≥ Friction force = 250 ≥ 400 μ 

As the given force is minimum force, so

400 μ = 250

∴ Coefficient of friction (μ) = \(\frac{250}{400}\) = 0.625
An external force of 40 N is acting on a wooden block moving on a rough surface with a constant velocity of 2 m/s. Find the friction force on the block.

When the block is moving on a rough surface, Kinetic Frictional forces try to resist the movement.


Here, a block is moving with constant velocity, which means that no resultant force is acting on the block. Thus, the frictional force is equal and opposite to the applied force and therefore 40 N force is acting on the block but in opposite direction to the external force.

Friction force = external force = 40 N

Three concurent forces F1, F2 and F3 are in equilibrium. The magnitude of the forces F1 and F2 is 3 N and 4 N respectively and both are acting perpendicular to each other. Find the magnitude of the third force.

Given,

\(F _{1}=3 N\) and \(F _{2}=4 N\)

As we know,

Three concurrent forces will be in equilibrium if the resultant of any two forces are equal and opposite to the third force. Therefore,

\(\overrightarrow{F_{1}}+\overrightarrow{F_{2}}=-\overrightarrow{F_{3}}\)

When two forces \(F_{1}\) and \(F_{2}\) act perpendicular to each other and the resultant force is given as,

\( F=\sqrt{F_{1}^{2}+F_{2}^{2}}\)

\(\therefore  F=\sqrt{(3)^{2}+(4)^{2}} \)

\(\Rightarrow F=\sqrt{9+16}  =5 N\)

Therefore, the magnitude of the third force \(F _{3}\) will be \(5 N\).
If the momentum of a body is constant, then:
It may or may not be in translational equilibrium

As we know that the momentum of a body is given as,

\(P = m × v \cdots (1)\)

Where \(m =\) mass, and \(v =\) velocity of the body

By equation (1) it is clear that if the momentum of a body is constant, then its velocity will also be constant and the acceleration will be zero.

An object is in translational equilibrium if the velocity of its translational motion is constant. To be in translational equilibrium, the net force acting on the object must be zero. So, if the momentum of a body is constant, then it will be in translational equilibrium.
Mayank is doing an experiment in a lab he suspended 5 Kg mass by string making angles 60° and 30° with horizontal as shown in the figure. Find the tension T1 and T2. (Take g = 10 m/s2)

Given,

\(m = 5 Kg, g = 10 m/s^2\)

Below is free body diagram of the given figure with its horizontal and vertical component.


From the figure we get,

Horizontal component

\(T_{1} \cos 30^{\circ}=T_{2}\cos  60^{\circ} \)

\(\therefore T_{1}  \cos 30^{\circ}-T_{2} \cos 60^{\circ}=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow T_{1} \times \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-T_{2} \times \frac{1}{2}=0\)

\(\Rightarrow \sqrt{3}T_{1}=T_{2}\)...(i)

Vertical component 

\(T_{1} \sin 30^{\circ}+T_{2}  \sin 60^{\circ}=50 N \)

\(\Rightarrow T_{1} \times \frac{1}{2} +T_{2} \times \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}=50\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{T_{1}}{2}+\frac{\sqrt{3}T_{2} }{2}=50\)

\(\Rightarrow T_{1}+\sqrt{3}T_{2} =100\)...(ii)

By solving equation (i) and (ii), we get

\( T_{1}+\sqrt{3} \times \sqrt{3}T_{1} =100\)

\(\Rightarrow 4T_{1}=100 \)

\(\therefore T_{1}=25 N \) 

\(T_{2}=\sqrt{3}T_{1}=\sqrt{3} \times 25=25 \sqrt{3} N\)
A \(0.2 kg\) object at rest is subjected to a force \((0.3 \hat{i}-0.4 \hat{j}) N\). What is the velocity after \(6s\)?

Given,

Force \((F)=(0.3 \hat{i}-0.4 \hat{j}) N\), Time \((t)=6 s\)

Mass \(( m )=0.2 kg\), Initial velocity \((u)=0\)

Let the velocity of the object after \(6 s\) be \(v\).

As we know, Force is given by,

\(F=m a \cdots(1)\)

or \(a=\frac{F}{m}\)

Substituting the values in above equation we get,

\(a=\frac{(0.3 \hat{i}-0.4 \hat{j})}{0.2} =\left(\frac{3}{2} \hat{i}-2 \hat{j}\right)\)

From equation of motion, we have

\(v=u+a t\)

Substituting the values in above equation we get,

\(v=0+\left(\frac{3}{2} \hat{i}-2 \hat{j}\right) \)

\(\Rightarrow v=\left(\frac{3}{2} \hat{i}-2 \hat{j}\right) \times 6 \)

\(\Rightarrow v=(9 \hat{i}-12 \hat{j})\)

So, the velocity of an object after \(6 s\) is \((9 \hat{i}-12 \hat{j})\).
A gun fires a small bullet. The recoiling momentum of the gun is:
Equal and opposite to momentum of the bullet.
Equal and in same direction to momentum of the bullet.
More than momentum of bullet but in opposite to that of bullet
Less than momentum of bullet but in opposite to that of bullet

Since there is no external force in the system of the gun and the bullet, all forces are internal. So the momentum of the system will be conserved.

According to the law of conservation of momentum, the initial momentum of the system is zero (as there is no motion initial). So the final momentum of the system will also be zero. This implies that the recoil momentum of the gun must be equal and opposite to that of the bullet.

\(P_{\text {initial }}=P_{\text {final }}\)

\(\Rightarrow 0=P_{\text {bullet }}+P_{\text {gun }}\)

\(\Rightarrow P_{\text {gun }}=-P_{\text {bullet }}\)

Here negative sign shows the momentum of the gun is opposite to the momentum of the bullet, and the magnitude is the same. So, the recoil momentum of the gun must be equal and opposite to that of the bullet.
Momentum of an isolated system of particles is conserved if:
There is no external force acting on the system
There is a force provided to the system externally

An isolated system means that there is no external interaction on the system. According to the law of conservation of momentum, the total momentum of a system is conserved for an isolated system. 

Thus, the momentum of an isolated system of particles is conserved if there is no external force acting on the system.
A particle of mass 2 kg is moving with 20 m/s collides with a stationary particle of mass 3 kg. After the collision, both particles moves together. Find the loss of kinetic energy of the system.

Given,

Mass of the first particle \((m _{1})=2 kg\), Mass of the second particle \((m _{2})=3 kg\)

Velocity of first particle \((u _{1})=20 m/s\), Velocity of second particle \((u _{2})=0 m/s\)

Initial \(KE =\frac{1 }{ 2 }m _{1} u ^{2}{ }_{1} =\frac{1 }{ 2} \times 2 \times (20)^{2} =400 J\)

Let \(V\) is the final velocity of both the particle after collision.

\(P_{1}=m_{1} u_{1}+m_{2} u_{2}=2 \times 20+0=40 \)

\(P_{2}=m_{1} v_{1}+m_{2} v_{2}=(2+3) V=5 V \)

\(P_{1}=P_{2} \)

\(\therefore 5 V=40 \Rightarrow V=\frac{40 }{ 5} \Rightarrow V=8 m / s\)

Final \(KE =\frac{1}{2}mV^2=\frac{1}{2}(m_1+m_2)V^2\)

\(=\frac{1 }{ 2} \times(2+3) \times 8^{2} =160 J\)

Loss in KE \(=\) Initial KE - Final KE \(= 400-160 =240 J\)
A bomb of 12 kg divides in two parts whose ratio of masses is 1 : 3. If the kinetic energy of the smaller part is 216 J, then the momentum of the bigger part in kg-m/s will be:

After division, the mass of the bomb divides into two parts ratio of masses is 1 : 3. So after division, the masses will be 3 kg and 9 kg and the kinetic energy of the smaller part is 216 J.

According to the law of conservation of momentum, the initial momentum of the system is zero (as there is no motion initial). So the final momentum of the system will also be zero. This implies that the momentum of the divided parts of the bomb must move in opposition to each other.

\(P_{\text {initial }}=P_{\text {final }} \Rightarrow 0=P_{\text {big }}-P_{\text {small }} \)

\(\Rightarrow P_{b}=P_{s}\)

The kinetic energy of the bigger part, \(K_{b}=\frac{P_{b}^{2}}{2 M_{b}}\)

The kinetic energy of the smaller part, \(K_{s}=\frac{P_{s}^{2}}{2 M_{s}}\)

Since, \(P _{ b }= P _{ s }\)

\(\therefore P _{ b }^{2}= P _{ s }^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow P_{b}^{2}=K_{s}\left(2 M_{s}\right) \quad [\because P _{ s }^{2}=K_{s}(2 M_{s})]\)

\(\Rightarrow P_{b}^{2}=216(2 \times 3) =216 \times 6 \)

\(\Rightarrow P_{b}=\sqrt{1296}=36 \) kg-m/s

\(\therefore\) The momentum of the bigger part is \(36\) kg-m/s.
A nucleus at rest splits into two nuclear parts having radii in the ratio 1 : 2 Their velocities are in the ratio:

The linear momentum of a body is given by,

Momentum \(=\) mass \(\times\) velocity \(= mv\)

In the nucleus, neutrons are closely packed in a small radius. The cube of the radius (r) of the nucleus is proportional to the mass number (m).

\(r ^{3} \propto m\)

or \(\left(\frac{r_{1}}{r _{2}}\right)^{3}= \frac{m _{1}}{m _{2}}\)

Given,

\(\frac{r _{1} }{r _{2}}=\frac{1 }{ 2}\)

Momentum \(= mv\)

By conservation of momentum, 

\(m _{1} v _{1}= m _{2} v _{2}\)

\(\frac{v _{1} }{ v _{2}}=\frac{ m _{2} }{ m _{1}}\)

Also from, \(\left(\frac{r_{1} }{r_{2}}\right)^{3}=\frac{m_{1} }{m_{2}}\)

\(\therefore \frac{ v _{1} }{ v _{2}}=\frac{ m _{2} }{ m _{1}}=\left( \frac{r _{2} }{r _{1}}\right)^{3} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{ v _{1} }{ v _{2}}=\left(\frac{2 }{ 1}\right)^{3} =\frac{8 }{ 1}\)

\(\therefore  v _{1} :v _{2}=8:1\)
Suppose 2 bodies undergo collision. When do we say the momentum between them is conserved?
In the absence of an external force

The Law of conservation of momentum states that for two or more bodies in an isolated system, the total momentum remains constant before and after the collision unless an external force is applied.

For a collision occurring between object 1 and object 2 in an isolated system, the total momentum of the two objects before the collision is equal to the total momentum of the two objects after the collision. Momentum is conserved for both elastic and inelastic collision and remains conserved only when an external force is not present.
A 12 kg bomb at rest explodes into two pieces of 4 kg and 8 kg. If the momentum of 4 kg piece is 20 Na, the kinetic energy of the 8 kg piece is:

Given,

Total mass of the system (bomb) = 12 kg, Mass of first piece (m1) = 4 kg

Mass of the second piece (m2­) = 8 kg

The bomb was initially at rest.

So initial momentum of the system (P1) = 12 × 0 = 0

After the explosion, the momentum of the first piece = 20 Na

Final momentum of the system (P2) = momentum of the first piece + Momentum of the second piece = 20 + Momentum of second piece

Since there is no external force on the bomb during the explosion, so the momentum of the system before or after the explosion will remain the same.

According to law of conservation momentum,

P1 = P2

∴ 0 = 20 + Momentum of second piece

Momentum of second piece = - 20 = m2 × V

⇒ 8 × V = - 20 ⇒ V = \(\frac{- 20}{8}\) = - 2.5 m/s

The negative sign shows the direction of the velocity.

Kinetic energy of second (8 kg) piece (K E) \(=\frac{1}{2} m V^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \times 8 \times (2.5)^{2} =4 \times 6.25 =25 J\)
A mass initially at rest exploded into two parts of 3 kg and 9 kg. If the speed of 3 kg mass is 18 m/s, find the speed of 9 kg mass.

Initially mass is at rest so Pinitial = 0

Now the explosion occurs due to internal forces, there is no external force involved, so momentum will be conserved.

According to the law of conservation of momentum, the initial momentum of the system is zero (as there is no motion initial). So the final momentum of the system will also be zero.

This implies that the momentum of the divided parts of the bomb must move in opposition to each other.

\(P_{\text {initial }}=P_{\text {final }}\)

\(\therefore 0=P_{b i g}+P_{\text {small }}\)

\(\Rightarrow 0=9 \times v+3 \times 18\)

\(\Rightarrow v=-6 m / s\)

Here negative sign means 9 kg mass will move opposite to the 3 kg mass.
An object of mass 5 kg is attached to the end of a rope. If the rope is pulled upward with an acceleration of 0.30 ms-2, what is the tension in the rope?

Given, 

Mass = 5kg, Acceleration of rope = 0.30 ms-2 , g = 9.8 ms-2

Free body diagram:

∵  Acceleration is upward with 0.3 ms-2

∴ T – mg = ma

⇒ T – (5 × 9.8) = 5 × 0.30 = 50.5 N

So, the tension in the tope is 50.5 N.

A certain spacecraft is used to transport astronauts from International Space Station (ISS) to Earth. The spacecraft is designed to have three parts labelled P, Q and R each of mass 1200 kg, 3150 kg, and 2800 kg respectively. When the spacecraft is launched the exhaust system produces a force of 1430 N. Calculate the acceleration of the spacecraft as it leaves the ISS.

Let the Mass of spacecraft = Mass of (P + Q + R)

From Newton's third law of motion, when the exhaust system produces a force of 1430 N, an equal and opposite force is exerted back on the spacecraft. Let this force be F.

∴ F = 1430 N

As we know,

F = m × a 

∴ 1430 = Mass of spacecraft × a 

⇒ 1430 = (1200 + 3150 + 2800) × a

⇒ 1430 = 7150 × a

∴ a = 0.2 m/s2

So, the acceleration of the spacecraft is 0.2 m/s2.
Change in momentum is equal to the:

According to Newton's second law of motion, the force on the body is given as,

\( F=\frac{d P}{d t} \)

\(\Rightarrow dP = F \times dt \)...(1)

\(\therefore\) Change in momentum \(= F \times dt\)...(1)

Where \(F=\) force and \(d t=\) time

As we know, 

Momentum of a body is given as,

Momentum \(( P )=\) mass \(( m ) \times\) velocity \(( v ) \)...(2)

By equation (2) the change in momentum is given as,

Change in momentum \(=\) mass \(\times\) change in velocity...(3)

The impulse is given as,

\(I=F \times d t \)...(4)

By equation (1) and equation (4), we get

\(I = dP=\) Change in momentum...(5)

By equation (1), equation (3), and equation (5), we can say that all the given options are correct.
An object of mass \(7 kg\) is moving with a velocity given by \(v = at \hat{ i }+ bt ^{2} \hat{\jmath}\) where \(t\) is the time. Then the force acting on the object is:

Given,

Mass \(( m )=7 kg\), Velocity \(( v )= at \hat{ i }+ bt ^{2} \hat{ j }\)

According to the Newton's second law of motion, the rate of change of momentum is directly proportional to the force applied by the moving body.

\(\frac{d p}{d t} \propto F\)

\(\therefore F=\frac{d p}{d t}=m \frac{d v}{d t} \)

\(\Rightarrow F=7 \times \frac{d(a t \hat{i}+b t^{2} \hat{j})}{d t} \)

\(\Rightarrow F=7(a \hat{i}+2 b t \hat{j}) = 7 a \hat{i}+14 b t \hat{j}\)
Ranveer pulled a table cloth from a table without dislodging the dishes. This is due to:

Newton’s first law of motion is also called the law of inertia. Inertia is the ability of a body by virtue of which it opposes a change. According to Newton’s first law of motion, an object will remain at rest or in uniform motion in a straight line unless acted upon by an external force.

When a body is at rest, it will remain at rest until we apply an external force to move it. This property is called inertia of rest. When a body is in a uniform motion, it will remain in motion until we apply an external force to stop it. This property is called inertia of motion.

When Ranveer pulled a table cloth from a table, at that time the dishes were at rest. Due to the inertia of rest, the dishes remain at rest because the cloth is removed soon.
A water tank is filled with water to half its capacity. The tank is kept on a truck that is moving with a constant velocity. On sudden application of the brake, the water in the tank would:

Newton's first law of motion states that an object at rest remains at rest, or if in motion, remains in motion at a constant velocity unless acted on by a net external force. This law is also known as the law of inertia.

As the truck is moving forward with a constant velocity, the tank along with the water is also moving under constant velocity. When a sudden brake is applied, it tends to oppose the forward motion of water in the tank. Due to the inertia of water, it would have a tendency to continue its forward motion. Therefore on sudden braking, it suddenly moves forward.
The magnitude of the difference between the individual measurement and true value of the quantity is called:

The magnitude of the difference between the individual measurement and true value of the quantity is called absolute error.

The absolute error is calculated by taking the absolute value of the difference between the measured value and the true value. Mathematically, it is expressed as:

Absolute Error = Measured Value − True Value

This ensures that the error is always positive (or zero), regardless of whether the measured value is greater or less than the true value.
The velocity of a freely falling body depends on \(g^{p} h^{q}\), where \(g\) is acceleration due to gravity and \(h\) is the height. The values of \(p\) and \(q\) are:

Given:

\(v \propto g^{p} h^{q}\)

We know that:

\(v=\left[\mathrm{L} \mathrm{T}^{-1}\right]\)

\(g=\left[\mathrm{L} \mathrm{T}^{-2}\right]\)

\(h=[\mathrm{L}]\)

By substituting the dimension of each quantity and comparing the powers in both sides we get:

\({\left[\mathrm{L} \mathrm{T}^{-1}\right]=\left[\mathrm{L} \mathrm{T}^{-2}\right]^{\mathrm{p}}[\mathrm{L}]^{\mathrm{q}}} \)

\(\Rightarrow {\left[\mathrm{L} \mathrm{T}^{-1}\right]=\left[\mathrm{L}^{\mathrm{p}+\mathrm{q}} \mathrm{T}^{-2 \mathrm{p}}\right]}\)

On comparing the powers

\( p+q=1,-2 p=-1 \)

\(\therefore p=\frac{1}{2}, q=\frac{1}{2}\)
Which of the following pairs has the same dimensions?

Impulse is defined as the change in momentum.

Impulse I \(=\Delta \mathrm{p}=\mathrm{mv}-\mathrm{mu}\)

So, both Impulse and momentum have the same units/dimensions.
Which of the following physical quantity is dimensionless?

\(\text { Angle }(\theta)=\frac{\text { Length of arc }(l)}{\text { radius }(r)} = \theta=\frac{\left[M^{0} L T^{0}\right]}{\left[M^{0} L T^{0}\right]}=1\)

\(\therefore\) An angle is a dimensionless quantity.

\(\text { Strain }=\frac{\text { change in length }(\Delta l)}{\text { original length }(l)} =\frac{\left[M^{0} L T^{0}\right]}{\left[M^{0} L T^{0}\right]}=1\)

\(\therefore\) Strain is a dimensionless quantity.

\(\text { Specific gravity }(\rho)=\frac{\text { Density of the object }\left(\rho_{\text {object}}\right)}{\text { Density of water }\left(\rho_{\text {water}}\right)} =\frac{\left[M L^{3} T^{0}\right]}{\left[M L^{3} T^{0}\right]}=1\)

\(\therefore\) Specific gravity is a dimensionless quantity.
Find the dimensional formula for magnetic field \(\vec{B}\) from the given formula \(\vec{F}=q \vec{B}|\vec{v} \sin \theta|\).

Given:

\(\vec{F}=q \vec{B}|\vec{v} \sin \theta|\)

\([F]=\left[M L T^{-2}\right]\)

\([Q]=[A T]\)

\([V]=\left[L T^{-1}\right]\)

\(\operatorname{Sin} \theta\) = Dimensionless

\([B]=\frac{\mid F]}{\mid q][v]}\)

\(=\frac{\left[M L T^{-2}\right]}{\mid A T]\left[L T^{-1}\right]}\)

\(=\left[M L^{0} T^{-2} A^{-1}\right]\)

\(=\left[M T^{-2} A^{-1}\right]\)
Express the formula of gravitational constant in terms of mass, velocity, and wavelength?

We know that:

\(\mathrm{F}=\mathrm{G} \frac{M^{2}}{R^{2}}\)

Dimention of \(G=\left[M^{-1} L^{3} T^{-2}\right]\).....(1)

\(\Rightarrow G=\left[M^{-1} L^{3} T^{-2}\right] \)

Where, \(\text {Mass }=[\mathrm{M}]\),

\(\text {Velocity }=\left[\mathrm{LT}^{-1}\right]\) and

\( \text {Wavelength }(\lambda)=[\mathrm{L}] \)

According to the question: we have to express the formula of gravitational constant in terms of mass, velocity, and wavelength.

So, 

\( G \propto M^{x}{V^{y}} \lambda^{z} \).....(2)

From (1).

\({\left[\mathrm{M}^{-1}\left. L^{3} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right] \propto\left[\mathrm{M}^{1}\right]^{\mathrm{x}}\left[\mathrm{LT}^{-1}\right]^{y}[\mathrm{~L}]\right.} \)

\({\Rightarrow \left[\mathrm{M}^{-1} L^{3} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right] \propto[\mathrm{M}]^{\mathrm{x}}[\mathrm{L}]^{y+z}[\mathrm{~T}]^{-y}}\)

On comparing the power of \(M, L{,} T\)

\(x=-1, y+z=3,-y=-2\)

Put these values in (2).

\( G \propto M^{-1} V^{2} \lambda^{1} \)

\(G \propto \frac{\left(V^{2} \lambda\right)}{M}\)

A physical quantity Q is found to depend on observables \(\mathrm{x}, \mathrm{y}\) and \(\mathrm{z}\), obeying relation \(\mathrm{Q}=\frac{\mathrm{x}^{2 / 5} \mathrm{z}^{3}}{\mathrm{y}}\) The percentage error in the measurements of \(\mathrm{x}, \mathrm{y}\) and \(\mathrm{z}\) are \(1 \%, 2 \%\) and \(4 \%\) respectively. What is percentage error in the quantity Q will be:

The given quantity \(Q=\frac{x^{3} y^{2}}{z}\)

Percentage error in \(\mathrm{Q} =\frac{\Delta \mathrm{Q}}{\mathrm{Q}} \times 100=3 \frac{\Delta \mathrm{x}}{\mathrm{x}} \times 100+2 \frac{\Delta \mathrm{y}}{\mathrm{y}} \times 100+\frac{\Delta \mathrm{z}}{\mathrm{z}} \times 100\)

Percentage error in \(\mathrm{x}, \mathrm{y}\) and \(\mathrm{z}\) are \(1 \%, 2 \%\) and \(4 \%\) respectively.

Percentage error in \(\mathrm{Q}= \frac{\Delta \mathrm{Q}}{\mathrm{Q}} \times 100=3 \frac{1}{100} \times 100+2 \frac{2}{100} \times 100+\frac{4}{100} \times 100\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\Delta \mathrm{Q}}{\mathrm{Q}} \times 100=3(1)+2(2)+1(4)\)

\(=11 \%\)
Measuring the quantity with more than one instrument
Taking large number of observations and then their mean

Random errors are statistical fluctuations (in either direction) in the measured data due to the precision limitations of the measurement device. Random errors can be evaluated through statistical analysis and can be reduced by averaging over a large number of observations (see standard error). These errors can be eliminated by taking large number of observations and then their mean.
If the fundamental quantities are energy \((E)\), velocity \((v)\) and force \((F)\), then what will the dimensions of mass?

We know that,

\( {[\mathrm{E}]=\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}} \)

\( {[{v}]=\mathrm{M}^{0} \mathrm{L}^1 \mathrm{~T}^{-1}} \)

\({[\mathrm{~F}]=\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~L}^1 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}}\)

Let dimension of mass in \(\mathrm{E}\) is \(=\mathrm{x}\)

Let dimension of mass in \({v}\) is \(=\mathrm{y}\)

Let dimension of mass in \(\mathrm{F}\) is \(=\mathrm{z}\)

Then, \(\mathrm{M}=\mathrm{E}^{\mathrm{x}} {v}^{\mathrm{y}} \mathrm{F}^{\mathrm{z}}\)

\(\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{T}^{0}=\left[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]^{\mathrm{x}}\left[\mathrm{M}^{0} \mathrm{L}^1 \mathrm{~T}^{-1}\right]^{\mathrm{y}}\left[\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~L}^1 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]^{\mathrm{z}}\)

\(\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{T}^{0}=\mathrm{M}^{\mathrm{x}+\mathrm{z}} \mathrm{L}^{2 \mathrm{x}+\mathrm{y}+\mathrm{z}} \mathrm{T}^{-2 \mathrm{x}-\mathrm{y}-2 \mathrm{z}}\)

\(\mathrm{x}+\mathrm{z}=1\cdots(i) \)

\(2 \mathrm{x}+\mathrm{y}+\mathrm{z}=0\cdots(ii) \)

\(2 \mathrm{x}+\mathrm{y}+2 \mathrm{z}=0\cdots(iii) \)

By equation (i), (ii) & (iii)

\( x=1 \), \( y=-2 \), \(z=0\)

So, \([\mathrm{M}]=\mathrm{E}{v}^{-2}\)
Which of the following units denotes the dimensions \(\frac{\mathrm{ML}^2 }{\mathrm{Q}^2}\), where \(\mathrm{Q}\) denotes the electric charge?

Henry is the unit of inductance (L). 

Inductance (L) \(=\frac{\text {Flux}(\phi)}{\text {Current}(I)}=\frac{\phi}{I}\)

Now,

Dimension of \(\phi=\left[ML^2 T^{-2} A^{-1}\right]\)

Dimension of \(I=[A]\)

\( L=\frac{\phi}{I}=\frac{\left[M L^2 T^{-2} A^{-1}\right]}{[A]}=\frac{\left[ML^2\right]}{\left[A^2 T^2\right]} \)

Charge \(=\text {Current}\times \text {time }\) or \({[Q]=[A][T]} \)

\(\Rightarrow L = \frac{\left[ML^2\right]}{\left[A^2 T^2\right]} =\frac{\left[ML^2\right]}{\left[Q^2\right]}\)
The dimensional formula of Planck's constant is:

Planck's constant is a physical constant that is the quantum of electromagnetic action. It relates the energy carried by a photon to its frequency by

\({E}={h v}\).

\( h=\frac{E}{v}\)

Where, \({E}=\) energy, \({v}=\) frequency and \({h}=\) Planck's constant.

Now,

Dimensional formula of energy \(({E})=\left[{ML}^2 {~T}^{-2}\right]\)

Dimensional formula of frequency \(({v})=\left[{T}^{-1}\right]\)

\( h=\frac{[M L^2 T^{-2}]}{[T^{-1}]} \)

\( \therefore{h}=[{ML}^2 {~T}^{-1}]\)
An Odometer is an instrument used to measure ________ in automobiles.

An odometer or odograph is a device used to measure the distance travelled by the vehicle.

An odometer is a device that is used for measuring the distance travelled by a vehicle. The odometer is usually situated in the vehicle's dashboard. The word "odometer" is derived from two Greek words meaning path and measure.
In a pendulum, the time period is measured by \(0.2 \%\) accuracy and length are measured by \(0.5 \%\) accuracy. Find the percentage accuracy in the value of \(\mathrm{g}\).

Time period formula using pendulum \(T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{L}{g}}\)

Or \(g=L \times\left(\frac{2 \pi}{T}\right)^2\cdots(1)\)

Putting the given values in the equation number (1) we get:

\(g=0.5 L \times\left(\frac{2 \pi}{0.2 T}\right)^2\)

And we know that Relative Errors on multiplication and division get added and Relative Errors on exponential get multiplied.

Error in measuring length is \(\frac{\Delta l}{l}=0.5\)

Error in measuring time period is \(\frac{\Delta T}{T}=0.2\)

Then

\(\frac{\Delta g}{g}=\frac{\Delta l}{l}+\frac{2 \Delta T}{T} \)

\(=0.5+2 \times 0.2=0.9 \%\)

Thus the percentage error in the value of \(g\) is \(0.9 \%\)
In SI system the fundamental units are:
meter, kilogram, second, ampere, Kelvin, mole and candela
meter, kilogram, second, coulomb, Kelvin, mole and candela
meter, Newton, second, ampere, Kelvin, mole and candela
meter, kilogram, second, ampere, Kelvin, mole and lux

Fundamental quantities are those which cannot be expressed or measured in terms of other physical quantities.  The SI system has seven fundamental quantities i.e. length, mass, time, electric current, thermodynamic temperature, amount of substance, and luminous intensity and their units in SI system are meter, kilogram, second, ampere, Kelvin, mole, and candela respectively.
The quantity that does not have mass in its dimension is:

Dimension of electrical potential \(= [\mathrm{M^1 L^2 T^{-3} A^{-1}}]\)

Dimension of electrical resistance \(= [\mathrm{M^1 L^2 T^{-3} A^{-2}}]\)

Dimension of specific heat \(= [\mathrm{M^0 L^2 T^{-2}K^{-1}}]\)

Dimension of magnetic flux \(= [\mathrm{M^1 L^2 T^{-2}A^{-1}}]\)

So, the specific heat does not have mass in its dimension.
If \(\mathrm{M}\) denotes angular momentum and \(\mathrm{p}\) denotes linear momentum, the dimensions of \(\frac{\mathrm M}{\mathrm p}\) is:

Linear momentum is the measure of impact caused due to a moving object with mass. 

Linear momentum \(\mathrm{p=m v}\)

Where \(\mathrm m=\) mass and \(\mathrm v=\) is the velocity.

Angular momentum  is the rotational equivalent of linear momentum.

Angular momentum, \(\mathrm{M}=\mathrm{r} \times \mathrm{mv}\)

Where \(\mathrm m=\) mass, \(\mathrm r=\) radius and \(\mathrm v=\) velocity.

Ratio \(=\frac{\mathrm M}{\mathrm p}=\frac{\mathrm{r m v}}{\mathrm{m v}}=\mathrm r\)

The dimension of \(\mathrm{r =[L^1]}\)

So, the dimensions of \(\frac{\mathrm M}{\mathrm p}\) is \([\mathrm L^1]\).

The linear momentum of a body is the quantity of motion contained in the body. It is measured in terms of the force required to stop the body in unit time. It is also measured as the product of the mass of the body and its velocity i.e.,

Momentum \((p)=\) mass \((m) \times\) velocity \((v)\)

As we know that, the SI unit of mass is \(\mathrm{kg}\) and the SI unit of velocity is \(\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\). Therefore the unit of momentum is

\(p=\mathrm{kgms}^{-1}\)
What is the dimensional formula of strain?

The ratio of change in configuration to the original configuration is called strain.

Strain \(=\frac{\text { Change in dimension }}{\text { Original dimension }}\)

As the strain is the ratio of two like quantities, it has no units and no dimensions.

Its dimension can be express as \(\mathrm{M}^{0} \mathrm{L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{0}\).
Which of following is the dimensional formula of Density?

Density: It is defined as mass per unit volume.

i.e., Density \(=\frac{\text { Mass }}{\text { Volume }}\)

Now,

Dimensional formula of mass = [M]

Dimensional formula of volume \(=\left[\mathrm{L}^{3}\right]\)

Density \(=\frac{[M]}{\left[L^{3}\right]}\)

\(\Rightarrow\) Density \(=[\mathrm{ML}^{-3} \mathrm{~T}^{0}]\)

\(\therefore\) Dimensional formula of density is \(\left[\mathrm{ML}^{-3} \mathrm{~T}^{0}\right.\) ].
Which of the physics quantity has the same unit in both C.G.S and M.K.S system?

Time period (T): The time taken to complete one full oscillation or cycle by the Wave is called the time period.

  • The SI unit of the time period is second (sec).
  • The CGS unit of the time period is second (sec).

From the above, it is clear that time is the physics quantity that has the same unit in both C.G.S and the M.K.S system.
If \(x=a+b t+c t^{2}\), where \(x\) is in meters and \(t\) is in second. What is the unit of \(b\) and \(c\) ?

Given equation \(x=a+b t+c t^{2}\),

Here, units of \(x\) are meters.

Therefore by the law of homogeneity, units of \(x\) are the same as units of \(a\).

Units of \(a=\) Meter \((m)\)

Units of \(x=\) units of \(a=\) units of \(b t=\) units of \(c t^{2}\)

From above:

\(x=a=\left[\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{0}\right] \)

\(x=\mathrm{bt} =\frac{x}{t}=\frac{\left[\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{0}\right]}{\left[\mathrm{M}^{0} \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{1}\right]}=\left[\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{-1}\right]\)

Therefore units of \(b\) is \(\mathrm{ms}^{-1}\). Similarly,

\(x=\mathrm{ct}^{2} \)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{c}=\frac{x}{t^{2}}=\frac{\left[\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{L}^{0} \mathrm{T}^{0}\right]}{\left[\mathrm{M}^{0} \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{2}\right]}=\left[\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]\)
The square root of the product of inductance and capacitance has the dimension of length:

Frequency is the number of oscillations or the number of waves passes a given point in one sec. 

\(\Rightarrow f=\frac{1}{T}\)

We know that the frequency of oscillations generated by the LC circuit entirely depends on the values of the capacitor and inductor and their resonance condition.

\(f=\frac{1}{2 \pi \sqrt{L C}}\)

Where \(L=\) Inductor and \(C\) = capacitor

From the above, it is clear that the resonant frequency can be written as

\(\Rightarrow f=\frac{1}{2 \pi \sqrt{L C}}\)

The above equation can be written as,

\( \Rightarrow \sqrt{L C}=\frac{1}{2 \pi f} \)

\(\Rightarrow \sqrt{L C}=\frac{T}{2 \pi}\)

Here, \(2 \pi\) is constant, therefore the dimension of \(\sqrt{L C}\) is

\(\Rightarrow \sqrt{L C}=\left[M^0 L^0 T^1\right]\)

So, the square root of the product of inductance and capacitance has the dimension of time.
Which one of the following is not a derived unit?

The work is the product of force and displacement.

\(W=F \times s\)

It can also be written as 

\(W=(m a) \times s=m \times \frac{v}{t} \times s=\frac{m s^{2}}{t^{2}}=m s^{2} t^{-2}\)

Substituting the fundamental units: mass, length and time.

\(\Rightarrow W=\left[M L^{2} T^{-2}\right]\)

Now,

The Watt is a unit of power. The power is the work done by time.

\(P=\frac{W}{t}\)

It can also be written as 

\(P=\frac{W}{t}=\frac{F \times s}{t}=\frac{(m a) \times s}{t}=\frac{m s}{t} \times \frac{v}{t}=\frac{m s^{2}}{t^{3}}=m s^{2} t^{-3}\)

Substitute the fundamental units: mass, length and time.

\(\Rightarrow P=\left[M L^{2} T^{-3}\right]\)

The Newton is a unit of force and force is the product of mass and acceleration.

\(F=m a\)

It can also be written as 

\(F=m a=m \times \frac{v}{t}=m \times \frac{s}{t} \times \frac{1}{t} =\frac{m s}{t^{2}}=m s t^{-2}\)

Now, we will substitute the fundamental units: mass, length and time.

\(\Rightarrow F=[M L T^{-2}]\)

Now consider, kilogram.

The dimensional formula of the kilogram is \(k g=[M]\)

So, Kilogram is not a derived unit.
Which of the following pair of physical quantities does not have the same dimensions?

Electric Flux \(=\left[\mathrm{M} \mathrm{L}^3 \mathrm{T}^{-3} \mathrm{I}^{-1}\right]\)

Electric Dipole Moment \([=\mathrm{A L T}]\)

Pressure \(=\left[\mathrm{M} \mathrm{L}^{-1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]\)

Young's Modulus \(=\left[\mathrm{M} \mathrm{L}^{-1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]\)

Electromotive Force \(=\left[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-3} \mathrm{~A}^{-1}\right]\)

Potential Difference \(=\left[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-3} \mathrm{~A}^{-1}\right]\)

Heat \(=\left[\mathrm{M} \mathrm{L}{ }^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right.\) ]

Potential Energy \(=\left[\mathrm{M} \mathrm{L}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]\)

So only the pair of electric flux and electric dipole moment has a different dimensional formula for both quantities.
A meter reads \(125 \mathrm{~V}\) and the true value of the voltage is \(125.5 \mathrm{~V}\). Find the absolute error of the instrument.

Given:

\(A_{m}=125 \mathrm{~V}, A_{t}=125.5 \mathrm{~V} \)

Absolute error \((E)=A_{m}-A_{t}\).....(1)

\(\mathrm{A}_{\mathrm{m}}=\) Measured value

\(A_{t}=\) True value

Put the given values in (1),

Absolute error \((E)=125-125.5 \)

\(\Rightarrow E=0.5 \mathrm{~V}\)
A wattmeter reads \(25.34 \mathrm{~W}\). The absolute error in measurement is \(-0.11 \mathrm{~W}\). What is the true value of power:

Measured value \(=25.34 \mathrm{~W}\)

Absolute error \(=-0.11 \mathrm{~W}\)

As we know,

Absolute error = Measured value - true value

Put the given values in above formula.

\(\Rightarrow-0.11=25.34\) - true value

\(\Rightarrow 25.34+0.11=25.45 \mathrm{~W}\)
Dimensional formula of \(\omega\) in equation \(y=a \sin (\omega t+k x)\) is:

Given \(y=a \sin (\omega t+k x)\)

As we know that the trigonometric function is a dimensionless quantity. So, (\(\omega{t}+{k x})\) is also a dimensionless quantity.

Here, \(t=\) time

The dimension of \({t}\) is given as,

\(\Rightarrow[t]=\left[M^0 L^0 T^1\right]\cdots(1)\)

Since the quantity \(\omega t\) is dimensionless.

\(\Rightarrow[\omega t]=\left[M^0 L^0 T^0\right]\cdots(2)\)

Let the dimension of \(\omega\) as,

\(\Rightarrow[\omega]=\left[M^x L^y T^z\right]\cdots(3)\)

By equation (1), equation (2) and equation (3),

\(\Rightarrow\left[M^0 L^0 T^1\right]\left[M^x L^y T^z\right]=\left[M^0 L^0 T^0\right] \)

\( \Rightarrow\left[M^x L^y T^{z+1}\right]=\left[M^0 L^0 T^0\right] \)

By comparison,

\(\Rightarrow x=0 \)

\( \Rightarrow y=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow z+1=0 \Rightarrow z=-1\)

So dimensional formula for \(\omega\) is,

\(\Rightarrow[\omega]=\left[M^0 L^0 T^{-1}\right]\)
Which of the following quantity has dimensional formula as that of \(\frac{\text { Energy }}{\text { Mass } \times \text { Length }}\) is:

We know that the dimension of the energy is given as,

Energy \(=\left[\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{L}^2 \mathrm{T}^{-2}\right]\)

So the dimension of \(\frac{\text { Energy }}{\text { Mass } \times \text { Length }}\) is given as,

\(\Rightarrow\left[\frac{\text { Energy }}{\text { Mass } \times \text { Length }}\right]=\frac{\left[\mathrm{M^1 L^2 T^{-2}}\right]}{\left[\mathrm{M^1 L^1}\right]} =\left[\mathrm{M^0 L^1 T^{-2}}\right]\)

The dimension of force is given as,

\(\Rightarrow[\mathrm{F}]=\left[\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~L}^1 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]\)

The dimension of power is given as,

\(\Rightarrow[\mathrm{P}]=\left[\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~L}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-3}\right]\)

The dimension of pressure is given as,

\(\Rightarrow[\mathrm{P}]=\left[\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~L}^{-1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]\)

The dimension of acceleration is given as,

\(\Rightarrow[\mathrm{a}]=\left[\mathrm{M}^0 \mathrm{~L}^1 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]\)

By the above explanation, it is clear that the dimensional formula for acceleration is the same as that of \(\frac{\text { Energy }}{\text { Mass } \times \text { Length }}\).
The dimensions of 'resistance' are same as those of __________ where \(h\) is the Planck's constant.

In the options, \({h}\) is the Plank constant and \({e}\) is the charge of an electron. Hence

Dimensional formula of e or charge \(\mathrm{Q=[A T]}\)

Dimensional formula of \(h=\left[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-1}\right]\)

Dimensional formula of Resistance \(=\left[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-3} \mathrm{~A}^{-2}\right]\)

Dimension of \(\frac{h}{e^2}=\frac{\left[\mathrm{M L^2 T^{-1}}\right]}{[\mathrm{A T}]^2}=\left[\mathrm{M L^2 A^{-2} T^{-3}}\right]\)

So the dimension of \(\frac{h}{e^2}\) is the same as the Resistance.
If the unit of length, time and mass are increased by 10 times, then the numerical value of "g" (acceleration due to gravity) will:

Given that: length, time, and mass are increased by 10 times.

Dimension formula of '\({g}\)' at initial condition \(=\left[\mathrm{LT}^{-2}\right]\) 

But after increasing the quantity by 10 times, acceleration due to gravity is '\(g_1\)'

Dimensional formula of '\(\mathrm{g}_1\)' \(=[10 \mathrm{L} ~100^{-1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}] \Rightarrow\left[\frac{\mathrm{LT}^{-2}}{10}\right]\)

\(\mathrm{g}_1=[\frac{\mathrm{L T^{-2}}}{10}] \)

So, \( \mathrm{g}_1=\frac{\mathrm{g}}{10}\)
If a string wave encounters a completely fixed end, what happens to its phase?

The reason for the phase to change by π is that the boundary displacement should be zero because it is rigid & by principle of superposition it is only possible if the reflected wave differs by a phase of π.
The equation of a wave is: y = 2sin(4x-3t). What will be the equation of the reflected wave from a free surface?

At the free surface reflected wave suffers no phase change.

Only the direction of wave propagation gets reversed.

So, the equation will be y = 2sin(4x+3t)
What is the minimum distance between a node & an antinode in a standing wave?

The amplitude in a standing wave is given by Asin(kx).

Node is a point where amplitude is zero and antinode is a point where amplitude is maximum.

For a node, sin(kx) = 0

kx = 2nπ OR (\(\frac{2π}{λ}\))x = nππ

x = \(\frac{nλ}{2}\)

For an antinode, sin(kx) = 1

kx =\( \frac{(2n+1)π}{2}\)

(\(\frac{2π}{λ}\))x =\( \frac{(2n+1)π}{2}\)

x =\( \frac{(2n+1) λ}{4}\)

∴ node is at \(\frac{λ}{2}, λ, \frac{3λ}{2}\) …

& antinode at \(\frac{λ}{4}, \frac{3λ}{4}, \frac{5λ}{4}\) …

∴ minimum distance \(=\frac{ λ}{2 }– \frac{λ}{4} =\frac{ λ}{4}\)
If a standing wave is vibrating in the fourth harmonic and the wavelength is λ, what is the length of the string?

If the length of string is L, then the wavelength of the standing wave is \(\frac{2L}{n}\).

Or we can say L = \(\frac{nλ}{2}\), where n corresponds to nth harmonic.

∴ L = \(\frac{4λ}{2}\)

= 2λ
Consider the case of normal modes of vibration for the air column with only one end closed. What is the length of the air column for the fundamental harmonic?

For the given condition wavelength is related to length by: λ = \(\frac{4L}{(2n+1)}\)

∴ For fundamental harmonic n=0, & L = \(\frac{(2n+1)λ}{4}\)

= \(\frac{(0 + 1)λ}{4}\)

= \(\frac{λ}{4}\)
A pipe is open at both ends. What should be its length such that it resonates a 10Hz source in the 2nd harmonic? Speed of sound in air = 340m/s

For a pipe open at both ends frequency ‘f’ = \(\frac{nv}{2L}\), where n is speed of sound.

Given: f = 10 & n=2

∴ 10 =\( 2\times\frac{340}{2L}\)

∴ L = \(\frac{680}{20}\)

= 34m
Consider standing waves in an air column with one end closed. What is a pressure node?
The point where there is an antinode corresponds to maximum amplitude of displacement. This also implies that here, pressure changes are minimum and it is therefore called a pressure node.
A pipe open at both ends has a fundamental frequency of 2Hz. If the pipe is closed at one end and half filled with water, what will be the fundamental frequency?

The fundamental frequency in the first case is given by: f1 = \(\frac{v}{2L}\)

In the second case length becomes half & one end is closed,

so fundamental frequency f2 =\( \frac{v}{(\frac{4L}{2})}\)

= \(\frac{v}{2L}\) = f1

So the value of f2 = 2Hz
What does the given equation: x = Asin(ky+wt+a) represent?

A way of looking at a travelling wave is considering the direction in which a particular value of transverse displacement moves. For the given equation x = Asin(ky+wt+a) we have to see the direction in which x moves. For eg: If we consider the amplitude A, for x =A as t increases, y should decrease. So, we can say that the wave propagates in the negative y direction.
An equation of a wave is given by: y = 2sin(\(\frac{3x-2t+π}{2}\)). What is the minimum distance between two points having the same phase?

In the given equation the phase is \(\frac{3x-2t+π}{2}\).

This is repeated after every 2π.

∴ sin(\(\frac{3x-2t+π}{2}\)) +2nπ = sin(\(\frac{3x-2t+π}{2}\))

We can consider the case at t=0, sin(3x+\(\frac{π}{2}\)) = sin(3x+\(\frac{π}{2}\)+2nπ)

OR cos(3x) = cos(3x+2nπ)

∴ n = 1 for minimum difference.

Minimum distance can be found from kx = 2π

OR x = \(\frac{2π}{k}\) = \(\frac{2π}{3}\)
Which of the following statement is correct?
Mechanical wave don't require any medium to propagate

Electromagnetic waves are transverse in nature.

Mechanical waves need a medium to propagate. Sound waves are longitudinal in nature. Electromagnetic waves don't require a medium to propagate.
Which of the following represent incorrect statement regarding longitudinal wave?
Direction of disturbance and direction of propagation is always perpendicular.
Direction of disturbance and direction of propagation is always parallel.
Longitudinal waves produces in a medium that can sustain compressive strain.

The direction of disturbance and direction of propagation is always perpendicular to each other in a transverse wave.

The direction of disturbance and direction of propagation is always parallel to each other in a longitudinal wave. The Sound waves are longitudinal in nature. Longitudinal wave generally forms in a medium that can sustain compressive strain.
The sound Wave is an example of:

Sound Wave is an example of Longitudinal Waves.

Transverse Wave always propagates in a perpendicular direction in which its constituent particle oscillates. A sound wave needs a medium to travel while electromagnetic waves don't require any medium to travel.
If the equation of a sound wave is \(y=0.0015 \sin (652.8 x+314 t)\) then its frequency will be:

Given that:

\(y=0.0015 \sin (652.8 x+314 t)\)

By comparing given equation with general equation we get,

\(\omega=314 ; k =652.8\)

We know that \(\omega=2 \pi f\) where \(f=\) frequency

\(\omega=314 \)

\(2 \pi f=314 \)

\(f=49.97 Hz\)

So, \(f= 5 0 H z\)
A wave travelling along a string is describes as \(y=0.005 \sin (80 x-3 t)\). Calculate the displacement of wave at \(x=30 m\) and \(t=20 sec\).

Given that:

\(y=0.005 \sin (80 x-3 t)\)

To find the displacement at \(x=30 cm\) and \(t=20 sec\)

Put the value of \(x\) and \(t\) in given equation

\(x=0.3 m \)

\(y=0.005 \sin \left(\left(80 \times 0.3\right)-(20 \times 3)\right)\)

\(y=0.005 \sin (-36) \)

\(y=5 mm\)
