The equation of progressive wave in a wire is \(y=4 \sin [\frac{\pi }{ 2}(\frac{8 t-x }{ 8})]\) if \(x\) and \(y\) are measured in \(cm\) then velocity of wave is:

\(y=4 \sin [\frac{\pi }{ 2}(8 t-\frac{x }{ 8})]\)

We know that \(\omega=2 \pi f\) and \(f=\frac{v }{ \lambda}\)

\(\omega=\frac{2 \pi v }{ \lambda} \)...(i)

We also know that

\(k=\frac{2 \pi }{ \lambda} \)

Now put the value of \(\lambda\) in equation (i) we get

It transfers both energy and matter from one point to another.
It transfers energy but does not transfer matter from one point to another.
It transfers matter but does not transfer energy from one point to another.
It does not transfer both energy and matter from one point to another.
A wave transfers energy but it does not transfer a matter from one point to another point.
The wave in which medium particles move perpendicular to the direction of wave is:

Transverse waves: The wave in which medium particles move perpendicular to the direction of the wave is called a transverse wave. Examples of transverse waves are: Ripples on the water surface, wave on a string.
If the equation of a sound wave is \(y=0.0015 \sin (652.8 x+314 t)\) then its wavelength will be:

Given that:

\(y=0.0015 \sin (652.8 x+314 t)\)

We know that \(k =\frac{2 \pi }{ \lambda}\)

By comparing general equation with given equation we get

\(k=652.8 \text { and } \omega=314 \)

\(k=\frac{2 \pi }{ \lambda} \)

\(652.8=\frac{2 \pi }{ \lambda}\)

Wavelength \((\lambda)=0.009 m \simeq 0.01 m\)
When a sound wave goes from one medium to another, the quantity that remains unchanged is:

When a sound wave goes from one medium to another, the frequency remains unchanged. The relation between wavelength, frequency, and speed \(v\) is \(\Rightarrow v = fx \lambda\).

The velocity of sound depends upon the elasticity and inertia of the medium. So when a particle moves from one medium to another its amplitude increases on decreases, depending upon the medium.

As we know the frequency of sound depends upon the source of the sound, not the medium of propagation. Hence it does not change.
A pulse travels through a uniform medium, the speed of the pulse will be:

The speed of a wave or a pulse depends upon the properties of the medium. If the medium is uniform or unchanging, then the speed is constant.

\(v =\sqrt{\frac{\text { Elastic property }}{\text { Inertial property }}} \Rightarrow v =\sqrt{\frac{ B }{\rho}} \)

Where \(B\) is the bulk modulus of medium and \(\rho\) is the density of the medium.
Which one of the following statements is correct?
The speed of sound waves in a medium depends upon the elastic property of the medium but not on the inertial property
The speed of sound waves in a medium depends upon the inertia property of the medium but not on elastic property
The speed of sound waves in a medium depends neither depends on its elastic property nor its inertia property
The speed of sound waves in a medium depends both on the elastic and inertia properties of the medium

Sound waves is one of the examples of Longitudinal wave.

And Longitudinal wave can be defined as the wave in which the movement of the particles are parallel to the motion of the energy and as wave progress, matter moves to and fro throughout its propagation. This means more elastic the medium will be more easily matters can vibrate hence greater the speed of sound.

Similarly, as a density of the material can be defined as mass per unit volume and as density increases the speed of sound decreases. Because denser the material particle more tightly will be packing of atoms which will restrict its vibration and hence causes decrease in velocity of sound.

Hence, we can say that \(v=\sqrt{\frac{\text { elastic property of material }}{\text { density of material }(\rho)}}\)
Which of the following is longitudinal wave?

Longitudinal waves are the waves in which particles of the medium oscillate parallel to the direction of wave propagation. Sound wave through air is a longitudinal wave. Light wave, radio wave and X-ray are examples of transverse waves.
In longitudinal wave motion, compression is a region where:

Longitudinal wave motion is that wave motion in which individual particles of the medium execute simple harmonic motion about their mean position along the same direction, in which the wave is propagated. It travels in the form of compression (C) and rarefaction (R).

Compression is a region of the medium in which particles are compressed i.e. particles come closer i.e. distance between the particles becomes less than normal distance between them. Thus, there is a temporary decrease in volume and consequently a temporary increase in pressure in the medium in the region of compression.
The speed of sound in water depends on?

The speed of sound in water depends on temperature, salinity, and pressure, and is therefore not uniform throughout different water environments. In the oceans, the speed of sound varies between 1450m/s and 1570m/s.
For the destructive interference of the two similar waves, the phase difference between the waves must be:

For the destructive interference of the two similar waves, the phase difference between the waves must be \(\pi\).

If two waves superimpose with each other in the opposite phase, the amplitude of the resultant is equal to the difference in amplitude of individual waves, resulting in the minimum intensity of light, this is known as destructive interference.
Which of the following is correct for the constructive interference of the two harmonic waves?
The amplitude of the resultant wave is equal to the sum of the amplitudes of individual waves
​The Intensity of the resultant wave is equal to the sum of the intensities of individual waves

'The amplitude of the resultant wave is equal to the sum of the amplitudes of individual waves' is correct for the constructive interference of the two harmonic waves.

When two or more waves come together at some point in space then the resultant disturbance wave is the vector sum of disturbance of the individual waves.

When two waves superimpose then the resultant amplitude of the wave at that point is the vector sum of amplitudes of each individual wave. This phenomenon is called the interference of waves.

If two waves superimpose with each other in the same phase, the amplitude of the resultant is equal to the sum of the amplitudes of individual waves resulting in the maximum intensity of light, this is known as constructive interference.
If two harmonic waves of equal amplitude and wavelength are superimposed, then amplitude of the resultant wave depends on the:

Let two harmonic waves of equal amplitude and wavelength be given as

\(\Rightarrow y _1= a \cdot \sin ( kx -\omega t ) \)

\(\Rightarrow y _2= a \cdot \sin ( kx -\omega t +\phi)\)

Where \(\phi=\) phase difference between \(y _1\) and \(y _2\).

By the principle of superposition, the net displacement is given by,

\(\Rightarrow y=2 a \cdot \cos \frac{\phi}{2} \sin \left(k x-\omega t+\frac{\phi}{2}\right)\)

By equation 1 the amplitude of the resultant wave is given as,\(\Rightarrow A=2 a \cdot \cos \frac{\phi}{2}\)
When two wave pulses overlap each other, the displacement of the resultant wave is the:
Algebric sum of the displacement due to each pulse
Vector sum of the displacement due to each pulse
Product of the displacement due to each pulse

According to the principle of superposition of waves, when two or more waves come together at some point in space then the resultant disturbance wave is the vector sum of disturbance of the individual waves.
Two waves are represented by \(y_1=a \cdot \sin (\omega t)\), and \(y_2=a \cdot \cos (\omega t)\). If both the waves are superimposed then the resultant amplitude will be:

Given: \(y_1=a \cdot \sin (\omega t)\), and \(y_2=a \cdot \cos \omega t\)

\(\Rightarrow y_2=\operatorname{acos}(\omega t)=\operatorname{asin}\left(\omega t+\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\)

The resultant amplitude of the wave after superposition of two waves:

\(\Rightarrow A=\sqrt{a^2+b^2+2 a \times b \times \cos \phi}\)

Where, \(a=\) amplitude of wave \(1, b=\) amplitude of wave 2 , and \(\phi=\) phase difference

Here, \( a = a , b = a \text { and } \phi=\frac{\pi}{2}-0=\frac{\pi}{2} \)

\(\Rightarrow A=\sqrt{a^2+a^2+2 a \times a \times \cos \frac{\pi}{2}} \)

\(\Rightarrow A=\sqrt{2 a^2} \)

\(\Rightarrow A=\sqrt{2} a\)
What is the SI unit of Compressibility?

As the compressibility is inverse of the bulk modulus so the Unit of compressibility \(\propto 1 /\) Unit of Bulk Modulus \(\propto\) \(1 / \mathrm{Nm}^{-2} \propto \mathrm{m}^2 \mathrm{~N}^{-1} \propto \mathrm{m}^2 / \mathrm{N}\).

Compressive strain: It is the change in length per original length due to a compressive force acting on the object. A compressive force generally causes a decrease in length.

When a compressive force acts on an object, it tends to deform by undergoing a decrease in its original dimension. So, the compressive strain is the decrease in length per original length.

A steel wire of \(1 \mathrm{~m}\) long and \(1 \mathrm{~mm}^2\) cross-section area is hanged from the rigid end when the mass of \(1 \mathrm{~kg}\) is hung from it then change in length will be (for wire Youngs coefficient \(\left.Y=2 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^2\right)\) :

Given: \(Y=2 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^2, \mathrm{~m}=1 \mathrm{Kg}, \mathrm{L}=1 \mathrm{~m}, \mathrm{~A}=1 \mathrm{~mm}^2=1 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{~m}^2, \Delta \mathrm{L}=\) ?, and \(\mathrm{F}=\mathrm{mg}=1 \times 10=10 \mathrm{~N}\)

The young modulus of the material is given by

\(\Rightarrow Y=\frac{F L}{A \Delta l}\)

The above equation can be rewritten for \(\Delta \mathrm{L}\) as

\(\Rightarrow \Delta L=\frac{F L}{A Y}\)

Substituting the given value in the above equation:

\(\Rightarrow \Delta L=\frac{10 \times 1}{1 \times 10^{-5} \times 2 \times 10^{11}}=5 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{~m}\)

\(\Rightarrow \Delta L=0.05 \mathrm{~mm}\)
Bulk modulus of steel is \(154 \mathrm{GPa}\) and modulus of rigidity of steel is \(77 \mathrm{GPa}\). Find Young modulus of elasticity.

The Young's modulus of steel is \(2.0 \times 10^{11}\) newton \(/ {m}^2\). If the interatomic distance is \(3.0 \mathring{\mathrm{A}}\), then the value of interatomic force constant in newton/metre is:

Given,

Young's modulus of steel, \(Y=2.0 \times 10^{11}\) newton \(/ \mathrm{m}^2\)

Interatomic distance, \(r=3.0 \mathring{\mathrm{A}}=3 \times 10^{-10} \mathrm{~m}\)

Interatomic force constant, \(k=Y \times r=\left(2.0 \times 10^{11}\right) \times\left(3 \times 10^{-10}\right)=60\) netwon \(/ \mathrm{m}\)
A weight \(\mathrm{Mg}\) suspended to a wire produces an increment 'l' in its length. Work done in the process will be:

Given \({W}\) (load in the wire \()={Mg}\), and \({l}=\) increment in the length

Let \(L=\) initial length of the wire

The developed stress in the wire is given as,

\(\Rightarrow \sigma=\frac{W}{A}\)

Where \(\mathrm{A}=\) cross-sectional area of the wire

\(\Rightarrow \sigma=\frac{M g}{A}\).....(1)

The strain in the wire is given as,

\(\Rightarrow \epsilon=\frac{\text { Change in length }}{\text { Initial length }}\)

\(\Rightarrow \epsilon=\frac{l}{L}\)......(2)

The volume of the wire is given as,

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{V}=\mathrm{AL}\).......(3)

We know that when a body is stretched by a load, then the work done by the load on the body gets stored in the form of strain energy. So work done on the wire is given as,

\(\Rightarrow\) Work Done \(=\) strain energy

\(\Rightarrow\) Work Done \(=E=\frac{1}{2} \times \sigma \times \epsilon \times V\)

\(\Rightarrow\) Work Done \(=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{M g}{A} \times \frac{l}{L} \times A L\)

\(\Rightarrow\) Work Done \(=\frac{M g l}{2}\)
Which of the following material has Poisson's ratio greater than 1 ?

Poisson's ratio is defined as the ratio of transverse strain to longitudinal strain in the direction of the stretching force.

Poisson's ratio, \(\nu=-\frac{\epsilon_t}{\epsilon_l}\)

Where \(\epsilon_t\) is the transverse strain and \(\epsilon_l\) is the longitudinal strain.

The Poisson's ratio for any material that is fixed should be between 0 and 1. There can be no material that has Poisson's ratio less than zero and greater than 1.
When elongation in a rubber band is \(3 \mathrm{~cm}\), the stored energy in it is of magnitude \(E\) units. What will be the energy stored when the elongation is \(6 \mathrm{~cm}\) ?

The energy of the rubber band when elongation is \(\mathrm{E} = 3 \mathrm{~cm}\)

Let, the energy of the rubber band when elongation is \(6 \mathrm{~cm}\) be \(E_2\).

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\mathrm{E}_2}{\mathrm{E}}=(\frac{\mathrm{X}_2}{\mathrm{X}_1})^2\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\mathrm{E}_2}{\mathrm{E}}=(\frac{6}{3})^2\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\mathrm{E}_2}{\mathrm{E}}=4\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{E}_2=4 \mathrm{E}\)

Hence, energy stored at \(6 \mathrm{~cm}\) elongation will be \(4 \mathrm{E}\).
When a spring is stretched by \(2 \mathrm{~cm}\) the energy stored is \(100 \mathrm{~J}\). If it is stretched further by \(2 \mathrm{~cm}\), its energy increases by:

The potential energy stored in the spring when it is stretched for a length of \(2 \mathrm{~cm}\) is given as \((x=\) \(2 \mathrm{~cm}=0.02 \mathrm{~m})\)

\(\Rightarrow U=\frac{1}{2} k x^2\)

\(\Rightarrow 100=\frac{1}{2} k \times 0.02^2\)

\(\mathrm{k}=500 \times 10^3\).........(1)

The potential energy stored in the spring when it is stretched for a length of \(2 \mathrm{~cm}\) is given as ( \(x=4\) \(\mathrm{cm}=0.04 \mathrm{~m})\)

\(\Rightarrow U=\frac{1}{2} k x^2\)

\(\Rightarrow U^{\prime}=\frac{1}{2} \times\left(50 \times 10^3\right) \times 0.04^2\)

\(\Rightarrow U^{\prime}=400 \mathrm{~J}\)

The energy increases by \(\Delta U=U^{\prime}-U\)

\(\Delta U=400-100=300 \mathrm{~J}\)
Factor of saftey is given by the formula:

The factor of safety is the ratio of Ultimate(or maximum) stress to the permissible stress of a structure.

Factor of safety=\(\frac{\text { yield stress }}{\text { allowable stress }\left(\sigma_{\text {allowable }}\right)}\)

A pendulum \(P_1\) is at rest while another pendulum \(P_2\) is oscillating continuously and comes to rest after some time. Now, the two pendulums \(P_1\) and \(P_2\) are made to oscillate simultaneously. Which of the following will be observed?

A pendulum oscillating is subjected to a force.

As pendulum \(\mathrm{P}_2\) was initially subjected to deforming force and oscillating, further oscillations will lead to elastic fatigue.

On the other hand, pendulum \(\mathrm{P}_1\) was at rest. Hence, it will not be under elastic fatigue.

If a body is subjected to stress or strain continuously it becomes weak due to elastic fatigue. Therefore, \(\mathrm{P}_2\) comes to rest earlier than \(\mathrm{P}_1\).
What happens when a tensile stress is applied axially across the cross section of a cylindrical metal rod?
Stress doesn't work when applied axially to any body

The cross-sectional part of a cylinder is a circle and thus the area for this circular region is

\(\Rightarrow A=\pi r^2=\frac{1 }{ 4} \pi D^2\)

Where \(\mathrm{D}=\) the diameter of the circular region

Since area(or diameter) is inversely proportional to the tensile stress, thus when the tensile stress increases the diameter of the cylinder decreases.
Which of the following shows Longitudinal Strain?

Longitudinal strain is possible only in solids because only solids can have a length that can be changed by applying force.

The strain in liquids and gases causes a change in volume and is called volumetric strain.
A \(120 \mathrm{~cm}\) long rod is subjected to an axial pull of \(18 \mathrm{kN}\). If the diameter of the rod is \(3 \mathrm{~cm}\), the stress acting on it is:

Given,

Axial force, \(\mathrm{F}=18 \mathrm{kN}=18 \times 10^3 \mathrm{~N}\)

Diameter of the rod, \(d=3 \mathrm{~cm}=30 \mathrm{~mm}\)

Cross-sectional area, \(\mathrm{A}=\frac{\pi}{4} d^2=\frac{\pi}{4}(30)^2=706.85 \mathrm{~mm}^2\)

Stress, \(\sigma=\frac{F}{A}=\frac{18 \times 10^3}{706.85}=25.47 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{mm}^2\)
If the length of a rod has becomes half by cutting it, how much load it can bear before breaking as compare to before?

Breaking Stress: It is also called ultimate tensile stress. It is the maximum stress a material can stand before it breaks.

From the definition, it is clear that the breaking stress of a rod does not depend on its length. So, If we half the length of the rod, the force required to break it will remain the same. So it can bear the same load as before.
The property of a material by virtue of which it can be beaten into thin sheets is called as:
The property of a material to be beaten or rolled into plates is known as malleability and the material is called malleable material.
When a stress applied to the body is increased beyond the maximum value and removed after some time, it is noted that:
the body will come back to its original position
the body cannot return to its original position completely

The material starts long its elastic nature once the stress crosses the elastic limit. Thus, the body does not regain its original position when the external force is removed.

Therefore, the body cannot return to its original position when stress applied to the body is increased beyond the maximum value and removed after some time.
Which among the following is a material that does not show elastic after effect?

Steel, copper, and rubber are known to regain their original shape and size after being deformed within the elastic limit.

Quartz is highly elastic in nature as it does not get deformed easily. As a result, quartz has practically no elastic after effect.
The following four wires made of the same material. Which of these will have the largest extension when the same tension is applied?

Young's Modulus is given by,

\(\begin{aligned} & Y=\frac{\text { stress }}{\text { strain }} \\ & \Rightarrow Y=\frac{\frac{F}{A}}{\frac{\Delta L}{L}} \\ & \Rightarrow \Delta L=\frac{F L}{Y A}\end{aligned}\)

As material is same, so \(Y\) will be the same for each wire, and load applied (F) is also equal for each wire.

\(\Rightarrow \Delta L \propto \frac{L}{A} \propto \frac{L}{\pi\left(\frac{d^2}{4}\right)}\)

\(\Rightarrow \Delta L \propto \frac{L}{d^2} \ldots \text { (i) }\)

For option(A),

\(L=500 \mathrm{~mm}, d=0.5 \mathrm{~mm}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{L}{d^2}=2000\)

For option(B),

\( L=1000 \mathrm{~mm}, d=1 \mathrm{~mm} \)

\( \Rightarrow \frac{L}{d^2}=1000\)

For option(C),

\(L=2000 \mathrm{~mm}, d=2 \mathrm{~mm} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{L}{d^2}=500\)

For option(D),

\(\mathrm{L}=3000 \mathrm{~mm}, \mathrm{~d}=3 \mathrm{~mm}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\mathrm{L}}{\mathrm{d}^2}=\frac{1000}{3}\)

From Eq.(i), the order of extension produced in the wires will be:

(A) \(>\) (B) \(>\) (C) \(>\) (D)

Since \(\frac{L}{d^2}\) value is highest for the wire in option (A), it will have the maximum extension.

There are two wires of the same material and the same length while the diameter of second wire is two times the diameter of first wire, then ratio of extension produced in the wires by applying the same load will be:
4 : 1
1 : 2
1 : 1
2 : 1

As both wires are of same length and same materials it means they both have same young modulus and let it will be  Y

By using formula of young modulus,

\(Y=\frac{\frac{F}{A}}{\frac{l}{L}}\)

As both have same young modulus it means

\(\mathrm{Y}_1=\mathrm{Y}_2\)

\(\frac{F L}{A_1 l_1}=\frac{F L}{A_2 l_2}\)

As, both have same length and weight, therefore

\(r_1^2 l_1=r_2^2 l_2,\)

\(\frac{l_1}{l_2}=\left[\frac{r_2}{r_1}\right]^2=4\)

\(l_1: l_2=4: 1\)
Which one of the following is not a unit of Young's modulus?

Young's modulus Y \(=\frac{\text { Stress }}{\text { Strain }}\)

As we know, strain is a dimensionless quantity whereas stress is defined as force per unit area.

Stress has units as \(\mathrm{Nm}^{-2}\) (SI unit), Dyne \(\mathrm{cm}^{-2}\) (cgs unit) or Pascal (Pa). 

As Young's modulus has same unit as that of stress, thus \(\mathrm{Nm}^{-1}\) is not a unit of Young's modulus.
According to Hook's law of elasticity, within the elastic limit, if stress is increased, then the ratio of stress to strain:

According to Hook's law of elasticity, within the elastic limit stress is proportional to the strain.

∴ The ratio of stress to strain is always constant. If stress is increased, strain will also increase so that their ratio remains constant.
When a elastic material with Young's modulus Y is subjected to a stretching stress S. The elastic energy stored per unit volume of the material is:

The elastic energy stored per unit volume of the material is

\(\mathrm{U}=\frac{1}{2} \times \) stress \( \times\)  strain 

Now, Young's modulus is

\(Y=\frac{\text { stress }}{\text { strain }}\)

\(\therefore\) strain \(=\frac{\text { stress }}{Y}\)

\(\therefore U=\frac{1}{2} \times\) stress \( \times \frac{\text { stress }}{Y}=\frac{\text { stress }^2}{2 Y}=\frac{\mathrm{s}^2}{2 Y}\)
Which of the following statements is correct for ductile materials.
Large deformation takes place between elastic limit and fracture point
Ductile materials are those which can be drawn into wires as they deform by a significant amount between elastic limit and fracture point.
What does the area under the stress-strain curve represent?

Area under the stress-strain curves represents toughness. Total deformation is given by the net strain multiplied by original length. Modulus of elasticity is the ratio of stress to strain under elastic limit.
Which of the following stresses causes change in density, as long as force acts on the body?

Volumetric stress is due to forces applied on the surface of a body from all directions such force is along normal at each point. This causes a change in volume while mass, obviously, remains the same. So, there is a slight change in density. Note that it is negligible but this change of density doesn’t occur in any other type of stresses, as the change in longitudinal length is compensated by change in lateral length in case of longitudinal stresses.
A wire of length L and cross section area A is made of a material of Young's modulus Y. If the wire is stretched by an amount x, the work done is:

Work done in stretching a wire is

\(W=\frac{1}{2} \times \) load \( \times\) extension

\(W=\frac{1}{2} F x\)

\(W=\frac{1}{2} \frac{Y A x}{L} .x\)

\(W=\frac{Y A x^2}{2 L}\)

The edge of an aluminium cube is 10 cm long. One face of the cube is firmly fixed to a vertical wall. A mass of 100 kg is then attached to the opposite face of the cube. The shear modulus of aluminium is 25 GPa. What is the vertical deflection of this face?

Given,

side of cube, \(L=10 \mathrm{~cm}=\frac{10}{100}=0.1 \mathrm{~m}\)

\(\therefore\) Area of each face, \(A=(0.1)^2=0.01 \mathrm{~m}^2\)

Tangential force acting on the face,

\(F =100 \mathrm{~kg}=100 \times 9.8=980 \mathrm{~N}\)

\(\text { Shear modulus, } \eta =25 \mathrm{GPa}=25 \times 10^9 \mathrm{Nm}^{-2}\)

Since shear modulus is given as:

\(\eta=\frac{\text { Tangential stress }}{\text { Shearing strain }}\)

\(=\frac{F}{A \eta}=\frac{980}{0.01 \times 25 \times 10^9}=3.92 \times 10^{-6}\)

Lateral Strain \(=\) Shearing strain \(\times\) Side of the cube

\(=3.92 \times 10^{-6} \times 0.1\)

\(=3.92 \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{~m}\)
A solid copper cube, initially 10 cm on each edge, is subjected to a hydraulic pressure of 7.0 × 106 Pa. What is the volume contraction of the cube under this pressure?

Length of an edge of the solid copper cube, \(l=10 \mathrm{~cm}=\) \(0.1 \mathrm{~m}\)

Hydraulic pressure, \(p=7.0 \times 10^6 \mathrm{~Pa}\)

Bulk modulus of copper, \(B=140 \times 10^9 \mathrm{~Pa}\)

Bulk modulus, \(B=\frac{p}{\frac{\Delta V}{V}}\)

Where, \(\frac{\Delta V}{V}=\) Volumetric strain

\(\Delta V=\) Change in volume

\(V=\) Original volume.

\(\Delta V=\frac{p V}{B}\)

Original volume of the cube, \(V=l^3\)

\(\therefore \Delta V  =\frac{p l^3}{B}\)

\(=\frac{7 \times 10^6 \times(0.1)^3}{140 \times 10^9}\)

\(=5 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{~m}^3\)

\(=5 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\)

Therefore, the volume contraction of the solid copper cube is 5 × 10–2 cm–3.
How much should the pressure on a litre of water be changed to compress it by 0.10%?

Volume of water, V = 1 L

It is given that water is to be compressed by 0.10%.

\(\therefore\) Fractional change, \(\frac{\Delta V}{V}=\frac{0.1}{100 \times 1}=10^{-3}\)

Bulk modulus, \(B=\frac{p}{\frac{\Delta V}{V}}\)

\(p=B \times \frac{\Delta V}{V}\)

Bulk modulus of water, \(B=2.2 \times 10^9 \mathrm{Nm}^{-2}\)

\(p  =2.2 \times 10^9 \times 10^{-3}\)

\(=2.2 \times 10^6 \mathrm{Nm}^{-2}\)

Therefore, the pressure on water should be \(2.2 \times 10^6\) \(\mathrm{Nm}^{-2}\).

The value of acceleration due to gravity at Earth's surface is \(9.8 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\). The altitude above its surface at which the acceleration due to gravity decreases to \(4.9 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\), is close to: (Radius of earth \(=6.4 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~m}\) )

Given:

Acceleration due to gravity at Earth's surface is  \(g_{0}=9.8 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\). 

Acceleration due to gravity decreases to \(g=4.9 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\).

We know that radius of earth (R) \(=6.4 \times 10^{6}\) m

Let height is h

\(g=\frac{g_{0}}{\left(1+\frac{h}{R}\right)^{2}}\)

Put all the given values in above formula:

\(4.9=\frac{9.8}{\left(1+\frac{h}{6.4 \times 10^{6}}\right)^{2}}\)

\(\Rightarrow 1+\frac{h}{6.4 \times 10^{6}}=\sqrt{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow h=(\sqrt{2}-1) 6.4 \times 10^{6} \)

\(\Rightarrow h=(1.414-1) 6.4 \times 10^{6} \)

\(\Rightarrow h=2.6 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~m}\)

The gravitational field in a region is given by \(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{E}}=(3 \hat{\mathrm{i}}-4 \hat{\mathrm{j}}) \mathrm{N} \mathrm{kg}^{-1}\). Find out the work done(in joule) in displacing a particle by \(1 \mathrm{~m}\) along the line \(4 \mathrm{y}=3 \mathrm{x}+9\).

Given:

\(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{E}}=(\hat{\mathrm{i}}-4 \hat{\mathrm{j}}) \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{kg}\)

Force acting as unit mass \(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{F}}=\mathrm{m} \overrightarrow{\mathrm{E}}\)

\(=(3 \hat{\mathrm{i}}-4 \hat{\mathrm{j}}) \mathrm{N}\)

The motion of unit mass along the line \(4 \mathrm{y}=3 \mathrm{x}+9\)

\(\mathrm{y}=\frac{3 \mathrm{x}+9}{4}\)

At \(x_{2}=1, \quad y_{2}=\frac{12}{4}=3\)

Let the point be \(A\).

At \(\mathrm{x}_{1}=0, \quad \mathrm{y}_{1}=\frac{9}{4}\)

So vector \(\vec{d}\) from \(A\) to \(B\)

\(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{d}} =\left(\mathrm{x}_{2}-\mathrm{x}_{1}\right) \hat{\mathrm{i}}+\left(\mathrm{y}_{2}-\mathrm{y}_{1}\right) \hat{\mathrm{j}} \)

\(=(1-0) \hat{\mathrm{i}}+\frac{(3-9)}{4} \hat{\mathrm{j}} \)

\(=\hat{\mathrm{i}}+\left(\frac{12-9}{4}\right) \hat{\mathrm{j}} \)

\(=\hat{\mathrm{i}}+\frac{3}{4} \hat{\mathrm{j}}\)

Now work done is moving unit mass a long given line is:

\(\mathrm{W}=\overrightarrow{\mathrm{F}} \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathrm{d}}\)

\(=(3 \hat{\mathrm{i}}-4 \hat{\mathrm{j}}) \cdot\left(\hat{\mathrm{i}}+\frac{3}{4} \hat{\mathrm{j}}\right) \)

\(=3 \hat{\mathrm{i}} \times \hat{\mathrm{i}}-4 \hat{\mathrm{j}} \times \frac{3}{4} \hat{\mathrm{j}} \)

\(=3-3=0\)

Four identical particles of mass \(M\) are located at the corners of a square of side ' \(a\) '. What should be their speed if each of them revolves under the influence of others' gravitational field in a circular orbit circumscribing the square?

For the net gravitational force on a particle.


\(F=\frac{G M^{2}}{a^{2}} \).....(1)

\(F_{1}=\frac{G M^{2}}{(a \sqrt{2})^{2}}\)

\(=\frac{G M^{2}}{2 a^{2}}\).....(2)

According to fig.:

For net force, \(F=\sqrt{F^{2}+F^{2}}+F_{1}\)

\(F_{net}=F \sqrt{2}+F_{1}\).....(3)

Put values from (1) and (2) in (3).

\(F_{net}=\frac{G M^{2}}{a^{2}} \sqrt{2}+\frac{G M^{2}}{2 a^{2}}\)

This force will act as centripetal force. Distance of particle from centre of circle is \(\frac{\mathrm{a}}{\sqrt{2}}\).

\(\mathrm{~F}_{\mathrm{C}}=\frac{\mathrm{Mv}^{2}}{\mathrm{r}} \)

\(\mathrm{r}=\frac{\mathrm{a}}{\sqrt{2}}\)

\(F_{C}=F_{net}\)

\(\frac{\mathrm{Mv}^{2}}{\frac{\mathrm{a}}{\sqrt{2}}}=\frac{\mathrm{GM}^{2}}{\mathrm{a}^{2}}\left(\frac{1}{2}+\sqrt{2}\right) \)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{v}^{2}=\frac{\mathrm{GM}}{\mathrm{a}}\left(\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2}}+1\right) \)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{v}^{2}=\frac{\mathrm{GM}}{\mathrm{a}}(1.35) \)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{v}=1.16 \sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{GM}}{\mathrm{a}}}\)

Two planets orbit the Sun in circular orbits, with their radius of orbit as \(\mathrm{R}_{1}=\mathbf{R}\) and \(\mathrm{R}_{2}=4 R\). Ratio of their periods \(\left(\frac{T_{1} }{ T_{2}}\right)\) around the Sun will be:

Given:

\(1^{\text {st }}\) orbital radius \(\left(R_{1}\right)=R\), and \(2^{\text {nd }}\) orbital radius \(\left(R_{2}\right)=4 R\)

According to the law of periods: The square of the period of revolution (T) of any planet around the sun is directly proportional to the cube of the semimajor axis of the orbit i.e., \(T^{2} \propto R^{3}\)

\( \mathrm{T}^{2} \propto \mathrm{R}^{3} \)

\(\Rightarrow\left(\frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}\right)^{2}=\left(\frac{R_{1}}{R_{2}}\right)^{3} \)

\(\Rightarrow\left(\frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}\right)^{2}=\left(\frac{R}{4 R}\right)^{3}\)

\(=\frac{1}{64} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}=\left(\frac{1}{64}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}\)

\(=\frac{1}{8}\)
Kepler's II law is a consequence of:

Kepler's Second Law: The line that joins any planet to the sun sweeps equal areas in equal intervals of time.


The planet \(\mathrm{P}\) moves around the sun in an elliptical orbit. The shaded area is the area \(\Delta A\) swept out in a small interval of time \(\Delta t\). i. e.,

\(\frac{\mathrm{dA}}{\mathrm{dt}}=\) constant

From above it is clear that Kepler's second law (law of areas) is nothing but a statement of conservation of angular momentum.
A satellite that is revolving around the earth has a minimum distance from earth equal to \(r_{1}\) and a maximum distance of \(r_{2}\), then the time period of the satellite will be?

According to keplars law: The square of time period of revolution of the planet is proportional to the cube of semi major axis of the ellipse traced by the planet.

\(T^{2} \propto\) \(a^{3}\)

This equation is modified to:

\(T^{2}=\frac{2 \pi a^{3}}{G M}\)

\(\mathrm{T}=\) Time period of the satellite

\(\mathrm{a}=\) semi-major axis

\(\mathrm{G}=\) gravitational constant

\(\mathrm{M}=\) mass of the earth (in this case)

Here, \(\frac{2 \pi}{G M}\) is the constant of proportionality.

So: \(T=\frac{\sqrt {2 \pi}}{\sqrt{GM}}a^{\frac{3}{2}}\).....(1)

Now, we know the semi-major axis of an elliptical path is the arithmetic mean of the minimum and the maximum distance covered by the planet.

Therefore, in this case:

\(r_{1}=\) Minimum distance covered

\(r_{2}=\) Maximum distance covered

So,

\(a=\frac{r_{1}+r_{2}}{2}\)

Put this value in (1).

\(T=\frac{\sqrt {2 \pi}}{\sqrt{GM}} \left( \frac{r_{1} +r_{2}}{2} \right)^{\frac{3}{2}}\)

Thus, this is the value of the time period of the satellite.
The mean distance of mars from the sun is 1.5 times that of earth from the sun. What is approximately the number of years required by mars to make one revolution about the sun?

Kepler's law tells us that the square of the Time period (T) of a satellite is proportional to the cube of its distance (R) from the orbiting planet.

∴T2 ∝R3

The time period of earth's orbit around the sun is 1 year, and assuming the mean distance between earth and sun as R, we can write the mean distance between mars and the sun as 1.5R.

Let, T be the time period of mars' orbit around the sun.

Thus from the above proportionality,

T2R3is a constant.

(1 year)2R3=T2(1.5R)3

T2 = (1.5)3

T=(1.5)32

 ≈1.85 years

What would be the escape velocity (in km/s) from a planet of mass \(\frac{1}{4}\)th of mass of earth and radius \(\frac{1}{9}\)th the radius of the earth, if escape velocity from the earth is 11 km/s?

Given:

Mass of a planet (Mp) = \(\frac{1}{4}\)th of the mass of the earth \((M_e)\)

The radius of a planet (rp) = \(\frac{1}{9}\)th the radius of the earth \((r_e)\) 

Escape velocity from the earth (Ve) = 11 km/s

The escape velocity on the earth is given by:

\( V_{e}=\sqrt{\frac{2 G M_{e}}{r_{e}}}\).....(1)

The escape velocity on the planet is given by:

\( V_{p}=\sqrt{\frac{2 G M_{p}}{r_{p}}}\)

\(=\sqrt{\frac{2 G \frac{M_{e}}{4}}{\frac{r^{e}}{9}}} \)

\(=\sqrt{\frac{2\left(9 G M_{e}\right)}{4 e_{e}}}\)

\(=\frac{3}{2} \sqrt{\frac{2 G M_{e}}{r_{e}}}\).....(2)

On dividing equation (1) and (2), we get:

\( \frac{V_{e}}{V_{p}}=\frac{2}{3} \)

\(\Rightarrow V_{p}=\frac{3}{2} V_{e}\)

\(=\frac{33}{2} km / s\)
The escape velocity on earth is 11.2 km/s. Find the escape velocity on a planet having mass twice that of earth and radius half that of the earth.

Given:

Escape velocity: The minimum velocity required to escape the gravitational field of earth is called escape velocity. It is denoted by \(V_{ e }\).

The escape velocity on earth is given by:

\(V_{e}=\sqrt{\frac{2 G M}{R}}=11.2\) km/s.....(1)

Where, \(G\) is universal gravitational constant, \(M\) is mass of the earth and \(R\) is radius of the earth.

Mass of the planet \(\left(M^{\prime}\right)=2 M\)

Radius of the planet \(\left(R^{\prime}\right)=\frac{R }{ 2}\)

So, The escape velocity on the planet is given by:

\(V_{e}^{\prime}=\sqrt{\frac{2 G M^{\prime}}{R^{\prime}}}\)

\(=\sqrt{\frac{2 G \times 2 M}{\frac{R}{2}}}\)

\(=2 \times \sqrt{\frac{2 G M}{R}}\)

From (1).

\(=2 \times 11.2\)

\(=22.4\) km/s
What would be the acceleration due to gravity (in m/s2) of a planet of radius 6000 km, if escape velocity from it is 12 km/s?

Given: 

\(V _{ e }=12 ~km / s =12 \times 10^{3} ~m / s\)

Radius \(( R )=6000~km =6 \times\) \(10^{6} ~m\)

The escape velocity on earth is given by:

\(V_{e}=\sqrt{\frac{2 G M}{R}}\)

As we know, \(G M=g R^{2}\)

\( V_{e}=\sqrt{2 g R}\)

By squaring both sides, we get,

\(\left(V_{e}\right)^{2}=2 g R\)

\(\Rightarrow g=\frac{V_{e}^{2}}{2 R}\)

Put all the given values in above formula:

\( g=\frac{\left(12 \times 10^{3}\right)^{2}}{2 \times 6 \times 10^{6}}\)

\(=12 m / s ^{2}\)
What is the maximum height attained by an object that is projected from the surface of the earth with a velocity that is one-third of the escape velocity? (Radius of the Earth=R)

We know that,

\(\text { Escape velocity } (v _{ e })=\sqrt{\frac{2 G M}{R}} \ldots \ldots . .(1)\)

Where \(G\) is the Universal Gravitational Constant and \(M\) is the mass of the Earth.

Velocity of the object.

\(v=\frac{v_{e} }{ 3}=\sqrt{\frac{2 G M}{9 R}}\)..... (2)

The initial kinetic energy of the object.

\(K E_{1}=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}=\frac{1}{2} m \frac{2 G M}{9 R} \ldots\)... (3)

The initial potential energy of the object.

\(P E_{1}=-\frac{G M m}{R} \ldots \ldots .\) (4)

Here \(m\) is the mass of the object.

Let \(h\) be the maximum height reached by the object. when the object reaches the maximum height, its velocity becomes zero which is why its final kinetic energy \(= KE _{2}=0 \ldots \ldots \ldots\) (5)

At the maximum height, the potential energy of the object \(\left( PE _{2}\right)=-\frac{G M m}{R+h} \ldots \ldots .(6)\)

According to the law of conservation of energy,

\(KE _{1}+ PE _{1}= KE _{2}+ PE _{2}\)

(From \(3,4,5\), and 6)

\(\frac{1}{2} m \frac{2 G M}{9 R}-\frac{G M m}{R}=0-\frac{G M m}{R+h}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{9 R}-\frac{1}{R}=-\frac{1}{R+h}\)

\(\Rightarrow -\frac{8}{9 R}=-\frac{1}{R+h} \)

\(\Rightarrow  8 R+8 h=9 R\)

\(\Rightarrow h=\frac{R}{8}\)

Thus, the maximum height reached will be \(\frac{R }{ 8}\).
What is the escape speed from the surface of the Earth equal to?

The escape velocity on earth is given by:

\(V_{e}=\sqrt{\frac{2 G M}{R}}\)

As we know, \(G M=g R^{2}\)

\( V_{e}=\sqrt{\frac{2 g R^{2}}{R}}=\sqrt{2 g R}\)

For earth, \(g=9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\) and \(R=6.4 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~m}\)

\( V_{e}=\sqrt{2 \times 9.8 \times 6.4 \times 10^{6}} \)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{e}}=11.2 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{s}}=11.2 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{s}\)
A satellite orbits the earth in a circle of radius 8000 km. At that distance from the earth, the velocity of the satellite is (g = 9.8 m/s2)

Given:

Radius of the earth \((r)= 6400 \mathrm{~km}\)

Radius of the orbit \((r)=8000 \mathrm{~km}\)

\(\mathrm{g}=9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}=9.8 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\)

So,

\(V_{o}=\sqrt{\frac{g R^{2}}{r}}\)

Put all the given values in above formula:

\(=\sqrt{\frac{9.8 \times 10^{-3} \times 6400^{2}}{8000}} \)

\(=\sqrt{50.17}\)

\(=7.08 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{s}\)
The time period of a geostationary satellite that moves in a circular orbit around the earth in the equatorial plane is:

The time period of a geostationary satellite that moves in a circular orbit around the earth in the equatorial plane is 24 hours.

Geostationary Satellite:

  • The satellite which appears stationary relative to the earth is called a geostationary or geosynchronous satellite.
  • A geostationary satellite always stays over the same place above the earth such a satellite is never at rest.
  • Such a satellite appears stationary due to its zero relative velocity w.r.t. that place on earth.
  • The orbit of a geostationary satellite is known as the parking orbit.
  • It takes 24 hours to complete one revolution of the earth by satellite, which is the same time as the earth takes to rotate once on its axis.
  • A geostationary orbit has an orbital period equal to the Earth's rotational period i.e., 23 hours, 56 minutes, 4 seconds, which is rounded off to 24 hours.
A geostationary orbit is chosen for communication satellites because:
It is stationary at one point in space
With respect to a spot on earth, it looks stationary
This orbit provides earth's coverage of more than \(50 \%\) using a single satellite
The length of \(4700 \mathrm{~km}\) is convenient for launching

A geostationary orbit is chosen for communication satellites because with respect to a spot on earth, it looks stationary.

  • A geostationary orbit is a circular orbit approx. 36,000 kilometres above the Earth's equator and following the direction of the Earth's rotation. A satellite in geostationary orbit lies in the same plane as the equator. This implies that an object that is placed in this orbit has an orbital period equal to the Earth's rotational period and therefore stays at the same spot with respect to the Earth.
  • Weather satellites are, therefore, placed in the geostationary orbit as the position allows them to observe and monitor weather conditions that vary on a short timescale.

Applications of Geostationary (GEO) satellite includes:

  • Broadcasting: mainly TV
  • Point to Multi-point communications
  • Mobile Services

Direction: Given question consists of two statements, one labelled as the 'Assertion (A)' and the other as 'Reason (R)'. You are to examine these two statements carefully and select the answers to these items using the codes given below.

Assertion (A): A geostationary orbit is the same as a geosynchronous orbit.

Reason (R): A geostationary orbit does not necessarily lie in the equatorial plane.
Both \(A\) and \(R\) are individually true and \(R\) is the correct explanation of \(A\)
Both \(\mathrm{A}\) and \(\mathrm{R}\) are individually true but \(\mathrm{R}\) is NOT the correct explanation of \(\mathrm{A}\)

The satellite that is placed at a height of \(36000 \mathrm{~km}\) from the earth's surface, their time period of rotation is the same as earth rotation period i.e. 24 hours that's why it looks stationary w.r.t earth and it is called geostationary orbit.

The time period of any satellite \((T)=\sqrt{\frac{4 \pi^{2}(R e+h)^{3}}{\mu}}\)

Where \(\mathrm{Re}=\) earth radius \(=6400 \mathrm{~km}\)

\(h=\) height from the surface of the earth

\(\mu=\) Kepler's constant \(=3.986 \times 10^{5}\)

for geostationary orbit \(\mathrm{h}=36000 \mathrm{~km}\)

\(\mathrm{T}=\sqrt{\frac{4 \pi^{2}(6400+36000)^{3}}{3.986 \times 10^{5}}} \simeq 86400 \mathrm{sec} \)

\(\simeq 24 \text { hour }\)

The geostationary orbit lies on the same plane as the equator (inclination = 0), the geosynchronous satellites have a different inclination (not 0 ).

This is the key difference between the two types of orbits.
A __________ is a repeater between many transmitting stations and many receiving stations.

A communication satellite is a repeater between many transmitting stations and many receiving stations.

Communications satellite

  • It is an artificial satellite that relays and amplifies radio telecommunications signals via a transponder; it creates a communication channel between a source transmitter and a receiver at different locations on Earth. We can say satellite works as a repeater between transmitting and receiving antenna. Communications satellites are used for television, telephone, radio, internet, and military applications. Based on working it has two types:
  • Active Satellites
  • Passive Satellites
Which of the following statements about gravitational force is NOT correct?
It is experienced by all bodies in the universe
It is a dominant force between celestial bodies
It is a negligible force for atoms
It is the same for all pairs of bodies in our universe

Gravitational force is not the same for every pair of bodies, it will vary with different masses and distance between them. So option (D) is wrong.

Newton's law of gravitation:

Every particle in the universe attracts every other particle with a force, which is directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them.

If two bodies with mass \(m_{1}\) and \( m_{2}\), where \(r\) be the distance between two masses, the gravitational force:

\(F \propto \frac{m_{1} m_{2}}{r^{2}}\)

\(\Rightarrow F=G \frac{M m}{r^{2}}\)

Where, \(\mathrm{F}=\) force of attraction

\(G=6.67 \times 10^{-11} \mathrm{~N}-\mathrm{m}^{2} / \mathrm{kg}^{2}\) (gravitational constant)

\(\mathrm{m}_{1}\) and \(m_{2}=\) mass of bodies

\(r=\) distance between them.

Unit of ' \(\mathbf{G}\) ' is \(\mathrm{Nm}^{2} / \mathrm{kg}^{2}\)

Dimensional formula of \(G\) is \(\left[\mathrm{M}^{-1} \mathrm{~L}^{3} \mathrm{~T}^{-2} \mathrm{~J}\right]\).

If three particles, each of mass \(\mathrm{M}\) are placed at the three corners of an equilateral triangle of side a, the force exerted by this system on another particle of mass \(M\) is placed at the midpoint of a side is:

The gravitational force at \(\mathrm{D}\) due to \(\mathrm{C}\) is:

\(\Rightarrow F_{D C}=G \frac{M M}{\left(\frac{a}{2}\right)^{2}}=G \frac{4 M^{2}}{a^{2}}\)

The gravitational force at D due to \(B\) is

\( F_{D B}=G \frac{M M}{\left(\frac{a}{2}\right)^{2}}\)

\(=G \frac{4 M^{2}}{a^{2}}\)

Since \(F_{B D}\) and \(F_{D C}\) are equal in magnitude but they are opposite in direction, therefore they will cancel out each other.

So,

\( A D^{2}=\sqrt{A C^{2}-C D^{2}} \)

\(\Rightarrow A D^{2}=\sqrt{a^{2}-\frac{a^{2}}{4}}\)

\(=\sqrt{\frac{3 a^{2}}{4}}\)

The gravitational force at \(\mathrm{D}\) due to \(\mathrm{A}\) is

\( F_{D C}=G \frac{M M}{A D^{2}}\)

\(=G \frac{4 M^{2}}{3 a^{2}}\)

Find the magnitude of the gravitational force between two protons separated by a distance of \(1 A\). It is given that \(m_{p}=\frac{5 }{ 3} \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{~kg}\). \(\mathrm{G}=20 / 3 \times 10^{-11} \mathrm{Nm}^{2} \mathrm{~kg}^{-2}\)

Given:

\(m_{1}=m_{2}=m_{p}=\frac{5 }{ 3} \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{~kg}\)

\(\mathrm{r}=1 \mathrm{~A}^{o}=1 \times 10^{-10} \mathrm{~m}\), and \(\mathrm{G}=\frac{20}{3} ×10^{-11}\) Nm2 Kg-2

The equation for the gravitational force of attraction is given by,

\( F=\frac{G m_{1} m_{2}}{r^{2}} \)

\(\Rightarrow F=\frac{G m_{p}^{2}}{r^{2}} \)

Put all the given values in above formula:

\( F=\frac{\frac{20}{3} \times 10^{-11}\left(\frac{5}{3} \times 10^{-27}\right)^{2}}{\left(1 \times 10^{-10}\right)^{2}}\)

\(=\frac{42×500 \times 11^{-65}}{27 \times 10^{-20}}\)

\(=0.01851 \times 10^{-42} \)

\(\Rightarrow F \approx \frac{10^{-42}}{54}\)
Three-point masses each of mass \(\mathrm{m}\) are placed at the three corners of an equilateral triangle of side \(x\). Find the resultant force acting on anyone particle at the corner.

Let the fig be like.

Force on one mass \(\mathrm{m}\) is like. We know that each angle of the equilateral triangle is \(60^{\circ}\).

So Apply vector addition of these two forces,

\(F_{\text {resultant }}=\sqrt{F^{2}+(-F)^{2}+2 F \cdot(-F) \cos 120^{\circ}} \)

\(=\sqrt{2 F^{2}-2 F^{2}\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right)}\)

\(=\sqrt{3 F^{2}}\)

\(=F \sqrt{3}\)

Since, \(F=G \frac{m^{2}}{x^{2}}\)

So, \(F \sqrt{3}=\frac{\sqrt{3} G m^{2}}{x^{2}}\)

What would be the acceleration (in \(\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\) ) due to gravity on a planet whose mass is \(\frac{1 }{ 7}\) th the mass of earth and radius half the radius of earth? \(\left(\mathrm{g}=9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\right)\)

Given:

Mass of planet, \(\mathrm{Mp}=\frac{1 }{ 7} \mathrm{x}\) mass of earth \(\mathrm{M}\)

The radius of the planet, \((R p)=\frac{1 }{ 2}\) radius of the earth

The acceleration due to gravity is given by

\( g_{P}=\frac{G M_{P}}{R_{P}^{2}}\)

\(=\frac{G \times\left(\frac{M}{7}\right)}{\left(\frac{R}{2}\right)^{2}}\)

\(=\frac{4 G M}{7 R^{2}} \)

\(g_{P}=\frac{4}{7} g\) \((\because g=9.8)\)

\(=5.6 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \)
A body freely falling from rest has acquired a velocity 'v' after it falls through a distance ' \(h\) '. The distance it has to fall down further for its velocity to become double is:

In the question, we are given a body that falls from rest. This body gains velocity \(\mathrm{v}\) after falling through a height h. We are asked to find the distance that the body has to fall down such that its velocity becomes double.

Let us note down all the quantities that are given in the question. It is said that the body is falling from rest, so it means the initial velocity of the body is zero.

\(u=0 ~m / s\)

The final velocity on reaching a height \(\mathrm{h}\) is \(\mathrm{v~m} / \mathrm{s}\) and also, the acceleration of a body under free fall is that due to gravity,

\(a=g\)

Now Newton's equation of motion given by,

\(v^{2}-u^{2}=2 a s\)

Substituting the given values,

\(v^{2}-0=2 g h \)

\(\therefore h=\frac{v^{2}}{2 g}\).....(1)

Let \(\mathrm{h}\) ' be the height the body reaches at which its velocity is doubled, then,

\((2 v)^{2}-0=2 g h^{\prime} \)

\(\Rightarrow h^{\prime}=\frac{4 v^{2}}{2 g}\)

From (1),

\(h^{\prime}=4 h\)

The distance it has to travel from height h so as to double the velocity is given by,

\(4 h-h=3 h\)

It has to travel \(3 \mathrm{h}\) distance more to gain double the velocity.

Therefore, at four times the given height, the velocity gets doubled.
What is the force required to produce an acceleration of \(9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\) on a body of weight \(9.8 \mathrm{~N}\) ? Take \(\mathrm{g}=9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\)

Given:

Acceleration \((\mathrm{a})=9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\)

Weight of the body \(=9.8 \mathrm{~N}\)

Since, Weight of the body \(=\mathrm{mg}\)

Mass \(=\) Weight \(/ \mathrm{g}\)

\(=\frac{9.8 }{ 9.8}\)

\(=1 \mathrm{~kg}\)

We know that,

\(F=m \times a \)

\(\Rightarrow F=1 \mathrm{~kg} \times 9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \)

\(\Rightarrow F=9.8 \text { Newton }\)
At what height above the surface of the earth does the weight of an object reduce by \(1 \%\). Given the radius of the earth is \(6400 .\)

Given that radius of earth is \(6400 \mathrm{~km} .~1 \%\) decrease in gravity.

Acceleration due to gravity above the surface of earth at height \(\mathrm{h}\) is given

\(g^{\prime}=g\left(1-\frac{2 h}{R_{e}}\right)\).....(1)

Here, \(g^{\prime}=0.99 \mathrm{~g}\)

Put the given values in (1).

\( 0.99=1-\frac{2 h}{R_{e}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{2 h}{R_{e}}=0.01\)

\(\Rightarrow h=\frac{0.01}{2} R_{e}\)

Put the value of \(R_{e}\) in above equation.

\( h=\frac{0.01}{2} \times 6400\)

\(=32 \mathrm{Km}\)

\(\mathrm{h}=32 \mathrm{Km}\)
The ratio of kinetic energy and the potential energy of the satellite rotating around the earth is:

We know that the kinetic energy of the satellite is given as,

\( E_{K}=\frac{G M m}{2 r}\)

We know that the potential energy of the satellite is given as,

\( E_{P}=\frac{G M m}{r}\)

Where \(r=\) distance of the satellite from the center of the planet. By equation (1) and equation (2).

\(\frac{E_{K}}{E_{P}}=\frac{1}{2}\)

Two satellites of masses \(3 \mathrm{M}\) and \(\mathrm{M}\) orbit the earth in the circular orbits of radii \(\mathrm{r}\) and \(3 \mathrm{r}\) respectively. The ratio of their orbital velocities is:

Given:

Two satellites of masses \(3 \mathrm{M}\) and \(\mathrm{M}\)

Circular orbits of radii \(\mathrm{r}\) and \(3 \mathrm{r}\)

\(\mathrm{v} \propto \sqrt{\frac{1}{\mathrm{r}}}\)

This means the orbital velocity depends on the orbital radius of the satellite but not on the mass of the satellite. From the relation, we thus form an equation,

\(\frac{\mathrm{v}_{1}}{\mathrm{v}_{2}}=\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{r}_{2}}{\mathrm{r}_{1}}}\)

In the question,

\(\frac{\mathrm{r}_{1}}{\mathrm{r}_{2}}=\frac{1}{3}\)

Then,

\(\frac{\mathbf{v}_{1}}{\mathbf{v}_{2}}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{1}\)
A body weighs \(72 \mathrm{~N}\) on the surface of the earth. What is the gravitational force on it due to earth at a height equal to half the radius of the earth from the surface?

Given:

At the surface of Earth, weight \(\mathrm{W}=72 \mathrm{~N}\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{F}=\mathrm{mg}=72 \mathrm{~N}\)

\(\mathrm{~m}=\frac{72}{10}=7.2 \mathrm{~kg}\)

Now, at some height, h acceleration due to gravity is given as

\(\mathrm{g}^{\prime}=\frac{\mathrm{g}}{\left(1+\frac{\mathrm{h}}{\mathrm{R}}\right)^{2}}\)

Here, \(\mathrm{h}=\frac{\mathrm{R}}{2}\)

\(\mathrm{g}^{\prime}=\frac{\mathrm{g}}{\left(1+\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}}\)

\(=\frac{4}{9} \mathrm{~g}\)

\(=4.44 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\)

Now, the force experienced by the body at half of the radius of the earth is given by:

\(\mathrm{F}^{\prime}=\mathrm{mg}^{\prime}\)

\(=7.2 \times 4.44\)

\(=31.97 \mathrm{~N} \)

\(\approx 32 \mathrm{~N}\)
At which height above earth's surface value of \(g\) is same as in a mine \(100 \mathrm{~km}\) deep.

Given:

\(d=100m\)

We know that:

The variation of with height is:

\(\mathrm{g}=\mathrm{g}\left(1-\frac{2 \mathrm{~h}}{\mathrm{r}}\right)\)

The variation ofgwith depth is \(g=g\left(1-\frac{d}{r}\right)\)

Equating the above two equation we get the height as:

\(\mathrm{h}=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{2} \)

\(=50 \mathrm{~km}\)
At what depth below the surface of the earth acceleration due to gravity ′g′ will be half of its value at 1600 km above the surface of the earth?

Given:

\(h=1600\) Km

\(R=6400\) Km

Let us consider that the value of \(g\) outside the earth is \(g^{'}\). Therefore, variation of \(g\) outside the earth is given by;

\(g^{'}=g\left(1-\frac{2 h}{R}\right)\)

Here, \(g=\) Acceleration due to gravity \(\left(10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\right), h=\) Height above the earth surface \((1600 \mathrm{~km})\) and \(R=\) Radius of the earth \((6400)\).

Now, putting all the given values in the equation we will find the acceleration due to gravity outside the earth.

\( g^{'}=10\left(1-\frac{2 \times 1600}{6400}\right) \)

\(\Rightarrow g^{'}=5 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\)

Now, let us consider the variation of acceleration due to gravity \(g\) inside the earth be \(g^{''}\). Again, putting the same formula we will find the variation inside the earth.

\(g^{''}=g\left(1-\frac{2 h}{R}\right)\)

Now, it is said to us that, acceleration due to gravity inside the earth will be half of acceleration outside the earth.

\(g^{''}=\frac{g^{'}}{2} \)

\(\Rightarrow g^{''}=\frac{5}{2}=2.5 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\)

Now, putting all the value in the equation we will find the acceleration due to gravity inside the earth.

\(2.5 m s^{-2}=10\left(1-\frac{h}{R}\right)\)

After evaluating the value we will get it as

\(\frac{1}{4}=1-\frac{h}{6400}\)

Now, from here we will find the \(h\).

\(h=\frac{3}{4} \times 6400 \mathrm{~km} \)

\(\therefore h=4.8 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~m}\)

Find the pressure \(P\) at the bottom of the liquid container if the atmospheric pressure is \(P _0\) and height of the liquid column is \(H\). (density of liquid is \(\rho\) and \(g\) is the gravitational const.)

Given that atmospheric pressure is \(P _0\). So

Pressure at the upper surface of the liquid will be \(P_0\).

As we go below by height \(h\) inside the liquid, the pressure inside a liquid increases by:

\(P _1=\rho gH\)

So total pressure at the bottom of the liquid is:

\(P =\) atmospheric pressure at upper surface + pressure due to liquid in the container

\( P=P_0+P_1\)

\( P=P_0+\rho g H\)
Three liquids of densities \(8 d , 3 d\), and \(4 d\) are mixed together at the same volume. Find density of the mixture.

Given that both the fluids have the same volume. Let it is \(V\).

The density of first fluid \(=d_1\)

Mass of first fluid \(= m _1= V d _1\)

The density of second fluid \(=d_2\)

Mass of second fluid \(= m _2= V d_2\)

The density of third fluid \(=d_3\)

Mass of third fluid \(= m _3=V d_3\).

Now after mixing the fluids.

Density of mixture \(=\frac{\text { Total mass }}{\text { Total volume }}\)

Density of mixture \(=\frac{m_1+m_2+m_3}{V+V+V}\)

From eq (i), (ii), and (ii)

Density of mixture \(=\frac{V d_1+V d_2+V d_3}{3 V}\)

Density of mixture \(=\frac{d_1+d_2+d_3}{3}\)

Density of mixture \(=\frac{8 d+3 d+4 d}{3}=5 d\)
The liquid mainly used in a barometer is:

Mercury is used inside a barometer. Mercury is preferred over other liquids because of its high density.

The high density of mercury makes it expand less and thus rise to a reasonable height to measure atmospheric pressure.
What is the relation between the pressure at points \(A, B, C\), and \(D\) if the liquid in all the shapes is up to the same height?

The pressure inside a liquid is given by:

\(P=\rho g h\)

Therefore the Pressure inside the liquid at a point depends on-

1. \(\rho\) the density of the liquid,

2. \(h\) the depth of the liquid from the free surface,

3. \(g\) the acceleration due to gravity. It does not depend on the shape of the container.

From the formula, \(P =\rho\) gh pressure at the bottom of all the surfaces will be the same. However, all four will have a different shape and a different amount of water.

So Pressure inside liquids at a point does not depend on the shape of the container and pressure at A, B, C, D will be the same i.e.

\(P_A=P_B=P_C=P_D\)
Pascals is the SI unit of pressure and 1 bar \(=10^5\) Pascals
A hydraulic lift has two pistons. If the area of piston B is greater than the area of piston \(A\), find a relation in their masses.

Given that area of the piston, \(B\) is greater than the area of piston A i.e. \(A_A<A_B\)

From Pascal's Law, the pressure inside the liquid will be equal at every place. So the pressure at \(A\) and \(B\) will be equal.

\(P _{ A }= P _{ B }\)

Pressure \(=\frac{\text { Force }}{\text { Area }} \)

\(\frac{F_A}{A_A}=\frac{F_B}{A_B} \)

\(\frac{m_A g}{A_A}=\frac{m_B g}{A_B} \)

\( \frac{m_A g}{A_A}=\frac{m_B g}{A_B} \)

\( \frac{m_A}{m_B}=\frac{A_A}{A_B} \)

if \( A _{ A }< A _{ B } \)

Then \( m _{ A }< m _{ B }\)
The statement, "The pressure in a fluid at rest is the same at all points if they are at the same height" represents which of the following?
The statement, "The pressure in a fluid at rest is the same at all points if they are at the same height" represents pascal's law.
A glass bottle filled with liquid will break at the bottom if a stopper is forced into its open end as per:

Pascal's principle: Pascal's Law is the principle of transmission of fluid-pressure.

It says that "a pressure exerted anywhere in a point of the confined fluid is transmitted equally in all directions throughout the fluid".
The pressure at the bottom of a liquid tank is not proportional to the:

According to the formula of the fluid pressure;

\(\Rightarrow\) Pressure \((P)=\rho g h\)

Pressure on the surface only depends on density of fluid, acceleration due to gravity and the height of the fluid.

The pressure is independent of area of the liquid surface.
Hydraulic lift is an equipment based on application of ___________.

A hydraulic lift is a device for moving objects using the force created by pressure on a liquid inside a cylinder that moves a piston upward. Incompressible oil is pumped into the cylinder, which forces the piston upward. The principle for hydraulic lifts is based on Pascal's law.
The mercury column in the barometer has a height of about \(cm\) at sea level.

A barometer is a scientific instrument that is used to measure air pressure.

The height of the level of mercury in the tube is nearly \(76 cm\) above the free level of mercury in the trough.

Formula to calculate the atmospheric pressure is, \(P _{ a }=\rho g h\)

The reading in the barometer can be calculated by the formula

\(h=\frac{P_a}{\rho g}\)

Where, \(\rho=\) density of mercury, \(g=\) acceleration due to gravity, and \(h=\) vertical distance.

From above it is clear that the mercury column in the barometer has a height of about \(76 cm\) at sea level.
The dynamic lift due to spinning is called viscosity:

Dynamic lift is the force that acts on a body, such as an airplane wing, a hydrofoil, or a spinning ball, by virtue of its motion through a fluid. The dynamic lift due to spinning is called the Magnus effect.
Instrument to measure atmospheric pressure is called:

A barometer is used to measure atmospheric pressure.

A thermometer is used to measure the temperature. A Calliper is used to measure the dimensions(length or diameter) of an object. An ammeter is used to measure electric current.
The S.I unit of relative density is:

Density: The mass per unit volume is called density.

Density \((\rho)=\) Mass \(( m )\) Nolume \(\left( m ^3\right)\)

The SI unit of density is \(kg / m ^3\).

Relative density: It is the ratio of a density of an object to the density of water at \(4^{\circ} C \left(1000 kg m ^{-3}\right)\).

Relative density \(\left(\rho_{\text {relative }}\right)=\frac{\text { Density of fluid }\left(\rho_{\text {fluid }}\right)}{\text { Density of water }\left(\rho_{\text {water }}\right)}\)

It is a unitless term or quantity.

The relative density is the ratio of two densities. So it is a unitless quantity.
Filter pumps or aspirators work on the principle of:

Filter pumps or aspirators work on the principle of Bernoulli's principle.

In fluid dynamics, Bernoulli's principle states that an increase in the speed of a fluid occurs simultaneously with a decrease in pressure or a decrease in the fluid's potential energy.
____________ is based on conservation of mass in streamline flowing incompressible fluid.

Continuity equation is based on conservation of mass in streamline flowing incompressible fluid.

Continuity equation: The law of conservation of mass states that mass can neither be created nor be destroyed.

The rate at which mass enters the region \(=\) Rate at which mass leaves the region + Rate of accumulation of mass in the region. 

The above statement can be expressed analytically in terms of velocity and density field of flow and the resulting expression is known as the equation of continuity or the continuity equation.
A fluid is flowing through a horizontal pipe. When pipe is constricted then:

According to the continuity equation:

When the pipe is constricted (means area decreased):

\(A _1 V _1= A _2 V _2=\) Constant 

The velocity will increase.

\(P+\frac{1}{2} \rho v^2+\rho g h=\) constant (Bernoulli's principle)

Here pipe is horizontal (so \(h\) remains constant).

\(V\) is increasing so the pressure will decrease.

Thus when the pipe is constricted then velocity increases and pressure decreases.
The relation between pressure and velocity of an incompressible, non-viscous and streamline fluid flowing horizontally is given by-

It can be expressed as Mathematically:

Which of the following statement is correct regarding turbulent flow of fluids?
At a point velocity is not same with time
All of the above are correct statements.

Option (A): If Reynold's number is greater than 4000 , then it will be turbulent flow.

It means velocity should be more than a limit (critical velocity) for turbulent flow.

If velocity is low, the flow can be laminar.

Option (B): Turbulent flow is not regular. It does not flow in layers. It can flow in any direction at any speed. So it is an irregular flow.

Option (C): If we make a point in the turbulent flow, at different the velocity of flow will different at this point. So all the statements are correct.
The speed of a particle always remains the same
The velocity of a particle always remains the same
The kinetic energies of all the particles arriving at a given point are the same
The moments of all the particles arriving at a given point are different

Path \(A B C\) is streamlined as shown in the figure and \(v_1, v_2\), and \(v_3\) are the velocities of the liquid particles at \(A, B\), and \(C\) point respectively.

From above it very much clear that the speed and the velocity of a particle in a streamline flow are the same as the preceding element passes through that point but it may change as it moves ahead.

All the particles arriving at a point in a streamline flow have the same velocity. Therefore all the particles arriving at that point will have the same kinetic energy and the same momentum.
The Bernoulli's Principle is based on the:

Bernoulli's principle is based on the law of Conservation of Energy. 

Bernoulli's Principle is given by Swiss physicist Daniel Bernoulli derived an expression relating the pressure to fluid speed and height in 1738 .

It states that the sum of the pressure energy, kinetic energy, and potential energy per unit volume of an incompressible, non-viscous fluid in a streamlined flow remains constant.
Blood flow in artery can be explained by:

Blood flow in an artery can be explained by Bernoulli's principle.

Bernoulli's relation may be stated as: As we move along a streamline the sum of the pressure \(( P )\), the kinetic energy per unit volume \(\left(\frac{\rho v^2}{2}\right)\), and potential energy per unit volume ( \(\left.\rho gh \right)\) remain constant.

Bernoulli's principle is given by the equation: \( P+\frac{1}{2} \rho v^2+\rho g h=K \) (const.) 

The dimension of \(\frac{P}  K\) is the same as:

Given equation is \(P+\frac{1}{2} \rho v^2+\rho g h=K\) (const.)

So, the dimension of \([ P ]\) will be equal to the dimension of \(\left[\frac{1}{2} \rho v^2\right]\) and \([\rho g h]\) and \(K\) (const. )

\([P]=\left[\frac{1}{2} \rho v^2\right]=[\rho g h]=[K]\)

The dimension of \([ P ]=\) The dimension of \([ K ]\)

So the dimension of \(\left[\frac{P}{K}\right]=\) dimensional less or no dimension.

There the quantity \(\frac{P}{K}\) is a dimensionless quantity.
low viscosity and incompressible fluids in turbulent flow
high viscosity and compressible fluids in streamline flow
low viscosity and compressible fluids in turbulent flow
low viscosity and incompressible fluids in streamline flow

Bernoulli's principle states that the sum of pressure energy, kinetic energy, and potential energy per unit volume of an incompressible, non- viscous fluid in a streamlined irrotational flow remains constant along a streamline.

This means that in steady flow the sum of all forms of mechanical energy in a fluid along a streamline is the same at all points on that streamline.

\(P+\frac{1}{2} \rho V^2+\rho g h=A\) constant

From the above definition, it is clear that Bernoulli's equation holds only for low viscosity and incompressible fluids in streamline flow.

The property of an ideal fluid is/are:
Ideal Fluid: An ideal fluid (also called a perfect fluid) is a fluid that has no viscosity, incompressible, and has zero surface tension. A perfectly ideal fluid does not exist.
Through an opening of diameter \(1 cm\) at the bottom of a tank water is flowing out at \(20 m / s\). What must be the height (in \(m\) ) of water in that tank?

Given- diameter of the tank at the bottom \(=1 cm\) and velocity of water \(=20 m / s\)

The velocity with which water will come out through a sharp-edged hole at the bottom of a tank filled to a depth ' \(h\) ' is

\(\Rightarrow v=\sqrt{2 g h}\)

By squaring both and on rearranging for \(h\), we get

\(\Rightarrow h=\frac{v^2}{2 g}=\frac{20 \times 20}{2 \times 10}=20 m\)
Which of the following principle is based on the conservation of energy?

Option (A): According to the principle of continuity,

\(\rho VA =\) constant

\(\rho_1 V_1 A_1=\rho_2 V_2 A_2\)

So, Mass passing from one cross-section area will be the same for another cross-section area.

So here mass is conserved in the principle of continuity.

Option (B): Bernoulli's Principle basically states that the sum of all the energies (Pressure energy, gravitational potential energy, and kinetic energy of fluid) is constant.

One form of energy can be converted into another but the total sum will remain constant.
