One end of a cylindrical pipe of cross-section \(6.6 cm ^2\) has 14 holes each of radius \(1 mm\). If water is flowing in the pipe at \(1 m / min\) then what is the speed (in \(m / s\) ) of efflux through the holes?

Given that:

\( A_1=6.6 cm ^2=6.6 \times 10^{-4} m ^2 \)

\( v_1=1 m / min =(1 / 60) m / sec\)

Radius of holes \((r)=1 mm =10^{-3} m\)

\(A_2=\pi r^2=3.14 \times\left(10^{-3}\right)^2=3.14 \times 10^{-6} m ^2\)

There are a total of 14 holes:

Let the \(v\) is the speed of efflux through the holes:

So \(A_1 v_1=A_2 v_2\)

\(6.6 \times 10^{-4} \times(1 / 60)=3.14 \times 10^{-6} \times 14 \times v\)

So \(v =0.25 m / s\)
The velocity of flow of water in a horizontal pipe is \(5.0 m / sec\). The velocity head of water is ( \(g =\) \(10 m / sec ^2\) )

Mathematically for a unit volume of liquid flowing through a pipe.

\(P+\rho g h+\frac{1}{2} \rho v^2=\) const 

\(\frac{P}{\rho g}+h+\frac{v^2}{2 g}=\) const

Where \(P / pg\) is called pressure head, \(h\), is called gravitational head and \(v ^2 / 2 g\) is called velocity head

So, we have to calculate here velocity head

Velocity \(v =5.0 m / sec\)

Acceleration due to gravity \(g =10 m / sec ^2\)

Velocity head \(=\frac{v^2}{2 g} \)

\(\Longrightarrow \) Velocity head \(=\frac{(5 m / s )^2}{2 \times 10 m / s ^2} \)

\( \Rightarrow \) Velocity head \(=1.25 m\)
The farther away a planet is from the Sun:
longer it takes to orbit the Sun once
shorter it takes to orbit the Sun once

According to Kepler's second law of planetary motion, the planets move faster near the Sun and move slowly away from the Sun to cover equal areas in equal intervals of time.

Therefore, as the distance of the planet increases from the Sun, it will orbit the Sun slower and hence, takes a longer time.

Hence, the farther away a planet is from the Sun, the longer it takes to orbit the Sun once.
According to Kepler's law of motion, the planets orbit around the sun in a/an orbit.

Kepler's first law explains that planets orbit the sun in a path described as an ellipse. It is not circular.

That is why the distance between the earth and the sun is not constant. It is changing.
The force that binds the atmosphere around the Earth is the:
The force that binds the atmosphere around the Earth is the force of gravity.
If the distance between two objects made three times, the new force of gravitation between them will become:

The gravitational force between two objects is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them. If the distance is increased, the force reduces.

Let, the mass of the two bodies be \(\mathrm{m}_1\) and \(\mathrm{m}_2\) respectively and the distance between their centers be \(r\).

Then, the gravitational force between them is given by:

\(F=\frac{G m_1 m_2}{r^2}\)

Now, when the distance between them is made three times, the gravitational force will be:

\(F^{\prime}=\frac{G m_1 m_2}{(3 r)^2}\)

\(\Rightarrow F^{\prime}=\frac{G m_1 m_2}{9 r^2}\)

\(\Rightarrow F^{\prime}=\frac{F}{9}\)
Which of the following statement is true regarding gravitational attraction between man and Earth?
Man and Earth have the same acceleration
Man and Earth pull each other with the same force
The acceleration of man is independent on Earth's mass
The magnitude of attraction exerted by the man is greater that of earth

We know that gravitational force is dependent on the mass of the two bodies and the distance between their centres.

The gravitational attraction exerted by the man on Earth and by the Earth on man is the same:

\(F=\frac{G M m}{R^2}\) in both the case.

So, the magnitude of the force will be the same.

Thus, man and Earth pull each other with the same force.

The value of \(\mathrm{G}\) in a vacuum is \(6.67 \times 10^{-11} \mathrm{~N} \mathrm{~m}^{-2} \mathrm{~kg}^{-2}\). What will be the change in its value in liquid of density \(10^{-4} \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}\) ?

The law of gravitation is called universal as it is the same for all bodies in the universe irrespective of the medium, temperature, and other physical conditions of the body. Hence, the gravitational constant does not depend on the nature of the medium in which the masses are kept.

Thus, in the given case, the value of \(\mathbf{G}\) in a dense medium will be the same.

Therefore, the change \(=G_{\text {vacuum }}-G_{\text {dense }}=6.67 \times 10^{-11}-6.67 \times 10^{-11}=\) zero .
The value of the gravitational constant in the cgs unit is-
The value of the gravitational constant in the cgs unit is \(6.67 \times 10^{-8}\) cgs unit.
Which among the following statement is true about the acceleration due to the gravity?
It is maximum at the poles and minimum at the equator.
It is maximum at the equator and minimum at the poles.
It is uniform everywhere on the Earth.
It is uniform everywhere in the Universe.

Acceleration due to gravity is inversely proportional to the radius of the Earth. The Earth is an elliptical object that is flat at the poles (radius is less) and is a little more bulged at the equator(radius is more).

Therefore, \(g\) is maximum at the poles and minimum at the equator.
If the gravity of the Earth becomes zero, then for a body:
Neither the weight nor the mass gets affected

When the gravity of the Earth becomes zero, acceleration due to gravity " \(\mathrm{g}\) " also becomes zero.

Hence, the weight of the body becomes zero. Mass is the amount of substance in the body. It will not change.
Intensity of gravitational field at the centre of a hollowsphere will be:

At the centre of the hollow sphere,

\(\Rightarrow d=R\)

So the gravitational acceleration at the centre of a hollow sphere,

\(\Rightarrow g^{\prime}=g\left(1-\frac{d}{R}\right)\)

\(\Rightarrow g^{\prime}=g\left(1-\frac{R}{R}\right)\)

\(\Rightarrow g^{\prime}=g(1-1)\)

\(\Rightarrow g^{\prime}=0\)

At a certain height \(\mathrm{H}\) above the surface of the earth, the value of acceleration due to gravity equals that at a depth of \(200 \mathrm{~km}\) into the surface. Then the distance \(\mathrm{H}\) from the surface of Earth is:

Given,

At \(\mathrm{h}=\mathrm{H}\) and \(\mathrm{d}=200 \mathrm{~km}\), the acceleration due to gravity has the same value i.e. \(\mathrm{g}^{\prime}=\mathrm{g}^{\prime \prime}\)

\(\Rightarrow g\left(1-\frac{d}{R_e}\right)=g\left(1-\frac{2 H}{R_e}\right)\)

\(\Rightarrow\left(R_e-d\right)=\left(R_e-2 H\right)\)

\(\Rightarrow d=2 H\)

\(\Rightarrow 200=2 H\)

Therefore, \(\mathrm{H}=100 \mathrm{~km}\)
The gravitational acceleration on the earth with________ increase in height above earth's surface and________ with increase in depth below the surface.

Gravitational acceleration at height \(h\) is given by

\(g_h=\frac{g}{\left(1+\frac{h}{R}\right)^2}\)

As we go above \(h\) increases, so \(\left(1+\frac{h}{R}\right)^2\) increases.

As \(\left(1+\frac{h}{R}\right)^2\) increases, \(g_h=\frac{g}{\left(1+\frac{h}{R}\right)^2}\) decreases.

So, as we go above the earth's surface, the gravitational acceleration decreases.

Gravitational acceleration at the depth \(d\) is given by:

\(g_d=g\left(1-\frac{d}{R}\right)\)

As we go below the earth's surface, the depth 'd' will increase.

As d increases, \(\left(1-\frac{d}{R}\right)\) will decrease.

As \(\left(1-\frac{d}{R}\right)\) decreases, \(g\left(1-\frac{d}{R}\right)\) will also decrease.

So \(g_d\) will decrease with depth.

So as we go below the earth's surface, the gravitational acceleration decreases.
The acceleration due to gravity reduces by \(75 \%\) at a height \(h\) above the surface of the earth. Find \(h\) in terms of radius of earth (R).

Given,

Acceleration due to gravity reduces by \(75 \%\).

So the acceleration due to gravity at height a height (h) \(=25 \%\) of \(g=0.25 \mathrm{~g}=\mathrm{g} / 4\)

Acceleration due to gravity at height \(\left(g^{\prime}\right)=\frac{g}{\left(1+\frac{h}{R}\right)^2}=\frac{g}{4}\)

\(1+\frac{h}{R}=2\)

\(\Rightarrow\frac{h}{R}=1\)

\(\Rightarrow{h}={R}\)
A box weighs \(432 \mathrm{~N}\) on the surface of Earth. If \(\mathrm{R}\) is the radius of the Earth, what is the weight of the box at a height of 3R above the Earth's surface?

Given that:

Weight of the object on Earth, \(\mathrm{W}=432 \mathrm{~N}=\mathrm{mg}\)......(1)

Acceleration due to gravity at height \(\mathrm{h}=3 \mathrm{R}\) from the surface of Earth, \(g^{\prime \prime}=g\left(1+\frac{h}{R_e}\right)^{-2}\)

\(\Rightarrow g^{\prime \prime}=g\left(1+\frac{3 R}{R}\right)^{-2}=g(4)^{-2}=\frac{g}{16} m / s^2\)

Using, \(\mathrm{W}=\mathrm{mg}\)

The weight of the box at \(3 \mathrm{R}, W^{\prime \prime}=m g^{\prime \prime}=m \times \frac{g}{16}=\frac{W}{16}\)......(2)

Substituting (1) in (2),

\(W^{\prime \prime}=\frac{423}{16}=27 N\)

Two objects of mass \(m_1\) and \(m_2\) are separated by a distance \(r\). The ratio of the magnitudes of gravitational force between them and the gravitational potential energy of any one object at that distance is:

The gravitational force between \(\mathrm{m}_1\) and \(\mathrm{m}_2, F=\frac{G m_1 m_2}{r^2}\)

The gravitational potential energy of mass \(\mathrm{m}_1\) at a distance \(\mathrm{r}, \mathrm{U}=-\frac{G m_1 m_2}{r}\)

Ratio of magnitudes \(=\frac{F}{U}=\frac{\frac{G m_1 m_2}{r^2}}{\frac{G m_1 m_2}{r}}=\frac{1}{r}\)
The gravitational potential energy of an object is negative. It means_______.
Object is not bounded to the system
Negative gravitational potential energy is not possible

Work is done (+ve) by the gravitational field in bringing a mass from infinity and

Potential energy \(=-\) work done

So potential energy is negative at the earth surface

In other words, work has to be done on a body if the body has to be taken away from the gravitational field of the earth.

If work is not on the body to take it away, it will be bounded to the system.

So, Negative energy means a body is bounded to some system, and some energy is required to come out from the bond (or system).

The potential energy of a particle in a force field is: \(U=\frac{A}{r^2}-\frac{B}{r}\), where \(\mathrm{A}\) and \(\mathrm{B}\) are positive constants and \(\mathrm{r}\) is the distance of the particle from the center of the field. for stable equilibrium the distance of the particle is:

Give - potenital energy \(U=\frac{A}{r^2}-\frac{B}{r}\)

Relationship between force and potential energy is given by

\(F=-\frac{d U}{d r}\)

\(\Rightarrow F=-\frac{d U}{d r}=-\frac{d\left(\frac{A}{r^2}-\frac{B}{r}\right)}{d r}\)

\(\Rightarrow F=-\left(\frac{-2 A}{r^3}+\frac{B}{r^2}\right)=\left(\frac{2 A}{r^3}-\frac{B}{r^2}\right)\)

In equilibrium \(\mathrm{F}=0\), then

\(\Rightarrow 0=\left(\frac{2 A}{r^3}-\frac{B}{r^2}\right) \Rightarrow \frac{2 A}{r^3}=\frac{B}{r^2}\)

\(\Rightarrow r=\frac{2 A}{B}\)

The distance at which both the particle will be in stable equilibrium is \(r=\frac{2 A}{B}\).

A body of mass ' \(m\) ' is raised through a height ' \(h\) ' above surface of the Earth so that the increase in its \(\mathrm{PE}\) is \(\mathrm{mgR} / 5\), where \(\mathrm{R}\) is the radius of Earth, then \(\mathrm{h}=\)

The body of mass \(m\) is raised by height \(h\),

So \(r=R+h\)

Increase in PE \(=\mathrm{m} \mathrm{g} \mathrm{R/5}\)

Since \(g=\frac{G M}{R^2}\)

So \(\mathrm{GM}=\mathrm{g} \mathrm{R}^2\)

PE on the earth surface, \(P E=-\frac{G M m}{R}=-\frac{(g R^2) m}{R}=-m g R\)

At height \(\mathrm{h}, \mathrm{PE}=-\mathrm{mg} \mathrm{R}+\frac{\mathrm{mg} \mathrm{R}}{{5}}=\frac{-4 \mathrm{mg} \mathrm{R}}{5}\)

\(P E=-\frac{G M m}{r}=\frac{-(g R^2) m}{(R+h)}=\frac{4 m g R}{5}\)

\(\frac{\mathrm{R}}{(\mathrm{R}+\mathrm{h})}=\frac{4}{5}\)

\(5 \mathrm{R}=4 \mathrm{R}+4 \mathrm{~h}\)

So \(h=\frac{R}{4}\)
The mass of stone \(A\) is more than stone \(B\), then the ratio of the escape velocity of stone \(A\) to stone \(B\) from the surface of the earth is:

As we know that the escape velocity from the surface of the earth is given as,

\(\Rightarrow v_e=\sqrt{\frac{2 G M}{R}}\).........(1)

Where \(\mathrm{G}=\) gravitational constant, \(\mathrm{M}=\) mass of the earth, and \(\mathrm{R}=\) radius of the earth

By equation 1 it is clear that the escape velocity depends upon the mass and the radius of the earth but it is independent of the mass, shape, and size of the projected body.

So the escape velocity for stone \(A\) and stone \(B\) will be equal.

Therefore the ratio of the escape velocity of stone \(A\) to stone \(B\) from the surface of the earth is 1.
What is the relationship between the orbital velocity \(v_0\) and escape velocity \(v_e\) ?

The orbital velocity of a satellite is given by:

\(v_o=\sqrt{g R}\)

The escape velocity is given by:

\(v_e=\sqrt{2 g R}\)

So \(v_e=v_o \sqrt{2}\)
The sizes of planet \(A\) and planet \(B\) are equal but if the density of planet \(A\) is more than planet \(B\), then which planet will have more escape velocity?
Both the planet will have equal escape velocity

Given \(R_A=R_B=R\), and \(\rho_A>\rho_B\)

As we the escape velocity from the surface of the planet is given as,

\(\Rightarrow v_e=\sqrt{\frac{2 G M}{R}}\)........(1)

Where \(\mathrm{G}=\) gravitational constant, \(\mathrm{M}=\) mass of the planet, and \(\mathrm{R}=\) radius of the planet

If the radius of the planet is constant then,

\(\Rightarrow v_e \propto \sqrt{M}\).....(2)

The mass of the planet is given as,

\(\Rightarrow M=\rho \times \frac{4}{3} \pi R^3\)

\(\Rightarrow \rho_A>\rho_B\)

\(\Rightarrow M_A>M_B\)

So \(v_{e A}>v_{e B}\)

Where \(v_{e A}=\) escape velocity for planet \(A\), and \(v_{e B}=\) escape velocity for planet \(B\)

So we can say that planet A will have more escape velocity.
A missile is launched with velocity lesser than escape velocity. Total kinetic and potential energy of missile will be:

If a missile is launched with velocity \(v\) from the surface of the earth, then its kinetic energy at the surface of the earth is given as,

\(\Rightarrow K E=\frac{1}{2} m \times v^2\)........(1)

Where \(m=\) mass of the missile

The potential energy of the missile at the surface of the earth is given as \((h=0)\)

\( \Rightarrow U=-\frac{G M m}{R+h}\)

\(\Rightarrow U=-\frac{G M m}{R}\).......(2)

If a missile is launched with a velocity lesser than the escape velocity, then after launching it will remain in the gravitational field.

The gravitational potential energy bound the object with the earth's gravitational field, so the gravitational potential energy will be higher than the kinetic energy when the projected velocity is less than the escape velocity.

The total energy is given as,

\(\Rightarrow E=\frac{1}{2} m \times v^2-\frac{G M m}{R}\)

Since,

\(\Rightarrow \frac{G M m}{R}>\frac{1}{2} m \times v^2\)

So,

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{E}<0\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{E}=\text { negative }\)

The escape velocity of a body of mass \(m\) on Jupiter is \(v\) when it is thrown vertically upward. If the mass of the body is increased to \(2 \mathrm{~m}\) and it is projected at an angle of \(60^{\circ}\) on the Jupiter, then its escape velocity will become?

The escape velocity is given as,

\(\Rightarrow v_e=\sqrt{\frac{2 G M}{R}}\)......(1)

Where \(\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{e}}=\) escape velocity, \(\mathrm{G}=\) gravitational acceleration, \(\mathrm{M}=\) mass of the planet and, \(\mathrm{R}=\) radius of the planet

The escape velocity is independent of the mass of the projected body and the angle of projection.

So when the mass of the body is increased to \(2 \mathrm{~m}\) and the angle of projection is \(60^{\circ}\), the escape velocity will not change.
A satellite moving in a circular orbit around earth has a total (kinetic + potential) energy \(E_0\). Its potential energy will be:

Given - The total energy of a system \((T)=E_0\)

\(\Rightarrow E_o=-\frac{G M m}{2 r}\).......(1)

As we know, Gravitational Potential Energy \((U)\) is

\(\Rightarrow U=-\frac{G M m}{r}\)

Equation 1 can be written as

\(\Rightarrow E_o=\frac{U}{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow U=2 E_0\)

The time period of the satellite is T hours. As the satellite was moved into a new orbit the time period of the satellite changed to 8 times its initial value. what is the amount of increase of radius of the orbit is:

Given \(T_1=T\) hours, \(T_2=16 T, R_1=R\)

The ratio of the time period is given by

\(\Rightarrow \frac{T_1}{T_2}=\left(\frac{R_1}{R_2}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}\)

The above equation can be rewritten as

\(\Rightarrow \frac{R_1}{R_2}=\left(\frac{T_1}{T_2}\right)^{\frac{2}{3}}\)

Substituting the given values

\(\Rightarrow \frac{R}{R_2}=\left(\frac{T}{8 T}\right)^{\frac{2}{3}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{R}{R_2}=\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{R}_2=4 \mathrm{R}\)
The time period of a satellite of earth is 5 hours. If the separation between the earth and the satellite is increased to 4 times the previous value, the new time period will become:

Given that,

The time period \(\left(T_1\right)=5\) hours

The final radius of the path of the satellite \(\left(r_2\right)=4 r\)

For the satellite:

\(\begin{aligned} & \mathrm{T}^2 \propto \mathrm{r}^3 \\ & \frac{\mathrm{T}_1^2}{\mathrm{~T}_2^2}=\frac{\mathrm{r}_1^3}{\mathrm{r}_2^3} \Rightarrow \frac{5^2}{\mathrm{~T}_2^2}=\frac{\mathrm{r}_1^3}{\left(4 \mathrm{r}_1\right)^3} \Rightarrow \frac{25}{\mathrm{~T}_2^2}=\frac{1}{4^3} \\ & \mathrm{~T}_2^2=25 \times 64 \Rightarrow \mathrm{T}_2=5 \times 8=40 \text { hours }\end{aligned}\)
The energy of an orbiting satellite cannot be zero because-
the object escapes to infinity when the energy is zero
the speed of the satellite decreases when the energy is zero
the satellite will fall towards the earth when the energy is zero

The total energy of an orbiting satellite is inversely proportional to the radius of the orbit.

Satellites are always at a finite distance from the earth and hence their energies cannot be positive or zero.

The energy of the satellite can be zero when the orbital radius is infinity i.e. the object escapes to infinity.
The satellite commonly used for remote sensing and meteorology is:

A camera fixed on a polar satellite can view small strips of the earth in one orbit. Adjacent strips are viewed in the next orbit and thus, the whole earth can be viewed strip by strip during the entire day.

Since they are low-altitude satellites, it gives good resolution data of the regions on Earth. Hence, polar satellites are commonly used for remote sensing and meteorology.
For a geostationary satellite the angular speed in units of radians per hour is:

Time is taken by Earth to rotate = Time taken by geostationary satellite to revolve \(=24\) hours.

One revolution \(=360^{\circ}\)

Angular speed \(=\frac{\text { angular distance }}{\text { time taken }}\)

\(=\frac{360^{\circ}}{24}=\frac{2 \pi}{24}=\frac{\pi}{12} \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{hr}\left(\because 360^{\circ}=2 \pi\right.\) radians \()\)
A geosynchronous satellite should be placed at a height such that it moves:
from west to east in equatorial plane
from west to east in polar plane
from south to north in polar plane
from south to north in equatorial plane

A geostationary satellite is also known as a geosynchronous satellite as it matches the Earth's rotation.

We know that the Earth rotates from the west-east direction. So, in order to make the satellite appear stationary from Earth, it will have to orbit the Earth from west to east in an equatorial plane.
The specific latent heat of vaporization of a substance is the quantity of heat needed to change unit mass from:
liquid to vapour with a change of temperature
liquid to vapour without a change of temperature
vapour to liquid without a change of temperature
vapour to liquid with a change of temperature
Specific latent heat of vapourization is the quantity of heat required to convert unit mass of a substance from liquid to vapour state without change of temperature.
The heat given to a substance during the phase change is called:
The heat given to the substance during the phase change is called latent heat. It can be either the latent heat of fusion or the latent heat of vaporization depending upon the phase change.
The scale of temperature in which the temperature is only positive is:

Since the absolute zero temperature is 0 Kelvin. Below this temperature, we can't measure in kelvin scale. So the Kelvin scale of temperature is only positive. The Kelvin scale has the ice point at  273K and the steam point at 373K.
When we rub our palms they gets heated but to a maximum temperature because:

Friction arises when there is a relative motion between two objects. As we know that when two objects come in contact or if there is a relative motion between them, then frictional force comes into play. Therefore when we rub two hands a frictional force is produced, therefore the temperature of palm becomes above the atmosphere so it starts losing heat to the surroundings.

The frictional force is produced where there is a kinetic force acting between the two objects.
___________is a device used to measure exchange of heat in a closed system.

The device which is used to measure the heat for exchange in a closed system is called a calorimeter.

The vessel of a calorimeter is made up of a metallic material because it is a good conductor of electricity.It is used to measure the heat exchanged between the system and surrounding inside a closed system.
A pressure cooker works on the principle of:
Elevation of boiling point of water by application of pressure
Making the food-grains softer by application of pressure
Making the food-grains softer by application of pressure and temperature
Keeping the food-grains inside steam form a longer time

When we give heat to the pressure cooker then due to an increase in temperature the steam generated in the vessel. Due to this generated steam, the pressure inside the vessel increases. So the food gets cooked soon.

Thus by the application of pressure the boiling point of the water increases. There is no relation between food-grains with the boiling point of water.
A glass is heated first and then it is cooled down suddenly. It breaks due to:

When the glass heated, it expands and the density decreases. When it is suddenly cooled, its density tries to decrease in some part of the glass and in some part it remains as it is. Due to this density difference, the glass breaks.
The kink near the bulb of a clinical thermometer:
allows the level of mercury to fall easily when taken out of our body.
prevents the mercury level from falling on its own when taken out of our body
allows the level of mercury to rise when taken out of our body

The thermometer is generally placed inside the human body and taken out to see the reading. While reading, it is necessary that the mercury does not fall back to show the room temperature.

This is taken care of by the kink which prevents the mercury level from falling on its own when taken out of our body.

In resistance thermometer, the resistances at \(0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) and \(100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) are \(5.8 \Omega\) and \(8.4 \Omega\) respectively. The temperature corresponding to \(6.2 \Omega\) resistance is:

Given, \(R_0=5.8 \Omega, R_{100}=8.4 \Omega\), and \(R=6.2 \Omega\)

For the resistance thermometer,

\(\Rightarrow t=\frac{R-R_o}{R_{100}-R_o} \times 100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

\(\Rightarrow t=\frac{6.2-5.8}{8.4-5.8} \times 100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{t}=15.4^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)
A gas is kept in a closed container and temperature of the container is increased then the number of collisions between the gas molecules will:

When the temperature of the gas molecules is increased then the kinetic energy of the molecules increases and hence the velocity of the molecules increases. Due to increase in velocity of the molecules, the molecules takes less time to reach the wall and at other molecules and hence the number of collisions increases.
Volume expansion coefficient of a gas equal to:
Inversely proportional to square root of temperature

The ideal gas law is given by

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{PV}=\mathrm{nRT}\).........(1)

The above equation can be rewritten as

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{T}=\frac{n R}{P V}\)

From equation (1), it is clear that at constant pressure, temperature and volume are the only two terms that can vary, hence equation 1 can be rewritten as

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{P} \Delta \mathrm{V}=\mathrm{nR} \Delta \mathrm{T}\)

The above equation can be rewritten as

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\Delta V}{\Delta T}=\frac{n R}{P}\).......(2)

The L.H.S of the equation represents the rate of change of volume with respect to change in temperature, hence it is the coefficient of volume expansion i.e.,

\(\Rightarrow \alpha_V=\frac{\Delta V}{\Delta T}\)

\(\therefore\) Equation (2) can be written as

\(\Rightarrow \alpha_V=\frac{n R}{P}=\frac{1}{T}\)

The coefficient of volume expansion is \(\alpha_V=\frac{1}{T}\)
The gap kept between rail lengths on railway tracks is based on the phenomenon of:

The rails are generally made of metals. The gap between the rails provides a space for the metal to expand during the summer and contract during the winter season. Therefore, the gaps between rail lengths are to accommodate the expansion and contraction of metal due to thermal expansion.
The pendulum of a clock is made of:

invar is an alloy of iron and nickel,and it has a negligible small co- efficient of linear expansion. the pendulum of a clock is made of invar so that neither the clock loses time in summer due to expansion ,nor it gains time in winter due to contraction.
During thermal expansion of a material, the heat energy supplied to the material is utilized in:
decreasing the kinetic energy and increasing the potential energy of molecules.
heating up the material by increasing kinetic energy.
increasing kinetic energy and overcoming the intermolecular forces.

The temperature of an object is directly linked to its kinetic energy, meaning that an increase in temperature corresponds to a rise in kinetic energy. When a substance undergoes thermal expansion, it expands, occupying more space with the same mass. This expansion is achievable only if the material experiences a reduction in intermolecular forces, allowing increased spacing between molecules. Consequently, the supplied heat energy plays a dual role: it augments the kinetic energy and counteracts the intermolecular forces, facilitating the expansion by enhancing molecular spacing during thermal expansion.
Heat given to a body which raises its temperature by \(1^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) is known as:

The heat required to raise the temperature of a body by  \(1^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)  is termed as the capacity of that body for a thermal change, thus it is called thermal capacity or the heat capacity.

It is given by: \(C=\frac{\Delta Q}{\Delta T}\)

Where \(\mathrm{Q}\) is denoted as the heat in joules and \(\mathrm{T}\) is denoted as the temperature in Celsius,

An elevation in pressure results in a reduction in the melting point of ice. This occurs as an increase in pressure leads to a decrease in volume, and since the volume of water is less than that of ice, the transition from a solid to a liquid state becomes more facile. Consequently, the melting point experiences a decrease under heightened pressure.
Which of the following is true about calorimetry?
It works on the principal of conservation of heat energy.
Temperature of the mixture is always less than the lower temperature of the body.
Temperature of the mixture is always greater than the higher temperature of the body.
It works on the principal of conservation of mass of the body.

When two bodies at different temperatures are mixed, then the body at higher temperature releases heat while the body at lower temperature absorbs it, so that heat loss is equal to the heat gained. Thus, calorimetry represents the law of conservation of heat energy.
If \(2000 \mathrm{~J}\) of heat is required to melt \(80 \mathrm{~g}\) of lead kept at its melting point, then what Latent Heat of Fusion of lead (in \(10^5 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{kg}\) )?

Given, \(\mathrm{Q}=2000 \mathrm{~J}\) and \(\mathrm{m}=80 \mathrm{~g}=0.08 \mathrm{~kg}\)

The latent heat of fusion is

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{Q}=\mathrm{mL}\)

\(\Rightarrow L=\frac{2000}{0.08}=25000 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{kg}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{L}=0.25 \times 10^5 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{kg}\)

Find the heat (in \(\mathrm{J}\) ) required to vaporise \(20 \mathrm{~g}\) of ethyl alcohol kept at its boiling point? (Latent heat of vapourisation of ethyl alcohol is \(8.5 \times 10^5 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{kg}\) )

Given - Mass of ethyl alcohol \((\mathrm{m})=20 \mathrm{~g}=0.02 \mathrm{~kg}\) and Latent heat of vapourisation of ethyl alcohol \((\mathrm{L})=8.5 \times 10^5 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{kg}\)

The amount of heat (in \(\mathrm{J}\) ) required to vaporise \(20 \mathrm{~g}\) of ethyl alcohol kept at its boiling point

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow Q=\mathrm{mL} \\ & \Rightarrow Q=0.02 \times 8.5 \times 10^5 \\ & \Rightarrow Q=0.17 \times 10^5 \mathrm{~J} \\ & \Rightarrow Q=17000 \mathrm{~J}\end{aligned}\)
The temperature at which a solid melts to become a liquid at the atmospheric pressure is called its melting point. The melting point of a solid is an indication of:
strength of the intermolecular force of attraction
strength of the intermolecular force of repulsion

The melting point is an important physical property of a compound. The melting point can be used to identify a substance and as an indication of its purity. The melting point of solid is defined as the tempertaure at which the solid exists in equilibrium with its liquid under an external pressure of one atmosphere.

Melting point also depends upon the intermolecular force of attraction between the molecule.
At one atmospheric pressure, the amount of thermal energy required to convert one kilogram solid into liquid at their melting point is called:

At one atmospheric pressure, the amount of thermal energy required to convert one kilogram solid into liquid at their melting point is called the latent heat of fusion. 

The heat energy required to change the state of a material from solid-state to its liquid state is called the latent heat of fusion. It is also the amount of heat energy released when at melting point liquid changes to solid.
The snow on the mountains does not melt all at once when it is heated by the sun, because it:
reflects most of the heat from the sun
has a high latent heat of fusion

The heat received from the sun increases the temperature of the snow from negative to zero. At zero degrees the snow changes from solid to the liquid state and the energy required for this change is called latent heat.

The substantial presence of snow on the mountain contributes to its immense mass. This extensive mass results in a significantly large latent heat of fusion. Given the magnitude of this heat requirement, it becomes impractical for the sun to deliver such a substantial amount of heat all at once. Consequently, the ice on the mountain does not undergo instantaneous melting.
The phase change of a matter from liquid state to gaseous state is known as_________.
When a matter changes its phase from liquid state to gas state is known as 'vaporization'.
Boiling water is changing in to steam. The specific heat of boiling water is:

During boiling when water is converted to steam, the temperature remains constant as the heat energy is utilized to change the state of matter. At this point, since the temperature is constant, \(\Delta T=0\) 

Specific heat capacity,

\(\Rightarrow c=\frac{\Delta Q}{m \Delta T}=\frac{\Delta Q}{m \times 0}=\frac{1}{0}=\infty\)

Thus, the specific heat of boiling water is infinity.
The conduction of heat transfer is maximum in:

Conduction is majorly takes place in solids, liquids, and gases.

Conduction is maximum in solids because their atoms and molecules are located very closely together as compared to liquid and gas.
A cold steel spoon is dipped in a cup of hot milk. Heat is transferred to its other end by the process of___________.

Conduction occurs when two objects at different temperatures are in contact with each other. Heat flows from the warmer to the cooler object until they are both at the same temperature.

When a cold steel spoon is dipped in a cup of hot milk. It transfers heat to its other end by the process of conduction.
Which of the following is a good conductor of heat in liquid state compared to other?
Mercury is the liquid which is good conductor of heat. This is the reason behind the usage of mercury in traditional mercury thermometer.
The central heating system in buildings works on the principle of:

Convection is a mode of heat transfer by the actual motion of matter.

  • Convection is a type of heat transfer that can only happen in liquids and gases.
  • The particle of liquid and gases can move freely as compared to solid.
  • A central heating system is a process that works on the convection heat transfer principle.
The process by which heat is transmitted from one place to another in the form of waves through space or through a material medium is called:

Radiation is the process by which heat is transmitted from one place to another in the form of waves through space or through a material medium.

Example of Radiation: The heat from the sun reaches the earth by the process of radiation, covering millions of kilometers of empty space or vacuum.
Absorption co-efficient of an open window is____________.

Open windows and doors are considered to be completely absorptive, with 100% absorption.

Thus the absorption coefficient of an open window is unity(1).
When a horse pulls a wagon, the force that causes the horse to move forward, is the force that:

When the horse pulls the wagon, it pushes the ground in the backward direction. Due to the third law of motion, the ground exerts a forward force which has the same magnitude. As the backward force applied by the wagon is weaker than the force applied by the horse, the wagon moves in the forward direction.
The first law of motion is also known as the law of:

Newton's First Law of Motion, also known as the Law of Inertia, states that an object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and in the same direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force.
If the earth were suddenly contracted to half of its present radius (without any external torque on it) and Assume earth to be perfectly solid sphere then:

In our case, the earth is a rotating sphere and its angular momentum \(L\) will be conserved and can be given as \(L=I \times \omega\) hence option (A) is true now for angular velocity

let the present radius of earth \(=R, T_1=24\) hour

Radius after contraction, \(R_1=R / 2, T_2=\) ?

By conservation of angular momentum,

\(I_1 \omega_1=I_2 \omega_2\)

Using this we can predict that time period will be different and hence omega will be different. So both option (A) and (B) are correct.
Motion of a body as a whole from one point to another is called:

Motion of a body as a whole from one point to another is called translation. It is that motion in which a body, which is not a point mass body is moving such that all its constituent particles move simultaneously along parallel straight lines and all its constituent particles shift through an equal distance in a given interval of time. For example, A body slipping along the inclined plane has translatory motion.

A force acts for \(10 \mathrm{~s}\) on a body of mass \(100 \mathrm{~kg}\), after which the force ceases to act and the body describes \(160 \mathrm{~m}\) in the next \(8 \mathrm{~s}\). What is the magnitude of the force?

Mass, \(\mathrm{m}=100 \mathrm{~kg}\)

Time interval, \(\Delta \mathrm{t}=10 \mathrm{~s}\)

Distance traveled in next 5 seconds, \(d=100 \mathrm{~m}\)

Thus, velocity acquired by body, \(\mathrm{v}=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{t}}=\frac{100}{5}=20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

Acceleration produced by the force, \(a=\frac{\mathrm{v}}{\Delta \mathrm{t}}=\frac{20}{10}=2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\)

Magnitude of force, \(\mathrm{F}=\mathrm{ma}=100 \mathrm{~kg} \times 2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2=200 \mathrm{~N}\)

A single horizontal force \(F\) is applied to a block of mass \(M_1\) which is in contact with another block of mass \(\mathrm{M}_2\) as shown in the figure. If the surfaces are frictionless, the force between the block is:

Let the acceleration of the whole system be a and the normal force acting between the blocks be \(\mathrm{N}\).


Total mass of the system \(\mathrm{M}=\mathrm{M}_1+\mathrm{M}_2\)

\(\therefore\) Acceleration of the system \(a=\frac{F}{M}=\frac{F}{M_1+M_2}\)

Thus normal force between the blocks \(N=M_2 a=\frac{M_2 F}{M_1+M_2}\)
A stone of mass m tied to a string of length l is rotating along circular path with constant speed v. The torque on the stone is:

Stone mass \(=m\), Length of string \(=l\), Velocity \(={v}\)

Torque \(\tau=r \times F\)

Torque is given by \(=r \times \frac{m v^2}{r}\)

where, \(a=\) acceleration, \(r=\) axle radius, \(v=\) speed

As the direction of centripetal force and position vector is directed toward center

\(\tau=r \times F \)

\(\tau =r F \sin \theta \)

here \(\theta=0^{\circ}\)

Therefore \(\tau=0\)

So, the torque will be zero.

A spring is compressed between two blocks of masses \(m_1\) and \(m_2\) placed on a horizontal frictionless surface. When the blocks are released, the blocks travel distance \({x}_1\) and \({x}_2\) respectively before coming to rest. The ratio \(\frac{{x}_1}{ {x}_2}\) is:

Initial momentum of the system is zero i.e. \(P_i=0\)

Let the velocity acquire by masses \(m_1\) and \(m_2\) just after they are released be \(v_1\) and \(v_2\).

Final momentum of the system \(P_f=m_1 v_1-m_2 v_2\)

Using conservation of momentum : \(\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{i}}=\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{f}}\)

\( \therefore 0={m}_1 m{v}_1-{m}_2 {v}_2 \)

\( \Rightarrow {m}_1 {v}_1={m}_2 {v}_2\left({v}=\frac{{dx}}{{dt}}\right) \)

\( \Rightarrow {m}_1 {x}_1={m}_2 {x}_2 \)

\( \Rightarrow \frac{{x}_1}{{x}_2}=\frac{{m}_2}{{~m}_1}\)
What was the flaw in Aristotle's Law of motion?
He did not take into account friction.
He assumed that velocity can never be negative.

According to Aristotelian law of motion, an external force is necessary to keep a body moving with uniform velocity. Aristotle's views were proved wrong by Galileo Galicia (1564-1642) about two thousand years later on. It was observed that external forces were necessary to counter the opposing forces of friction to keep bodies in uniform motion. If there were no friction, no external force would be needed to maintain the state of uniform motion of a body. So, he did not take into account friction.

A ball of mass \(0.6 \mathrm{~kg}\) attached to a light inextensible string rotates in a vertical circle of radius \(0.75 \mathrm{~m}\). It has a speed of \(5 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) when the string is horizontal. Tension in string when it is horizontal on the other side is: (Take \(\mathrm{g}=\) \(10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2})\)

Tension in the string when it makes angle \(\theta\) with the vertical

\(T=\frac{m v^2}{r}+\mathrm{mg} \cos \theta\)

When the string is horizontal, \(\theta=90^{\circ}\)

\(\therefore \quad T=\frac{m v^2}{r}+m g \times 0=\frac{m v^2}{r} \)

\( =\frac{0.6 \times(5)^2}{0.75}=20 N\)
A car overturns while taking a turn. Which of the following option that is experienced by the wheels of the car?
First, both inner, as well as the outer wheel, leave the ground
First, the inner wheel leaves the ground
For the inner wheel, the radius of the turn is less than the outer wheel. Therefore its maximum speed is also less than for the outer wheel. So, the inner wheel leaves the ground first.

A cyclist starts from the centre '\({O}\)' of a circular park of radius \(1 {~km}\), reaches the edge '\({P}\)' of the park, then cycles along the circumference and returns to the centre along '\(Q O\)' as shown in the figure. If the round trip takes 10 \({min}\), the net displacement and average speed of the cyclist respectively (in \({m}\) and \({km}/{hr}\)) are:

As the initial and the final points coincide at the centre of the circle therefore, the net displacement of the cyclist is \(0\).


The length of the arc \( P Q\) is given as,

\(P Q=\theta \times R\)

where, \(\theta=\) angular displacement and \(R=\) radius of the park

By substituting the given values in the above equation, we get \(P Q=\frac{1}{4} \times 2 \pi \times 1 \mathrm{~km}\)

The average speed is given as, \({v}=\frac{\text{Total distance travelled}}{\text{Total time taken}} =\frac{{OP}+{PQ}+{QO}}{t}\cdots(1)\)

Time taken, \(\mathrm{t}=10 \mathrm{~min}= \frac{10}{60} {hr}=\frac{1}{6}{hr}\)

By substituting the given values in equation (1), we get

\( v=\frac{[1 {~km}+(\frac{1}{4} \times 2 \pi \times 1 {~km})+1 \mathrm{~km}]}{(\frac{1}{6} \mathrm{~h})}\)

\(=6(2+1.57){km/h}\approx 21.4 {~km}/{~h}\)

Thus, the average speed of the cyclist is \(21.4 \mathrm{~km} \mathrm{~h}^{-1}\).

A circular road of \(1000 \mathrm{~m}\) radius has banking angle \(45^{\circ}\), the maximum safe speed of a car having \(2000 \mathrm{~kg}\) mass will be:(The coefficient of friction between tyre and road \(= 0.5).\)

Given that \({r}=1000 \mathrm{~m} , \theta=45^{\circ}\) and \(\mu=0.5\)

Maximum safe velocity for a banked road is calculated by

\(v=\sqrt{\frac{r g(\tan \theta+\mu)}{1-\mu \tan \theta}}\)

where \(\mu=\) coefficient of friction, \(\theta=\) angle at which the road is banked, \(r=\) radius of the road, and \({g}=\) gravitational acceleration

\(v =\sqrt{\frac{1000 \times 9.8\left(\tan 45^{\circ}+0.5\right)}{1-0.5 \times \tan 45^{\circ}}} \)

\({v}  =172 {~m}/{s}\)
Ram is teaching in a class he said for particle is in equilibrium it must satisfy the following condition. Which of the following condition Ram is talking about?

A body is said to be in equilibrium if it is in translational equilibrium and rotational equilibrium. Both translational and rotational equilibrium is required to a body in equilibrium. Ram is talking about satisfying both the condition simultaneously. Both \(\sum F=0\) and \(\sum {T}=0\) must require to a body is in equilibrium.

A body is said to be in translational equilibrium if the net sum of all the forces (F) acting on a body is zero.

\(\Sigma F=0 \Rightarrow F_{\text {net }}=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow F_1+F_2+F_3+\ldots \ldots . .+F_n=0\)

A body is said to be in rotational equilibrium if the net sum of all the torque (\({T}\)) acting on a body is zero.

\( \Sigma {T}=0 \Rightarrow  {~T}_{\text {net }}=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow  {~T}_1+ {T}_2+ {T}_3+\ldots \ldots \ldots+ {T}_{ {n}}=0\)

The maximum and minimum tension in the string whirling in a circle of radius \(2.5 \mathrm{~m}\) with constant velocity are in the ratio \(5: 3\) then its velocity is: \(\left(g=9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\right)\)

Let the particle although moving in a vertical loop but its speed remain constant.

Tenstion at lowest point \(T_{\max }=\frac{m v^2}{r}+m g\)

Tension at highest point \(T_{\min }=\frac{m v^2}{r}-m g\)

Therefore,

\(\frac{T_{\max }}{T_{\min }}=\frac{\frac{m v^2}{t}+m g}{\frac{m v^2}{t}-m g}=\frac{5}{3}\)

\(v=\sqrt{4 g r}=\sqrt{4 \times 9.8 \times 2.5}=\sqrt{98} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

A cubical block of mass \(m\) rests on a rough horizontal surface, \(\mu\) is the coefficient of static friction between the block and the surface. A force \(m g\) acting on the cube at an angle \(\theta\) with vertical side of the cube pulls the block. If the block is to be pulled along the surface then the value \(\cot (\frac{\theta}{2})\) is:

It is clear from the figure that vertical component of force will decrease the normal reaction \(=\mu(\mathrm{mg}-\mathrm{mg} \cos \theta)\)


and frictional force \(=\mu \mathrm{N}\)

Now block can be pulled when, horizontal component of force \(\geq\) frictional force

i.e., \(m g \sin \theta \geq \mu(m g-m g \cos \theta)\)

or \(2 \sin \frac{\theta}{2} \cos \frac{\theta}{2} \geq \mu(1-\cos \theta)\)

or \(2 \sin \frac{\theta}{2} \cos \frac{\theta}{2} \geq 2 \mu \sin ^2 \frac{\theta}{2}\)

or \(\cot \frac{\theta}{2} \geq \mu\)action, i.e., \({N}={mg}-{mg} \cos \theta\)

The minimum force required to move a body up an inclined plane of inclination \(30^{\circ}\) is found to be thrice the minimum force required to prevent it from sliding down the plane. The coefficient of friction between the body and the plane is:

Force required to move body upward, \({F}_1={mg} \sin \theta+\mu {mg} \cos \theta\) 

Force required to prevent sliding, \({F}_2={mg} \sin \theta-\mu {mg} \cos \theta\) 

According to question,

\(F_1= 3F_{2}\)

\({mg} \sin \theta+\mu {mg} \cos \theta=3({mg} \sin \theta-\mu {mg} \cos \theta)\)

\( \Rightarrow 2 \sin \theta=4 \mu \cos \theta \)

\( \Rightarrow \tan \theta=2 \mu\)

\( \Rightarrow \tan 30^{\circ}=2 \mu\)

\(\mu=\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{3}}\)
A book of mass \(10 \mathrm{~kg}\) is lying at the front desk of a classroom. coefficient of static friction is 0.5. A force of \(40 \mathrm{~N}\) is applied to the book. The book will:

Mass of the book \(({m})=10 \mathrm{~kg}\), 

Coefficient of friction \(\left(\mu_{{s}}\right)=0.5\)

and external force applied \((F)=40 \mathrm{~N}\).

Normal reaction force is given by:

\(\Rightarrow {N}={mg}=10 \times 9.8=98 {~N}\)

Where \({g}\) is the acceleration due to gravity

Limiting force of friction:

\(\Rightarrow {f}_{{s}}={\mu}_{{s}} {N} \)

\(\Rightarrow({fs})_{\max }=0.5 \times 98=49 {~N}\)

As \(F<f_s(40<49)\), so the book will not move.
The friction is a force that acts:
In the direction the motion of the object
In the opposite direction of the motion of body

Frictional force offers the resistance to the applied force opposing its motion. So, it always acts in the direction opposite to that of the object in motion. An object moving in the forward direction whereas frictional force act just opposite in the direction of motion of the body, so we can conclude that friction opposes the motion of the body.

The coefficient of static friction \(\left(\mu_{\mathrm{s}}\right)\) between block A of mass \(2 \mathrm{~kg}\) and the table as shown in the figure is \(0.2\). What would be the maximum mass value of block \(B\), so that the two blocks do not move? The string and the pulley are assumed to be smooth and massless. (Take \(\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\) )

Free body diagrams of two masses are


We get equations

\( T-f=m_A a\) 

and \(f=\mu N=\mu m_A g \)

\(\Rightarrow T=m_A a+\mu m_A g\) 

and \(T=m_B g\)  for (\(a=0) \)

\(\therefore \mu N=m_B g\) 

\(\Rightarrow m_B=\mu m_A=0.2 \times 2=0.4 {~kg}\)
A cylinder rolls up an inclined plane, reached some height, and then rolls down without slipping throughout these motions. The directions of the frictional force acting on the cylinder are:
Up the incline while ascending and down the incline while descending
Up the incline while descending and down the incline while ascending
Down the incline while ascending and descending
Up the incline while ascending and descending

The force of friction always acts in a direction, opposite to that in which the body tends to move. While ascending, the cylinder tries to pull the ground backward while moving forward, thus frictional force acts upwards. During descending, the frictional force again acts upwards. If the friction were absent from the body, then the body would have slid down. Thus the frictional force in this case. is responsible for the rolling motion of the cylinder.
The law of __________ was inferred by Galileo from observations of motion of a ball on a double inclined plane.

The property for which a body restrains the force applied to it is called inertia. The law of inertia was inferred by Galileo from observations of motion of a ball on a double inclined plane. He noticed that moving a heavy body is very hard than moving a light body. No force is exerted on a moving body of constant velocity.

Consider we are planning a space station shaped like a doughnut. The distance between space pod and the centre of the ring of "dough" is \(1 {~km}\) as shown below:


In this case, what is the minimum angular velocity needed to create artificial gravity of \(1{~g}\) ?

Centripetal acceleration \(\left(\mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{c}}\right)\) can be written as

\(a_c=\frac{v^2}{r}=r \omega^2 \ldots(\because v=r \omega)\)

Where

\({a}_{{C}}=\) centripetal acceleration, \({v}=\) velocity, \({R}=\) the radius.

\(\omega=\) angular velocity


The speed and kinetic energy of the particle remains constant.

Given that,

Radius of space station, \(r=1={~km}\)

Centrifugal acceleration, \(a=a_c=1 g=\frac{v^2}{r}\)

\(\omega = \sqrt{\frac{a}{r}}=\sqrt{\frac{10}{1000}}=0.1 {~rad} /{sec}\)
If we apply oil on door hinges, the friction will:

The resistance offered by the surfaces that are in contact with each other when they move over each other, is called friction. Friction can be reduced by using proper lubricants like oil, grease, etc. These lubricants aim at reducing friction between two moving pieces. It also helps in reducing and transferring heat generated. So, after applying oil on door hinges, the friction will decrease.
Tyres made of rubber are preferred than that of steel. This is because:
Coefficient of friction between rubber tyres and road is smaller than that between steel tyres and road.
Coefficient of friction between rubber tyres and road is greater than that between steel tyres and road.

Tyres made of rubber are preferred over steel. This is because the coefficient of friction between rubber tyres and road is smaller than that between steel tyres and road. So the amount of force required (pushing the peddle in this case) to overcome the force of friction will be less in the case of a rubber tyre.

The coefficient of limiting friction is given by:

\(\Rightarrow(f)_{\max }=\mu=\frac{f_{\max }}{N}\)
Inertia of motion of a body depends on:

The law of inertia says that If an object is at rest it remains at rest, or if in motion, remains in motion at a constant velocity unless an external force acts on it. If a body has more mass, it will have a tendency to remain at rest for more time than less mass. So inertia of motion of a body depends on the mass.
Which of the following statements is not true?
The mass of an object is a measure of its inertia.
In a high jump an athlete is made to fall on a cushioned bed to decrease his time of fall and impact
In an isolated system (where there is no external force), the total momentum remains constant

In a high jump an athlete is made to fall on a cushioned bed to decrease his time of fall and impact. 

In the case of high jump, the athlete will achieve more kinetic energy (velocity) and when it will hit the ground will feel more force that will cause high impact force and may get leg fracture. That's why a cushioned bed is used so that it can reduce the velocity slowly and hence the impact of lower but there is no change in the time of fall.
If we move the tree branch fast, some leaves are separated from the tree. It is caused by:

If we move the tree branch fast, some leaves are separated from the tree. It is caused by inertia. Newton's first law of motion, which is sometimes called the law of inertia, explains that an object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion remains in motion with the same velocity unless acted upon by an external force.

A spacecraft takes off by expelling a large amount of gases at a very high speed produced as a result of the combustion of fuel. The fuel is expelled in the vertically downward direction and the spacecraft takes off in a vertically upward direction. Which Newton's laws of motion can be used to describe this process?

According to the Newton's third law of motion, "To every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. Forces always exist in pairs and an action-reaction pair acts on two distinct objects. A force acting perpendicular to a surface is called thrust".

A spacecraft of a large amount of high-speed gases produces a thrust in a downward direction which in turn generates an equal and opposite thrust on the spacecraft in an upward direction and thus the rocket takes off.
The conservation of linear momentum can be understood by which of the following laws?
Both Newton's second and third law of motion

According to Newton's second law of motion:

Force \((F)=\frac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}\)

If there is no external force then, \(\mathrm{F}=0\)

Force \((F)=\frac{\Delta p}{\Delta}=0\)

\(\frac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=\frac{P_1-P_2}{\Delta t}=0\)

\(\left(\mathrm{P}_1-\mathrm{P}_2\right)=0\)

\(\mathrm{P}_1=\mathrm{P}_2\)

So, the initial momentum is equal to final momentum if there is no external force on the system. So this is the law of the conservation of linear momentum. Newton's third law of motion states that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. It also explains the conservation of momentum.
In uniformly accelerated motion, which of the following statements is true?
The velocity-time graph is a straight line
In uniformly accelerated motion, the velocity-time graph is a straight line. The acceleration remains constant, resulting in a linear relationship between velocity and time.
On a position-time graph, what does the slope of the curve represent?
The slope of the position-time graph represents the velocity of the object. A steeper slope indicates higher velocity, while a shallower slope indicates lower velocity.
What is the significance of the area under the velocity-time graph in uniformly accelerated motion?
The area under the velocity-time graph in uniformly accelerated motion represents the displacement of the object. It is obtained by finding the area between the graph and the time axis.
In projectile motion, what is true about the horizontal component of velocity?
It changes with time due to acceleration
It is equal to the vertical component of velocity

In projectile motion, the horizontal component of velocity remains constant, assuming no external forces act in the horizontal direction. This is because there is no horizontal acceleration (ignoring air resistance).
Two cars A and B are moving in the same direction. If A is faster than B, an observer in car A will perceive:
In the scenario described, since car A is faster than car B and both are moving in the same direction, an observer in car A will perceive car B as moving forward but at a slower pace.
What is terminal velocity in the context of motion?
The maximum velocity reached by a falling object
The average velocity over a specific time interval
Terminal velocity is reached when the force of air resistance (drag) equals the force due to gravity, resulting in zero net acceleration. At this point, the object falls with a constant velocity.

A car accelerates uniformly (constant acceleration) from \(0 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) to \(30 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) in 12 seconds, and continues to accelerate at the same rate. Find the distance  the car travels in the first 30 seconds of the motion:

By using the third equation of motion,

\(x=u t+\frac{1}{2} a t^2\)

\(u=0, a=\frac{5}{2}\) and \(t=30\) :

\(x=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{5}{2} \times 30^2=1125\) metres.

The car travels 1125 meters in the first 30 seconds of motion.
A particle moves in a straight line. It is initially at rest at the origin. The acceleration of the particle is given by \(\ddot{x}(t)=\frac{1}{3} \cos 3 t\). The velocity at time t is:

Starting from \(\ddot{x}(t)=\frac{1}{3} \cos 3 t\) and integrating once, we obtain

Since \(\dot{x}(0)=0\), we have \(c_1=0\). Hence,

\(\dot{x}(t)=\frac{1}{9} \sin 3 t\)

A ball dropped from one metre above the top of a window, crosses the window in \({4}\) s. If the same ball is dropped from \(2 \mathrm{~m}\) above the top of the same window, time taken by it to cross the window is \(t_2\) second. Then:

The ball which is dropped from greater height above the top of the window will have higher speed while crossing the window, by 3rd equation of motion:

v2=u2+2aS, where u=0

The ball with higher speed will take less time to cross the window. 

\(\begin{aligned} & \because \mathrm{H}_2>\mathrm{H}_1 \\ & \Rightarrow \mathrm{v}_2>\mathrm{v}_1 \\ & \therefore \mathrm{t}_2<\mathrm{t}_1\end{aligned}\)

A proton in a uniform electric field moves along a straight line with constant acceleration starting from rest. If it attains a velocity \(4 \times 10^3 {~km} / {s}\) at a distance of \(2{~cm}\), the time required to reach the given velocity is:

It takes one minute for a passenger standing on an escalator to reach the top. If the escalator does not move it takes him 3 minutes to walk up. How long will it take for the passenger to arrive at the top if he walks up the moving escalator?

Let the distance to the top be d.

therefore the speed of the man with escalator not moving \(=\left(\frac{\mathrm{d}}{1}\right) \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min}\)

therefore the speed of the escalator with the man at rest \(=\left(\frac{\mathrm{d}}{3}\right) \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min}\)

when both the main and the escalator are moving, effective speed \(=\left(\frac{d}{3}+d\right)\) \(\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min}=\frac{4}{3}\) m/min

Therefore time taken when both men and escalator are moving

\(=\frac{\text { distance }}{\text { speed }}=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\frac{4 \mathrm{~d}}{3}}\)

\(\frac{3}{4} \min =45~\text {seconds} \)

From an elevated point P a stone is projected vertically upward. When it reaches a distance y below the point of projection its velocity is double the velocity when it was at a height y above P. The greatest height reached by it above P is

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow v_1^2-u^2=-2 g y \\ & \Rightarrow v_1^2=u^2-2 g y \\ & \Rightarrow \frac{v_2^2}{v_1^2}=\frac{u^2+2 g y}{u^2-2 g y} \\ & \Rightarrow 4=\frac{u^2+2 g y}{u^2-2 g y}\end{aligned}\)

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow 4 u^2-8 g y=u^2+2 g y \\ & \Rightarrow 3 u^2=10 g y \\ & \Rightarrow u^2=\frac{10}{3} {g y} \\ & \therefore \text { Max Height }=\frac{u^2}{2 g}=\frac{5 y}{3}\end{aligned}\)
A body travels 200 cm in the first two seconds and 220 cm in the next four seconds. The velocity at the end of seventh second from start is:

\(\mathrm{s}=\mathrm{ut}+\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{at}^2\)

For case 1.

\(200=2 u+2 a\)

\(\mathrm{u}+\mathrm{a}=100 \ldots(1)\)

For case 2. i.e. next 4 seconds, we have distance \(=420 \mathrm{~cm}\) and time \(=6 \mathrm{~s}\)

\(\begin{aligned} & 420=6 u+18 a \\ & u+3 a=70 \ldots(2)\end{aligned}\)

Solving equation 1 and 2, we get, \(\mathrm{u}=115 \mathrm{~cm} / \mathrm{s}\) and \(\mathrm{a}=-15 \mathrm{~cm} / \mathrm{s}^2\) Now by

\(\mathrm{v}=\mathrm{u}+\mathrm{at}\)

\(\mathrm{v}=115-15 \times 7\)

\(\mathrm{v}=10 \mathrm{~cm} / \mathrm{s}\)

A ball after having fallen from rest under the influence of gravity for \(6 {s}\), crashes through a horizontal glass plate, thereby losing two-third of its velocity. Then it reaches the ground in \(2 {~s}\), height of the plate above the ground is:

\(v_B=v_A+g t=0+g(6)=6 g\)

Now, \(\frac{2^{\text {rd }}}{3}\) of the velocity is lost.

Hence, \(\frac{1}{3} \times 6 \mathrm{~g}=2 \mathrm{~g}\) velocity is left.

\(\mathrm{h}=\mathrm{ut}+\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{gt}=(2 \mathrm{~g})(2)+\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{~g}(2)^2=6 \mathrm{~g}=58.8 \mathrm{~m}\)
A body starts from rest and travels \(\mathrm{s} \mathrm{m}\) in \(2^{\text {nd }}\) second, then, acceleration is:

Given, body starts from rest i.e. \(\mathrm{u}=0\), distance \(\mathrm{s}=\mathrm{s} \mathrm{m}\) and \(\mathrm{n}=2\)

As we know that, the distance covered by a body in \(\mathrm{n}^{\text {th }}\) second is given by

\(s_{n^{t h}}=u+\frac{a}{2}(2 n-1)\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{s}=0+\frac{\mathrm{a}}{2}(2 \times 2-1)\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{a}=\frac{2 \mathrm{~s}}{3} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\)
What is the ratio of the average acceleration during the intervals OA and AB in the velocity-time graph as shown below?

During \(O A\), acceleration \(=\tan 30^{\circ}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\)

During \(A B\), acceleration \(=-\tan 60^{\circ}=-\sqrt{3} m s^{-2}\)

Required ratio \(=\frac{\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}}{\sqrt{3}}=\frac{1}{3}\)
A body covers 16, 18, 20, 22 meters in 5th, 6th, 7th and 8th seconds respectively. Which of the following statements is true about the body?
The body moves with a uniform velocity from rest
The body from rest moves with uniform acceleration
The body moves with an initial velocity and moves with uniform acceleration
The body moves with an initial velocity and then moves with uniform velocity
The body moves with an initial velocity and moves with uniform acceleration.
If distance covered by a particle is zero, what can be said about its displacement?
It may or may not be zero
Distance covered by a particle is zero only when it has not changed its position i.e. remained at rest. Therefore, its displacement must be zero.
An athlete completes one round of a circle track of radius \(R\) in 40 seconds. What will be the displacement at the end of 2 minutes 20 seconds:

Total time duration in consideration \(=2 \mathrm{~min} 20 \mathrm{sec}=140 \mathrm{sec}\)

He completed 1 round in \(40 \mathrm{sec}\)

In \(140 \mathrm{sec}\), he will cover \(=\frac{140}{40}=3.5\) rounds

After 3.5 rounds, he would be on the opposite side of the starting point

So, the displacement will be the diameter or \(2 \mathrm{R}\).
Which of the following remains constant if a body travels with constant acceleration?
f a body travels with constant acceleration, the correct answer is: None of the above.
Given here is a velocity-time graph of the motion of a body. What is the distance travelled by the body during the motion?

Since, the motion of the body is unidirectional, displacement of the body is the area of trapezium \(O A B C\)

\(\operatorname{ar}(O A B C)=\frac{1}{2}(O C+A B) \times A D\)
