So, the \(v-t\) curve can be shown as
Which among the following forces can probably act on a body whose motion is in a straight line?

Since no surface in the world of physics is frictionless, whenever a body is in motion, the force of friction acts on it. And rest, all the given forces act on the body under some special conditions, like when it moves along a curve, and the magnetic force acts on a body when placed in a magnetic field.
Starting from rest, acceleration of a particle is \(a=2(t-1)\). The velocity of the particle at \(t=5 \mathrm{~s}\) is:

We have 

\(a=2(t-1)=2 t-2\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\mathrm{dV}}{\mathrm{dt}}=2 \mathrm{t}-2\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{dV}=(2 \mathrm{t}-2) \mathrm{dt}\)

\(\Rightarrow \int_0^V d V=\int_0^5(2 t-2) d t=\left(\frac{2 t^2}{2}-2 t\right)_0^5\)

\(=\left(t^2-2 t\right)_0^5\)

\(=\left(5^2-2 \times 5\right)-\left(0^2-2 \times 0\right)\)

\(=(25-10)-0=15\)

\(\Rightarrow [\mathrm{V}]_0^{\vee}=15\)

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow \mathrm{V}-0=15 \\ & \Rightarrow \mathrm{V}=15 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\end{aligned}\)
Speed of two identical cars are \(u\) and \(4 u\) at a specific instant. The ratio of the respective distances in which the two cars are stopped from that instant is:

By Newton's third law of motion

\(v^2-u^2=2\) as

here acceleration a is negative since it is retardation, displacement s is the stopping distance d, u is the initial velocity and v is the final velocity.

Since the objects tops after the motion, v = 0

thus

\(\begin{aligned} & -u^2=-2 a d \\ & d=\frac{u}{2 a}\end{aligned}\)

Let take \(d_1\) as the distance traveled by the car with velocity \(u\) and \(d_2\) as the distance traveled by the car with velocity \(4 \mathrm{u}\).

The retardation for both the car is -a

\(\frac{d_1}{d_2}=\frac{u^2 2 a}{2 a(4 u)^2}\)

\(\frac{d_1}{d_2}=\frac{1}{16}\)
A man is \(45 {~m}\) behind the bus when the bus starts accelerating from rest with acceleration of \(2.5 {~m} / {s}^2\). With what minimum velocity should the man start running to catch the bus?

Given,

u = 0 m/s Speed of bus

\(\mathrm{a}=2.5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\)

From 2nd equation of motion,

\(\begin{aligned} & \mathrm{s}=\mathrm{ut}+\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{at}^2 \\ & \mathrm{~s}=0+\frac{1}{2} \times 2.5 \mathrm{t}^2\end{aligned}\)

\(s=\frac{2 \cdot 5}{2} t^2 \ldots \ldots \ldots\)(1)

Lets consider, \(\mathrm{u}=\) initial velocity of man

From the above figure, man need to covered distance \((45+s) \mathrm{m}\) at time \(t\) to catch the bus

\(\mathrm{ut}=45+\mathrm{s}\)

\(u t=45+\frac{2 \cdot 5}{2} t^2\) (from equation 1)

\(\mathrm{u}=\frac{45}{\mathrm{t}}+2 \cdot 5 \mathrm{t}\)

For minimum velocity,

\(\frac{\mathrm{du}}{\mathrm{dt}}=0\)

\(-\frac{45}{t^2}+1.25=0\)

\(45=1.25 \mathrm{t}^2\)

\(\mathrm{t}^2=\frac{45}{1.25}=36\)

\(t=6 s\)

From equation (2),

\(u_{\min }=\frac{45}{6}+1.25 \times 6\)

\(\mathrm{u}_{\min }=7.5+7.5\)

\(\mathrm{u}_{\min }=15 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)
The position of a particle along \(x-\) axis at time \(t\) is given by \(x=1+t-t^2 \mathrm{~m}\).The distance travelled by the particle in first \(2\) sec is:

\(x=1+t-t^2\)

At \(\mathrm{t}=0\) sec, \(\mathrm{x}_{\mathrm{0}}=1 \mathrm{~m}\)

We know that, \(v=\frac{d x}{d t}=1-2 t\)

So, at \(t=\frac{1}{2} \sec , v=0\)

And displacement, \(x_{\frac{1}{2}}=1+\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{4}=\frac{5}{4}=1.25 \mathrm{~m}\)

Distance travelled by the particle from \(t=0\) to \(t=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{sec}\)

\(=\left|x_{\frac{1}{2}}-x_0\right|=1.25 m-1 m=0.25 m\)

Position of particle at the end of \(2\) sec is given by \(x_2=1+2-2^2=-1 m\)

Distance travelled by the particle \(t=\frac{1}{2} \sec\) to \(t=2 \mathrm{sec}\)

\(=\left|x_2-x_{\frac{1}{2}}\right|=|-1 \mathrm{~m}-1.25 \mathrm{~m}|=2.25 \mathrm{~m}\)

Total distance travelled by the particle from t=0 sec to t=2 sec will be
∴x=0.25 m+2.25 m=2.5 m
Which of the following types of motion cannot describe the motion of a clock’s hands?
The hands of a clock move in a circular manner. Hence, the motion exhibited is circular motion. Moreover, it happens periodically, so it is also periodic motion. But its is not rectilinear motion.
Which of the following are obtained by dividing total displacement by total time taken?

The average velocity is obtained by dividing total displacement by total time taken. Instantaneous velocity is calculated at an instant and not over a period of time. Speed is distance divided by time. Velocity is said to be uniform when velocity at every instant is equal to the average velocity.
A ball is thrown upwards with an initial velocity of 20 ms−1. Find the time of flight and the maximum height reached by the body respectively. (g=10 ms−2)
4 sec, 20 m
5 sec, 25 m
4 sec, 24 m
5 sec, 30 m

Given:

Initial velocity, \(\mathrm{u}=20 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\)

Acceleration due to gravity, \(\mathrm{g}=-10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\)

Upward direction is taken as positive.

At maximum height, velocity will be zero, (v = 0) as the ball will change the direction of motion. Let the maximum height be H.
Using third equation of motion,

\(\mathrm{v}^2=\mathrm{u}^2+2 \mathrm{as}\)

\(\mathrm{0}^2=2 \mathrm{0}^2+2 \times(-10) \times \mathrm{H}\)

\(\mathrm{H}=20 \mathrm{~m}\)

When the ball returns to the initial point, net displacement is zero. Let the time of flight be \(T\). Using second equation of motion, we get:

\(s=u t+\frac{1}{2} a t^2\)

\(0=20 \times t+\frac{1}{2} \times(-10) \times t^2\)

\(\mathrm{t}=\mathrm{0}\) or \(\mathrm{t}=4 \mathrm{~s}\)

Time of flight is more than zero. So, it is 4 s.
The Venturi-meter is a device to measure the flow speed of the incompressible fluid. Venturimeter works on the principle of Bernoulli's equation.
Venturi-meter is used in the carburetor of an automobile to:
Provide the correct mixture of air to fuel
Separate the moisture from the air fuel mixture

The Venturi-meter is a device to measure the flow speed of the incompressible fluid. Venturimeter works on the principle of Bernoulli's equation.

The carburetor of an automobile has a Venturi channel (nozzle) through which air flows at a large speed. The pressure is then lowered at the narrow neck and the petrol (gasoline) is sucked up in the chamber to provide the correct mixture of air to fuel necessary for combustion.
What does happen in the heart attack?
Pressure in the artery decreases due to the accumulation of plaque
Pressure in the artery increases due to the accumulation of plaque
Pressure in the heart decreases due to the accumulation of plaque

Bernoulli's principle helps in explaining blood flow in arteries.

When the artery gets constricted due to the accumulation of plaque on its inner walls. In order to drive the blood through this constriction, a greater demand is placed on the activity of the heart.

The speed of the flow of the blood in this region is raised which lowers the pressure inside and the artery may collapse due to the external pressure. As the blood rushes through the opening, the internal pressure once again drops due to the same reasons leading to a repeat collapse. This may result in a heart attack.
Blood flow in the artery can be explained by:

Bernoulli's principle helps in explaining blood flow in arteries.

The artery may get constricted due to the accumulation of plaque on its inner walls. In order to drive the blood through this constriction, a greater demand is placed on the activity of the heart.
If plaque is accumulated at point 1 in the artery of a human body then which of the following statement is correct?
At point 1 both speed and pressure of the blood increases
At point 1 both speed and pressure of the blood decreases
At point 1 speed of the blood decreases and pressure of the blood increases
At point 1 speed of the blood increases and pressure of the blood decreases

When the artery gets constricted due to the accumulation of plaque on its inner walls.

In order to drive the blood through this constriction, a greater demand is placed on the activity of the heart.

The speed of the flow of the blood in this region is raised which lowers the pressure inside and the artery may collapse due to the external pressure.
Two rain drops of radius r and 2r are falling through air. Find the ratio of their terminal velocities.

Given that radius are \(r\) and \(2 r\). So \(\frac{r_1}{r_2}=\frac{1}{2}\)

Terminal velocity \(v\) is given by:

\(v=\frac{2}{9} r^2 g\left(\frac{\sigma-\rho}{\eta}\right)\)

\(v \alpha r^2\) (since all other parameters are the same for both the drops)

\(\frac{v_1}{v_2}=\frac{r_1^2}{r_2^2}=\frac{1^2}{2^2}=\frac{1}{4}=1:4\)
A metal ball is falling with terminal velocity in a liquid. If we change the radius of ball, how the viscous drag force, acting on the ball, will change?

The viscous drag force is given by:

F = 6πηrv

So F ∝ r
There is a film of fluid between the flat plates. On which of the following parameter the force required to move the plates does not depend?

The force required to drag the plate:

\(F= \pm \eta A \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta z}\)

This force depends on:

  • coefficient of viscosity μ 
  • area of plate A
  • the velocity of plate Δv
  • the distance between the plates Δz

From the given options, it is clear that the force required to drag the plate does not depend on the surface tension of the fluid.

The terminal velocity of a copper ball of radius 2 mm falling through a tank of honey is 30 mm/s. What will be the drag force exerted by the oil on the copper ball if the viscosity of the oil is 1 N-s/m2.

Given that \(r =2 mm =2 \times 10^{-3} m ; v =30 mm / s =30 \times 10^{-3} m / s ; \eta=1 N - s / m ^2\)

viscous drag force \(F=6 \pi \eta r v\)

\(F=6 \pi \times 1 \times 2 \times 10^{-3} \times 30 \times 10^{-3} \)

\(F=360 \pi \times 10^{-6} N \)

\( F=1.13 \times 10^{-3} N\)
Coefficient of viscosity (η ) of the liquid depends upon the:
Both area of layer in contact and velocity gradient between two layers

Coefficient of Viscosity (η): The tangential viscous force required to maintain the unit velocity gradient between its two parallel layers each of unit area is called the coefficient of viscosity. 

Coefficient of Viscosity is a constant term which only depends on the nature of the fluids and gives measures of viscosity.
Viscosity of a liquid ________ with the increase in temperature.

The viscosity of a liquid decreases with the increase in temperature.

Viscosity is the property of fluid by virtue of which an internal force of friction comes into play when a fluid is in motion and which opposes the relative motion between its different layers. Viscosity is considered an internal resistance that comes into play when fluid is in motion.
The Newton's law of viscosity gives the relationship between:

NEWTON'S LAW OF VISCOSITY:  The ratio of shear stress(τ) to the rate of shear strain(du/dy) is a constant and is known as viscosity or coefficient of viscosity(µ).

\(\tau=\mu \frac{d u}{d y}\)

Newton's law of viscosity gives a relation between the shear stress and the rate of shear strain. Shear stress is directly proportional to the rate of shear strain.
The coefficient of viscosity of liquids is analogous to the ________.

The coefficient of viscosity of liquids is analogous to the modulus of rigidity of solids.

  • Unlike solids, the strain in a flowing liquid increases with time continuously.
  • So for solids with an elastic modulus of rigidity, the shearing stress is proportional to the shear strain
  •  For fluids, it is proportional to the time rate of change of strain or strain rate.
  • The coefficient of viscosity (η) of a fluid can be defined as the ratio of shearing stress to the strain rate.
In the direction of flow of liquid

The property of a fluid due to which it opposes the relative motion between its different layers is called viscosity (or fluid friction or internal friction) and the force between the layers opposing the relative motion is called viscous force.

The force acting between the different layers of a fluid is given by: \(\Rightarrow F=-n A \frac{ dv }{ d x}\)

Where n= coefficient of viscosity, A = area of the plane, and \(\frac{ dv }{ d x}\) = velocity gradient.

The viscous force always opposes the relative motion between the layers of liquid. Therefore it acts opposite to the flow of liquid.

The viscosity of the liquid increases if the density of the liquid increases. We know that the density of the liquid decreases as the temperature increases and hence viscosity also decreases.

So we can say that the viscosity of liquid depends on the density and temperature both. Hence, option (C) is correct.
The SI unit of kinematic viscosity is:

Kinematic Viscosity is the ratio of dynamic viscosity to mass density.

Hence, the unit of kinematic viscosity will be \(=\frac{N / m^2-s}{ kg / m ^3}=\frac{ kg \times m / s ^2 \times s }{ m ^2 \times kg / m ^3}=\frac{ m ^2}{ s }\)
When a spinning ball is thrown in the blowing air the path of the ball becomes curved due to the:

When a spinning ball is thrown in the blowing air the path of the ball becomes curved due to the Magnus effect.

The Magnus effect is an effect in which a spinning ball or a cylinder curves away from its principle path of flight.
The flow speed of air above the aircraft wing is v1 and below the aircraft wing is v2, then which of the following is correct for the dynamic lift of the aircraft?

Given v1 = the flow speed of air above the aircraft wing, v2 = the flow speed of air below the aircraft wing.

The cross-section of the wings of an airplane looks somewhat like the aerofoil with streamlines around it.

When the aerofoil moves against the wind, the orientation of the wing relative to flow direction causes the streamlines to crowd together above the wing more than those below it.

Therefore the flow speed on top is higher than that below it.

So we can say that for the dynamic lift of the aircraft, \(v_1>v_2\)

In a venturi-meter the area of the narrow neck is one-third of the broad neck. The density of the incompresible fluid flowing in the venturi-meter is ρ and the velocity of the fluid at the narrow neck is v. Find the pressure difference between the broad neck and the narrow neck.

Given \(a=\frac{A} { 3}, \rho=\) density of the fluid flowing, and \(v_2=v\)

By the continuity equation for the broad neck and the narrow neck of the venturi-meter,

\(\Rightarrow Av _1= av _2 \)

\( \Rightarrow 3 av _1= av \)

\( \Rightarrow v_1=\frac{v}{3}\)

By Bernoulli's equation, the pressure difference between the broad neck and the narrow neck of a venturi-meter is given as,

\(\Rightarrow P_1-P_2=\frac{1}{2} \rho v_1^2\left[\left(\frac{A}{a}\right)^2-1\right] \quad \ldots(2)\)

Where A = cross-sectional area at the broad neck, a = cross-sectional area at the narrow neck, v1 = speed of the fluid at the broad neck, v2 = speed of the fluid at the narrow neck, and ρ = density of the fluid

By equation 1 and equation 2,

\(\Rightarrow P_1-P_2=\frac{1}{2} \rho\left(\frac{v}{3}\right)^2\left[\left(\frac{3 a}{a}\right)^2-1\right] \)

\( \Rightarrow P_1-P_2=\frac{4}{9} \rho v^2\)

The water is flowing in the venturi-meter and the area of the broad neck is double of the narrow neck. If the difference in height of the mercury column in the U-tube manometer is 13.6 cm, then find the speed of the water at the broad neck of the venturi meter.

Given \(A =2 a , g =9.8 m / sec ^2\) and \(h =13.6 cm =0.136 m\)

We know that the relative density of mercury is 13.6 .

\(\therefore \frac{\rho_m}{\rho}=13.6\)

We know that the speed of the fluid at the broad neck of a venturi-meter is given as,

\(\Rightarrow v_1=\sqrt{\left(\frac{2 \rho_m g h}{\rho}\right)}\left[\left(\frac{A}{a}\right)^2-1\right]^{-1 / 2}\)

By equation 1 and equation 2 ,

\( \Rightarrow v_1=\sqrt{2 \times 13.6 \times 9.8 \times 0.136}\left[\left(\frac{2 a}{a}\right)^2-1\right]^{-1 / 2} \)

\( \Rightarrow v_1=\sqrt{2 \times 13.6 \times 9.8 \times 0.136}\left[\left(\frac{2 a}{a}\right)^2-1\right]^{-1 / 2} \)

\( \Rightarrow v_1=\frac{19.04}{\sqrt{30}} m / sec\)

A fully loaded aircraft has a mass of \(3 \times 10^5 kg\). The total wing area is 300 \(m ^2\). If it is in level flight with a speed of \(900 km / hr\), then find the difference between the speed of the air on the upper surface of the wing relative to the lower surface. (Take density of air \(\rho=1 kg / m ^3\) and \(g =10 m / sec ^2\))

Let \(P_1=\) pressure below the wing, \(v_1=\) velocity of air below the wing, \(P_2=\) pressure above the wing, and \(v_2=\) velocity of air above the wing

Given \(m =3 \times 10^5 kg , A =300 m ^2, v =900 km / hr =250 m / sec , h _1= h _2, \rho=1\) \(kg / m ^3\), and \(g =10 m / sec ^2\)

We know that the weight of the aircraft is balanced by the upward force due to the pressure difference, so we can say,

\(\Rightarrow\left( P _1- P _2\right) A = mg \)

\(\Rightarrow P_1-P_2=\frac{3 \times 10^5 \times 10}{300} \)

\(\Rightarrow\left( P _1- P _2\right)=10^4 N / m ^2\)

If the speed of level flight is \(v\), then we can write as,

\(\Rightarrow v=\frac{v_1+v_2}{2}\)

By Bernoulli's equation for the below and above the wing,

\( \Rightarrow P_1+\frac{1}{2} \rho v_1^2+\rho g h_1=P_2+\frac{1}{2} \rho v_2^2+\rho g h_2\)

\( \Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} \rho\left(v_2^2-v_1^2\right)=\left(P_1-P_2\right) \)

\( \Rightarrow \rho\left(v_2-v_1\right)\left(\frac{v_2+v_1}{2}\right)=\left(P_1-(P_2\right) \quad-(3)\)

By equation 1, equation 2 , and equation 3 ,

\( \Rightarrow 1 \times\left(v_2-v_1\right) \times 250=\left(P_1-P_2\right)\)

\(\Rightarrow 1 \times\left( v _2- v _1\right) \times 250=10^4\)

\( \Rightarrow\left( v _2- v _1\right)=40 m / sec\)
A metal plate 5 cm × 5 cm rests on a layer of castor oil 1 mm thick whose coefficient of viscosity is 1.55 Nsm-2. Find the horizontal force required to move the plate with a speed of 2 cms-1.

Newton's formula for the viscous force between two parallel layers is given by:

\(F=\eta A \frac{d v}{d x}\)

Here \(A=25 cm ^2=25 \times 10^{-4} m ^2, dx =1 mm =10^{-3} m , \eta=1.55 Nsm ^{-2}, dv =2 \times 10^{-2} ms ^{-1}\)

On putting the value of the above we get,

\(F=\eta A \frac{d v}{d x}=1.55 \times 25 \times 10^{-4} \times 2 \times 10^{-2} / 1 \times 10^{-3}=0.0775 N\)

The horizontal force required to move the plate with the speed of \(2 cms ^{-1}\) is \(0.0775 N\).
How much force is required to move the plate with a velocity of 2 m/s, if the thickness of oil is 1 mm between a flat plate of area 10-2 m2? (given that coefficient of viscosity for is 1 poise)

Given that \(\Delta v=2 m / s ; \Delta z=1 mm =10^{-3} m ; A=10^{-2} m ^2 ; \eta=1\) poise \(=10^{-1} Ns / m ^2\)

Force required to drag the plate:

\( F= \pm \eta A \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta z}\)

\(F=10^{-1} \times 10^{-2} \times \frac{2}{10^{-3}} \)

\(F =2 N\)
The effect of temperature on viscosity of a liquid:
Viscosity increases with an increase in temperature.
Viscosity decreases with an increase in temperature.

For liquids, the cohesive force predominates the molecular moment transfer due to the close-packed molecules.

Therefore, with the increase in temperature, the cohesive force decreases and thus viscosity decreases.
The Newton's formula for viscous force between two parallel layers is:

Newton's formula for the viscous force between two parallel layers is given by \(F=\eta A \frac{d v}{d x}\)

Viscosity is the property of fluid by virtue of which an internal force of friction comes into play when a fluid is in motion and which opposes the relative motion between its different layers. Viscosity is like friction which converts kinetic energy into heat energy.
A backward dragging force that acts tangentially on the layers of the fluid in motion and tends to destroy its motion is called:

Viscosity: The property of fluid by virtue of which an internal force of friction comes into play when a fluid is in motion and that opposes the relative motion between its different layers is called viscosity. A backward dragging force is called viscous drag and it acts tangentially on the layers of the fluid in motion and tends to destroy its motion.

Viscosity is like friction which converts kinetic energy into heat energy.

Viscosity is considered an internal resistance that comes into play when fluid is in motion.
Which device is used to measure pressure?

Barometer is a device used to measure air pressure. Odometer is a device used to measure the distance travelled by a wheeled vehicle (it is the speed indicator in your vehicle). Dynamometer is a device used to measure torque or rpm of an engine. Hydrometer is used to measure specific gravity of liquids. Also keep in mind that the liquid used in a barometer is mercury.
the change in pressure cannot be determined

Pressure (P) =\(\frac{ \text{Force (F)}}{\text{Area (A)}}\)

From the above equation, we can see that the pressure is inversely proportional to area.

Hence, the pressure will increase when the area is decreased.

What will be the relation between F and F’ if a force F is acted upon a uniform rod of cross-section A and a force F’ is acted upon a uniform rod of cross-section 4A, and the pressure on both the rods is the same?

Pressure (P) = \(\frac{F}{A}\) (on first rod)

Pressure (P’) = \(\frac{F’}{4A}\) (on second rod)

Given;

P = P’

\(\frac{F}{A} =\frac{ F’}{4A}\)

\(\frac{F}{F’} = \frac{1}{4}\)
From which of the following is the working of hydraulic machines based on?

Pascals Law states that a pressure change at any point in the fluid is transmitted throughout the fluid such that the same change occurs everywhere. This is employed in hydraulic machines by varying cross-sectional areas at required places.
A body of mass \(0.05 \mathrm{~kg}\) is observed to fall with an acceleration of \(9.5 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\). The opposing force of air on the body is: \(\left(g=9.8 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\right)\).

A force acts on the object of mass \(3 \mathrm{~kg}\), the acceleration of the object is \(10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\). When the same force acts upon another object, its acceleration is \(15 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\). What is the mass of the object?

Given,

Mass of object \(\left(M_1\right)=3 \mathrm{~kg}\)

Acceleration in \(\mathrm{M}_1\) is \(\mathrm{a}_1=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\)

Let, the mass of other object \(M_2=\) ?

Acceleration of other object \(\left(a_2\right)=15 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\)

We know that According to Newton's Second law formula

\(\vec{F}=m \times \vec{a}\)

Since the forces acts on both the bodies are same so,

\(F_1=F_2 \)

\(F_1=M_1 \times a_1=3 \times 10=30 N \)

\(F_2=M_2 \times a_2 \Rightarrow 30 N=M_2 \times 15 \)

\(\Rightarrow M_2=2 \mathrm{~kg}\)
Three moving wooden blocks have the same mass. Then they will have:

Inertia is the property of an object by virtue of which it opposes any event that attempts to put the object in motion or to change its velocity. Greater the mass of the object more will be the tendency to resist the events. So, mass is a measure of the inertia of the object. The three wooden blocks have the same mass. So their inertia will also be the same.
If a horse starts moving suddenly from rest, there is tendency to fall in the backward direction. It is due to:

According to Newton's third law of motion, every action has an equal and opposite reaction. Therefore, When the horse starts motion from rest due to its weight it opposes the forward motion, so there is a tendency of falling back. It is due to the inertia of rest.

A mass \(M\) of \(100 {Kg}\) is suspended with the use of string \(A, B\) and \(C\) as shown in the figure, where \({W}\) is a vertical wall and \({R}\) is a rigid horizontal rod. The tension in the string \(B\) is: (take \(g\) as a gravitational acceleration)

"When a hanging carpet is beaten with a stick, dust particles start coming out of it". This phenomenon is best example of:

The concept can be explained based on Newton's first law of motion. According to this law, a body continues to be in its state of rest or of uniform motion along a straight line unless it is acted upon by some external force to change the state.

When the carpet is beaten with a stick, the stick exerts a force on the carpet which sets it in motion. The inertia of the dust particles residing on the carpet resists the change in the motion of the carpet. Therefore, the forward motion of the carpet exerts a backward force on the dust particles, setting them in motion in the opposite direction. This is why the dust comes out of the carpet when beaten.
A particle moves in a circle of radius \(25 \mathrm{~cm}\) at two revolutions per second. The acceleration of the particle in \(\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^2\) is:

Angular velocity of particle \(\omega=2 \times 2 \pi=4 \pi \mathrm{~rad} / \mathrm{s}\)

Since angular velocity is constant, there is no tangential acceleration.

Centripetal acceleration \(\mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{c}}\) is given by

\(a_c=\omega^2 r=(4 \pi)^2 \times 0.25 \)

\( =4 \pi^2\)

Therefore net acceleration \(=a_c=4 \pi^2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\)
The pulleys and the strings shown in the figure are smooth and of negligible mass. For the system to remain in equilibrium, angle \(\theta\) should be:

A body from height \(h\) is dropped, if the coefficient of restitution is \(e\), then calculate the height achieved after one bounce.

When a body falls from height \(h\), it strikes the ground with a velocity \(v=\sqrt{2 g h}\).

Let it rebounce with a velocity \(v\) and rise to a weight \(h_1\).

\({v}=\sqrt{2 {gh}_1} \)

\({e}=\frac{u}{v} \sqrt{\frac{{h}_1}{{~h}}}\)

So, \({h}_1={e}^2 {h}\)

A motorcycle moving with \(90 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}\) speed stops after \(10 \mathrm{~s}\) after applying brakes. If the total mass of motorcycle including rider is \(200 \mathrm{~kg}\). Find force applied by brakes on motorcycle.

Mass \((m)=200 {~kg}\).

Final velocity \((v)=0{~m} /s\)

Time taken \((t)=10 \mathrm{~s}\)

Now, acceleration \((a)=\frac{v-u}{t}\)

\(\Rightarrow a=\frac{0-25}{10}=-2.5{~m} /{s}^2\)

Here, negative sign indicates retardation. 

We know that,

Force \((F)=m a\)

\(\Rightarrow F=(200) \times(2.5)=500 N\)

An ice cart of mass \(60 \mathrm{~kg}\) rests on a horizontal snow patch with coefficient of static friction \(\frac{1}{3}\). Assuming that there is no vertical acceleration, find the magnitude of the minimum horizontal force required to move the ice cart. \(\left(g=9.8 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\right)\)

Mass of the ice cart \((\mathrm{m})=60 \mathrm{~kg}\), Coefficient of static friction \((\mu)=\frac{1}{3}\)

Coefficient of static friction \((\mu)\) is the ratio between the force of friction between two objects in contact when they are not moving and the force pressing them together. 

The maximum force of static friction \( { F_{max} }=\mu \times \mathrm{~N}\)

Where \(\mathrm{N}\) is the normal force exerted by the surface on the object. In this case, since there is no vertical acceleration, the normal force is equal to the weight of the ice cart, which can be calculated using the formula:

\(\mathrm{N}=\mathrm{m}\times \mathrm{~g}\)

\(\mathrm{N}=60 \times 9.8 =588 \mathrm{~N}\)

\(F_{max} =(\frac{1}{3} \times  588 \mathrm{~N}) \approx 196 \mathrm{~N}\)

Therefore, the magnitude of the maximum horizontal force required to move the ice cart is approximately \(196 \mathrm{~N}\).
A car of mass \(800 \mathrm{~kg}\) moves on a circular track of radius \(40 \mathrm{~m}\). If the coefficient of friction is 0.5 , then maximum velocity with which the car can move is:

When a car goes round a curved road, it requires some centripetal force. While rounding the curve, the wheels of the car have a tendency to leave the curved path and regain the straight line path. Force of friction between the wheels and the mad opposes this tendency of the 

\(\therefore \frac{{mv}^2}{{r}} \leq \mu {mg} \)

\({v}^2 \leq \mu {rg} \Rightarrow {v} \leq \sqrt{\mu {rg}}\)

So, the maximum velocity with which a vehicle can go round a level curve, without a skidding is \(\mathrm{v}=\sqrt{\mu \mathrm{rg}}\)

Here, \({r}=40 {m}\)

\(\mu=0.5 \)

\(\therefore {v}=\sqrt{0.5 \times 40 \times 9.8} =14 {~m} / {s}\)

A car is moving in a circular horizontal track of radius \(10 \mathrm{~m}\) with a constant speed of \(10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\). A plumb bob is suspended from the roof of the car by a light rigid rod. The angle made by the rod with the vertical is:

velocity \(=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)

Two kids \(X\) and \(Y\) are standing on their skateboards facing each other. If both of them push each other and travel in opposite directions, who travels the farthest? Assume that \({X}\) and \({Y}\) have identical mass.

When both of them push each other, a force is exerted on each other which is equal in magnitude and opposite in direction. This is inferred from Newton's third law of motion.

We know that Force \(=\) mass \(\times\) acceleration. 

Since the forces exerted on them are equal:

\(m_x a_x=m_y a_y\)

Given that they have identical mass 

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{x}}=\mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{y}}\)

Therefore, \(a_{\mathrm{x}}=\mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{y}}\)

Also, since there is no external force acting on the system so the momentum will be conserved for the system which causes velocities of equal magnitude but in an opposite direction as the masses are the same. Now, as per laws of motion, if a body is having same initial velocity and acceleration will travel the same distance at any moment of time. So, both kids \(X\) and \(Y\) will travel the same distance.

An elevator car whose floor-to-ceiling distance is equal to \(2.7 \mathrm{~m}\) starts ascending with constant acceleration \(1.2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\). \(2 \mathrm{~s}\) after the start, a bolt begins falling from the ceiling of the car. Find the bolt's free fall time.

At \({t}=0\) lift started, \(\mathrm{u}=\mathrm{0}\)

So \({U}_{{b}}=+2.4 {~m}/{s}\)

Acceleration of bolt \({a}_{{b}}=-9.8 {~m}/{s}^2\) as immediately it comes under the influence of gravity

Lets be the lift for a while. 

\({U}_{\frac{b}{l}}={U}_{{b}}-{U}_{{l}}=2.4-2.4=0{~m} / {s} \)

\({a}_{\frac{b}{l}}={a_b}-{a_l}=-9.8-1.2=-11{~m} / {s}^2\)

Now for the lift the bolt fell from ceilling to floor so displacement relative \(={s}_{{b} / {l}}=-2.7 {~m}\)

\(\therefore 2.7\) is the height of the lift

\({S}_{\frac{b}{l}}={U}_{\frac{b}{l}}({t})+\frac{1}{2} {a}_{\frac{b}{l}} {t}^2 \)

\(-2.7=0+\frac{1}{2}(-11) \mathrm{t}^2 \)

\({t}=0.7 {sec}\)

A body takes time \(t\) to reach the bottom of an inclined plane of angle \(\theta\) will the horizontal. if the plane made rough, time takes now is \(2 t\). The coefficient of friction of the rough surface is:

length of incline,

Nature and material of the surfaces in contact

The frictional force that opposes the relative motion of two surfaces in contact. It depends upon the nature and material of the surfaces in contact.It is independent of shape and area of contact between two surfaces. The relative velocity between the two surfaces provided the relative velocity is neither too large nor too small.

If \(f_k\) is the kinetic friction, \(\mu_k\) the coefficient of kinetic friction, and \(N\) is the normal reaction force, the law of kinetic friction may be written as:

\( {f}_{{k}}=\mu_{{k}}{N}\)
Radha is moving her bike with its brakes on. In this case:
Sliding friction is converted into rolling friction
Rolling friction is converted into sliding friction

When an object is rolled over the surface of another object an opposing force comes into action. This opposing force is called rolling friction. The rolling body in contact with the plane gets slightly compressed and the motion relative to the plane is zero.

Sliding friction is the opposing force that comes into action when a body is sliding over a surface.

When Radha is moving her bike with its breaks on the rotation of the wheels cannot occur. As a result the bike skids. So, the rolling friction is converted into sliding friction.

Ram is playing with a thread and a brick of mass \(2 \mathrm{~Kg}\). He tied a thread one of its end with brick and another end with the roof. He holds the thread at \(1 \mathrm{~m}\) below the roof and applying a force of \(50 \mathrm{~N}\). What is the tension that appeared in the upper part of the thread which is stick with the roof? \({~T}_1=\frac{20}{\operatorname{Cos}68^{\circ}}\)

\({T}_1={53.38} {N}\)
Consider a train of mass \(10^4 {~kg}\) taking a sharp turn of radius \(200 {~m}\) at a speed of 100 \({m}/{s}\), in this case, the horizontal thrust exerted on the rail track is if it is not banked?

Given that,

mass of train, \({m}=10^4 {~kg}\)

radius of track, \(r=200 {~m}\)

speed of train, \(v=100 {~m}/{s}\)

Now in our case when the train just begins to overturn, the inner tire will just begin to lift off from the ground which will reduce the pressure on the inner track (i.e., \(N_1\) becomes zero) and increase pressure on the outer track. This leads to zero pressure on the ground will become zero, so that reaction \(N_1\) on the inner wheels will become zero.

So, the horizontal thrust on the outer track can be expressed as

\(F=\frac{m v^2}{r}=\frac{10^4 \times 100^2}{200}=5 \times 10^5 N\)
An object of mass \(5 \mathrm{~kg}\) is attached to the end of a rope. If the rope is pulled upward with an acceleration of \(0.30 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\), what is the tension in the rope?

Change in momentum is equal to the:

According to Newton's second law of motion, the force on the body is given as,

\(\Rightarrow F=\frac{d P}{d t} \)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{dP}=\mathrm{F} \times \mathrm{dt} \cdots(1) \) 

Change in momentum \(=\mathrm{F} \times \mathrm{dt}\)

Where \(\mathrm{F}=\) force and \(\mathrm{dt}=\) time

We know that momentum of a body is given as,

Momentum (P) \(=\) Mass(m) \(\times\) Velocity (v) \(\cdots(2)\)

By equation 2 the change in momentum is given as,

Change in momentum \(=\) Mass \(\times\) Change in velocity \(\cdots(3)\)

The impulse is given as,

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{I}=\mathrm{F} \times \mathrm{dt} \cdots(4)\)

By equation 1 and equation (4) ,

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{I}=\) Change in momentum \(\cdots(5)\)

By equation 1, equation 3 , and equation 5 , we can say that all the given options are correct.
Which of the following has the largest inertia?

Inertia is a property of an object to resist changes in its current state of motion and is directly proportional to the mass of the object. Mass is solely dependent upon the inertia of the object. Higher the inertia more mass the body will have and vice versa. A heavier object has a higher tendency to resist changes in its state of motion. So, the human body has the highest mass thus it has the highest inertia.

A certain spacecraft is used to transport astronauts from International Space Station (ISS) to Earth. The spacecraft is designed to have three parts labelled P, Q and R each of mass \(1200 \mathrm{~kg}, 3150 \mathrm{~kg}\), and \(2800 \mathrm{~kg}\) respectively. When the spacecraft is launched the exhaust system produces a force of \(1430 \mathrm{~N}\). Calculate the acceleration of the spacecraft as it leaves the ISS.

Let Mass of spacecraft \(=\) Mass of \((P+Q+R)\)

From Newton's third law of motion, when the exhaust system produces a force of \(1430 \mathrm{~N}\), an equal and opposite force is exerted back on the spacecraft. Let this force be \(\mathrm{F}\).

\(1430 \mathrm{~N}=\mathrm{F} \)

\( 1430=\mathrm{m} \times \mathrm{a}=\)

\(1430=(1200+3150+2800) \times \mathrm{a} \)

\(\mathrm{a}=0.2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\)
Which of the following is an example of action-reaction pair?
A boy is sitting on the chair, his weight and the upward normal reaction on the boy by the chair
When gun is triggered, the force on gun and bullet

Newton's third law states that for every action there is an equal and opposite reaction. Action and reaction forces act on two different bodies. When a gun is triggered, the force on the gun and bullet is an action-reaction pair because in this case, the forces are acting on two different bodies.
The point on the Earth's orbit that is farther away from the Sun is:

From Kepler's first law, we know that the Earth orbits the Sun in an elliptical path. The Sun is situated at one of the foci of this elliptical orbit.

Aphelion is the point on the Earth's orbit that is farthest away from the Sun.

Perihelion is the point on the Earth's orbit that is nearest to the Sun.
If the radius of Earth's orbit is reduced by \(75 \%\), the duration of an year will-

From the third law of Kepler, the square of the time period \((T)\) is directly proportional to the cube of the semi-major axis (R).

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{T}^2 \propto \mathrm{R}^3\)

Let the radius and time period of Earth be \(\mathrm{R}\) and \(\mathrm{T}\) respectively.

If \(R^{\prime}\) and \(T^{\prime}\) are the new radius and time period,

When the radius of Earth's orbit is reduced by \(75 \%, \mathrm{R}^{\prime}=25 \%\) of \(\mathrm{R}=0.25 \mathrm{R}\)

Then the new time period will be:

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow\left(\frac{T^{\prime}}{T}\right)^2=\left(\frac{R^{\prime}}{R}\right)^3 \\ & \Rightarrow\left(\frac{T^{\prime}}{T}\right)^2=\left(\frac{0.25 R}{R}\right)^3 \\ & \Rightarrow\left(\frac{T^{\prime}}{T}\right)^2=0.25^3 \\ & \Rightarrow T^{\prime}=\sqrt{0.25^3} T=0.125 T \\ & \Rightarrow T^{\prime}=12.5 \% T\end{aligned}\)

Therefore, the new time period gets decreased by \(87.5 \%(100 \%-12.5 \%=\) \(87.5 \%)\)

Two planets revolve around the sun such that their mean distances from the sun are \(d_1\) and \(d_2\) respectively and their time periods are \(T_1\) and \(T_2\). If \(n_1\) and \(\mathrm{n}_2\) are their corresponding frequencies, which of the following is correct?

From the third law of Kepler, the square of the time period \((T)\) is directly proportional to the cube of the mean distance (d).

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{T}^2 \propto \mathrm{d}^3\)

We also know that, time period, \(T=\frac{1}{\text { frequency }}=\frac{1}{n}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{n^2} \propto d^3\)

For the two planets revolving around the sun,

\(\Rightarrow \frac{n_2^2}{n_1^2} \propto \frac{d_1^3}{d_2^3}\)

\(\Rightarrow n_1^2 d_1^3=n_2^2 d_2^3\)

The moon revolving around the Earth is subjected to a centripetal acceleration \(a_m\) due to the gravity of the Earth. Which of the following best denotes the relationship between centripetal acceleration \(\mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{m}}\) and time period \(\mathrm{T}\) of the moon?

From the equation of centrifugal force, centripetal acceleration \(a_m=\frac{v^2}{R_m}\).... (1)

Where \(R_m\) is the radius of the moon's orbit.

The time period of the moon for a complete revolution, \(T=\frac{\text { distance }}{\text { speed }}=\frac{2 \pi R_m}{v}\)

\(\Rightarrow v=\frac{2 \pi R_m}{T}\)........(2)

Substituting (2) in (1),

\(\Rightarrow a_m=\frac{\frac{\left(2 \pi R_m\right)^2}{T^2}}{R_m}=\frac{4 \pi^2 R_m}{T^2}\)

\(\Rightarrow a_m \propto \frac{1}{T^2}\)

A body of mass \(M\) is broken into two smaller parts each of mass \(m_1\) and \(m_2\) such that the gravitational force between them is the maximum. Then which of the following is the correct relation?

Given that:

Mass of one part \(=\mathrm{m}_1\)

Mass of the second part \(=\mathrm{m}_2={M}-\mathrm{m}_1\)

Let us assume the distance between their centers is R.

\(\Rightarrow F=\frac{G m_1 m_2}{R^2}=\frac{G m_1\left(M-m_1\right)}{R^2}\)

For this force to be maximum, \(\frac{d F}{d m_1}=0\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d F}{d m_1}=\frac{d\left(\frac{G m_1\left(M-m_1\right)}{R^2}\right)}{d m_1}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d F}{d m_1}=\frac{G\left(M-2 m_1\right)}{R^2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{M}-2 \mathrm{~m}_1=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{m}_1=\frac{\mathrm{M}}{2}\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{m}_2=\frac{\mathrm{M}}{2}\)

Thus, the gravitational force is maximum when \(m_1=m_2\).
the product of the mass of two bodies separated by a unit distance
the force of attraction between two unit masses separated by a unit distance
the energy between two masses separated by some distance

From the law of universal gravitation, \(F=\frac{G m_1 m_2}{R^2}\)

If we consider two unit masses separated by a distance of one unit i.e. \(R=1\) unit, \(m_1=m_2=1\) unit

\(\Rightarrow F=\frac{G(1)(1)}{1^2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{F}=\mathrm{G}\)

Thus, the universal gravitational constant numerically equals the force of attraction between two unit masses separated by a unit distance.
Suppose the value of the universal gravitational constant reduces gradually in the future, which of the following is likely to occur?
Earth will move closer to the Sun
Earth will become extremely hot and humid

Gravitational force is a centripetal force that helps the Earth to move around the Sun. If the value of G decreases, the gravitational force between the Earth and Sun decreases. Over a long period of time, the gravitational force will become so weak that it will not support the movement of Earth around the Sun in a closed orbit.

As a result, the Earth is likely to move away in a tangential path to orbit.

Thus, there is a probability that Earth will leave the solar system.

If gravitational acceleration on a planet is half of gravitational acceleration on earth, find weight of 5 \(\mathrm{kg}\) object on that planet. (given g on earth \(=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\) )

Given that \(\mathrm{m}=5 \mathrm{Kg}\) and \(\mathrm{g}_{\text {planet }}=\frac{\mathrm{g}_{\text {earth }}}{2}=\frac{10}{2}=5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\)

From the definition, the weight of the body at a place is given by \(\mathrm{W}=\mathrm{mg}\)

Weight on the planet \(={W}={m g}_{\text {planet }}\)

\(W=5 \times 5={2 5 N}\)

The acceleration due to gravity on Earth and Saturn are \(g_e\) and \(g_s\) respectively. If the radius and mass of Saturn is twice as that of the Earth, the ratio of their acceleration due to gravity is:

Using \(g=\frac{G M}{R^2}\)

Acceleration due to gravity on Earth, \(g_e=\frac{G M_e}{R_e^2}\)

Acceleration due to gravity on Saturn, \(g_s=\frac{G M_s}{R_s^2}\)

Given that:

\(\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{s}}=2 \mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{e}} \text { and } \mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{s}}=2 \mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{e}}\)

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow g_s=\frac{G\left(2 M_e\right)}{\left(2 R_e\right)^2} \\ & \text { Ratio }=\frac{g_e}{g_s}=\frac{\frac{G M_e}{R_e^2}}{\frac{G 2 M_e}{\left(2 R_e\right)^2}} \\ & \Rightarrow \frac{g_e}{g_s}=\frac{\left(2 R_e\right)^2}{2} \times \frac{1}{R_e^2} \\ & \Rightarrow \frac{g_e}{g_s}=\frac{4}{2}=\frac{2}{1}\end{aligned}\)
If earth shrinks by one third of its present radius, the acceleration due to gravity will be:

Given: radius of earth shrink by \(\frac{1}{3}\).

\(R^{\prime}=R-\frac{R}{3}=\frac{2 R}{3}\)

If new gravitational acceleration is \(\mathrm{g}^{\prime}\) then,

\(g=\frac{G M}{R^2}\)

\(g \propto \frac{1}{R^2}\)

\(\frac{g^{\prime}}{g}=\frac{R^2}{(2 R / 3)^2}=\frac{9}{4}\)

\(g^{\prime}=\frac{9}{4} g\)
The value of gravitational acceleration at the centre of earth is:

Given:

\(\begin{aligned} & g=\text { acceleration due to gravity at depth 'h'. } \\ & g_0=\text { acceleration due to gravity }\left(9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2 \text { ) }\right. \\ & \text { For } h \text { (depth) }=r \text { (radius of earth). } \\ & r=\text { radius of earth. } \\ & g=g_0(1-h / r) \\ & g=9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2(1-r / r) \\ & g=9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2(0) \\ & g=0 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\end{aligned}\)
If \(\mathrm{g}\) on the surface of the earth is \(10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\), its value at a height of \(6400 \mathrm{~km}\) is (Radius of the earth = \(6400 \mathrm{~km}\) )

Given - The acceleration due to gravity on the surface of the earth is \(\left(g_e\right)=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\)

The acceleration due to gravity on the surface of the earth is given by,

\(\Rightarrow g_e=\frac{G M}{R^2}\).....(1)

Acceleration due to gravity at height \(h\) from the surface of the earth -

\(\Rightarrow g_h=\frac{G M}{(R+h)^2}\)......(2)

On dividing equations 1 and 2 , we get

\(\Rightarrow \frac{g_e}{g_h}=\frac{\frac{G M}{R^2}}{\frac{G M}{(R+h)^2}}=\frac{(R+h)^2}{R^2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{10}{g_h}=\frac{(6400+6400)^2}{6400^2}=4\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{g}_{\mathrm{h}}=\frac{10}{ 4}=2.5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2\)
The minimum velocity that an object must attain to escape the gravitational force of the Earth is approximately equal to:

The approximate value of acceleration due to gravity on the surface of the Earth is 9.8 \(\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^2\) or \(9.8 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{s}^2\).

The approximate value of the radius of Earth is \(6400 \mathrm{~km}\).

\(V_e=\sqrt{2 g R}\)

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow V_e=\sqrt{ \left(2 \times 9.8 \times 10^{-3} \times 6400\right)} \mathrm{km} / \mathrm{s} \\ & \Rightarrow V_e=\sqrt{125.44} \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{s} \\ & \Rightarrow V_e=11.2 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{s}\end{aligned}\)
The correct expression for the escape velocity \(\left(\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{e}}\right)\) of a projectile from the Earth is:

Escape velocity \(\left(\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{e}}\right)\) : The minimum velocity that an object must attain to escape the gravitational pull of the Earth is called the escape velocity.

It is given as:

\(V_e=\sqrt{2 g R}\)

where \(\mathrm{g}=\) acceleration due to gravity on the surface of the Earth, \(\mathrm{R}=\) Radius of the Earth
Escape velocity at the surface of earth is \(11 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{s}\), if the radius of earth is doubled then the escape velocity will be :

Given,

At the surface of Earth, \(v_e=11 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{s}\)

Let us assume:

\(R=\) Radius of Earth, \(R_e\)

\(\mathrm{M}=\) Mass of Earth, \(\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{e}}\)

\(\mathrm{d}=\) mean density of the Earth

\(\Rightarrow d=\frac{M_e}{V_e}=\frac{M_e}{\frac{4}{3} \pi R_e^3}\)

\(\Rightarrow M_e=\frac{4}{3} \pi R_e^3 d\)

Using \(V_e=\sqrt{\frac{2 G M}{R}}\) 

\(\Rightarrow V_e=\sqrt{\frac{8}{3} \pi d G R_e^2}\)

If the radius of the earth is doubled \(\Rightarrow R=2 R_e\).......(2)

Substituting (2) in (1),

\(\Rightarrow V_e^{\prime}=\sqrt{\frac{8}{3} \pi d G\left(2 R_e\right)^2}\)........(3)

Dividing (3) by (1),

\(\Rightarrow \frac{v_e^{\prime}}{v_e}=\frac{\sqrt{\frac{8}{3} \pi d G\left(2 R_e\right)^2}}{\sqrt{\frac{8}{3} \pi d G\left(R_e\right)^2}}=\frac{\sqrt{2^2}}{\sqrt{1^2}}\)

\(\Rightarrow v_e^{\prime}=2 v_e=2 \times 11=22 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{s}\)
The escape velocity of a body does not depend upon:

From the formula of escape velocity \(V_e=\sqrt{2 g R}\), it is clear that it only depends upon the acceleration due to gravity(g) and the radius of the Earth(R).

The escape velocity of a body does not depend upon its mass.

The total energy of a satellite at height \(\mathrm{H}\) from the surface of the Earth is the same as its potential energy at a height \(3 R\) from the surface of the earth. If \(R\) is the radius of the earth, then:

Total energy of the body T. \(\mathrm{E}=\frac{-\mathrm{GMm}}{2 \mathrm{r}}\) where \(\mathrm{r}\) is the distance of body from center of earth

\(\therefore \mathrm{r}=\mathrm{R}+\mathrm{H}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{T} \cdot \mathrm{E}=\frac{-\mathrm{GMm}}{2(\mathrm{R}+\mathrm{H})}\)

Potential energy P. E \(=\frac{-\mathrm{GMm}}{(R+3 R)}=\frac{-\mathrm{GMm}}{4 \mathrm{R}}\)

According to the question, \(\frac{-\mathrm{GMm}}{2(\mathrm{R}+\mathrm{H})}=\frac{-\mathrm{GMm}}{4 \mathrm{R}}\)

or, \(\mathrm{R}+\mathrm{H}=2 \mathrm{R}\)

or, \(\mathrm{H}=\mathrm{R}\)
If the radius of an orbiting satellite is increased then:

Consider a satellite orbiting the earth at a height \(h\) from the surface of the earth of radius \(\mathrm{R}\).

The circumference of orbit of satellite \(=2 \pi(R+h)\)

The orbital velocity of the satellite at a height \(h\) is given by:

\(\Rightarrow v_0=\sqrt{\frac{G M}{R+h}}\)

Where \(M\) is the mass of the Earth.

The kinetic energy of the satellite of mass \(m\) in a circular orbit is

\(K E=\frac{1}{2} m v^2=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\frac{G M}{R+h}\right)\)

The potential energy at distance \((R+h)\) from the centre of the earth is

\(P E=-\frac{G m M}{R+h}\)

The total energy of a circularly orbiting satellite is

\(T E=K E+P E=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{G m M}{R+h}\right)+\left(-\frac{G m M}{R+h}\right)=-\frac{G m M}{2(R+h)}\)

Kinetic energy is inversely proportional to the radial distance from the centre of the Earth for an orbiting satellite.

Hence, when the radius of orbiting is increased for a satellite its kinetic energy decreases.
An object weighs \(10 \mathrm{~kg}\) on the surface of the earth. The apparent weight of the object in a geostationary satellite is:

Every part of the satellite orbiting the earth has an acceleration towards the centre of the earth which is exactly the value of earth's acceleration due to gravity at that position. Thus in the satellite, everything inside it is in a state of free fall. When an object is in free fall, it is weightless as there is no upward force to counteract the gravitational force. Hence, an object under freefall experiences weightlessness.

If ' \(g\) ' is the acceleration due to gravity of Earth at a certain position inside the satellite and 'a' is the acceleration of the satellite, then the apparent weight of the object inside the satellite will be:

\(W^{\prime}=m g-m a\)

As the satellite is under free fall, \(a=g\)

\(\Rightarrow\) Apparent weight, \(\mathrm{W}^{\prime}=\mathrm{mg}-\mathrm{mg}=0 \mathrm{~N}\)

A and B are two satellites revolving around the Earth in a circular orbit of radius R and 9R, respectively. If the time period of satellite A is 1 hour, then what will be the time period of satellite B?

Radius of orbit of satellite \(A\left(R_A\right)=R\)

Radius of orbit of satellite \(B\left(R_B\right)=9 R\)

Time period of satellite \(A\left(T_A\right)=1\) hour

From kepler's laws, we know that

From kepler's laws, we know that

\(\frac{T_A}{T_B}=\left(\frac{R_A}{R_B}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}\)

\(\frac{1}{T_B}=\left(\frac{R}{9 R}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}\)

\(\frac{1}{T_B}=\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^3\)

\(\frac{1}{T_B}=\frac{1}{27}\)

\(\Rightarrow T_B=27 \text { hours }\)

A satellite of mass \(m\) revolves around the earth of radius \(\mathrm{R}\) at a height \(\mathrm{x}\) from its surface. If \(g\) is the acceleration due to gravity on the surface of the earth, the orbital speed of the satellite is:

We have:

\(\frac{m v^2}{R+x}=\frac{G M m}{(R+x)^2} \Rightarrow v=\sqrt{\frac{G M}{R+x}}=\sqrt{\frac{G M}{R^2} \times \frac{R^2}{R+x}}=\sqrt{\frac{g R^2}{R+x}}\)

because the gravitational force provides the centripetal force for revolution.

The period of revolution of an earth satellite close to surface of earth is 90 min. The time period of another satellite in an orbit at a distance of three times the radius of earth from its surface will be:

Distance of second satellite from the centre of earth has become four times.

Now \(T^2 \propto r^3\) or \(T \propto r^{\frac{3}{2}}\)

\(\therefore\) Time period of second satellite will become \((4)^{\frac{3}{2}}\) or 8 times.

Hence \(T^{\prime}=8 T=8×90=720 \mathrm{~min}\)
The velocity of a satellite in a parking orbit is:

The parking orbit is the orbits of geo-stationary satellite. Here time period, \(\mathrm{T}=24 \mathrm{hr}\)

Using Kepler's law, \(\mathrm{T}^2=\frac{4 \pi^2 \mathrm{r}^3}{\mathrm{GM}}\) or \(\mathrm{r}=\left(\frac{\mathrm{GMT}^2}{4 \pi^2}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}\)

Now, \(v^2=\frac{G M}{r}=G M \times\left(\frac{4 \pi^2}{\mathrm{GMT}^2}\right)^{\frac{1}{ 3}}\)

Or \(\operatorname{v}=\left(\frac{2 \pi \mathrm{GM}^{\frac{1}{3}}}{\mathrm{~T}}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}=\left(\frac{2 \pi \times 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \times 6 \times 10^{24}}{24 \times 3600}\right)^{\frac{1}{ 3}}=3.1 \times 10^3 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}=3.1 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{s}\)
The height at which the weight of a body becomes \((\frac{1}{16})^{th}\) of its weight on the surface of the earth (radius R) is:

Given - Weight of body at height (W') = mg', the weight of the body on the surface of earth (W) = mg and 

Acceleration due to gravity at height h from the surface of the earth

\(\Rightarrow g^{\prime}=\frac{g}{\left(1+\frac{h}{h}\right)^2}\)

Multiply both sides by \(m\), then we get

\(\Rightarrow m g^{\prime}=\frac{m g}{\left(1+\frac{h}{R}\right)^2}\)

\(\Rightarrow W^{\prime}=\frac{W}{\left(1+\frac{h}{R}\right)^2}\)

According to question, \(\mathrm{W}^{\prime}=\frac{\mathrm{W}} { 16}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{W}{16}=\frac{W}{\left(1+\frac{h}{R}\right)^2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{16}=\frac{1}{\left(1+\frac{h}{R}\right)^2}\)

\(\Rightarrow\left(1+\frac{h}{R}\right)^2=16\)

\(\Rightarrow\left(1+\frac{h}{R}\right)=4\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{h}{R}=3\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{h}=3 \mathrm{R}\)

The weight of an object at a height \(\mathrm{H}\) above the surface of the Earth is \(63 \%\) of that measured on the Earth's surface. If the radius of the Earth is roughly 6300 \(\mathrm{km}\), then (Assume \(\mathrm{H} \ll\) radius of earth) :

We know that weight, \(\mathrm{W}=\mathrm{mg}\)

Let the acceleration due to gravity on the surface be \(\mathrm{g}\) and that at a height \(\mathrm{H}\) be \(\mathrm{g}_{\mathrm{H}}\).

Given that:

\(W_H=63 \% W\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{mg}_{\mathrm{H}}=0.63 \mathrm{mg}\)

\(\Rightarrow g_H=0.63 \mathrm{~g}\).......(1)

Using \(g^{\prime}=g\left(1-\frac{2 h}{R_e}\right)\)

\(\Rightarrow g_H=g\left(1-\frac{2 H}{R}\right)\)........(2)

Substituting (1) in (2),

\(\Rightarrow 0.63 g=g\left(1-\frac{2 H}{R}\right)\)

\(\Rightarrow 0.63 \mathrm{R}=\mathrm{R}-2 \mathrm{H}\)

\(\Rightarrow 2 \mathrm{H}=0.37 \mathrm{R}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{H}=0.185 \mathrm{R}=0.185(6300)=1165 \mathrm{~km}\)
Two bodies of masses m and 4m are placed at a distance r. The gravitational potential at a point on the line joining them where the gravitational field is zero, is:

Two masses \(m\) and \(4 \mathrm{~m}\) kept at a distance \(r\). Let, gravitation field be zero at \(P\) as shown in figure.

\(\therefore \frac{\mathrm{Gm}}{\mathrm{x}^2}=\frac{\mathrm{G} \times 4 \mathrm{~m}}{(\mathrm{r}-\mathrm{x})^2}\)


\(\Rightarrow(2 x)^2-(r-x)^2=0]\)

\(\Rightarrow 2 x=r-x\)

\(\Rightarrow x=\frac{r}{3}\)

Potnetial at point \(P\)

\(\therefore V_P=-\frac{G m}{x}-\frac{G(4 m)}{r-x}\)

\(=-\frac{3 G m}{r}-\frac{6 G m}{r}\)

\(=-\frac{9 G m}{r}\)
Kepler's second law regarding constancy of the areal velocity of a planet is a consequence of the law of conservation of:
Kepler’s second law, is a consequence of the fact that the force of gravity is a central force, which in turn implies that angular momentum is constant.

The value of escape velocity does not depend upon the mass of the projected body, instead it depends on the mass and radius of the planet from which it is being projected. The value of escape velocity does not depend on the angle and direction of projection.

acceleration due to gravity.

Now acceleration due to gravity become 4 times of original value.

4.89 times the escape velocity of earth

5 times the escape velocity of earth

The centre of mass of a rigid body lies:

Center of the mass of a body is the weighted average position of all the parts of the body with respect to mass. The centre of mass is used in representing irregular objects as point masses for ease of calculation. The location of the centre of mass depends on two factors - the shape of the body and the distribution of the mass. In the case of a circular ring, the centre of mass lies at its geometric centre which is a point outside its body. Since the centre of mass is a point where the whole mass of the system appears to be concentrated, it is not necessary that this point should be inside the body.  So, the centre of mass of a body can be either inside or outside the body.
If the vector sum of all the forces acting on the system of particles is zero, then we can say that:
All the particles must move with constant velocity
Acceleration of the centre of mass must be zero
The position of the centre of mass must not change

Given \(\overrightarrow{F_1}+\overrightarrow{F_2}+\ldots+\vec{F}_n=0\)

We know that the total mass of a system of particles times the acceleration of its centre of mass is equal to the vector sum of all the forces acting on the system of particles.

\(\Rightarrow M \vec{a}=\vec{F}_1+\overrightarrow{F_2}+\ldots+\vec{F}_n \)

\(\therefore M \vec{a}=0\)

We know that the total mass of the system of particles can't be zero. Therefore in this case acceleration of the centre of mass must be zero. The position of the centre of mass may change.
A dancer on ice spins faster, when she folds her arms. This is due to:
Decrease in energy and increase in angular momentum
Increase in energy and increase in angular momentum
Increase in energy and decrease in angular momentum
Constant angular momentum and increase in KE

Inertia \({I}\) of a discrete the mass \({m}\) at distance \({r}\) from an axis is given by (about the axis)

\({I}={mr}^2 \Rightarrow \mathrm{I} \propto \mathrm{r}^2\)

So, when \(r\) decreases inertia \(I\) decreases

Now,

Angular momentum \((L)\) is a conserved quantity and remains constant when external. Torque on a body is zero

\(\frac{{d} \overrightarrow{{L}}}{{dt}}=\vec{\tau} \)

if \(\tau=0 \Rightarrow \overrightarrow{{L}}=\) constant

We know that

\(|\overrightarrow{\mathrm{L}}|=\mathrm{I} \cdot \omega \Rightarrow \omega=\frac{|\overrightarrow{\mathrm{L}}|}{\mathrm{I}} \Rightarrow \omega \propto \frac{1}{\mathrm{I}}\)

When the dancer folds her arms basically he is decreasing her inertia.

And, \(\omega \propto \frac{1}{\mathrm{I}}\)

So, decreasing of inertia \((I)\) results, in inrease of angular momentum. So, the dancer spin faster due to constant angular momentum and increase in KE.
There are two objects of masses \(1 {~kg}\) and \(2 {~kg}\) located at \((1,2)\) and \((-1,3)\) respectively. The coordinates of the centre of mass are:

Body \({A}\) has mass of \(1 {~kg}\) and location (1,2)

Body \({B}\) has mass of \(2 {~kg}\) and location \((-1,3)\)

The coordinates of the centre of mass

For first coordinate

\(m_c x_c=m_1 x_1+m_2 x_2 \)

\((1+2) x_c=(1\times  1)+(2\times-1) \)

\(x_c=-\frac{1}{3}\)

Similarly, for second coordinate

\(m_c y_c=m_1 y_1+m_2 y_2 \)

\((1+2) y_c=(1\times 2)+(2\times 3) \)

\(y_c=\frac{8}{3}\)

So the coordinates of centre of mass are \((-\frac{1}{3},\frac{8}{3})\).
If a force \(10 \hat{i}+15 \hat{j}+25 \hat{k}\) acts on a system and gives an acceleration \(2 \hat{i}+3 \hat{j}-5 \hat{k}\) to the centre of mass of the system, the mass of the system is:

Force on a system \(({F})_{{cm}}=10 \hat{i}+15 \hat{j}+25 \hat{k} \)

\({a}_{{cm}}=2 \hat{i}+3 \hat{j}-5 \hat{k}\)

We know that force is multiplication of mass and acceleration therefore,

\(({F})_{{cm}}={ma} \)

\(10 \hat{i}+15 \hat{j}+25 \hat{k}=\mathrm{m}(2 \hat{i}+3 \hat{j}-5 \hat{k})\)

\({m}=\frac{10 \hat{i}+15 \hat{j}+25 \hat{k}}{2 \hat{i}+3 \hat{j}-5 \hat{k}}\)

\({m}=\frac{\sqrt{10^2+15^2+25^2}}{\sqrt{2^2+3^2+5^2}}\)

\({m}=\frac{\sqrt{950}}{\sqrt{38}}\)

\({m}=\frac{5 \sqrt{38}}{\sqrt{38}}=5\) units

Three dumbbells are shown in the figure. They have a massless rod of length \(d\) and spherical weights attached to their ends. If the spheres on the first and second dumbbell have the same density \(\rho\) and that of the third sphere is \(2 \rho\), what can be concluded about their centre of mass?
The centre of mass of first dumbbell is to the extreme left side.
The centre of mass of third dumbbell is to the extreme right side.
The centre of mass of first and second dumbbell is same, but different for the third dumbbell.
The location of the centre of mass is the same for all dumbbells.

The mass of each sphere can be obtained from the relation, Mass \(=\) Density \(\times\) Volume.

The centre of mass for a system of two equal masses is given by:

\(C_x=\frac{m x_1+m x_2}{m+m}=\frac{x_1+x_2}{2}\)

So, irrespective of the density of the dumbbells, since each end has the same mass of spheres, their centre of mass is located at \(\frac{x_1+x_2}{2}\).

Let us assume that the sphere on left is at the origin.

Then, \({x}_1=0\) and \({x}_2={d}\)

Thus, \(C_x=\frac{x_1+x_2}{2}=\frac{0+d}{2}=\frac{d}{2}\)

For all three dumbbells, the centre of mass will be at \(\frac{d}{2}\). It means the location of the centre of mass is the same for all dumbbells.
A shell at rest explodes. The centre of mass of the fragments:

As the shell is initially at rest and explosion is under internal forces only, so linear momentum of the system is conserved.

Since, linear momentum of the shell was zero initially, so linear momentum of the centre of mass is also zero after explosion. Therefore centre of mass of the fragments remains at rest.

Consider a two particle system with particles having masses \(m_1\) and \(m_2\). If the first particle is pushed towards the centre of mass through a distance d, by what distance should be second particle be moved, so as to keep the centre of mass at the same position?

If \(x_1\) and \(x_2\) are the positions of masses \(m_1\) and \(m_2\), the position of the centre of mass is given by \(x_{c m}=\frac{m_1 x_1+m_2 x_2}{m_1+m_2}\)

If \({x}_1\) changes by \(\Delta {x}_1\) and \({x}_2\) changes by \(\Delta {x}_2\), the change in \({x}_{{cm}}\) will be,

\(\Delta{x}_{{cm}}=\frac{{m}_1 \Delta{x}_1+{m}_2 \Delta {x}_2}{{~m}_1+{m}_2}\)

Given \(\Delta {x}_{{cm}}={o}\) and \(\Delta {x}_1={d}\)

Using these values in eq.(i), we get 

\({m}_1{~d}+{m}_2 \Delta {x}_2=0\)

or \(\Delta {x}_2=-\frac{{m}_1 {~d}}{{~m}_2}\)

\(\therefore\) Distance moved by \({m}_2=\frac{{m}_1 }{{m}_2}{d}\).

The mass of the moon is about \(0.013\) times the mass of the earth and the distance from the center of mass to the center of the earth is about \(60\) times the radius of the earth. How far is the centre of mass of system from the centre of Earth?(Take the earth's radius to be \(6400 {~km}\))

Let the mass of earth to be \(m \mathrm{~kg}\), then the mass of the moon which is about \(0.013\) times the mass of the earth would be \(0.013 \mathrm{~m}\). 

Now consider that the center of the earth lies at origin. Then the distance of the moon from the center of the earth which is given to be about 60 times the radius of the earth will be \(60 R\), where \(R\) is the radius of the earth.

The center of mass of the earth-moon system \(=\frac{m_1 x_1+m_2 x_2}{m_1+m_2}\)

On substituting the values in the formula, we get:

Centre of Mass \(=\frac{m \times 0+0.013 m \times 60 R}{m+0.013 m} \)

\(\Rightarrow\) Centre of Mass \(=\frac{0.78 m R}{1.013 m} \)

\(\Rightarrow\) Centre of Mass \(=\frac{0.78 R}{1.013} \)

\(\Rightarrow\) Centre of Mass \(=0.76999 R\)

Now, we know that the radius of earth is given as \(6400 \mathrm{~km}\).

On substituting the value in the equation, we get:

Centre of Mass \(=0.769199 \times 6400 \)

\(\Rightarrow\) Centre of Mass \(=4927.936 {~km} \)

\(\therefore\) Centre of Mass \( \approx 4928 {~km}\)

So, the approximate value of the distance of center of mass of the earth-moon system from the center of earth comes out to be \(4928{~km}\).

A body is projected at an angle with some initial velocity from the surface of the earth and follows the parabolic path. If the body explodes somewhere during the flight and splits into a number of particles, then the centre of mass of the particles will move in:

The body is projected at an angle with some initial velocity from the surface of the earth and follows the parabolic path. The body explodes somewhere during the flight and splits into a number of particles. When the body explodes only internal forces acts on the body and we know that the internal forces contribute nothing to the motion of the centre of mass. So, the centre of mass will follow the same parabolic path after the explosion.

Three particles, each of mass \(1 {~kg}\), are placed at the corners of a right-angled triangle \(A O B\) with \(O\) being the origin of the coordinate system ( \(O A\) and \(O B\) along positive \(X\)-direction and positive \(Y\)-direction). If \(O A=O B=1 \mathrm{~m}\), then the positive vector of the centre of mass (in/ metres) is:

The \((x, y)\) co-ordinates of the masses at \(O, A\) and \(B\) respectively are \(\left({x}_1=0, ={y}_1=0\right),\left({x}_2={a}, {y}_2=0\right)\) and \(\left({x}_3=0, {y}_3={b}\right)\).

The \((x, y)\) co-ordinates of the centre of mass are given by

\(x_{cm}=\frac{m_1 x_1+m_2 x_2+m_3 x_3}{m_1+m_2+m_3}=\frac{m \times 0+m \times a+m \times 0}{m+m+m}=\frac{a}{3} \)

\(y_{cm}=\frac{m_1 y_1+m_2 y_2+m_3 y_3}{m_1+m_2+m_3}=\frac{m \times 0+m \times 0+m \times b}{m+m+m}=\frac{b}{3}\)

The position vector of the centre of mass is 

\(x_{cm} \hat{i}+y_{cm}\hat{j}\) \(=\frac{a}{3} \hat{i}+\frac{b}{3} \hat{j}=\frac{1}{3}(a \hat{i}+b \hat{j})\).

The linear momentum of a system of two particles is expressed as \(20 \hat{i}+30 \hat{j}+40 \hat{k}\) and \(20 \hat{i}+40 \hat{j}+60 \hat{k}\) units respectively. If their centre of mass has a velocity of \(4 \hat{i}+5 \hat{j}\) \(+7 \hat{k}\) unit, the mass of the system is:

Given:

\(p_1=20 \hat{i}+30 \hat{j}+40 \hat{k}\) and \(p_2=20 \hat{i}+40 \hat{\jmath}+60 \hat{k}\)

Velocity of the centre of mass, \((v_{\text {com }})=4 \hat{\imath}+5 \hat{\jmath}+7 \hat{k}\)

Let \(M\) be the mass of the system.

We know that,

If \(p\) is the linear momentum of each particle then

\(\Sigma p=M\times  v_{\text {com }} \)

\(\Rightarrow(20 \hat{i}+30 \hat{j}+40 \hat{k})+(20 \hat{i}+40 \hat{j}+60 \hat{k}) =M(4 \hat{i}+5 \hat{j}+7 \hat{k})\)

Considering the \(x\) direction,

\(\Rightarrow(20 \hat{i})+(20 \hat{i})=\mathrm{M}(4 \hat{i}) \quad\) (Mass is a scalar quantity.lt will have no components in different directions)

\(\Rightarrow 40 \hat{i}=M 4 \hat{i} \)

\(\Rightarrow M=10\) units
The angular speed of the second's hand of a watch is:

Angular velocity \((\omega)=\frac{\theta}{t}\)

Time taken to complete \(1\) revolution, \(t=60 {~sec}\)

Angle rotated \((\theta)=2 \pi {~rad}\)

Angular speed \((\omega)\) of a second hand is given by:

\(\left(\omega_s\right)=\frac{2 \pi}{60}=\frac{\pi}{30}{~rad}/{s}\)
The kinetic energy of an object is increasing with time. Choose the correct statement from the following?
The resultant force on the particle must be at an angle less than \(90^{\circ}\) all the time.
The magnitude of its linear momentum is increasing continuously.

All moving objects have kinetic energy.

We know that Kinetic energy \((K E)=\frac{1}{2} m v^2\). 

Multiplying and dividing by \(m\) we get,

\(\Rightarrow K E=\frac{1}{2} m v^2 \times \frac{m}{m}=\frac{p^2}{2 m} \)

\(\Rightarrow p=\sqrt{2 m K E} \)

\(\Rightarrow p \propto \sqrt{KE}\)

So, increasing kinetic energy increases the magnitude of linear momentum. Work done on the object will be the measure of its kinetic energy. 

We know, Work done \(=\mathrm{F\times s} \cos \theta\)

So, the angle between the force \((F)\) and displacement \((s)\) must be less than \(90^{\circ}\) for the work to be done. So, the resultant force on the particle must be at an angle less than \(90^{\circ}\) all the time.

A circular disc of radius \({R}\) is removed from a bigger circular disc of radius \(2 R\) such that their circumferences coincide. The centre of mass of the new disc is at a distance of \(\alpha R\) from the centre of the bigger disc. The value of \(\alpha \) is:

Let the mass per unit area be \(\sigma\).

Then the mass of the complete disc \(=\sigma\left[\pi(2 R)^2\right]=4 \pi \sigma R^2\)

The mass of the removed disc \(=\sigma\left(\pi R^2\right)=\pi \sigma R^2\)

Let us consider the above situation to be a complete disc of radius \(2 R\) on which a disc of radius \(R\) of negative mass is superimposed.

Let \(O\) be the origin. 


\(X_{com}=\frac{\left(4 \pi \sigma R^2\right) \times 0+\left(-\pi \sigma R^2\right) R}{4 \pi \sigma R^2-\pi \sigma R^2} \)

\(\therefore X_{com}=\frac{-\pi \sigma R^2 \times R}{3 \pi \sigma R^2} \)

\(\therefore R_{com}=-\frac{R}{3}\)

So, distance of centre of mass from centre of big disc is \(=\frac{R}{3}\) 

\(\Rightarrow  \alpha =\frac{1}{3}\)

A given shaped glass tube having uniform cross-section is filled with water and is mounted on a rotatable shaft as shown in figure. If the tube is rotated with a constant angular velocity \(\omega\), then:
Water levels in both sections \(A\) and \(B\) go up
Water level in section \(A\) goes up and that in \(B\) comes down
Water level in section \(A\) comes down and that in \(B\) goes up
Water levels remain the same in both sections
Water level in both A and B will go up. The pressure difference thus created will provide the necessary centripetal force for the water body to rotate around the vertical axis.
The angle turned by a body undergoing circular motion depends on time as \(\theta=\theta_0+\theta_1 t+\theta_2 t^2\). Then the angular acceleration of the body is:

Angle turned by the body \(\theta=\theta_0+\theta_1 \mathrm{t}+\theta_2 t^2\)

Angular velocity

\(\omega=\frac{{d} \theta}{{dt}} \)

\(=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{dt}}\left(\theta_{\circ}+\theta_1 \mathrm{t}+\theta_2 \mathrm{t}^2\right)\)

\(=\theta_1+2 \theta_2 \mathrm{t}\)

Angular acceleration \((\alpha)=\frac{d w}{d t}\)

\(=\frac{d}{d t}\left(\theta_1+2 \theta_2 t\right)\)

\(=2 \theta_2\)

The angular velocity of a body changes fro \(\omega_1\) to \(\omega_2\) without applying a torque but by changing the moment of inertia. What is the ratio of the initial radius of gyration \(({K}_1)\) to the final radius of gyration \(({K}_2)\)?

The magnitude of angular momentum of a strong body is given by:

\({L}={IW}\)

If no torque acts, the angular momentum is conserved, i. e. , \(IW =\) constant

\(\therefore {I}_1 {~W}_1={I}_2 {~W}_2\cdots (1)\)

\({K}_1\) and \({K}_2\) are the initial and final radius of gyration,  then

\({I}_1={MK}_1{ }^2 \)

\({I}_2={MK}_2{ }^2 \)

From eq (1)

\({I}_1 {~W}_1={I}_2{~W}_2 \)

or \({MK}_1{ }^2 {~W}_1={MK}_2{ }^2 {~W}_2 \)

or \(\frac{{K}_1}{{~K}_2}=\frac{\sqrt{{W}_2}}{\sqrt{{W}_1}} \)

or \({K}_1: {K}_2=\sqrt{{W}_2}: \sqrt{{W}_1}\)

A thin circular ring of mass '\(M\)' and radius '\(R\)' is rotating about its axis with a constant angular velocity \(\omega\). Four objects each of mass '\(m\)', are kept gently to the opposite ends of two perpendicular diameters of the ring. The new angular velocity of the ring will be:

Initial angular momentum of ring \(=I \times \omega=M R^2 \omega\)

If four object each of mass \(m\), and kept gently to the opposite ends of two perpendicular

diameters of the ring then final angular momentum \(=\left(M R^2+4 m R^2\right) \omega^{\prime}\)

By the conservation of angular momentum

Initial angular momentum \(=\) Final angular momentum

\(M R^2 \omega=\left(M R^2+4 m R^2\right) \omega^{\prime}\) 

\(\Rightarrow \omega^{\prime}=\left(\frac{M\omega}{M+4 m}\right) \)
What will be torque of the force \({F}\) if the direction of force is along the direction of radius?

We know that,

Torque \(\vec{\tau}=\vec{r} \times \vec{F}\)

where \(\vec{r}=\) Position vector and \(\vec{F}=\) Force on the particle

The direction of force is along the direction of the radius. It means the angle between radius and torque is \(0^{\circ}\).

\(\vec{\tau}=\vec{r} \times \vec{F}=r F \sin \theta \)

As \(\sin \theta=\sin 0^{\circ}=0\) 

So \(\vec{\tau}=r F \sin \theta=r F \sin 0^{\circ}=0\)
Two point mass \(m\) and \(2 {~m}\) are at a distance of \(5\) units and \(2\) units from the origin. What will be the moment of inertia of the system?

We know that,

\({I}={m} \times {r}^2\)

where \(I=\) Moment of Inertia, \({m}=\) Mass, \({r}=\) Perpendicular distance from the axis of rotation.

For a rigid body system, the moment of inertia is the sum of the moments of inertia of all its particles taken about the same axis.

\(I=\sum m_i r_i{ }^2\)

where \({I}=\) Moment of Inertia, \({m}=\) Mass, \({r}=\) Perpendicular distance from the axis of rotation.

Given masses are \({m}\) and \(2 {~m}\), radii are \(5\) and \(2\)

For discrete points moment of inertia is calculated by

\(I=\sum m_i r_i^2=m_1 r_1^2+m_2 r_2^2 \)

\(I=m \times 5^2+2 m \times 2^2=33 m\)
If the mass of a body is situated at large distance from the axis of rotation, its moment of inertia will be comparatively:
It can either be larger or smaller
Moment of inertia does not depend on mass

For a rigid body system, the moment of inertia is the sum of the moments of inertia of all its particles taken about the same axis.

\(I=\sum m_i r_i^2\)

where \({I}=\) Moment of Inertia, \({m}=\) Mass, \({r}=\) Perpendicular distance from the axis of rotation.

If the mass is situated at a large distance from the axis Moment of Inertia will be large because the distance of mass particles from the axis of rotation will be large. As the mass is at a greater distance from the axis of rotation, the effective radius will be larger. This is why the moment of inertia \(\left(I=\sum m_i r_i{ }^2\right)\) will be larger.
What will happen to the moment of inertia if we start to rotate a body and gradually increase the speed of rotation?
There will be no change in moment of inertia and it will remain the same.

We know that,

\(I= m \times r^{2}\)

There is no role of the angular velocity to find the moment of inertia. It does not depend on the angular velocity. So if we start to rotate a body and gradually increase the speed of rotation, there will be no change in the moment of inertia.
The ratio of moment of inertia of solid sphere and hollow sphere is: (Given that both have the same mass and the same radius)

We know that, the moment of inertia of a solid sphere of mass '\(m\)' and radius '\({R}\)' about an axis passing through the center \((I_1)=\frac{2}{5} m r^2\)

Moment of inertia of a Hollow sphere of mass '\(m\)' and radius '\(R\)' about an axis passing through the center  \((I_2)=\frac{2}{3} m r^2\)

Their ratio \(\frac{I_1}{I_2}=\frac{\frac{2}{5} m r^2}{\frac{2}{3} m r^2}\)

\(\frac{I_1}{I_2}=\frac{3}{5}\)
The ratio of total kinetic energy to the rotational kinetic energy of a solid sphere rolling on a horizontal surface is:

The rolling kinetic energy of a sphere is the sum of the translational kinetic energy of its centre of mass plus the rotational kinetic energy about the centre of mass.

The translational kinetic energy of an object of mass \(m\) and velocity \(v\) is given as

\(K_1=\frac{1}{2} m v^2\)

Rotational kinetic energy, \(K_2=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^2\)

Rolling kinetic energy, \(K_3=K_1+K_2\)

Ratio \(=\frac{K_3}{K_2}=\frac{K_1+K_2}{K_2}=\frac{K_1}{K_2}+1\)

On substituting the values,

\(\Rightarrow \frac{K_3}{K_2}=\frac{\frac{1}{2} m v^2}{\frac{1}{2} I \omega^2}+1 \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{K_3}{K_2}=\frac{m v^2}{I \omega^2}+1\)

We know that linear velocity, \(\mathrm{v}=\mathrm{r} \omega\) and moment of inertia for a sphere, \((I)=\frac{2}{5} M R^2\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{K_3}{K_2}=\frac{m(r \omega)^2}{\frac{2}{5} m r^2 \omega^2}+1=\frac{5}{2}+1 \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{K_3}{K_2}=\frac{7}{2}=7:2\)

The moment of inertia of a body about an axis passing through the center of mass is \({I}_{{cm}}\). If the mass of the body is \({m}\), find the moment of inertia about an axis parallel to the center of mass and at a distance of \({R}\) from it.

Given that moment of inertia of a body about an axis passing through the center of mass is \({I}_{{cm}}\).

Mass \(={m}\) and \({I}=\) moment of inertia at \({r}\) distance from \({I}_{{cm}}\)

According to parallel axis theorem, the moment of inertia of a body about an axis parallel to the body passing through its center of mass is equal to the sum of the moment of inertia of the body about the axis passing through the center of mass and product of the mass of the body times the square of the distance between the two axes.

\({I}={I}_{{cm}}+{MR}^2\)

Moment of inertia of a body about two perpendicular axes \({X}\) and \({Y}\) in the plane of lamina are \(20 {~kg}-{m}^2\) and \(25 {~kg}-{m}^2\) respectively. Its moment of inertia about an axis perpendicular to the plane of the lamina and passing through the point of intersection of \({X}\) and \({Y}\) axes is:

According to perpendicular axis theorem,

The moment of inertia of a plane lamina about an axis that is perpendicular to the plane of the lamina is equal to the sum of the moments of inertia of the lamina about the two axes at perpendicular to each other, in its own plane intersecting each other at the point.

\(I_Z=I_X+I_Y\)

Where \(I_Z\) is moment of inertia about \(Z\)-axis, \(I_X\) is moment of inertia about \(X\)-axis and \(I_Y\) is moment of inertia about \(Y\)-axis

\({I}_{{X}}=20 {~kg}-{m}^2\)

\({I}_{{Y}}=25 {~kg}-{m}^2\)

So moment of inertia about the axis perpendicular to \(X\) and \(Y\) axis \(\left(I_Z\right)=I_X+I_Y=\) \(20+25=45 {~kg}-{m}^2\)
If the moment of inertia of a disc about the tangent in its plane is \({I}\), its moment of inertia about the tangent perpendicular to the plane will be:

The Moment of Inertia of the disc across its center of Mass \({I}=\frac{{MR}^2}{4}\)

Where \({M}=\) Mass of the disc and \({R}=\) radius

The Moment of Inertia of the disc across its center of mass in the plane is given as

\({I}^{\prime}=\frac{{MR}^2}{4}\)

Here \({MR}^2=4I\)

\({R}=\) radius of disk

The required axis across which we have to find Moment of Inertia is \(I\). The distance from tangent to the center is the radius is \({r}\). So, the parallel distance between both axis is \({R}\).

So, By Parallel axis theorem, the Moment of Inertia about the tangent \(I\) in the plane

Here \(\mathrm{I}=\mathrm{I}^{\prime}+\mathrm{MR}^2\)

\(I=\frac{5 M R^2}{4} \)

\({MR}^2=\frac{4 {I}}{5}\)

Moment of inertia about tangent in perpendicular plane is given by:

\(I_t=\frac{M R^2}{2}+M R^2=\frac{3 M R^2}{2}=3 \times\frac{(\frac{4I}{5})}{2}=\frac{6}{5} I\)
The speed of a homogeneous solid sphere after rolling down on inclined plane of vertical height \(h\) from rest without sliding is:

We know that,

Gravitational potential energy \(P=m g h\)

\({m}=\) Mass, \({g}=\) Acceleration due to gravity, \({h}=\) Height

Linear Kinetic Energy \((K)=\frac{1}{2} m v^2\)

Where \(v= \) speed of moving body

Moment of Inertia \((I)=\frac{2}{5} m r^2-(1)\)

where \(r=\) radius of solid sphere, \(m=mass\) 

Angular Velocity \((\omega) =\frac{v}{r}\cdots(2)\)

where \(v=\) linear velocity, \(r=\) radius of rotational motion

Rotational Kinetic Energy \((K_R)=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^2\)

Since the whole potential energy of the ball at height, \(\mathrm{h}\) is converted into Kinetic energy.

\(m g h=\frac{1}{2} m v^2+\frac{1}{2}\ I \omega^2 \cdots(3)\)

Using Eq (1) and Eq (2) in Eq (3) we get

\(m g h=\frac{1}{2} m v^2+\frac{1}{2}\times  \frac{2}{5} m r^2\times \left(\frac{v}{r}\right)^2 \)

\(\Rightarrow g h=\frac{1}{2} v^2+\frac{1}{5} r^2\left(\frac{v^2}{r^2}\right) \)

\(\Rightarrow g h=\frac{1}{2} v^2+\frac{1}{5} v^2 \)

\(\Rightarrow g h=\frac{7}{10} v^2 \)

\(\Rightarrow \sqrt{\frac{10}{7} g h}\)

So, speed is \(\sqrt{\frac{10}{7} g h}\)
Angular momentum is constant in absent of external:

We know that \(L=I \times \alpha=T_{\text {net }}\)

Where, \(\mathrm{L}=\) angular momentum, \(\alpha=\) angular acceleration, \(\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{net}}=\) Net external torque.

If \(\mathrm{T}_{\text {net }}=0\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{dL} / \mathrm{dt}=0\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{L}=\) constant

If the total external torque on a system is zero, its angular momentum remains constant. This is known as the principle of conservation of angular momentum.
